author: {'steamid': '76561198089326320', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1492275568}
review:
"Listen to me my boy. The possibility of you connecting this next attack is %95. But the possibility for that possiblity to be possible is only %2." 

I bought this game with a bundle discount and i still regret it. Altough this game has great potential, the whole rng system makes everything so frustrating. And trust me, I'm saying this as a person who's blessed by rngeesus himself. When you slay through all the enemies in one go after ragequitting months ago for missing five million turns on the goddamn 3rd fight into the game, I believe it's safe to say that there is something wrong with the whole system. There are times that this game feels almost unplayable. I hate downvoting Daedalic Entertainment games, but I must do it for a second time unfortunately.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980206817', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1491770634}
review:
I would very much not reccomend this game. After reading through comments and reviews I saw one of the biggest issues was unfair RNG in fights, I figured it must be a bit like Xcom and similar games with % hit chances where you'll miss the odd 99% chance to hit. Which I could understand, but not when it happens on the 2nd fight out of the tutorial, 4 times in a row mixed with 2 missed spell casts. Again I can handle bad RNG but not when the enemies have a 40% chance to hit and never miss. Even if that was not an issue, running into a bug that stops me from completeing the 2nd fight in the graveyard by not letting me interact with the thing the game is screaming at me to interact with to stop mobs spawning. 

I came into this game optimistic and figuring people were just too used to easy games that held your hand and gave it negative reviews because they didn't have to think. This game has proven that thinking wrong, its just a bad designed game with subpar voice acting, from what little I saw an unoriginal story (Accused of murder and coviently having no memory of it or anything.) No real customisation and just in general poor gameplay.

If you've read this far and have not bought the game I would say do not waste time and money on this and go get Divinity Original Sin for a similar but all round greater gaming experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047800149', 'num_games_owned': 1189, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2366, 'last_played': 1492588708}
review:
Update: Finished game, would hardly call unfair, most fights in the game took a max of 2-3 tries, plenty were 1shots. Did all sidequests I ran across before completion, not sure how close to 100% I was, but I'd guess I probably did a good 85-90% of the content on offer. It's just about learning the game to be honest, there's nothing super difficult here. I play a good variety of games and hardly am "an expert" at turn based tactics games for comparison to what you can expect. Fun game, a couple of times I found the combat very slow and wished I could skip through enemy turns when there were lots of enemies (last dungeon had a couple like this...)

Pretty funny seeing all the people here whine about this game being unforgiving or super difficult... I am completely new to Dark Eye game systems and have just taken my time in looking at the character trees etc and sort of feeling my way into where I'm spending my AP. I would say that if difficult = not 1shotting every single battle, then the game is "difficult". But beyond that, it's not very difficult. Every single encounter has taken me no more than 2 tries barring the end encounter for Chapter 2 (louse queen as a 3rd battle in a row with no recovery time. I decided to power thru it vs trying to load an old save and set myself up for easier success over all 3 as a whole with the knowledge I'd gained... too lazy to do that). And I can even say that the first attempt is often experimentation or trial/error with the different maps, traps and interactables etc and perhaps new enemy types. 

It's fairly easy so far, although I will say that the difficulty is spiky; it runs the gamut from faceroll to mildy challenging (and some of the reviews I see whining about difficulty are from people that spent far less time than I, so I doubt it's where I am in the game) -- honestly if you are having trouble, maybe reevaluate your movement and positioning. I've found that there is a lot of advantage to be gained and strategy in positioning and more or less "gaming the map" to keep control and manage some of the risk/rng. This is a hex based game, and sometimes moving 2 hexes right or left can change a whole lot. 

To give an example -- I saw a "WTF is" by TotalBiscuit, where he played a fairly early map and thought it was frustrating and difficult... immediately started making major positioning oversights in the very first turn he had. The corridor is bottlenecked to 3 hexes wide and there are like 6 active crypt lice. Why would you not move 3 characters onto each of those hexes and wait for the lice to come to you? Then you are only fighting 3 at once you only have 3 characters of your choosing taking damage (far more control over damage intake). Following this, you have infinite recovery turns on the map to heal before moving forward and "activating" the next group. This is just a very basic example... and I don't really even dabble in strategy games all that much. I just don't see how this game is hard. It's fairly simple with a bit of trial and error involved. The RNG complaints are also pretty bullshit... there is even a "wounds" system to manage the RNG... which I discovered at my leisure after continually investigating the ruleset as I played. Have some patience... you definitely don't need to read character guides to suceed. I've learned after playing and reading around that the optimal route is playing a mage as the hero (there's 0 disadvantage since there are basically characters that can cast and characters that can't -- everything else can be developed as you see fit as the game goes on...), and I'm doing just fine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041769343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 3131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3101, 'last_played': 1427945983}
review:
I highly enjoyed this game. I've read over a few of the other reviews and i'm seeing a trend - the game is hard to the point of unfair. While there are some very challenging fights in the game I only ran into a couple actually took more than one attempt. 

If you want to see a bit of the game play you can click through my let's play of the game. https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLV4VR6BqqFu4dMvMwv_uo5V-WjivoYUYm

The combat was fun, challenging, and character development was fair. Your characters do need to specialize but that's part of a party building strategy game. Cover your weaknesses, develope battle plans, and execute. When a plan doesn't work you reassess and start again. Personally I felt the story was very weak but the gameplay is solid.

review:
Ach, ich wÃ¼rde dieses Spiel gerne empfehlen. ber ich kannes nicht. Ja es ist ein nettes Rollenspiel, die taktischen KÃ¤mpfe sind auch oft ganz spaÃŸig. Aber: viel zu sehr vom GlÃ¼ck abhÃ¤ngig. Und bei falscher Positionierung der Helden kann es auf manchen Karten passieren, das es unmÃ¶glich wird den Ausgang zu erreichen, weil unendlich spawnende Gegner den Weg versperren. Ich musste mehrmals KÃ¤mpfe neuladen aufgrund solche Begebenheiten. Die Story ist eigentlich ganz gut. Das Ende jedoch langweilig und enttÃ¤uschend. Der letzte Bosskampf auch eifach nur nervig und langatmig. Selbst auf leichten Schwierigkeitsgrad sind die KÃ¤mpfe so zufallsabhÃ¤ngig, dass man manchmal total Chancenlos ist und auch dann hilft nur ein Neuladen des Kampfes.

Alles in allem, habe ich mich eher zum Ende durchgequÃ¤lt, weil ich die Story und das Spiel beendet wissen wollte. Mit genÃ¼gend Geduld, kann das Spiel aber durchaus SpaÃŸ machen. Ich wÃ¼rde sagen, dass ich zu 40 % des Spiels stark genervt war und zu 60 % SpaÃŸ hatte.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014539053', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2821, 'last_played': 1491121883}
review:
Eigentlich ein interessantes Spiel ,wennn es nicht zeitweise unfair wÃ¤re.

Leider hat man teilweise mehrere KÃ¤mpfe hintereinander ohne SpeichermÃ¶glichkeit.Da man vorher nicht weiÃŸ,wieviel KÃ¤mpfe man durchstehen muÃŸ,ist man oft schlecht vorbereitet und muÃŸ gegebenfalls alle KÃ¤mpfe(auch die gewonnenen) wiederholen.Das fÃ¼hrt zu Frust und Ã„rger...

Auch erscheint mir die angezeigte Trefferquote nicht plausibel (Trefferquote 100% ... und ich treffe nicht ???).Oft wird bei hoher Prozentzahl nicht getroffen,wenn ich von der gleichen Stelle den Gegner angreife(Trefferquote 90% und ich treffe 4 mal hintereinder nicht ...???....dann mÃ¼ÃŸte ich rein rechnerisch die nÃ¤chsten 36 mal treffen).

Grafik und Geschichte finde ich ok bis gut ... immer wieder die gleiche KÃ¤mpfe durchzuspielen wurde mir letztendlich zuviel.... ohne bestandene Hauptquest-KÃ¤mpfe ist das Spiel vorbei.Es gibt nur eine linare MÃ¶glichkeit  die nÃ¤chsten Kapitel frei zu schalten. FÃ¼r mich war das Spiel  im Kapitel 3 zu Ende.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995368942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1671024631}
review:
It is easy to forget that RNGESUS is a wrathful and jealous god. I thank the developers for reminding me that although a game might look "sweet" on the surface, there is an unfair, unforgiving, and unbalanced mechanic lurking beneath ready to drain all the fun out of the experience.

"For lo I say unto ye our lord's rod is stiff, long and hard and he rolls a natural 20. Yea the unbeliever might do the math and sayeth he that 75% chance to hit means there is only a 1 in 4 chance to miss, but blaspheme not so! For the lord will punish ye all the way through to 95% chance to hit. Ye shall miss as certain as ye have bound the quick load/save to ye mouse buttons." -Numbers 1:20.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967768801', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1880, 'last_played': 1465495655}
review:
A fairly simple game in turns of mechanics and layout.
However it is quite interesting. And there are some variations to it depending on your choices.

It's a nice casual game for us who like the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074386839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 460, 'last_played': 1505131196}
review:
[b] My view:[/b]

The game is worth one play-through, though on replay it is already disgustingly similar. Personally I think that a warrior, a ranger, a rogue, and a mage would live different lives, make different choices, define different loot. Here it does not even matter, as long, as you win fight after fight.

Tactical, combat-enforced hex-map fantasy chess with RPG stats of the once most beloved German pen & paper roleplaying game. The game starts nicely, even though the linearity of the story, and the lack of impact one makes unto the world around the chosen or hand-built protagonist seems to remind of decade old mistakes in RPG's.

The game is A LOT about tactical combat on a hex map, not much skills versus environment, not much story or choices which matter, but if you unlock the console and type WIN after pressing F12, then patch version 1.8 of the game is decent.

Given that several patches still failed to relieve us of all glitches and bugs, that isn't too impressive.

One mistake I found sucking:

Merchants offer a standard script of equipment. Entire armor sets and weapons can only be gained by using the 'give all items' cheat. Sadly that one crashes the game later, as it spawns a bug sabotaging the quest resolving.

Additionally you need your DirectX and VCredists (from 2008 to 2013) in peak-performance-state, or glitches and bugs are guaranteed!

Crystals and chests cannot be damaged by daggers or fencing weapons! Use two-weapon fighting plus a torch or slash or bash type of weapon, IF you need daggers or foils, rapiers to imagine your character (Horasian area of Aventuria)...

[b]The good aspects:[/b]

The character creation is decent.

The world is harsh and unforgiving, while still being the once famous Aventuria (Aventurien in German) of THE DARK EYE RPG system.

The allies of the protagonist and their voiceovers ain't bad.

Background music is decent, too. 

Skills like streetwise and survival make a difference, even though some can only be taken at character creation in expert mode. No trainers found later in the game.

The game does build atmosphere, but only for one more tactical combat on those ancient, antiquated, oldschool hexagone maps...

The oft-shunned Nameless God is much better implemented than in 'Demonicon'.

I purchased it years after first sale, for only 2â‚¬ plus 1,20â‚¬ steam key. For that pricing it was good enough to fill one evening, but not enough to make that old fever aka joy arise in my ex-roleplayer soul.

review: Nach gut 50 Spielstunden habe ich es nun endlich durch. Ein tolles Spiel. Die Nebenquests hÃ¤tte man aber auch weglassen kÃ¶nnen. Denn 50 Stunden zehrt schon extrem an meiner Motivation. Scheinbar gibt es auch unterschiedliche Enden. Denn ganz hat es meine Gruppe nicht geschafft alle Errungenschaften zu meistern. Die aber ohne erneutes durchspielen wohl nicht erreichbar sind. Aber noch mal 50 Stunden habe ich keine Lust ;) Werde dafÃ¼r aber direkt mit Blackguards 2 weitermachen. Ich hoffe nur das der zweite Teil nicht auch wieder so lange dauert. Ich mag so lange Spiele eigentlich nicht. Wie auch immer, wÃ¼rde das Spiel jedem Rundenstrategen und Rollenspieler empfehlen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972309532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1514, 'last_played': 1490816482}
review:
The first time I came to write a review for this game it was going to be a vitriolic missive of woe and anger. In true fashion, and not for the first time, the game had put me on my ass. It was during the games infamous second chapter, where fights come thick and fast, and leave you feeling brutalised and frustrated. I perservered however and came out of the other side happier for it.

This game is far from perfect, but for fans of tactical RPGs it is a truly a diamond in the rough. Battles are varied and interesting and party composition and tactical choices really make a difference. The combat system is deeper than it first appears and that hidden depth is one of the games finer qualities. It is also it's biggest drawback. The game is closely based on a pen and paper RPG and unfortunately in many ways just as indecipherable to the beginner. 

The character progression system is almost arcane in its complexity, to the point that it is almost certain that you will make mistakes in the way you build up your party. These mistakes will be deadly on even normal difficulty. It's reliance on a pen and paper system mean that unless you have a copy of the rulebook and many hours to ponder it and try out permutations, your characters will be woefully shy of optimal. This may lead to you having to restart the game several times as you begin to unravel its mysteries.

That being said , the game is sufficiently fun, interesting and challenging that you won't mind having to restart. I didn't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141897960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1490048362}

author: {'steamid': '76561198325719395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2783, 'last_played': 1479041742}
review:
Kann ich nicht empfehlen, nicht fÃ¼r den vollen Preis.

Ein knapp Ã¼berdurchschnittliches Taktikspiel (rundenbasiert), das versucht, sich als Rollenspiel zu verkaufen.
Abgesehen von der Charakterentwicklung findet kein nennenswertes Rollenspiel statt, und Taktikspiele gibt es bessere.

Dass die (sehr lineare) Story in Aventurien angesiedelt ist, merkt man fast nur an den Ortsnamen - erst gegen Schluss kommen spezifische Eigenschaften des Settings zum tragen... ein wenig.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070616040', 'num_games_owned': 501, 'num_reviews': 268, 'playtime_forever': 1677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1413, 'last_played': 1457263424}
review:
Remember don't starve's difficulty curve? it's the same here, only less forgiving, it's a great game but it's better than the second game so explore and read everything, restart, retry and have fun.
It's an amazing game with a good system, it lacks balancing and needs more combat, more diverse combat

author: {'steamid': '76561198117760235', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1489642382}
review:
3/5 Right on the fence between recommend or not, I chose not because of the game's very poor support of Mac graphics, which made it an epic challenge to get the game running initially and renders the Steam overlay unusable. Combine this with its comandeering of the OS â€” no alt-tabs here â€” and it is a largely unpleasant gaming experience.

On the plus side, if you are a fan of tactical turn-based strategy RPG (very light on the RP), and are running Windows (you fool!) then go for it.

All in all, I'd say take the advice of Rock, Paper, Shotgun: give Blackguards a pass and save up your money for Blackguards 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971156862', 'num_games_owned': 69, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 494, 'last_played': 1453660932}
review:
Avevo delle grandi aspettative su questo gioco e, da appassionato di strategia a turni, pensavo che la sfida contro l'AI potesse essere impegnativa e avvincente, per questo l'ho giocato alla massima difficoltÃ . All'inizio Ã¨ stato divertente, poi il ripetersi delle battaglie Ã¨ diventato noioso, giÃ  poco oltre la metÃ  del gioco non vedevo l'ora di concludere, anchÃ¨ perchÃ¨ i miei personaggi erano diventati fortissimi, quasi invincibili e a parte le sfide contro un paio di boss, ho faticato poco a completare le quest sia principali che secondarie, per cui da qui alla noia il passo Ã¨ stato decisamente breve.
La storia comunque non Ã¨ male, il gameplay perÃ² Ã¨ molto lontano dalla qualitÃ  vista in titoli come X-Com o il sottovalutato Expeditions Conquistadores per fare alcuni esempi, che, almeno per me, rappresentano delle pietre di paragone per il genere.
Credo comunque che una mezza dozzina di Euro si possano spendere su questo titolo, in fondo, ad altri potrebbe anche piacere. A me ha deluso.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056318208', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2185, 'last_played': 1490545413}
review:
Blackguards is a fairly entertaining tactical RPG. It can be hard at times,frustrating and random. You do need to put some thought into your character stats and abilities as they develop. It would be nice to be able to reset it by paying a cost or through some in-game service.

It is fairly complex but no more so than other JRPGs out there.

There story is pretty good with some decent voice acting. I am not sure why so many people don't just give this game a proper try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999282226', 'num_games_owned': 971, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 546, 'last_played': 1434765597}
review:
Blackguards is a turn based RPG game. A very difficult, very unforgiving one. The backbone of the game is made up by the Dark Eye system, a system similar to DnD and (from what I understand) very popular in Germany. I've played  alot of DnD, and read a lot about the game's system and guides before playing Blackguards, but didn't really feel like it made much of a difference. The RNG is very unforgiving, in that if your characters' builds are not razor optimized, you will have an incredibly difficult time with the game, more than it already is. I STRONGLY suggest looking at character guides and just following one to the T in terms of what are good skills, what are must haves, where to put your points, and the like, as it is very easy to render a character effectively useless in a battle as you continue to invest points in skills.

Damage and  status efects stay with characters after fights, and consumables are in relatively short supply, meaning strings of fights become very dicey. Magic casting runs off of the same RNG as the melee attacks do, so it's possible to cast spells, have them fizzle entirely, but still lose mana - very frustrating since you then need to use one of your limited resources in money or mana potions to get them back to the point to where they can even begin to be useful again - or so you hope.

These difficulties in learning the games system will unfortunately turn people away from what is a very enjoyable and very think-y turn based combat game. Almost every single individual map is handcrafted and presents new challenges to the party, and the game often forces you to use various party members in different compositions: Aggravating if you chose to focus on one in particular, but from a game design standpoint, if executed well lets you offer all sorts of new challenges. The problem lies in the game's very punishing permanent levellnig system. With no way to undo bad choices and mistakes (and don't be fooled: there ARE mistakes and just bad choices you can make in character builds), you might be stuck at a fight you now have no way of winning, fifteen hours into the campaign.

The story is not particularly interesting, in my opinion, but I have played  alot of very intensely narrative focused games so I admit my bar may be set a little bit high. The characters are interesting, and it's fun to see a story told from the perspective of sly ne'er-do-wells rather than heroic caricatures. Unfortunately, I never really felt like anything groundbreaking or innovative was really done with the characters or situations they could have used, and instead it just sort of became background set up fora relatively generic story that could have been done with the more "Usual Suspects" of heroic characters.

Ironically, I garnered the most fun from the game when my frustration was at its peak and I simply used Cheat Engine to level my characters to the max immediately, giving myself essentially unlimited skill points and ability points to make the characters I actually wanted to make. Due to the punishing RNG and the thoughtful, puzzle-y situations the game likes to put you in, in every single combat, this takes less of the challenge out of the game than you might immediately think (it DOES make it much easier, of course.). Your mileage may vary, but for someone that wants to experience the combat system and the story, i would actually recommend just cheat engining your characters to max level and giving them all the skills you want them to have, and then enjoy using them in the varied combat situations the games put you in.

In the end, I give the game a thumbs down - but only because I think the game's opaqueness and difficulty in learning the system is such a a negative that many people will feel immediately turned off by a combinatioin of that and the game's innate difficulty that they'll be unable to enjoy the game for its positive sides.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024580466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3726, 'last_played': 1488371058}
review:
Insgesamt ein sehr herausforderndes Spiel mit einer gut erzÃ¤hlten Geschichte im DSA-Universum. Ich habe es auf normal durchgespielt und auch dort waren viele KÃ¤mpfe sehr schwer, und es gab durchaus frustrierende Momente. Die Spielzeit betrÃ¤gt ca. 40 Stunden, wenn man sich alles anschaut. Das Spiel richtet sich an Spieler die auf der Suche nach herausfordernden taktische RundekÃ¤mpfen sind. Trotz einiger Defizite kann ich das Spiel empfehlen.


Pro:
- Gute Geschichte
- Toll designte Begleiter, die auch immer wieder BeitrÃ¤ge liefern
- Durchdachtes Kampfsystem

Contra:
- Begleiteranzahl insgesamt gering (man hat auch keine WahlmÃ¶glichkeiten, wer einen begleitet, wie in vielen anderen Rollenspielen)
- gerade in den ersten zwei Kapiteln sind die KÃ¤mpfe stark vom Zufallsfaktor dominiert. Die Charaktere patzen hÃ¤ufig beim Zaubern. Dies Ã¤ndert sich im spÃ¤teren Verlauf, trotz allem habe ich noch kein Spiel gespielt, wo das Zaubern so schwer ist
- Man kann sich sehr leicht verskillen. Wenn man sich mit den DSA-Regeln nicht auskennt, kann man sehr schnell in einer Sackgasse landen. Ein  reskillen ist leider nicht mÃ¶glich, man muss sehr weit im voraus planen. Bei der groÃŸen SkillmÃ¶glichkeit kann man leicht Ã¼berfordert sein.

author: {'steamid': '76561198288467486', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3891, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2430, 'last_played': 1490327305}
review: dont waste your money. the AI is very rigged for failure. the percentages of success are fake. i purposely tried casting a spell with a 70% chance of success and because i would assume i was winning it would always fail. tried it several times. the story line is weak and unimaginative and the graphics are poor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045512003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7652, 'last_played': 1488711050}
review:
Another example of a great (in places) game putting off players do to poor presentation of core game mechanics to player base / very poor ingame feedback. 

I don't know what the developers were aiming for with the way the final product turned out (it is NOT due to technical ineptitude or lack of creative ability - the game mechanics are consistent with its defined rule set, full of intelligent puzzles and reasonably bug free).

The lack of transparency (markedly unsound - it badly hurts their sales numbers by quickly alienating the "shallower" player base. ) seems to be caused largely due to intended design. Maybe TDE (dark eye) game rules are were so second nature to the developers they coudn't see how difficult it will be for "foreigners" to make sense of their otherwise "working within parameters" product. 

It almost like the game is made by aliens strangers to earth based game interface progression in the last 20 years. Maybe this what a game made by programmers/designers that don't play computer games should be expected to turn out (speculation). 

cons
-very limited ruleset/mecanics exposition and ingame feedback (steam guides mostly fixes this)
-alien game interface: bits of relevant information are scattered all over the place (need to navigate 5-6 "screens" to gather basic info about a character - a feat the good modern games can achieve in 1-2 "screens" with overwelmingly superior amount of detail - wastes player time, hurts immersion)
-stoneage like combat log functionality (mising a lot game critical events and the ones presented lack detail)  
-rough spell/ weapon class balance
-nearly impossible to read opponent's percentage based resists ( some even have vulnerabilities to certain damage types but it is extremely hard to tell due to the hidden resist stats , RNG damage component and poor combat log features)
-liniar story, set drops(limited itemisation issues) and poor spell/abilities balance (few powerbuilds builds) leads to poor replayability value. (maybe the obfuscation was intended to mask/hide the poor balance to the players - or the poor balance is the result of the obfuscation making it hard for the devs to see the problems ?)

pros
-the community with a bit of help from developers managed to unwind most of the critical game mechanics (check out the game's player guides section)
-the game is well oiled (very few bugs), the creative people did great - very high intelligent puzzle combat variation(enjoyable once you start grasping the game mechanics).  
 
I still recommend this game despite its numerous flaws because it has the capability to enthral players for hours, but wait for significant special offer discounts .

review:
Bem se espera que vocÃª passe horas jogando e explorando o mapa do jogo, mas isso nÃ£o Ã© possÃ­vel. O jogo tem basicamente dois tipos de cenÃ¡rios as cidades e os campos de batalha. Ou vocÃª estÃ¡ lutando ou estÃ¡ na cidade.

Como todo RPG os personagens possuem uma Ã¡rvore de habilidades que vÃ£o sendo preenchidas com o desenvolvimento dos personagens, no BlackGuards o sistema nÃ£o Ã© baseado em level e sim em pontos de habilidade que vocÃª ganha apÃ³s cada batalha. AtÃ© ai tudo bem e normal, sÃ³ que o sistema Ã© justo somente no primeiro capÃ­tulo do jogo jÃ¡ no capÃ­tulo 2 em diante fica impossÃ­vel/injusto o progresso no jogo para os demais capÃ­tulos. Ou seja, mesmo se vocÃª for um jogador experiente em RPGs de um modo geral nÃ£o passarÃ¡ do capÃ­tulo 2. Provavelmente, vai recorrer a algum trainner na internet para poder progredir no jogo. Mesmo assim, os NPCs treinadores na cidade nÃ£o irÃ£o treinar vocÃª em todas habilidades do jogo, vocÃª vai ficar limitado a uns 5 a 6 habilidades no mÃ¡ximo(mesmo vocÃª cumprindo os requisitos para aprende-las) , ou seja, somente no final do jogo terÃ¡ um NPC que treinarÃ¡ seus personagens com  todas as skills disponÃ­veis no jogo. Algumas skills vocÃª somente aprende comprando livros nos NPCs comerciantes e fazendo quests, mas sÃ£o muito poucas.


PrÃ³s:

-Cumpre a funÃ§Ã£o de ser um RPG com batalhas em turnos
-AmbientaÃ§Ã£o e interatividade com os cenÃ¡rios durante as batalhas.
-CustomizaÃ§Ã£o do personagem com armas e habilidades.
-AtÃ© divertido e bom para passar o tempo
-Legendado em PT-BR

Contras :

-Aos poucos o jogo vai te proporcionando uma experiÃªncia extremamente frustante.
-Os NPCs treinadores sÃ£o totalmente limitados e os pontos de batalha para vocÃª treinar suas habilidades tambÃ©m.
-O jogo Ã© justo sÃ³ no primeiro capÃ­tulo, a progressÃ£o para os capÃ­tulos seguintes Ã© praticamente impossÃ­vel.
-HistÃ³ria fraca e bem confusa.


OBSERVAÃ‡ÃƒO:  Eu queria ter positivado esse jogo, porÃ©m ele aos poucos foi se tornando uma experiÃªncia  frustante a medida o progresso dos seus personagens Ã© extremamente desproporcional ao progresso dos inimigos que vocÃª encontra, mesmo se vocÃª for um jogador experiente vai ver os defeitos bem visÃ­veis nessa questÃ£o de jogabilidade e outras. A sensaÃ§Ã£o Ã© de que o jogo foi feito e depois foi abandonado pelos desenvolvedores em relaÃ§Ã£o a um monte de defeitos , provavelmente isso faz com as pessoas que compraram abandonem o jogo com poucas horas jogadas.

{'steamid': '76561198058241149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1442624520}
review:
Someone else put this much better than I ever could.
I don't remember who said it, or the exact words, but it was something to the tune of "This game is like a wax apple."
It looks beautiful on the outside, and there's really no reason it should be bad, but the feel of the game is artificial, slow, and not very good. 
Supposedly Blackguards 2 is better, but I haven't played it myself. This one kinda left a bad taste.

review:
6,5/10 Blackguards (fight, heal, sell/buy)

Good:
-10zÅ‚
-multi-heros(3 or more)
-long game
-tactic

author: {'steamid': '76561198101352874', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1003, 'last_played': 1486650526}
review: This game is underrated.  If you like turn-based combat, where your characters learn new skills over time, and combat is the focal point of the game (minor story, which I think makes some reviewers not like the game), then this game is great.  Sense of accomplishment on every fight you beat, especially the hard ones.  It takes a while to figure out tactics for some of the harder fights, but there's nothing better than the feeling of beating it. This is a good game.  Try the demo, you'll get the idea from that, but it does get better after a few hours and you level a bit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080814955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 639, 'last_played': 1583700446}
review:
In general the game is good but the combat is terrible. You'll have 95% chance to hit something and you will miss 5 times.  From what ive seen so far the story is great, character progression and the option to make decisions are fun. i enjoy the battles even though the majority of the time you are greatly out numbered. I liked everything but the combat, that alone makes the game so rough. Its not that its hard strategy wise.

the combat really holds this game back a key destructible item will give you 100% chance to hit and you will still miss, or other times it will take you 2 - 3 hits to destroy it and sometimes it will take one. the consistency is terrible.

review: Grid for positioning the characters, combat options and strategy concepts are poorly designed; in addition, this game has a serious problem of balance and enjoyability. I can't recommend it at all, I gave it a try of about 19 hours, and finally I had to uninstall it to never come back. Sorry for the developers

author: {'steamid': '76561198041647533', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6185, 'last_played': 1484487227}
review:
Great writing and voice acting.
Fun use of evironment in battles. (not hitting stuff when 100% chance, not so fun).
Beatiful map, but painful traveling in the cities.

Seems to be rushed development, ending feels.. pale, few "Adam add textures here" moments.

Buy if you like grumpy dwarves!

author: {'steamid': '76561198051709367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1754, 'last_played': 1484225731}
review:
Detesto scrivere recensioni negative ma questo gioco mi ha lasciato piuttosto deluso. Nonostate abbia apprezzato molto [i] The Dark Eye [/i] all'epoca di Drakensang, trovo questa versione piÃ¹ povera e negativa sotto vari aspetti. 
L'equipaggiamento Ã¨ abbastanza ridotto e costoso, soprattutto i libri di magia. Avere un budget decente da gestire sarÃ  uno dei grandi problemi per buona parte del gioco. 
Nessun crafting. La composizione del gruppo Ã¨ sbilanciata, i punti avventura distribuiti con approssimazione (vi consiglio di crearlo da voi il personaggio principale). Molti scontri sono abbastanza frustranti. L'interazione con l'ambiente, in generale, offre risultati migliori del combattimento diretto. La storia Ã¨ piuttosto buona ma ci sono anche scontri a catena e diversi momenti di delusione. Le ricompense migliori si ottengono spesso con quest risolte malvagiamente (che non alterano la storia), in generale si avranno poche soddisfazioni. Piuttosto che a Blackguards, consiglio vivamente la saga di Drakensang.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059308538', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 8072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8072, 'last_played': 1483924750}
review:
Blackguards is a very interesting game with complex dynamics of the Dark Eye.

IMHO this game deserves a 8.5/10 and definitely worth hours of gameplay and to some extent re-playability. I found myself planing for hours what spells to get and how to develop some characters. 

Pros:
- Detailed characters that come to life
- Good roles mixture (I played as a mage but my real emphasis was a fighter with usage of the shadow spell)
- Detailed scenarios
- Fantastic spells and animations.
- Hard difficulty requires strategic previous character planning to be able to beat some encounters.

Cons:
- No 360 camera support
- Sometimes win or lose a battle feels more luck than strategy (Fail all the hits and all the magic, bad luck meaning lose).
- Mechanics such as Buy/Sell kind of feels incomplete and Weight system feels off
- End of the story is incomplete and leaves you wondering (Blackguards 2 continues this?)

Overall I must say I did really enjoy the game, and the story development might is interesting although not among the most interesting from the Daedalic games or Baldur's gates games storylines.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112810429', 'num_games_owned': 2591, 'num_reviews': 578, 'playtime_forever': 6362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4576, 'last_played': 1484022999}
review:
If only Steam would allowed that, I'd post it under the neutral banner. The game is neither all good or all bad, it's somewhat of any of those extremes.

I really liked the story part, especially the main villain figure, and all that dark cult agenda, it was really fitting. With that said, I'm quite not happy with the pace and rhythm the game plot proceed, the characters making their moves and all such things. It's all... static and boring. Yeah, again, the story is good, the way it was written and told is really subpar.
I liked the subquests, some of them are really creative and interesting... But buggy and not really rewarding.

I... liked the battles, at least, good bunch of them. The maps are challenging, the variety of abilities and ways to get going is really good. With that... Have you noticed the time counter Steam thinks I was playing? Something around 100 hours? Well, in truth it's maybe around 20. I've played the Blackguards on holidays, I never really needed to shut the game. So I was just playing over the moment I get bored and frustrated, and then just leaving the game without closing it. Mostly, it was around some combats, where you abide, and abide... And tarry the tide, if you know that verse.

You see, some of the combats are really long, with big maps, lots of enemies, unobvious goals or some freaky bugs not letting you to finish the fight. Like, for example, a crystal you have to break to proceed. You're standing next to it, with a hammer and 100% hit chance. And then you miss. 5 times in the row. The hit percentage is maybe the one of the worst abominations that Blackguards shows to the world of turn-based RP games. They are so unfair, as loaded dices.

Finally, with all that pro and contra stuff going hand in hand, there are broken achievements and over-the-top strange pattern to make a good ending. In the end, all the game is unrewarding. Unworthy. My mark is 5.8/10. Think twice over this buy, even on the lowest price possible.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960675266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 151, 'playtime_forever': 931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 931, 'last_played': 1483465268}
review:
I have mixed feelings on this game. I got it on sale and would recommend it as such, but this game is not worth 40$. 

Nothing in this game is bad except for the UI, but nothing is good either. Nothing impressed me at all. The spell system having 3 stats associated to every spell just doesn't make sense. I need strength for magic? Wait what? Okay it would make sense if its a force push or something maybe that fits right? Well one of them creates and arcane wall, the other is a debuff. How is that associated to strength at all? 

Most irritating part is some fights are just not properly balanced. There is one fight I spent over an hour on, had the moves mapped to a science, and just needed the RNG to connect. If you let the guy hit you on the second turn and poison you, you simply cannot win. So one companion has to move the perfect amount of tiles away from the enemy so it will chase him, while the other moves away and shoots at the non poisoning opponent. Kiting of this level doesn't have a place in a game like this. When I have to take my tank and run him in circles to not die, I feel like the developers missed something...  And to put it in perspective, I have the best armor and stats possible at the current place for a tank, and he cannot tank nor do I even consider him "tanky". Your shield will add a lot to your parry, but you can only parry once per turn turn so what is the point? My mage honestly has just as good of a chance to survive as he does wearing cloth without a shield. 

I love games like this, and this one just doesn't shine enough for me to recommend it over what is out there. As I said I don't feel it is bad, but I am not finishing the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991845568', 'num_games_owned': 2230, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 1249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1482936040}
review:
100% manure.
While first 2 chapters are fun, from 3 it goes down hill. Especially chapter 5, which is incredibly cheap and frustrating. The game explains itself poorly and people comparing it to xcom should play xcom first.
In this game hit chance % is actually not a real one, because the one that is displaying doesn't add dodge/parry/block to the equation, so the real hit chance is much lower in the end.

Graphics for a game from 2014 are meh, but fps droping to 35 on gtx980 show what an unoptimised mess it can be. If you want to actually check where it drops like that, go to arena and when there is a level with torches and what appeares to be rivers of oil, touch the torch, so half the map is on fire. If you will make them all fall, the fps will go down significantly. Music is unmemorable, characters are just there (with no real development) with really awful VO work. If you thought Bethesda was worst, check this game out on youtube. Completely stoned elf chick is horrendous.
Overall the game is incredibly buggy, from missing sound to other hilarious things.

The only pros for this game that I can think of are:
- cards, which you can sell
- if you really care about playtime, it can be from 20 to 50 hours.
- it is buggy. Why count it as a pros? Because there is a bug in the final fight when the game will beat itself, even if you lose, so you don't have to suffer this cheap and unfair fight anymore (with a trophy for completing and supposedly best ending!). At least I got it and I'm really happy.

2/10, stay away.

PS I will give you some awesome trivia and food for thought - only 7% of the owners actually beat the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996979104', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1318, 'last_played': 1483176508}
review:
First of all this game does not deserve the mixed reviews it has received.  I've been a fan of CRPGs since the days of Might and Magic.  Maybe it's the nostalgia of the Dark Eye ruleset that reminds me of games like Star Trail, which even with its flaws I love. I cannot understand some of the complaints I've heard here. I find the battle difficulty perfect. I know this may turn some people off, but I love it. I typically play all of my RPGs on the hardest settings. I play this on normal. There is an easy mode if you need. It's understandable. That said everytime I'm frustrated I put it down, come back to it later, and succeed.  I will say that I restarted once because given the difficulty I was unhappy with how I had planned out my characters. Let me also say that I am happy there was not a "respec" option.

Pros:
Feels like a classic CRPG
Superb characters and voice acting
Great truly tactical combat system
Suprisingly mature storyline and writing
Lengthy - some might see this as a flaw, I love it

Cons:
Limited character creation/customization options
Uninteresting and simple models/textures for armor/characters
A few bugs, some graphical, at least one gameplay

Note: For those complaining about the RNG, please remember that the mother of all RPGs D&D is a dice game. Get over it.

TLDR:
Great game worth the 4$ or whatever it is in the store right now. I would have bought it for much more. I can't wait to start the sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995688069', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 4232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3768, 'last_played': 1482480570}
review:
Fun game overall, pleasant enough to play - and quite longer than I originally expected - but didn't like it enough to throw myself onto the second installment. I might wait for it to be on sale. For the time invested, the ending felt rushed and not all that satisfactory, but overall game still gets the thumbs up. 

I remember when this initially came out awhile back that people were going on about the darkness of the anti-heroes, the crudeness of the dialogue, almost juvenile humor, etc. Maybe years of playing the Witcher games have heightened (or is that lowered) my tolerance bar, but nothing in Blackguards even raised my eyebrow. In fact, rather than being the EDGY ANTI-HEROES that seem be everywhere these days, it was kind of relaxing to find out that my party were just a bunch of losers, with a lazy, whiny main character, a dwarf who is possibly nuts and most certainly an arsonist, a philandering wizard, and that's just to start with. Rather than choices that are downright eeeeeevil, you mainly get the choice between being a cold-hearted pragmatist or a bit more charitable, which works great. Voice acting was quite good for the price and the type of games, and the graphics, well, they are what they are, I don't mind (honorable mention goes to the fire effects which may be the prettiest I've seen in ANY game at ANY price tag.)

I didn't find the combat to be as intense, strategic or engaging as Original Sin, but it was satisfying enough. The lauded interactive elements were for the most part useless when the surest, easiest strategy (on Normal, anyway) was to fall back, put my tanks in front of my glass cannons, hop the former up with all the buffs I could lay on, and let rip. But the game would fairly frequently throw a curve ball to shake things up; some fights have limited turns before you lose an optimal victory condition, others force you to move forward with ever-spawning enemies or poison gas. There was enough variety that it never got too repetitive or boring, though obviously some of the fights are going to feel annoying or unfair, or leave you way too open for the revenge of the RNG demon. 

Conclusion: I feel no rush to play this again, but I have no regrets buying it in the first place.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010811784', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 15776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10600, 'last_played': 1450398743}
review: Great tactical RPG.  The sequel is better in some ways, but they're both great, so I recommend you start here.  There are a few ugly little graphical issues here & there, but they're not common, so it's not a big deal.  I love the relatively low-magic fantasy setting & the fact that just casting a spell successfully, not to mention hitting the target, is genuinely difficult at first.  The ending is the weakest part, unfortunately.  One issue I have before that is the way the game handles damage types.  It seems a bit odd & nonsensical to me.  For instance, if you get an enchanted mace that does fire damage, (& don't expect to find any such wonders easily,) it does pure fire damage & no physical damage, & this is just one example.  Skeletons are completely immune to piercing damage, etc., etc.. Still a good game, though.  Battles are pretty difficult at times.  A lot of people seem to think this game is too hard, but I disagree.  I enjoy the challenge, & I hope you do too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198278972391', 'num_games_owned': 471, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 4774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4238, 'last_played': 1515453411}
review:
Es un juego que me ha gustado y que he disfrutado, aunque he de reconocer, que tendrÃ­a problemas para alcanzar mÃ¡s de un aprobado raspado en un anÃ¡lisis serio. No obstante, creo que es un juego muy recomendable para los amantes de los SRPG.

Nada mÃ¡s empezar, el juego nos da a elegir entre escoger un personaje entre tres ya definidos (mago, arquero o guerrero) o crearnos uno propio. Es mucho mÃ¡s satisfactorio crearlo tu mismo. Para mi, la mejor opciÃ³n y la mÃ¡s divertida es crear un arquero/mago que use el arco para atacar y que pueda bostear y curar. De hecho en modo mÃ¡s difÃ­cil, el arquero/mago simplifica mucho el juego y lo hace mucho mÃ¡s llevadero. El ataque de arco "disparo triple" puede llegar a hacer unas cantidades de daÃ±o desproporcionadas y allana mucho el camino a la victoria.

La historia es entretenida y sirve para enlazar las batallas y sobre todo, de hilo conductor sobre el que mover a unos personajes que son uno de los puntos fuertes del juego. Todos ellos tienen fuertes personalidades y motivaciones y ambiciones que chocan con las de los otros compaÃ±eros de aventura, de forma que segÃºn sean nuestras decisiones, se puede crear una atmÃ³sfera tensa que sÃ³lo espera una pequeÃ±a chispa para estallar. Constantemente habrÃ¡ que tomar decisiones, las cuales afectarÃ¡n de forma significativa en el juego. Por ejemplo, el enano intentarÃ¡ arreglarlo todo a la fuerza, pero si dejamos que el mago lleve la voz cantante, buscarÃ¡ conseguir el mismo fin mediante sobornos. El sistema de batalla es el tÃ­pico de cualquier SRPG, pero con una peculiaridad: la interacciÃ³n con el entorno. En todas las batallas hay elementos del mapa que nos pueden servir de ayuda en la consecuciÃ³n de la victoria. Por ejemplo, las pozas en los pantanos pueden detener a los enemigos un nÃºmero determinado de turnos, o los barriles pueden bloquear el paso por determinadas zonas.

GrÃ¡ficamente cumple sin hacer ningÃºn alarde. Aunque lo que si se echa en falta, son cinemÃ¡ticas. Hay pocas y muy breves y podrÃ­an haber creado alguna mÃ¡s que sirviera para apoyar la narraciÃ³n.

Ahora bien, hay que reconocer que el juego tiene bastantes fallos, algunos importantes son:
-Por algÃºn milagro de la estadÃ­stica, es posible fallar ataques con un 100% de posibilidad de acierto.
-Unas pocas conversaciones estÃ¡n en un perfecto "spanglish".
-Algunas frases no aparecen traducidas.
-En ocasiones es casi imposible seleccionar al personaje sobre el que va a recaer una acciÃ³n y hay que hacer malabares con el ratÃ³n para poder conseguirlo.
-Bugs con algunos logros.

TambiÃ©n se puede hablar de otras cosas que se podrÃ­an mejorar:
-Algunos logros no tienen ningÃºn sentido. Por ejemplo, un logro te pide hacer un personaje que tenga 10 puntos de talento en todos los tipos de armas y lo normal es que uses un Ãºnico tipo de arma o a lo sumo dos, por lo que el logro te pide que tires los puntos en crear un personaje inÃºtil.
-Las clases no estÃ¡n bien balanceadas, siendo los arqueros mucho mÃ¡s poderosos que el resto.
-El poder de los hechizos ofensivos y su porcentaje de acierto es muy bajo (lo han arreglado en Blackguard 2 y se agradece).
-No se pueden escoger las posiciones iniciales de los personajes y en ocasiones, jugando en dificultades altas, esto puede suponer que las probabilidades de perder un personaje en el turno uno sean altÃ­simas (tambiÃ©n lo han arreglado en Blackguards 2).
-Si bien lo mÃ¡s importante es el camino, el final puede llegar a sentirse decepcionante e insÃ­pido.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981945199', 'num_games_owned': 1379, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1482017932}
review:
I've been playing the game for around 4 hours at this point and I'll be honest...  I don't get the bad rep this game is getting...  The characters (so far) are well voiced, the story, although fairly generic, is decent enough and the combat system is decent.

I will admit, I bought the game as a part of this weekends sale, so got both Blackguards 1 & 2 along with a bunch of other games for about Â£12.  I've been tempted by both of these for some time now, but was put off by the reviews and the price.  So far, I have found these to be unfounded.

I dove straight in on character creation rather than have the system do half the work for you and I am learning it as I go.  There's a lot to choose from so I just went with basics at least to start with.  It looks diverse enough to branch out later, which is always nice.

Sure, there is a large element of RNG, but look at XCOM...  That game has continually devastated its players by repeated 95%+ shots missing at the, single, most crucial shot of the game.  I can't count how many times in that I have missed that said shot and the mission suddenly went to hell.  This is no different, though I have yet to encounter anything so drastic, but it's still early days.

I can certainly see the game getting repetitive after a time, but there seems to be a lot more variation than XCOM in terms of attacks you can do, especially when you take in to account the spells.

I would say that this game is definitely recommended to fans of TBS games and also to those of strategic fantasy games.  I would also definitely say that this game 'should' be recommended.

To set 'not recommended' as others have because it's niche is just a tad overkill tbh.  If they aren't interested in a game just because it's a TBS or fantasy, then why are they looking at it in the first place?  It's a moot point.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011864330', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 4228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3998, 'last_played': 1481329792}
review:
So having finally finished the game, time for a quick review. 

[b]Is it worth buying?[/b]

Eh, just about. It's regularly on sale for Â£2 or Â£3, and I got 70hrs out of it, so on that basis you'd be a whiny little bitch to complain. 

[b]Is it any good?[/b]

Eh, just about. It's a classic TBS affair. The storyline's OK, but gets kinda convoluted throughout the game so by the end, you've pretty much lost the plot and stopped caring. Something to do with a Whisper...? Anyway. 

One big plus is the characters and writing. They're generally a likeable bunch and have good banter between them, and often their conversations raise a chuckle.

Progress is extremely limited - you won't be working your way up through half a dozen better and better sets of gear as you progress: in fact, once you've got a complete set by around chapter 2, you can pretty much forget about upgrading any more. So if you're a loot junky and love waiting for the loot windows at the end of every fight to see what shiny new gear your heroes are getting, you'll be disappointed.

Having said that, if you simply enjoy the basics of TBS combat and love moving your guys around a hexboard and using your new skills/spells to smash zombies in the face, you'll enjoy yourself.

[b]Overall[/b]

It's not the best TBS out there, but it's not awful. The thrill fades throughout the game so towards the end finishing it off becomes as much a chore as a pleasure, but at 90% off there's no reason TBS fans shouldn't have it in their library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031328124', 'num_games_owned': 279, 'num_reviews': 335, 'playtime_forever': 4605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4564, 'last_played': 1479770174}
review:
I really enjoyed it.. The difficulty can be ridiculous on certain enemies, and is extremely punishing if you screw up your builds.. Its very rng based, and people who hated the hit% crap from Xcom EU/EW will hate this as much.. I didnt have many technical issues, and I really enjoyed the game, and am looking forward to playing through part 2 when i get around to it.. 

I did have to turn the diff down to easy, as I was just unable to get through some fights (one in particular, which repeates later on, and is where i finally gave up) Irribar Illy or something.. Has tentacles, and wisps which can only be dmg via magic..  

Not only can melee attacks fail, but so do spell casts.. I dont mind misses when its a shitty chance to cast/hit, but when 90%+ chances miss consistently and consecutively, it just promotes save scumming to advance, and thats what i felt i had to do to progress..  Even on easy, as i said.. 

Later on, you feel much more powerful, but some other cheap feeling tactics are then thrown at you, often far out numbering the player.. 

Like I said, I enjoyed the game, but Ill be damned if i could figure out the difficulty, and Im no stranger to tactical games..

author: {'steamid': '76561198044258921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 710, 'last_played': 1470457905}
review: I can't begin to tell you how many times I've seen people say stuff like "Gee, I really wish I could recommend this game," and that's about how I feel about Blackguards. It's relatively interesting, there are some fun moments, etc., but overall it's just kinda lacking, especially in terms of giving the player a measure of freedom. I'd say just don't bother, it's certainly not worth $40, and I'd say it's only barely worth $5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066188237', 'num_games_owned': 695, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 877, 'last_played': 1463001058}
review:
My main problem is the RNG. Restarting matches (and they are matches of your units VS -random units here-) because of critical RNG failure leading to either important people not dying or important people on my side getting suddenly fireballed. Having all your stuff yanked from you every-so-often makes me far less invested in "getting that cool thing" or even bothering to upgrade past basic equip or drops. 

I liked combat when it wasn't trying to screw me over. Mages are irritating and not fun to have on party unless they only do one magic spell for the most part.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006001346', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1588000440}
review: Ok I'm done. Got in to a decent start and I thought the game is alright. But then came the baroness rescue. Tried to bang my head against the impossible for several hours. Gave up. In terms of making a game challenging, it has to be executed in some different way than throwing you into an impossible situation which requires basically every dice roll to go on your favor in a maximum way. Otherwise, reload and against the same situation again, and again, and again, and again, and again, and again, and again, and again. Nuff said? Yeah. Killed all the fun for me. Luckily I got this game with a 90% discount and got a few hours of pretty decent fun. It's a terrible shame really, it would've been interesting to dwell deeper into the storyline. The characters seemed pretty interesting with their personalities. Oh well, now I'm off to uninstall this piece of garbage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020543247', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1479617101}
review:
The RNG factor in this game is major issue. I love turn-based/strategy/tactic- games but this game just takes all the fun out of the gameplay in fights. Even if you execute the fights as the game wants you to (clearly), you will get those 90%-95%  misses in row and that makes you using F9 or "try again" all time. It is frustrating/repetitive as hell and is sucking the all the excitement out of the game. I must say at this point im breaking apart and will most likely just delete this crap. 
If you want to test your "skills" (patience&nerves)  grab this game when -90%. If not, buy Xcom or some other real title instead of this **** .

author: {'steamid': '76561198046652573', 'num_games_owned': 127, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 10470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8293, 'last_played': 1532998710}
review: I am playing this for the second time. First time I played a mage and now I am playing a dual sword-wielding woman. There is definitely good replayability here. My old computer crashed a lot when playing this game, but it seems to be running fine on my new computer. I recommend a more modern machine when playing this game. Check the sys requirements. Wwhat can I say about it? Some of the battles can seem impossible. Save a lot. Not just a quick save, but named saves too. I like that many of the battles have to be repeated with new strategies. You will need heal spells, potions, poisons, nets, traps and some good strategy. Try to figure out how to get the overhead perspective to work because sometimes WASD camera control just won't do. I have a trackball mouse, so sometimes I can't see all the enemies or my PCs' positions. For regular mice, it should be the scroll-wheel to zoom all the way out. I like the spell effects. Complicated level up system with lots of points to spend from attributes (which cost the most so save for these) to special abilities (need to find a trainer) to weapon skills and spell strength. It's based on The Dark Eye, a German pen-and-pencil RPG that is more complicated, can you believe it, than D&D and very popular throughout Europe. Con: can be confusing how to finish some quests as they lack location markers and you will need to remember in which cities certain trainers are and the merchants that sell the equipment that you want. Overall, I find it more enjoyable than frustrating and it is a good turn-based tactical experience. Plus the voice acting is better than you'd expect. Pick it up on sale. Note: some poisons that are listed as lasting "whole battle" may not. Weapons with a magic bonus do not hurt magical creatures. When a wizard is wounded some spells will have very low chance of success, especially debuffing spells. Bandages often do not heal wounds even with high score in the healing talent, so visit a healer for wounds as needed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035011027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1708185740}
review:
My impressions after first chapter, or 7 hours of gameplay.


I got this title, because I have quite liked "The Dark Eye" digital universe this far, Drakensang games having introduced me to it, and I think I like Demonicon better than the average game critic. I am generally a high-fantasy RPG fan, tending to like pauseable party based tactical combat evolved from Baldur's Gate the best.

In essence: I am not a natural fan of turn-based combat, and the biggest challenge to me on this first play-through is figuring out how to best invest my leveling points across attiributes, special abilities and skills etc.

However: I have liked the combat with Blackguards a lot this far, and have not found game-play frustrating, because the encounters are not that punishing after choosing the setting for players not familiar with Dark Eye rules at least. I've had both a few reloads, as well as feeling of particular successes when environmental effect or tactic has been just right!

What I like about these games is that the game-world feels like it has its own identity, and back-ground lore of belief systems, power structurs and faction relationships, owing to the original non-digital IP.

The gameplay design choices are in my view well prioritised, in view that the developer probably does not have a budget nowhere near the North American big gaming studios. Some choices are not so intutive to me, thou - I for example struggled a bit how to figure out how to get the world map after the intorductionary graveyeard quest!

I am personally pleased to have noticed this title, and have enjoyed my game a lot this far. I am curious to advance the story, and learning more about the game universe is also something that I personally enjoy with each Dark Eye title.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971190695', 'num_games_owned': 1377, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 1074, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1042, 'last_played': 1393956886}
review:
Known for old-school point & click adventure games such as Deponia and Edna & Harvey, German developer Daedalic took gamers by surprise when releasing Blackguards â€“ a tactical turn-based RPG based on The Dark Eye tabletop ruleset.

While the story sells itself as a dark narrative where you play as outlaws, itâ€™s rather cliche and heroic. The Dark Eye ruleset is the true drawing point. While some rules where cut, such as most non-combat talents, it remains a solid and complex (if rather intimidating) classless system, offering ample freedom when creating your character. Itâ€™s a joy for hardcore players, but very poorly explained for newcomers. Sadly, the forced party members end up limiting some of your party building possibilities â€“ sometimes even forcing a restart.

Blackguards knows its limitations and uses some unconventional design choices to compensate them, betting everything on its battles â€“ cities are presented as simple animated backgrounds with stores and NPCs to talk with, exploration is limited to a 2D world map full of icons, dungeons are but a semi-linear sequence of battles without rest and the story is told via simple cutscenes, with an occasional decision to be made. This leads to an unique â€œWestern Final Fantasy Tacticsâ€ feel, and while the game first hours are very linear, it later opens up to a wide range of interesting side-quests.

Daedalicâ€™s background as an adventure game developer is felt here in an unusual way. There are no random battles in Blackguards, meaning that every encounter happens in an unique arena specifically designed for it, often with unique challenges or tactical puzzles. There are traps, time limits, holes that spawn enemies, movable and destructible objects, healing orbs, falling chandeliers, mechanical blades, flying dragons, swamp gas, giant tentacles, mind-controlling plants, draw bridges, collapsing passageways, a giant cage on a crane, etc. 

Thereâ€™s not a single RPG out there that offers so many interesting combat scenarios. This alone makes Blackguards a must-play for any tactical fan â€“ or RPG designer. 

Unfortunately, the game stretches out for far too long (40 to 60 hours), and the limited variety of enemies and equipment result in a rather stale second half of the game. Still, fans of Tactical RPGs will have a blast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012560930', 'num_games_owned': 380, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1481482021}

author: {'steamid': '76561197989169791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1192, 'last_played': 1478192971}
review: I really wanted to like this game but every chapter starts with you kitting out your characters only to have all you items taken away because you were thrown in prison or caught by slavers or some stupid crap where now you have to fight with clubs in your underware against fully geared opponents. It wouldnt be too bad if it was a one time thing but this game litterally does this to you three times in first two chapaters......

author: {'steamid': '76561198211394059', 'num_games_owned': 216, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 3999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3959, 'last_played': 1477845066}
review:
Blackguards. 
Un nome una promessa.

E' un gioco che fa gridare al miracolo? No.
PerÃ² chi se ne frega !

E' un'ambientazione dove la cattiveria e la bastardaggine la fanno da padroni.
Nel role dei personaggi, con tutti i loro adorabili stereotipi.
Nelle scelte che ti permette di fare e le ricompense che ti da' se sei un gran fi**** di p****** la maggior parte delle volte.
Nel farti crescere dei compari e poi soffiarteli o metterteli addirittura contro: come suona tirar su l'arciere perfetto quando poi ti spara in faccia le sua frecce ?
Nel punirti se sbagli la tattica di gioco. E' difficile capirla? No. Tanto meglio cosÃ¬.

E' longevo, per quel che mi riguarda,. ci ho messo delle belle ore.
Si lascia giocare senza diventare noioso.
Secondo me merita se si Ã¨ ben convinti dell'acquisto.
Io lo ero: non mi ha deluso, per niente.

Da provare. Il due devo ancora provarlo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058768284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1765, 'last_played': 1494981938}
review: I have just finished the second chapter and I find the game really fun, so the large number of negative reviews surprises me. Actually one of the few games I got hooked on lately. Well, on the other hand since the score was so low, my expectations were quite low as well, resulting in a nice surprise. It is less RPG than tactical combat game but it is very good at what it is doing. Frustration because of hits are not landing even when the indicated probability is high, comes probably from the fact the people do not develop skills properly. All in all, recommended, my score is 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040243171', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 3454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3393, 'last_played': 1477537370}
review:
Bad: 
The story ending feels very rushed and tagged on, compared to the plot development in the other chapters.
The  battles clearly have a "right" way. (I like this, it feels like puzzle solving, but that's a matter of taste).
Items, even basic items like arrows and health potions, are limited.
Very, very constrained in level-up points. The leveling up system is quite involved, and the constraint from the points is too tight. It feels like that there is one layer too many,,,
The animation is... special. Everyone has a dislocated jaw. 

The good:
Even though you can see the plot twist coming from a mile away, I still struggled to make the "right" decisions to try and get a "good"ending. (Once you play enough games, you begin to see the "right" choice.)
The game has a high F-U factor. Spent 20 hours and tons of money leveling up a character? Guess what, they're dead now, too bad. You think your arrows can break a crystal and you didn't think to equip your archer with a different weapon? Well, that's sucks for you.  

Overall: This game needed a little bit more time and polish. If it had that, it would have become a classic. In it's current format, I find it highly enjoyable but I can imagine if you don't play many old games this will test your patience.  

***IMPORTANT*** Given how limited level-up points are, for your first playthrough you should use one of the pre-created classes. I would advise not playing a mage, given that there is an entire fourth page of skills to level up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977070647', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 3056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3056, 'last_played': 1477525244}
review:
Not super great. Occasionally interesting gimmick combats, but the storytelling is really not memorable and the game is just not that well executed.
Once you figure out that speed buff level 3 + hammerblow is the way to go, most combats become trivial.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053624632', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4787, 'last_played': 1610894293}
review:
Das Spiel ist echt gut, aber auch knackig schwer. Ich kann es all denen sehr ans Herz legen, die gerne tÃ¼fteln und eher bedÃ¤chtig vorgehen (Action-Fans sollten die Finger davon lassen). Die gewonnenen Erfahrungspunkte sollten wohlÃ¼berlegt ausgegeben werden, sonst ist bald der Punkt erreicht, an dem man viele KÃ¤mpfe nicht mehr schafft und frustriert aufgibt. Ich habe selbst erst einmal fÃ¼r etliche Stunden drauf los gespielt, bis ich die Feinheiten alle verstanden habe. Dann habe ich erneut von vorne begonnen, einen Charakter ganz nach meinen Vorstellungen erstellt und siehe da, es hat geklappt. Und dabei SpaÃŸ gemacht, umso mehr, je weiter ich in der Geschichte vorangekommen bin. Ich bin froh, dass ich auch nach mehr als 80 Stunden immer noch nicht ganz durch bin, denn am Ende eines so tollen Spieles bin ich immer ein wenig traurig (weil es vorbei ist).

Die wichtigsten Vorteile:
- Das Spiel besitzt eine Story, die gut und spannend erzÃ¤hlt wird. Viele Charaktere wachsen einem schnell ans Herz, bzw. auf einige Feinde bekommt man regelrecht einen Hass.
- Gute deutsche Sprecher, jede Stimme ist gut zu unterscheiden. Kurze, prÃ¤gnante Dialoge (kein blabla!).
- EinprÃ¤gsame, nicht nervige Musik.
- Jeder Kampf ist anders und findet auf verschieden gestalteten Territorien statt. Neben Nah- und Fernkampf kann man Fallen auslegen, BrÃ¤nde entfachen, Barrikanen errichten, die Waffen vergiften, zaubern, Schatztruhen Ã¶ffnen, Hebel umlegen, Glocken lÃ¤uten usw. usw. DesÃ¶fteren mÃ¼ssen bestimmte Ziele innerhalb einer bestimmen Rundenanzahl erreicht werden. Nicht selten passieren wÃ¤hrend des Kampfes unvorhersehbare Dinge: Der Feind erhÃ¤lt VerstÃ¤rkung, BrÃ¼cken brechen ein, Spinnen schlÃ¼pfen oder Ã¤hnliches. Oft reiht sich auch ein zweiter oder gar dritter Kampf unmittelbar an, so dass man darauf achten muss, den ersten mit mÃ¶glichst wenig Schaden zu Ã¼berstehen.
- Man kann jederzeit und in freier Reihenfolge eine der vielen Nebenquests erfÃ¼llen, um Abenteuerpunkte zu sammeln und die Charaktere zu verbessern.
- Das Spiel lÃ¤uft stabil, kurze Ladebildschirme, keine Bugs.

Ganz wenig Nachteile:
- Der Kampfbildschirm lÃ¤sst sich nicht drehen und auch nicht nach oben/unten verschieben. Er lÃ¤sst sich lediglich kippen. Manchmal muss man auf das Charakterportrait klicken, damit dieser wieder sichtbar wird, wenn er sich zu weit oben oder unten befindet.
- Wenn man Pech hat und der Gegner GlÃ¼ck, hilft oft nur, den Kampf erneut zu versuchen.
- Einige KÃ¤mpfe sind ultraschwer (wenige habe ich auch nach 5-10 Versuchen noch nicht geschafft; ich bleibe aber dran!)

Fazit:
Ein forderndes Spiel, das wohltuend anders ist und in Sachen QualitÃ¤t den allgemein gut kritisierten Adventures von Daedalic in nichts nachsteht. Klare Kaufempfehlung fÃ¼r Spieler mit KÃ¶pfchen!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992229015', 'num_games_owned': 1175, 'num_reviews': 776, 'playtime_forever': 1541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1451, 'last_played': 1476912299}
review:
So, Blackguards, either loved or hated it seems.

I wouldn't go in either direction. To me this is a solid Combat RPG with a pretty decent story and excellent voice acting. The characters are a bit stereotypical, though. There's your hero, the crazed dwarf who sees dragons everywhere and the macho mage, as well as some other characters I won't spoil now, but their backstory and motivations aren't that much better. Still, they managed to make this into a more interesting story than Dragon Age: Inquisition...for a CRPG it's more than you need.

Be warned though, this is NOT a traditional RPG, you will NOT be exploring a huge world, you will NOT have hundreds of different dialogues and quests and choices. There is quite a bit of that but it's not the main focus. Quests are usually: go here and do that. And by go here I mean "click on the overworld map to move to one of the interactive points" or on the city screen. This is how you navigate the world of Blackguards, you click a POI on a map and your party moves there. This is either a city in which you can further navigate different parts of said city and speak to people, buy stuff, heal and rest. Anything else is mostly combat.

Combat and gear in general are pretty in depth. There are different types of weapons which all have advantages and disadvantages and must be learned to use. So your spear wielding barbarian is no good with a 2 handed sword for instance. To improve a certain aspect of a character you have to spend AP. You can spend AP for pretty much everything: ranged combat, specific weapons, magic resist, hit points, detecting traps, healing wounds, improving spells, movement points, etc. Like I said the system is pretty deep. Special weapons also have special attributes that you need to factor in. Maybe a weapon does less "attack damage", but has a +6 fire damage value, increasing it's effective damage again. You need to do the math in your head, though. There aren't too many unique weapons though so not that big of a deal. Of course there is also armor and set bonuses as well as magic you need to consider.

Once you're happy with your characters' equipment you can do battle. On the easiest difficulty most battles can be won at first try. On the harder difficulties, however, the game becomes rather difficult and potentially frustrating. And I think this is why the game has "so many" negative reviews. The combat can be unforgiving and you can't save during a battle. Battles also last forever. Do you like Heroes of Might and Magic? Yeah, like that in the late game. One battle can easily take up to 30 minutes, esp. on higher difficulties. There is of course also a random element in hit and crit chance. There is no 100% hit chance, only when an enemy is prone. And even then I needed to roll x, which I did, and still missed. I'd say that's a bug. Oh, apparently the chances are decided by dice and not actual percentages, so beware of false security. There's a handy battle log though.

Overall I feel that this is a pretty good product IF you are looking for this type of game. If you want Dragon Age or Baldur's Gate, don't bother. This is not that.

review: The game is bad. Level designer is (bad language) and should be prohibited from making any game or anything which include brain activity as he clearly doesn't have one. I'm not going to count all stupidity of the game here. In short: most times it's frustrating and unfriendly to control and as I said designs of some levels just terrible. Don't buy it even on sale as I did, you will waste your time playing it. Want to feel like you're playing this game? Grab bunch of dies and throw them few times, it's easy like this. So in the end it's not so much important how you develop your characters most of the times result of the battle will depend on dies. Once again: don't buy this game!
