author: {'steamid': '76561198041219230', 'num_games_owned': 230, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 2575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 903, 'last_played': 1477593440}
review:
The visuals of this game are in real stark contrast with the game mechanics. Everything looks very nice, but when it comes to the combat, skill system, rest periods and so forth, the game begins to feel like it was drafted twenty years ago.

It's just so inbalanced. The classes are not in balance. The attributes, skills, talents, weapon talents and special talents (I probably forgot something) are not in balance. The cost of items and services - compare for instance provisions, healing, bandages, potions and taverns - are not in balance.

The game is haphazard inside and outside of combat. You may begin a series of events only to notice that there is no way to return anymore. There are unforeseeable series of battles, and failing one may set you back an HOUR of progress. Failing even one spell might flip the situation completely. Putting all points in a single weapon talent can screw you up, because, well... find it out yourself.

But all this got me thinking. Are we too pampered with forgiving games? Perhaps. Here's a game that you can seriously break by playing it wrong (or right, in a good way!). Here's a game that requires putting those annoyingly flexible talent points into right places. So begrudgingly thumbs up for this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007486006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 1899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1899, 'last_played': 1474401861}
review:
A pleasant, unexpected surprise.

An old-style, turn-based, class-based RPG, that reminded me of my first RPGs (Pool of Radiance, anyone?). Sure, it is not perfect; the story is interesting, but lacks depth; the characters have personalities and stories, but you only scratch the surface; the classes are rudimentary and poor; the gameplay is slightly repetitive.
Nonetheless, it has a lot of potential, and I wholeheartedly recommend it, especially if we consider the price and the fact that it won't take you so long to finish it, so you shouldn't get bored before then!

review: This seems like a turnbased dice game like warhammer made into a video game only the chance of you hitting anything is really high. There isn't much diversity in the game, The game's storyline is terrible and if i didn't get this in a humble bundle i would want a refund. Steam reviews exist for games like this so you don't waste money buying such a bad game. $40 for a indie game is already over priced. $40 for an indie game that isn't made well is thrash. 3/10 Cool graphhics and concept but no

author: {'steamid': '76561197993553287', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1467585372}
review:
I really want to like this game. It just feels off. Like the whole time I'm going up hill. None of the missions really ever seem fair. My spells never work. I miss all the time. Constantly feel like I don't have enough money. The character progression skill trees are overwhelming and confusing at best.

There are two missions that I tried over and over to beat, and absolutely can not beat them. I end up just taking the 'failure' option and feel bad about myself. Maybe I just suck at this game, but it feels like there is no way to really be good at it. I can't even 'grind' to level up my guys. It's just one disapointment after another.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103651772', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 5192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2240, 'last_played': 1474175238}
review:
I understand the negative reviews. The ruleset is complicated, and even more jarring perhaps to those used to D&D attributes and rules. That is why you should do as the game suggests and play on Normal difficulty and use the Basic (pre-made) character if it is your first time and unfamiliar to The Dark Eye. That's exactly what I did, and by the time I play a second time, I'll know enough of this convoluted system to choose a different class and choose my own stats.

It's a really fun strategy RPG, with an emphasis placed on usable objects on the battlefield, and unique battle maps. Every fight seems to have a "hook" to it. You will, however, spend hours looking at the manual, in-game tutorial and rules menu, and ultimately guides to explain what the hell is REALLY going on.

Talent modifiers to aid failed skill checks; Damage types as diverse and odd as Infantry, Piercing, Fire, Bashing and Magic (No, there is fire magic, it's just, well, the system is weird, OK); 3 separate attribute checks just to cast one spell; finally figuring out what the fuck Armor Rating and Encumbrance really mean. This is for all the true OGs of CRPGs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987316902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 686, 'last_played': 1473623556}
review:
The game locks up consistently.  Which means alot of restarts and lost time.

Regardless it's still boring.  Latest lock up came around the point I was feeling like it was all such a waste of time anyways.  Won't bother restarting again.  

RNG, I hate to complain about it...but...it's ridiculous in this case.  That's coming from someone who didn't mind it in Darkest Dungeon.

Linear.  With not much to do.  Imagine boring battle sequences with an even simpler point and click game in between.

Character progression.  Bleh.  The RNG has this covered to a point of non-consequential upgrades because a 10% chance to fail still means a 110% chance not to succeed.  Not always, just sometimes three times in a row... 

Clunky.  So clunky.  

Not alot of turn based combat games out there, which sucks.  But I'd give this one a solid pass if you're considering it.  It's just not worth the time.  I don't care how starved you think you are for that genre.

Bought this in a bundle for fairly cheap.  But even if it was free I'd still suggest a pass.  It's just so booooring.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971519880', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 2720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2626, 'last_played': 1472435671}
review:
First and foremost: this is NOT an RPG.  It's a party-based tactical combat game with RPG elements.  If you start with that understanding, you'll avoid the disappointment that many players have encountered.

The game is about figuring out how to beat a series of scenarios.  Sometimes it's about how you use abilities and items, sometimes it's about using the environment.

It's not a perfect game, but it's fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969512685', 'num_games_owned': 547, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1794, 'last_played': 1472400738}
review:
Ein SPiel welches SpaÃŸ machen kann, wenn man Ã¼ber einige, teils extrem schere, technische Fehler hinweg sehen kann. Das Spiel startet mit dem aktuellen Betriebssystem nicht korrekt, bzw. wenn es mal doch startet so hat man nach dem Startvideo plÃ¶tzlich ein schwarzes Bild.
Die LÃ¶sung, welche in diversen Foren kusiert, funktioniert nur zu 50%. Ich musste immer wieder, zwischen WinXP und Win7 wechseln, damit das Spiel dann doch lief.

Nun zum Spiel an sich. Grafik und Sound sind fÃ¼r die damalige Zeit ganz in Ordnung. Das Regelwerk basiert auf dem DSA mit einigen leichten AbschwÃ¤chungen.
Die Story ist weder Ã¼berraschend noch wirklich spannend,die Charaktere blieben bei dem kompletten Spielerlebnis ehr blass und eintÃ¶nig.
Die Skillung ist, bis auf beim Hauptchar, teilweise bereits vorgegeben und eine Umskillung vom Magier hin zum KÃ¤mpfer zwar mÃ¶glich aber nicht wirklich Sinnvoll.
Die einzigen wirklichen KÃ¤mpfer kÃ¶nnen auch nicht zu Magiern gemacht werden, da sie die MÃ¶glichkeit schlicht nicht haben. Das Spiel erklÃ¤rt das mit der Herkunft der beiden Chars.

[u]Fazit[/u]
Das Spiel selbst hat, bis auf diese paar Sachen und einige AbstÃ¼rze (welche zum GlÃ¼ck erst dann auftraten nachdem das Spiel gespeichert hatte) viel SpaÃŸ gemacht und teilweise waren die RundenkÃ¤mpfe sehr fordernd.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028707432', 'num_games_owned': 155, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1470144058}
review:
Lost patience very early. The tactical aspect of the fights is extremely poor, just few possibilities to individualize characters and all in all little scope of action. Hearing some generic fantasy story, have a boring fight, buy items, repeat. It's like a really unexperienced dev team tried to create their first TBS. Can't recommend. Buy Divinity: Original Sin instead; this is worth your money.

Oh, and the mages suck. Failing their casting check all the time.

review:
6/10

PROS:
- Great soundtrack
-Combat has a puzlzish feeling
- Story is not great, but is cativating enough
- Graphics and style are neat.

CONS:
- The puzzlish combat I've mentioned made me repeat several beattles over and over
- General interface feels a little awkward.
- Character development takes some time to get used to. Should have the option to redistribute the points somehow.
- Quite straightfowrad and linear, sidequests don't feel like add much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016977238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1088, 'last_played': 1474202871}
review:
This game was part of a bundle I bought 1 year ago - together with Memoria and Dark eye: Chains of Satinav. I did not install it at the time because the looks of the game did not appeal to me at first. I even thought back then that this was a strategy game (its actually a turn based RPG :P) 

One month ago, I decided to install the game in order to get the steam cards. Based on the reviews I was expecting a pretty aweful game. Nevertheless, I decided to play for an hour instead of idling.

The first screen I encountered was the character creation. I was pleasantly suprised by the depth and variety of choices and I found myself tinkering at the various options and builds for an hour!

Well, after an hour, I thought that the options did not really matter because I wasnt going to play the game given how bad it must be according to the reviews I had read. However, I was still waiting for those cards so I decided to have a look at the actual game. 

Again, to my suprise, although it started slowly, the game captured my interest. Slowly, but steadily, I started enjoying the story and the battles gameplay. That was it, after some time I was hooked!

Here is what I think of the game:

+Give the game some time at the beginning. It starts slowly but it steadily builds a strong story! Same goes for the gameplay. It looks a bit strange at first but I grew to like it very much! 
+The Graphs are really good. 
+Full sound + Voice + Subtitles 
+Dialogue options
+Decisions matter
+Challenging game
+Character creation system. There is no level up system - Using adventure points to create unique ways of fighting. 
+Story twists. 
+I havent encountered any in game bugs. 

-Some may find the game TOO challenging. Its not a forgiving game. You have to think the consequences of your gameplay. 
-Linear. Most of the times there is only one battle available. 
-THE MOST IMPORTANT PROBLEM AT THE MOMENT IS THAT THE GAME SEEMS TO HAVE SOME PROBLEM RUNNING IN WINDOWS 10. However, this issue can be solved with a little bit of tinkering. There are numerous solutions out there. 

To sum up, I fully recommend this game at a discount and even at full price if you enjoy turn based RPGS. I dont understand whats going on with other reviews. Perhaps people were expecting a different kind of game? However, keep in mind that the game has some compatibility issues with Win 10. 

I've already bought Blackguards 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030679370', 'num_games_owned': 308, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1588111252}
review: Here is the deal with Blackguards.  If you liked the drakensang games, or the Blade of destiny remake, you will like this game.  I happen to like TDE games, and so i recommend to you if you are into that.  It doesnt have the free roaming of eather, but it has a less painful version of the Blade of destiny(remakes) combat. An interesting easter egg in the english naration are black library narrators (wh40k audiobooks) like toby longworth, and someone else that i dont recognize by name but by voice.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971569035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 360, 'playtime_forever': 2492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2008, 'last_played': 1469488681}
review:
Se non conoscete il sistema di regole del gioco lasciate perdere o trovate i manuali del gioco cartaceo e leggeteveli. Il gioco non spiega nulla su come funzionino le dinamiche delle stats nelle azioni di gioco quindi o vi documentate o sbaglierete a creare\sviluppare gli eroi e prima o poi arriverete a un fight che non potete vincere e non potrete andare avanti. Stessa cosa per coperture, range ecc... Questa Ã¨ la premessa.

Il gioco Ã¨ assurdamente complicato, l'rng Ã¨ il 99.9% di ogni fight e a meno che non abbiate minmaxato i vostri personaggi sarete costretti a ripetere decine di volte il fight perchÃ¨ un tiro di dadi semplicemente Ã¨ andato male. Non c'Ã¨ nemmeno possibilitÃ  di annullare un azione o salvare durante i fight quindi anche un missclick vi puÃ² rovinare tutto costringendovi a ricominciare. La magia (cure e danni) sono rng anch'esse e le stats del personaggio influenzano pochissimo la % in vostro favore. Se non credete alle mie parole c'Ã¨ un mio screenshot dove una magia al 100% di riuscita Ã¨ fallita.

Il gioco non Ã¨ un RPG, manca la componente RP dato che a parte una customizzazione del vostro personaggio il gioco Ã¨ statico, segue una linea e non ci sono decisioni che influenzano minimamente qualcosa. Inoltre gli altri personaggi del party possono essere sviluppati seguendo solo PRECISI sviluppi, andate da altre parti e vi ritroverete dei personaggi inutili.

Molte volte vi ritroverete a fare 4-5 incontri di fila dove non potrete riposare nel mentre. Il gioco ve lo fa capire in certi modi almeno.

Alcuni "boss" delle sidequest non possono essere fatti a meno che non abbiate il party configurato in un certo modo. A meno che non vogliate ripetere l'incontro all'infinito finchÃ¨ i dadi non vi grazino con eccezionale fortuna. es. (se ci arrivate) la lily al capitolo 3 non puÃ² essere fatta a meno che non siate tutti arcieri (praticamente immune alla magia, i melee vengono esplosi prima di arrivargli addosso, un personaggio non Ã¨ utilizzabile).

Gli incantesimi che userete in gioco utili sono 3 circa. Gli altri sono inutili. I debuff sono inutili, qualsiasi caster che abbiate sottomano trattatelo come danni + danni + danni + danni. O healing. Per far entrare un debuff il gioco compie 3 tiri percentuale e i vantaggi sono praticamente minimi.

I talenti servono poco o nulla se non a conoscere quanti hp ha il nemico o quanta iniziativa ha. I talenti per le armi sarete costretti a prenderne alcuni inutili per sbloccare delle capacitÃ  speciali MANDATORIE per i vostri personaggi.

La trama Ã¨ interessante ma non approfondisce bene i personaggi rendendo l'idea che sia stato fatto molto di corsa.

Giudizio? Non ne vale la pena, il gioco Ã¨ frustrante e vi fa capire quasi a ogni fight che le vostre strategie o come avete sviluppato i pg conta poco o nulla contro a tiri fortunati o sfortunati. Il livello di frustrazione Ã¨ vicino a quello di dark souls + xcom a una difficoltÃ  elevata.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056445690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1468398263}
review:
I can't have more than an hour into this game, and it's already crashed twice on loading screens. I force-quit it on the third non-tutorial level.

I'm a big fan of daedalic, and I champion myself as being well versed in every turn based RPG of this nature. But this feels like it was never play-tested. It genuinely feels like no one sat down and played it, as a game, and said "okay, these elements work mechanically, but from a game-perspective, they dont." Every single time you miss a hit, and your enemy never misses at all, and you sit there for a dozen turns soaking up damage for what feels like--no strategic reason, you realise, "Oh great, this is one of those games where I need to return to town every fucking time I finish a level, to heal up"

Why? Why not just heal back to full between missions? What purpose does returning to the inn after every mission serve as an improvement to the pacing of the game? If you take a bow for your caster (I mean, that makes sense right, you've read the reviews, you know you're gonna run out of mana and you're a ranged character) and you switch to it, and "Oh, I'm pointblank range with this monster. Hit chance 25% 4dmg" monster has 20 hp. Wtf. So statistically it should take me 20 fucking turns to kill this? I'm not talking about this being late game and you made a series of bad choices. This is the first mission that doesn't hand-hold you through a required tutorial.

Turns out, yes. It's going to take you twenty fucking turns to do anything, while trying to negotiate the ridiculous gimmick (plug those lice holes! Pull those levers!) no. I was done. The game is not balanced in any satisfying way. It's not "challenging". At best, it just challenges your patience to see how many times you can watch your ridiculously weak spell miss for the 20th time, before you realise there's absolutely no pay-off. I understand miss and dodge mechanics. But when your game is structured around you missing more than 50% of the time... there's no fun in that. No one is sitting at home playing this game thinking "Oh oh oh, I missed! What fun! That's 3 in the row!"

author: {'steamid': '76561197997797295', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1565, 'last_played': 1467956085}

author: {'steamid': '76561198109670840', 'num_games_owned': 885, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 1499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1439, 'last_played': 1467586377}
review:
Shiny but overall bland.
Most missions feel like puzzles and not a turn based strategy game.
Very unbalanced - you can breeze through a bunch of missions but then simply get beaten and beaten and beaten in others just because you didn't level up the right "talent" - oh and I hope you have a old save game in that case otherwise good luck.

Overall: unless it is a really good bargin AND you don't have anything else TBS to play...don't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128728891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7325, 'last_played': 1547786416}
review: Great game! I really enjoyed the complexity of the strategy

author: {'steamid': '76561198033699915', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 4658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3221, 'last_played': 1467070178}
review:
For an overview - this is a neat rpg game. I enjoyed it but i have to admit it has some flaws.

The Good:
- A good storyline
- Plenty of side quests
- Interesting npcs
- All nicely voiced
- Not bad graphics
- Towns look especially well
- A lot of options on character development

The Bad:
- the rng can get annoying, especially early in the game
- no way to reset your skills, which can be a problem
- loading screens every time you change locations
- several achievements are still broken

Overall i think if you enjoy rpg games, you might enjoy this one as well. Especially if you buy it on sale and you go into the game aware of its flaws.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074647021', 'num_games_owned': 486, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1507088476}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001148097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1469718729}
review:
Because of the review I was in doubt. I bought on sale the package, and I just tried Blackguards 1 for now. I played 5 hours in a row, it was hard but i never failed and I have been moving forward in the storyline. My first character was built to be a 2handed sword monster (blademaster style) but I have yet to find a two handed sword, which is a shame. I have tested a lot of turn-based game and this game suits what I like, it is similar to "Expedition Conquistador." 
I recommend this game for turn-based game fans!

author: {'steamid': '76561198110858152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1479457151}

author: {'steamid': '76561198121718704', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 2431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1471498477}
review: Blackguards is one of the best games i have played in this style. Its characters are superb, and in depth combat system that is also quite simple if you dont look into it that far, it has great scenery and graphics, and to top it all off it has a great lore and map. The whole amnesia thing doesn't annoy you as much as it does in many other games because you get to play through most of it learning as you go along just enough that it drip feeds your imagination of what will come next.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047955394', 'num_games_owned': 1281, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 3262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3262, 'last_played': 1466484001}
review: This game has kept me interested for hours and hours of play.  The different scenarios forcing you to use different stragies, defeating you over and over, then finding a different strategy to kick it in the dirt is so satisfying.  The game allows you to build characters in any which way, whether you wanna shoot at the baddies from afar with bows and crossbows, or be a complete juggernaut and get your hands dirty with beefy armor and an axe.  Some features might cause the game to be a little too easy after a while, such as massive gold accumulation making cheap healing outside of combat very convenient.  Even so, this game is a great one to check out and play around with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025834652', 'num_games_owned': 1121, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2175, 'last_played': 1466225513}
review:
Blackguards is not a very good game. It's a great example of turn-based strategy gone horribly wrong and just because something uses hexagons doesn't make it inherently worthwhile.
Blackguards is cheaply made. That much becomes apparent as soon as the voice acting starts torturing your speakers. The voice actor for the male main character is weirdly familiar from other budget titles. He's not trying very hard and neither is anyone else. The graphics are also fairly poor. I didn't expect much but it looks incredibly cheap and one has to suspect it was meant to be a tablet title originally. The art direction is also incredibly generic. This game makes Dragon Age look like Zeno Clash.

Most of the game is really just battles. Towns, numerous as they are, serve to buy gear and heal up and not much more. There are side quests but they almost always result in even more combat. You would think a game that contains this much fighting would have deep mechanics but no. There is not even flanking or backstabbing. Most of the weapon abilities make you hit harder or pierce armor in exchange for accuracy and that's basically it for physical attackers. Abilities that can hit multiple enemies are only available very late and they are not great. There is a knockdown but it virtually never works and most elite enemies are outright immune to it. The game is terrible with double standards like this.

Mages have a bit more to do but the spells are horribly imbalanced, ranging from absolutely useless to pretty much necessary to beat the game. You can't even make a proper offensive mage because spells do poor damage and are not very mana-efficient. There's virtually no way to restore mana outside of the very poor regeneration between turns. Potions do exist but they are insanely expensive. They're something you use in a boss fight and not something you can waste in a regular encounter. To make things worse, spells are also line of sight dependent. That means if you surround an enemy with your melee fighters, you can't hit them and if one of your characters gets surrounded you can't heal them. Want to throw a fireball into a cluster of enemies? You can't because you have no line of sight to the center so you can never really hit the whole group. It's as annoying as it sounds. Level 4 spells on the other are insane. They can hit every single enemy or ally on the entire map, no matter how far away they are. Sadly, later on enemies use the same spells against you and it's awful because you can't do anything about it.

The game's biggest downfall are the gimmick maps. This is hard to explain. Basically, half the encounters are built some sort of gimmick except... the game doesn't explain these gimmicks to you or warns you that there even might be a gimmick instead of a regular skirmish. The most blatant example is when you plunder a crypt and you get attacked by a gang of skeletons (you never hear about skeleton gang violence in the media, typical) and every time you destroy one, it gets resurrected by some crystal. Fair enough, you have the skeletons distracted by some of your fighters and have another one sneak around and attack the crystal. You attack it with your spear and...it does no damage. The crystal is immune to thrust damage. There is no feedback to it, you can't figure it out on your own through the environment. Well, that would have been nice to know, I thought to myself. Most of the time the best way to beat is a map is to figure out the gimmick and immediately reload the fight in order to actually use it to its full effect. Everything else is an uphill battle.

So yeah, it's not a very good game. It's full of baffling design decisions and even the things outside of combat are not good. I could write for hours about the awful, incoherent story but it's not worth the effort.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085574601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4007, 'last_played': 1504057294}
review:
The game was quite interesting, a little fun. Though I found it quite short. For this reason, I suggest do not purchase it unless at a very good discount. These are the sort of games that you play once, and the story is done. Not much replay value, aside from nostalgia down the road. Honestly, who cares about acheivements anyway?

I went ahead and did the side missions, which still did not leave that much to do when all was said and done.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979827095', 'num_games_owned': 2042, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 3387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2153, 'last_played': 1616547807}
review: This is a good game.  It's refreshing that it doesn't coddle the players advancement and that there are consequences to choices and actions.  Definitely not for 'casual' players, and not a sandbox style open world, it still is a fantastic RPG that I find challenging and rewarding.  I plan to also play Blackguards 2 eventually, so I would  strongly recommend it to  RPG fans.  The graphics in the battles are pretty cool, the story is strong, and the acting/voice is nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052274912', 'num_games_owned': 697, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1488650404}
review:
Difficult to rate this game. I really really really wanted to like it. It seems like it has so much potential. But so far I have been unable to complete a play through without boredom or extreme crashes. I still plan to play the second gameâ€¦ I just gave up trying to finish this one before I do.
 
Pros 
-	Thorough character creation
-	Fun/beautiful environment and settings
-	Interesting characters

Cons
-	Complex (and at times confusing) character skill selections
-	Continuous failing high percentages ( 98% ) attacks often makes strategies pointless
-	Many technical issues (crashes) makes it difficult to complete game

author: {'steamid': '76561198036494887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1812, 'last_played': 1705899780}
review:
Edit: So, the problem below was fixed, I didnt change anything, just my windows version, its 10 now, and i could finnaly get past the fight that was freezing in chapter 4, so i[m changing it to positive and will talk a little bit about the game.
First I want to say that the review was negative because i was really sad I couldnt finish the game, that is to say I was loving it, now I intend to finish. 
The game is great, really good Character Creation, thats the main feature for me, really complex at first, so read a guide, but it only means they didnt dumb it down to appeal to the general public, hence the mixed reviews. but once you understand it and get used to it it is clear what a work of art it is, the people who created it are master RPG designer and i would love to see a table top RPG system created by them.
I even feel bad for leaving a bad review for so long, sorry about that devs. And keep up the good work. I even bought their complete collection even though i already had this game, so it was not optimal, but some great games there too. i didnt have time to try the second BG yet but i hope its as good as this one.

but it freezes my entire system after one specific fight in chapter 4, itÂ´s really disappointing not beeing able to finish the game because of that, i have all the recomended system requirements, but loading takes too long and this one cutscene appears to be requiring more memory than recomended. i dont know...

review:
The game is about combat but the combat sucks so dont bother!
The worst are the mages, they dont regenerate mana after battles and they make too many mistakes which means that too often they cast nothing. which ruins your tactics completely. Its slow, sluggish and unsatisfying. The loot that you get is 90% useless and there arent many sets of armors. I felt cheated way more often than rewarded in this game mostly because of the mages. I dont like to be frustrated so i didnt like this game..

author: {'steamid': '76561198113977353', 'num_games_owned': 447, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2861, 'last_played': 1464739523}
review:
I got this game in a bundle and was just curious to try it, so I first cheked the store page to see if there were good reviews. There weren\'t, and people was talking about it as too hard.
I agree, the character sheet is very complex and you end up wasting a lot of experience points, but it\'s not too bad.
I really enjoyed the story and I find that the voice acting is superb, there\'s a point in the game where you have more than 10 side quests and you really want to go on, but then there\'s a slow down and it gets quite heavy in the end. I don\'t think it\'s too hard, but I don\'t recommend playing this game at max difficulty, it\'s balanced enough at normal.
Overall it was a fun game, far from perfection but still enjoyable, I definitely won\'t play it a second time, but I will play Blackguards 2, which is said to be even better polished. Hope you found my review useful!

author: {'steamid': '76561197996426001', 'num_games_owned': 621, 'num_reviews': 327, 'playtime_forever': 2526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2526, 'last_played': 1464528385}
review:
When I started to play the game I was surprised that it have so many negative reviews, it looked like a very good game at the beginning, but then its flaws bacame evident.

pros: 
-good storyline
-interesting side quests
-huge freedom on character development
-decent graphic
-interesting combat system
-interesting magic/abilities

cons:
-freedom on character development can turn against you later in the game. there's no clue on which way you should get skills and abilities and you can come across certains fights where you absolutely need a certain skill to win or it will take a lot of luck. this is quite frustrating. expecially if you don't have a savegame old enought to learn the ability you need.
-inventory items are uninteresting: you only get good stuff from a few side quest in the entire game, merchants around the world only sell cheap/bad stuff. also I think the weight of the stuff (especially supplies) is unbalanced.
-major and minor bugs could prevent you from completing some side-quests
-unnecessary loading times


in the end I can recomend this game only if you are a turn based rpg enthusiast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020313592', 'num_games_owned': 984, 'num_reviews': 574, 'playtime_forever': 1207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1207, 'last_played': 1464257930}
review:
What is good about this game:

- Character development is complex
- Good setting
- Varied enemies
- Variety of situations you find yourself into
- Nice graphics

So why downvote?

Because my friends, of two reasons.

The GAME BALANCE. It is so broken i cannot even believe it. Some fights are so unbalanced i had to actually lower the difficultry to Normal to beat them, which i never ever did for any game in my life. This because you are put in situations where you just need luck to make it out alive.

And Luck is the real master of this game, not skill nor strategy. Just pure luck. RNG (Random Numerical Generation) (What determines % of success or failure of things) is so determining in the combat that it just rules over everything. In other turn based games there is RNG of course, but also other factors like strategy, formations, class builds, level are critical to win a fight, but not here in blackguards, not at the same level.

A single random critical, or spell failure (spells can FAIL casting, yes you got it right), or a random miss with 99% chance, or again some trap which activates randomly decides to turn just towards your party and wipe it out with a blast of fire.

All these things can make a fight fail. Random chance upon chance upon chance upon chance. Not even in Vegas there is so much gambling.

This more than a game of skill is a game of luck. I have many many years of experience in all kinds of RPGs but i just cannot take it anymore. I find myself by now to repeat fight over and over and over again just to get a fight where the RNG favors me, where traps do not activate on my team, or on the target i have to protect, etc, and make me fail after a well planned strategy.

Do yourself a favor, go and buy Divinity Original Sin, that's a turn based game made right, not this disguised slot machine of a game we have here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046882824', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 832, 'last_played': 1524451783}
review:
Blackguards ist ein rundenbasiertes Strategiespiel der Rpg-Familie. Es glÃ¤nzt durch eine umfangreiche Storyline welche mit wohl durchdacht geschrieben und umgesetzt wurde. Anfangs noch sehr leicht bietet es einen grandiosen Einstieg und baut eine Verbindung zwischen dem Charakter des Spielers, dem Zauberer und dem Zwerg sowie allen weiteren Begleitern und WeggefÃ¤hrten auf. Blackguards zeigt sich im spÃ¤teren Verlauf jedoch schon gehoben anspruchsvoll wodurch man endlich wieder lÃ¤nger an einem Level sitzt, grÃ¼belt und fiebert und natÃ¼rlich auch gerne mal schipft wie ein Rohrspatz :)
Ein Hammer Spiel, oftmal im Angebot und dann auf jeden Fall ein Spiel das in keiner Steambibliothek fehlen darf.
10/10 Punkten (+1 Punkt extra fÃ¼r den wahnsinnigen Spass die Entwickler zu verwÃ¼nschen, ausnahmsweise nicht aufgrund von Bugs, da glÃ¤nzt das Spiel ebenfalls und es gibt nahezu keine)

author: {'steamid': '76561198155045661', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 3727, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3726, 'last_played': 1466239330}
review:
Not a particular amazing game, but enjoyable enough and some cleverly designed scenes here and there prevent you from tackling each and every battle with exactly the same old strategy.  Comparing the number of pros and cons, it's a really impressive game; but one of the cons just happens to be super important to me, bringing the game down to just decent instead.

CONS
The game can basically be broken down into four parts: cutscenes; inventory/ability screens; towns/shops; and battle scenarios.  Each of these is actually very well done.  But it leaves the game feeling a bit hollow simply because you don't get much of a feeling of exploring.  You move around the map by clicking on dots.  You move around submaps by clicking on dots.  Even the towns/shops just feel like clicking on dots.  They shouldn't, because they're much more visual, but the game just builds that feeling of dot-clicking into it, and you can't shake it.  

The inventories get messy.  Weapons and armour can be seen separately, but everything else is all piled up in one section with no sorting options.  So when you're looking for healing or mana potions, be prepared to go through page after page of poisons, traps, buffing potions, throwing weapons, and EVEN all the 'quest items' - new and old, jumbled up with them.

PROS
The cutscenes are well done, the plot's interesting enough, and you really feel like you get to know the characters.

There's a good number of abilities, categorised in some interesting ways.  Most importantly, the spells have enough variety that you can really explore a range of different strategies.  Even within typical categories like direct damage or buffing, there's still variety.  (Potential SPOILER examples: [spoiler] Direct damage has single target, area of effect, enemy hunting single target, cloud spawning enemy hunting single target, and whole map blasts; and some of those stun, or knock down, or curse/debuff.  And that's just within direct damage.  My favourite quickly turned out to be a shadow duplicate spell - which for me meant creating a second archer-mage for 3-5 turns, whose arrows are shadow too, so it was like getting double the mileage out of each arrow). [/spoiler]  The variety might take a little while to sink in, because at first it looks like 24 spells with 4 levels of power each.  But within the 4 levels for each, most have at least one significant change, so it's actually more like 48 spells.

The options for non-spellcasters are more limited, but still allow for some good variety - especially since you can have up to three weapon sets; and/or make use of traps and throwing weapons.  It's hard to do early on, but each route you take eats up experience points, but this ultimately allows you to do things like: (a) Carry a giant two-handed bashing weapon for massive damage and quick battles, but be ready to switch into sword and shield if you need more defense and accuracy.  (b) Run around with a two-handed pike-style spear, but pitch javelins and poison bombs at your enemies before they get into melee range.  (c) Mix up archery and fencing.  (d) Go all archery, but set traps - especially stunning or slowing traps - around you when melee fighters look like they're going to get too close.  (e) etc, etc.

The weapons and armour are pretty bog-standard for an RPG overall, but are just varied enough.  The expense might seem frustrating at first, but I enjoyed the way it made me mix and match parts more often, and set different characters up with different equipment sets.  And when there are all kinds of traps and poisons and buff potions, etc, as well, it feels like you've always got something new to pick up.

The combat!  At first it looks like each map is going to be a matter of big vs small, wide vs narrow, and empty or covered with traps or blocking environment.  That'd lead to a bit of variety, but eventually you'd work out a couple of strategies that you'd just use over and over again.  But soon enough, you start seeing unique twists (some are repeated a couple of times; some are just used once).  There are plenty of them, and they are what really make the game worth it in the end.  (Potential SPOILER examples: [spoiler] A super long get to the end before the poisonous mist catches up to you map.  Skeletons keep coming back to life unless you smash the crystal maps.  Sneak through the dark and you won't have to fight at all maps. Maps with cages to open to let out support.  Maps with cages to close to trap beasts.  Maps with buildings you can knock down to crush some enemies.  Maps with spider webs hidden like traps and as bridges you can knock out from under the spiders.  And more and more.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198025033243', 'num_games_owned': 91, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1452, 'last_played': 1694219560}
review: As a newbie to tactical RPG games, I am enjoying it thus far. It is a bit tough if you are trying to learn the genre and the game at the same time. I like the turn-based format vs real-time because for obvious reasons of trying to figure out my plan. I don't like that you can't save your progress within a battle, but perhaps that's just how it is, like dingleberries are brown. Pick it up on a discount like I did and there will be little reason to regret it if it's not your type of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075078972', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1463066966}
review: This turn based RPG starts off good but soon becomes incredibly tedious, difficult and as a result, extremely boring. The combat is iffy in some parts as your chance attacks will miss a lot of the time even if its really high. I had to replay a lot of levels just to get through to the next one. Side missions aren't all that impressive and there was no drive for me to explore the whole map. There were a lot of towns that I just passed through without bothering to explore. In the end the extreme difficulty forced me There are multiple endings based on the conversation choices you make but the one I received was underwhelming and I felt hollow. Wouldn't recommend this game to players new to the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211099261', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 459, 'last_played': 1463069735}
review:
I have wanted to love this game. I really, really have. The character development system is complex and has a depth rarely found in RPGs. The story and choices are a combination of dark and darker, and yet there is no shortage of humor in the game. Having said all of that, I do NOT recommend this game for the casual gamer who enjoys RPGs. This is for the hardcore gaming fans who want to spend hours agonizing over points spent in skill and character development, only to find that you have to start over because you lack core abilities in your characters to survive. Further, the combat system is ridiculous. You get a wizard at the beginning of the game as a companion who has an ~80% accuracy range - however, in my experience, his spellcasting is weak at best, and backfires most of the time, and at often critical moments. Unfortunately, healing is also problematic because it uses an entire action (turn), and so by the next round, you may be down more health points than you were before you healed. Following me so far? That's good, because on top of that, you can count on being outnumbered and outmaneuvered in nearly every battle. 

I could go on to wax poetic about the ineptitude of the combat system and the way the developers correlated character development with combat in a way that is clear, but I think you can get the gist of it from above. I have to quit playing this game because after too much time trying the same battle over and over again to rescue some baroness who loves the less than useless wizard companion I have, I am going to retire this game entirely and quite playing it. It simply lacks any enjoyment for me at this point. I think the game designers have a lot of work to do to create a product that I would ever consider purchasing again. I feel cheated of my money and my time. 

Oh, and you don't have the option of really grinding your characters up to par, either. There are a set number of quests and side quests, and you spend those character development points at your own risk. 

Again, there may be a market for this to hardcore gamers and some others, but it is definitely not for the faint of heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976291722', 'num_games_owned': 416, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 3436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3436, 'last_played': 1463263143}
review:
I honestly took a long time to play this game (I knew I eventually would as I love turn based tactical RPG), because of all the mixed reviews.  Regardless, I can't believe how much fun the combat in this game is.  I'll break down some key game concepts that might persuade you to buy or push you away.

Good:
-Amazing character development using a deep system of random dice rolls and old-school board game elements
-Hard battles (some are pushovers) that make you think or have to re-do because of a single screw up
-Deep turn based hexagonal board-like combat involving traps and the environment
-A Baldur's Gate style of map minus the exploration
-The game really focuses on the battles without the fuss of wandering and exploring (ie. not an exploration game)

Bad:
-The story is not bad, but one shouldn't be getting this game for that reason
-The itemization and game mechanics are a bit complicated to understand and required a lot of Google searching
-Linear story and no exploration

If you are looking for a game that focuses purely on the tactical turn based combat, then this is truly it.  There is no wandering and exploring with your party and discovering secrets.  The world map is like Baldur's Gate, however, when you visit cities and places, you are either transported into a combat situation with some cutscenes or visit a town where NPC's are static screens filled with innkeepers, healers, merchants, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995311659', 'num_games_owned': 671, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1763, 'last_played': 1463174436}
review:
A frustrating design nightmare.  Suffers from classic Euro-dev 'difficulty' design flaws.  Everytime you lull yourself into a state of enjoying this game, the devs fuck up.  You can almost smell the body odour of the geek who thought taking away all your loot for an entire climactic segment of the game was a good idea.

Don't bother getting attached to characters or strategically saving points to spend on a worthwhile skill.  You can lose them without any notice, having wasted opportunities to use those points to get you through certain battles.  Cardinal error.

Some fights are designed to be artificially punishing.  I haven't used the word 'cheap' since I played Nintendo in the 90s.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133064279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1269, 'last_played': 1461304032}
review:
This is a pretty fun game.  There are a lot of looading pages, and even though the game auto saves before and after a battle, it is best to make your own save file. If you loose a battle, and the game reloads, it will autosave again, and unless you have your own save file, you'll be stuck in an endless loop until you succeed, and sometimes those battles weren't ment to be entered yet. 

The voiceacting is actually pretty welldone. I was suprised. The art is decent, the story thus far is very predictable, but still enjoyable. There's lots of side quests you can complete. It seems to be a good idea to do them, just to get the experience and the points to spend on spells, and abilities. Makes the game a little easier, and allows for more battle options. 

I'm not a fan of the buying system. There's seems to be a limited number of arrows. After buying all of them in a shop, it seems they don't restock. I've come back to shops after many battles to see if they resupply, but it doesn't seem they do. The potion prices are rediculous. Though you shouldn't need them very often. 

There is a little bit of a freedom  aspect. At a certain point you can choose where you want to go, and dialog options give you different results. You can choose which side to be on in some battles. 

I give the game a 6/10. It's nothing special, but I do enjoy playing the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198257719628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1464629694}
review:
I wish there was a middle choice like, "If it's your cup of tea," or; "If it's on sale."  Anyways, I can't openly recommend this game though I will continue playing it and do enjoy aspects of it. It's a start over too many times kind of game. Sometimes the CTH (chance to hit) can frustrate you more than anything else. Because it's played tactical turn style this makes some battles painfully long, and some easy battles unneccsarily hard. I truly had a fight where luck jsut spit on my and I failed every spell, before writing this review actually, and I was killed by two wolves...eh. 
It does get better, obviously as I said I will keep playing it. Nice feel, voice acting is ok, story is fine so far though nothing pushing the limits I feel it could move forward readily. I'm interested to see how strong I can make my characters and well I can customize them. Still, I can't recommend it.
Why?
It falls into a category of games where there are many options for you that are easier to pickup and just as customizable. If you've already played through a plethora of these titles you will then enjoy this as you're out of new stuff to do. But get a coffee, or whatever relaxes you, because it will frustrate you to ****.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996183984', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1449900114}
review:
If you aren't a little twatwaffle that hates anything resembling a challenge - but LOVE tactics-bassed combat, RP driven narrative, and a beautifully written story-line (which is NOT your typical weeaboo animoo trash power of friendship BS) - then this game is for YOU!

BUT, if you hate challenges, just go away now; This game is not made for the masters of easy mode - and as you will notice, all of the bad reviews and general gripes all go back to the game being too challenging and not letting you become an OP god.

"NAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAIL!
Tell these noobs to go hoooooome..."

author: {'steamid': '76561197991155039', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 781, 'last_played': 1461467627}
review:
Avoid this game.  I don't understand why game developers think that RNG and setting the odds against you makes a game fun.  If you enjoy loading over and over again until you get a perfect roll and get the scenario down perfect is fun than this is the game for you!

The graphics are mediocre, they characters look mediocre and no way to customize, the classes are mediocre and you don't gain enough skill points to keep up with the difficulty curve.

The game is linear, offering no real exploration.  Just move from one scenario to another.  One scenario will be easy the next not to bad and than they throw one at you that you have to reload over and over again until you get lucky.  No skill involved, just luck on RNG.  This game gets the terrible reviews it deserves.

I am in the second chapter stuck on fighting the "newcomer" gladiators.  They split your group into 2 groups.  So if you didn't choose a warrior in the beginning you will be stuck fighting 2 ranged against a tank and range setup, which is painful.  There is making the game difficult and then there is making it silly just to extend the life of the game.  I will try to finish the game and see but my will to continue is slowly dwindling, I am beginning to think that this company doesn't know how to make games.

OK Made it past that point, now I am to a part in the gladiator games where they throw 3 waves of enemies at you without any rest.  This really is some of the worst game design I have had the misfortune in playing.  You get no breaks, no way to bind your wounds... nothing.  I made it to the 8th wave and there is an instant win button the enemies can do that you have no way of stopping.  It is completely random.  I am very close to giving up on this game, it isn't difficult, it is, to put it country simple, stupid.  So far this game deserves all the bad reviews it has gotten.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033793041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 2299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 883, 'last_played': 1641653969}

author: {'steamid': '76561198004262008', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1409683959}

author: {'steamid': '76561198033268518', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 5111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4442, 'last_played': 1465000211}
review: The game itself is great, really nice graphic and a story that keeps the game entertaining.. but then theres the bugs, in combat i had to reload my savegame 3 times so far, because of a combat bug that just makes ur charater stop attacking on the second hit, u cant get past that point, unless u havd unlimited patience, and wait for that one out of 20 times where it doesent bug and u can actually get past that place.. it happened in several other combats aswell, and ive tried to get support for it, check the forums, write em.. hell even google.. but nothing.. no fix.. no support.. nothing.. and for 40 euro for the game and 5 euro for the DLC.. as much as i love the game i dont reccomend it.. because the bugs is just to frustrating.. and without any support for the game, seems the devs just left it.. then id say if it was a 5 euro game then the bugs, i could live with em, and just think pff it was only 5 euro.. but in this case its NOT just 5 euro wasted.. its 45 euro wasted..

author: {'steamid': '76561198036448651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2642, 'last_played': 1459705145}
review:
Now that I finished this game, is time to review it.

When I heard about a tactic turn-based strategy game, about some blackguards (that promised some bad guys doing bad things!) with RPG elements, and I saw the game was in my steam library, I said: "Yes!"
But... that was a big mistake.

The story of the game has a good start: A mystery. A murder. Are you guilty? Are you innocent? If you are innocent, who is the true murderer? Why can't you remember nothing?
And with that, you get out of prison to live some adventures.
The characters are charismatic and with personalities of their own. The world is full of life, but most of the secondary missions are only valuable for the Adventure Points (the XP of the game), and they are irrelevant to the story.

The game has a few plot twists and they are not bad at all, but before reaching them you will probably exhausted. The problem is that the ending is... well... is HORRIBLE. It is the ending that you can expect, but is displayed in a really awful and strange way that makes you think: "I really finished this game to see this?"

The gameplay is good in the beginning, but when you are more or less mid-game you will probably be sick of being poisoned. And that's only the start: The machine abuses the use of poisons. You will probably hear every turn "Poison!" or "I am poisoned!" or "I hate poison". Also, some special combats in Act 5 are never explained why are this special or why the special rules.

As many other tactic turn-based games, probabilities are really important. That means you can have a lucky day and impact an almost impossible shoot, or a really unlucky and fail all your 98% chance spells. But, as always, it seems "50%" means "1/2" to me and "1/10" to machine, as I never impacted an attack under 20% and usually failed things of 70-80%, 95% or even 98%. In a game where every movement, every action counts, this can make you sick really fast. Also, the enemies are as if they were taken out of Matrix, because they can dodge easily and usually all your attacks.

So, well, unless you really want to be poisoned EVERY combat, lose your patience failing your 98% chance spells and being parried attacks that shouldn't be parried, and playing a lot of hours to receive a half-cooked last Act with a fast ending as closure, you probably shouldn't play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211579817', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 499, 'last_played': 1462390839}
review:
No voto negativo el juego por su sistema o contenido. Al final lo explico...
Este juego es para ir muy poco a poco. No entrare en detalles sobre Ã©l mÃ¡s alla de lo que ya pueden explicar en los demÃ¡s posts.
La historia tiene su gancho. Los personajes su personalidad. Un sistema muy amplio de colocaciÃ³n de talentos, hechizos y especializaciÃ³n en armas...

Pero le encuentro un grabe problema, y es simplemente por esto que le doy Negativo:
DEBES GRABAR CONTINUAMENTE LAS PARTIDAS o por lo contrario te vas a dar con un canto en los dientes.

Llevar horas de juego intentando pasarte la dichosa batalla, y por fin, cuando te has relajado y piensas "vale, voy a la ciudad a curarme y grabar"... zas!! te salta en la pantalla una nueva batalla que te endosan porque la historia lo dice asÃ­... y Oh SORPRESA! Empiezas el combate con la vida tal y como acabÃ³ la Ãºltima, o sea, a mÃ­nimos Â¬Â¬
Eso supone que es una batalla que no vas a poder ganar nunca, pq al primer golpe mueres. Y no da ninguna opciÃ³n a situarte antes de esa batalla. Simplemente te da la opciÃ³n de "intentar de nuevo?" Y si te piensas que los autosave te van a salvar el culo, lo tienes claro. A empezar el juego desde 0

Por eso, o se estÃ¡ grabando continuamente, o juega en una habitaciÃ³n sin ventanas. Por lo que pueda ser.

Encuentro bastante poco acertado que un juego de estrategia, donde el cambio de un arma corta a largo alcance puede ser vital, no deje aceptar ese mero cambio antes del combate

author: {'steamid': '76561198006614818', 'num_games_owned': 523, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2472, 'last_played': 1425681067}
review: Blackguards ist ein sehr komplexes Rollenspiel in der Welt des "Schwarzen Auges", was kennern eigentlich schon alles sagen sollte. Die Story ist aufwendig und komplex und zog mich tief in ihren Bann. Die Grafik ist leider nicht besonders gut, was mich jedoch nicht besonders gestÃ¶rt hat, da es mir bei Rollenspielen mehr auf die Geschichte und die Charaktere ankommt. Diese mÃ¼ssen fÃ¼r mich glaubhaft und fesselnd sein und genau das schafft Blackguards meiner Meinung nach mehr als gut. Allerdings gibt es auch einige recht unfaire KÃ¤mpfe die einem tierisch auf die Nerven gehen kÃ¶nnen. Trotzdem mÃ¶chte ich dieses Spiel jedem empfehlen der spielerische Herausforderungen und gute Storys mag. Beides wird man in diesem Spiel finden. Aber AnfÃ¤nger sollten vielleicht doch noch ihre Finger hiervon lassen, weil es an manchen Stellen wirklich verdammt schwer ist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054216330', 'num_games_owned': 435, 'num_reviews': 240, 'playtime_forever': 3348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3299, 'last_played': 1458943379}
review:
Wie Ã¼blich, wer den Wall of Text nicht mag, scrollt ganz runter ^^

An und fÃ¼r sich kein schlechtes Spiel, allerdings haben hier dieses Mal die Negativpunkte so stark Ã¼berwogen, dass auch das gute KS sowie Skillsystem nix mehr retten konnten.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Das Gameplay der Oberwelt ist simpel gehalten. Zu simpel. Man hat eine Weltkarte, auf der gibt es Orte, die man anklickt, und man gelangt dann ziemlich zÃ¼gig an den gewÃ¤hlten Ort. In der Stadtansicht hat man dann einen Bildschirm, auf dem alle relevanten NPCs zu sehen sind, also HÃ¤ndler, heiler, Taverne etc. Abseits der KÃ¤mpfe spielt sich das Spiel wie ein PointÂ´n Klick Adventure. FÃ¼r ein Spiel der Marke "Das Schwarze Auge" meiner Meinung nach keine gute Eigenschaft, auch wenn Laufwege zu den Orten wegfallen. Zu einem zumpftigen RPG gehÃ¶rt es dazu, dass man was zum erkunden hat. Die Dungeons kann man lediglich mit gutem Willen als solche bezeichnen, denn wie auf der Oberwelt klickt man sich hier von Ort zu ort bzw von Kampf zu Kampf. Leider unspektakulÃ¤r.

Eine der StÃ¤rken des Spiels ist das Skillsystem, das erfreulichwerweise ein beinahe klassenloses skillen ermÃ¶glicht.
"Beinahe", weil immernoch zwischen magiebegabten und eben solchen ohne Magiebegabung unterschieden wird, Wie in Spielen des schwarzen Auges Ã¼blich, verteilt man Abenteuerpunkte, die man bekommt, wenn man Quests lÃ¶st oder KÃ¤mpfe gewinnt auf die unterschiedlichen Statuspunkte und Talente, die auf diesen Statuspunkten aufbauen. Planvolles Skillen ist hier schon zu Beginn angesagt, da es im Spiel nur begrenzt viele KÃ¤mpfe und damit Abenteuerpunkte gibt.
Ein Feature, das gut umgesetzt wurde, wie ich denke.

Ein weiterer Punkt sind die KÃ¤mpfe, die auch groÃŸteils gut gelungen sind. Kampffelder haben oft MÃ¶glichkeiten, Gegner auf unkonventionelle weise auszuschalten wie zum Beispiel durch enflammen brennbaren Sumpfgases. Mir persÃ¶nlich haben die KÃ¤mpfe viel SpaÃŸ gemacht, auÃŸer gegen Ende im letzten Dungeon, der eigentlich aus zwei Dungeons besteht in denen es wenn ich mich recht erinnere 15 PflichtkÃ¤mpfe gab, die zwar nicht alle schlecht aber eben auch nicht alle gut waren. An der Stelle habe ich lange gesessen, weil einfach die Motivation fehlte, weiter zu machen in dem Wissen, dass noch einige folgen.

[b]Interface[/b]
Der Questlog ist leider mitunter wenig hilfreichg gewesen, da zum Teil zwar erwÃ¤hnt wurde, zu wem man muss, aber nicht wo er ist, was bei einer groÃŸen Welt mit einem guten dutzend betretbaren Orten echt frusten kann, vorallem wenn man eine Quest bekommt, die man erst lÃ¶sen kann, wenn man eine andere gelÃ¶st hat, die man eben noch nicht gelÃ¶st hat, was wie ich denke ein Bug ist, aber dennoch Ã¤rgerlich.

Im AusrÃ¼stungsinterface der Charaktere wird nur die Behinderung durch zu schweres GepÃ¤ck angezeigt, aber nicht die durch die AusrÃ¼stung.

Das Schriftbild Ã¤ndert sich, wenn man einen anderen Schwierigkeitsgrad auswÃ¤hlt. Wirkt komisch und dadurch kÃ¶nnen sich WÃ¶rter Ã¼berlagern, was wirklich nicht schÃ¶n aussieht.

[b]Musik[/b]
Der OST ist soweit stimmig umgesetzt

[b]Zusammenfassung[/b]
Positiv
[list]
    [*]GroÃŸteils interessante und launige KÃ¤mpfe
    [*]Das Skillsystem wie DSA Fans es kennen und lieben
    [*]Atmospherischer OST
    [*]drei unterschiedliche Schwierigkeitsgrade, die sich im Spiel jederzeit Ã¤ndern lassen
[/list]
Negativ
[list]
    [*]wenig hilfreicher Questlog
    [*]am Ende spielt es sich extrem zÃ¤h
    [*]praktisch keine wirklichen ErkundungsmÃ¶glichkeiten
    [*]"PÃ¼nktchendungeons" in denen man sich von Kampf zu Kampf klickt
[/list]

[b]Fazit[/b]
Wie man in der Zusammenfassung sehen kann, gab es nicht so viele negative Punkte, aber diese haben gereicht.
Blackguards ist wirklich kein schlechtes Spiel, aber es krankt an einigen Stellen, wo es wirklich nicht hÃ¤tte sein mÃ¼ssen. Eine frei begehbare Oberwelt und ein weniger langwieriger Enddungeon (Ã¼berhaupt ordentliche Dungeons) hÃ¤tten das Spiel hier vor einer negativen Bewertung bewahren kÃ¶nnen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057689545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 2254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2254, 'last_played': 1458829332}
review:
Also ich habe das Spiel jetzt endlich durch nach qÃ¼Ã¤lenden Stunden mit unsinnigen % Angaben und nachdem ich das Spiel auf einfach stellen musste. 
Also das Spiel ist Story technisch sehr seicht und das Kampfsystem ist Ã¼berhaupt nicht Systematisch.
Die Prozente scheinen nur schÃ¶nes Beiwerk zu sein, anders kann ich mir nicht vorstellen, warum man mit teilweise 95% Trefferwarscheinlichkeit 6 mal hintereinander daneben haut und Feinde einen mit 20 % locker treffen.
Die Story ist ganz ok aber halt nix originelles. Ein BÃ¶sewicht den es zu finden gilt usw.
Also ich wÃ¼rde jedem abraten, der sich hier ein gutes Rundenbasierendes Spiel versprechen. Ich habe mich wÃ¤hrend dem groÃŸteil der Spielzeit nur gefrustet und muss sagen, obwohl ich dieses Genre eigendlich mag, dass ich dieses Spiel niemandem empfehlen wÃ¼rde.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030208468', 'num_games_owned': 691, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1457638372}
review:
It's just... bad.  The visuals are average, with bits of them bordering on terrible.  The story and exploration are linear, and the story itself is just plain boring.  The voice-work is just good enough to point out how comically bad it is.  Towns are bland and lifeless.  Combat is stagnant, and shows no complexity.  Even if you buy Blackguards on sale, you likely still won't find the time to sit down with it.  There just isn't any single thing exciting enough to make up for the blandness of the rest of the game.  Nothing to draw you back in, after the first time you've played.

It's well done from a mechanical standpoint - The skill trees are well thought out and balanced.  There's just nothing flashy in them to draw attention, and the execution becomes poor when you see your character dully performing their moves and abilities with passable graphics and poor weapons/equipment.  Blackguards is a pen-and-paper RPG adaptation that never really got past the pen-and-paper bit.  More of a visualisation of some DM's real-world tabletop setup that would seem much cooler set up with cardboard on your buddy's gaming table.

If you're hellbent on playing Blackguards, I hear Blackguards 2 is actually worth the time.  It's on my list of 'soon to play' games, so I'll put up a review ASAP.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993011508', 'num_games_owned': 1324, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 3313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3241, 'last_played': 1458351917}
review:
I'm really surprised at some of the negative reviews that this game has received. 

I personally found the story to be interesting and engaging, it's dark in places and you need to get your hands dirty, but that's how Dark Eye fantasy generally is. One moment in particular seems to have turned some players off, I thought it was a brave decision by the developers, and I thought it worked well, a story should generate emotion, and this one did. It's not all grim and dark however, and the humour is very finely tuned in places. 

Turn based tactical games are a genre that I'm very much into, I play a lot of Chaos Reborn on a daily basis for the PvP side of it. Consequentially I often find that with story driven turn based tactical games that the PvE battles are a let-down, I don't think an AI can generally replicate the engagement that comes from playing against a human opponent. But I tell you what, Blackguards comes as close to it as I've ever found. There's a real wealth of variation in the battles that occur from; small skirmishes, arena fights, fighting withdraws, chase downs, there's all sorts. The developers of Blackguards have really gone out of their way to keep the fighting fresh. As a result this is one story driven turn based tactical game that I can see myself replaying. Just taken on their own the fights are a lot of fun.

I think the one caveat that I'd give is that this is a game where it's worth checking out what happens to certain characters in advance. Iâ€™m not going to give anyway any spoilers here, but making your party build based on that knowledge does make a difference to the overall effectiveness of your party by the end of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025298436', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1466, 'last_played': 1458408380}
review:
Das Spiel wurde durch den Idioten verdorben, der die Gegner AI entwickelt hat. Diese ist unterentwickelt - dadurch muÃŸten die Computergegner so stark gemecht werden, diese einfach und schnell den Kampf gewinnen.

ABER:
Wenn die Gegner jeden Kampf gewinnen, gibt es doch gar keinen Anreiz das Spiel  zu spielen?

Das stimmt, aber hier kommt nun der Zufall ins Spiel. Obwohl die Computergegner betrÃ¼gen kÃ¶nnen man gegen sie gewinnen - alles was macht braucht in ein Kampf bei dem der Zufall bessere "WÃ¼rfel" auf der eigenen Seite und (!) schlechte "WÃ¼rfel" auf der Computerseite hat.

Wenn beide Seiten gute "WÃ¼rfel" haben, dann verliert man - einfach weil die  Computer NPC so extrem stÃ¤rker gemacht wurden als die Spieler figuren.  Von den 4 Konstellationen gewint also nur eine - das heiÃŸt das man KÃ¤mpfe 10-30x durchspielen muss bis die richtige Konstellation da ist - dies gilt vor allem in den frÃ¼hen Leveln wo man einfach zu schlecht ist, um den Kampf mit geschickten Aktionen zu gewinnen.

Das dies "suboptimal" ist, hat man wohl bei D. erkannt und "interaktive" Dinge in die Kampf-Map eingefÃ¼ht, die die NPC etwas abbremsen kÃ¶nnen - FALLS diese zufÃ¤llig in der NÃ¤he stehen - klappt also relativ selten. SelberverstÃ¤ndlich werden diese Elemente nicht erklÃ¤rt und man braucht einen Kampfversuch (von den 10-30 die sowieso nÃ¶tig sind) um rauszufinden, was das "Ding" nun macht.

Ich hÃ¤tte nie gedacht, eine negative Rezension fÃ¼r ein DSA Spiel abzugeben aber es ist einfach zu schlecht umgesetzt - zu Spielbeginn ist es einfach zu langweilig dauernd den Kampf neustarten zu mÃ¼ssen (einfach weil schon in der 1 Kampfrunde die hÃ¤lfte deiner NPCs nicht getroffen haben, wÃ¤hrend der Gegner (die immer in Ãœberzahl sind) alle Treffer gelandet haben und dabei sogar einige Crits dabei waren.

Ich hoffe D. investiert mehr Zeit in die Entwicklung der Computer AI so das die KÃ¤mpfe nicht durch "BetrÃ¼gen" des Computers spannend gemacht werden MÃœSSEN.

Setzen, Sechs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002229374', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1456536185}
review:
Ich habe mit Blackguards 2 angefangen und danach erst blackguards zugelegt.das alles bei einem steam sale.ich laÃŸ von diesem spiel zuvor in diversen pc magazinen.ich bin total erwartungsfrei an die sache ran.definitiv mag ich spiele dieser art!blackguards wurde so zu sowas wie eine hassliebe.gÃ¤be es einen mitteldaumen,wÃ¼rde ich diesen sofort benutzen fÃ¼r blackguards.es ist weder ein gutes noch ein schlechtes spiel.es unterhÃ¤lt und ist fÃ¼r den salepreis absolut ok.nur fÃ¤llt mir schwer zu glauben das dafÃ¼r auch mal eine ordentliche summe (vollpreis) dafÃ¼r verlangt wurde.da bin ich sehr froh darÃ¼ber ihn nicht gezahlt zu haben,den vollen preis!es ist schwierig den titel jemand wirklich zu empfehelen,bzw einer spielergruppe.ich sage,das muss jeder fÃ¼r sich selbst rausfindn!ich hatte definitiv unterhaltene stunden mit diesem spiel,nur motiviert es mich soo gar nicht,es wenigstens durchgespielt zu haben.ich stecke aktuell mittendrin,spiele es alle paar wochen mal fÃ¼r 1-2h und dann reichts mir auch schon wieder.ich glaube auch nicht an einen gewissen twist,das es plÃ¶tzlich so fahrt aufnimmt,damit ich es ja durchspielen mÃ¶chte/muss.aber das hat eh kaum in spiel in den letzten jahren.das letzte das mir wirklich das gefÃ¼hl gegeben hat es durchspilen zu mÃ¼ssen war bei mir bioshock2.metro2033 muss ich auch dazu zÃ¤hlen.wir sind definitiv in einer multiplayerzeit.es gibt leider kaum noch gute soloplayer spiele.und wenn ein spiel solo kommt,sollte es bei mir wenigstens die wirkung haben es durchspielen zu mÃ¼ssen.hier leider nicht der fall.
ABER,ich kann fÃ¼r mich festhalten,das der erste teil mir sogar besser gefiel,als der zweite!

Fazit:ist nett,macht vieles richtig,fesselt aber nicht!im sale kann man es sich gerne zulegen ohnme einen euro zu verschwenden,man sollte aber nicht hoffen die offenbarung in seiner gaming history zu erleben.....

author: {'steamid': '76561198015154719', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1458088011}
review:
After playing the game for ten hours I can see why it has such mixed reviews. I wouldn't recommend it based off of my standards for games but others might still find it enjoyable.

Cons
Terrible story ( Confusing, presents a lot of questions but gives few answers. Main character seems like a loser)
Flat characters, characters seem to blurt out whatever is in their head instead of talking to each other
Plot twists are in poor taste (They come of as 'we did this to you because we can')
Somewhat steep learning curve when it comes to training your characters
Weapon system seems biased in the sense that there is little to no benefit to pick x over y in any scenerio
Game consistantly pushes you back to square one by taking your gear/characters away from you and forcing you to fight at a severe disadvantage

Pros
Characters are customizable in their fighting style, although non mages have a limited non passive special talent selection.
Difficult (although for the wrong reasons imo)
Tactical turnbased game
Bug free from what I have seen.

If you are a diehard fan of tactical turn based games and do not care about story elements then this game might interest you. I would recommend watching youtube videos first before committing or wait for it to go on sale.

Overall rating 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198052465212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1457824685}
review: I can't say I like this game. The story is somewhat nice. I like RPGs in which you begin as an outlaw, unimportant nobody. Though very soon the story turned out to be generic and unappealing. The settings seems totally boring. You don't seem to really travel in an open world. The first town you appera in is not really a town, it's just one screen where you click four vendors. What a joke. I like where the combat tactic element is going so far, but overall I don't feel like playing this game again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030013349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 6770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2292, 'last_played': 1465226499}
review: I tried really hard to like this game. If there was a way to skip AI moves, it would be lots of fun. The AI can litarly take up to 10 second to complete their turn. So this game gets a thumbs down because some levels have over 10 AI. No game should make a player wait over a minute to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993590517', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1457307503}
review:
Save yourself.  Plays like a mediocre browser game.

I'd been back and forth on Blackguards since it came out and finally took the plunge.  After a scarce hour or two of play, with wonky "cinematic" interruptions, weirdly paced combat, and absolutely awful dialog, I just had to put it down and "delete local files."

Gameplay seems to be more about picking battlefields from a world map menu than anything. 

Just... no.
