author: {'steamid': '76561197971077885', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1840, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1457175456}
review:
Tja, was soll man dazu sagen....man muss schon ein eingefleischter DSA Fan sein, um das Spiel mit Begeisterung zu spielen.
GefÃ¼hlte 50% verbringt man im Loading screen...bei jedem Ortswechsel...das nervt bereits nach den ersten 4-5 KÃ¤mpfen.
Auch in Mathe muss hier nachgebessert werden...man heilt nen Char (der noch 5LP hat) mit 20 Punkten, er wird mit 17 Punkten getroffen...und sinkt dann leblos mit -2 LP zu Boden...WTF? Das ist das kleine ein mal eins!!! Wenn man eine Leertaste drÃ¼cken kann, dann sollte man das doch beherrschen, oder?
Leider ists damit noch nicht genug...die Steuerung ist ein Alptraum. Man kann die Sicht auf dem Schlachtfeld nur zoomen, aber nicht drehen...was Ã¼bel ist, wenn man einen Gegner angreifen will, der z.B. hinter einer SÃ¤ule steht, oder von einem Teammitglied verdeckt ist. Fehlangriffe sind da obligatorisch und kÃ¶nnen Ã¼ber den Ausgang des Kampfes entscheiden...was imo nicht passieren sollte. 
Und dann die Zauber...mal klappen sie, mal nicht...das ist dem DSA Regelwerk geschuldet und fÃ¼r mich soweit auch vÃ¶llig ok....ABER....mal kann man sie auf eigene Member anwenden...und manchmal klappt das einfach nicht...warum weiss kein Mensch....Mana ist da...Entfernung ist nicht zu weit...der Char kann seinen Zug machen...trotzdem geht es nicht....

Mit einem Wort...das Game ist einfach BUGGY...und da es schon Ã¤lter ist, wird sich daran auch nichts mehr Ã¤ndern... 

Wer Games wie Dragon Age, oder Elder Scrolls gewÃ¶hnt ist, der sollte tunlichst die Finger von Blackguard lassen...

author: {'steamid': '76561198089257610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 19691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13409, 'last_played': 1486011510}
review:
I wasn't sure what to review this game, but I thought a thumbs down would get the attention this comment merits as an OG gamer.  The biggest problem is that the harder settings make experience points go down and the mission harder...  breaking the standard expectation of harder missions and more experience that I wanted.  I don't want to go through on uber hard mode and end up with a nerfed character.  

I suppose the other problem, and if you're thinking balancing trouble is the deal with the criticism, I know, I've thought of that, the problem is that you're pigeon holed into one kind of min/max or maybe two if you want to beat the game on hard.  This, to me, is not acceptable, lol.

But, also, not that the difficulty setting thing means that, when you finally have to switch back to normal to kill the gators with your incorrectly min/maxed character build, you might have to make the disgusting decision to set it to easy...  which I know a lot of gamers like me just cannot fathom, lol.

I suppose this brings me to another failure of modern gaming...  it's not like and can grind out another level in the middle of the story, which I would love to do rather than abandon my character... but why nerf my powers when I have it on hard, really...

author: {'steamid': '76561198003602357', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1421951275}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043671770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1456952226}
review:
I think that this game can best be compared to playing chess.  Chess is often a slow game and to play it you have to think.  Sometimes you have to put several minutes of thought into a move before making it.  This game is like that but you have to put a fair amount of time and thought into almost EVERY move that you make.  When I was younger, I liked chess a great deal and I probably would have liked this game more.  But I havent played chess in years and find this game to be agonizingly slow to play.   The graphics are fairly decent, the voice acting is ok, the combat IA is pretty good but its just way too dang slow!  Im glad that I got it on sale for 3.99.  I may come back to it and play it some more on a rainy day sometime but probably not.  Actually, I havent played 2 hours yet.  I should just get a refund...

PS: BTW, I put "no" for this game based on whether or not I would recomend it to myself.  Nope!  But folks who like turn based games should go for it.  They would probably enjoy it very much.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972518312', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 2972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2972, 'last_played': 1456702385}
review:
I enjoyed it, though without a background in this particular DnD set (TDE) I'd suggest the balance is a little out of whack.  You'll likely need some internet research (and there isn't too much out there) to make any progress.  It's more about tactical combat than a "proper" RPG, so know what you are getting into.

Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002633455', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 3750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1939, 'last_played': 1485462395}
review:
This is great fun, and particularly recommended if you're looking for a less daunting, more linear story-driven turn-based RPG. 

It's perfect for busy people who perhaps have less time for too-open and deep an experience:
 
- Fairly linear, especially for the first half of the game (it opens out a little in Chapter 3, but even here it is still really just about having some choice about what order you do the quests and fights).
- Great story, with a central mystery, and lots of believable twists and turns; it takes you to lots of interesting locations and has you meet a range of engaging characters.  
- Good voice acting nearly throughout - only a few weaker performances. The main heroes and villains are all voiced very well. 
- Some great characters, such as Zuraban, the womanising socialite, Niam, the drug-addicted lost soul or the gold-loving dwarf. These may be fantasy archetypes, but the interaction between them often takes you to new territory, and is often funny. 
- Fairly deep (but not TOO complicated!) skill tree and leveling up system.  
- Good turn-based combat, and challenging if played on Hard. 

The only criticism I have so far is that there seem to be just a few areas that are a little unpolished - for example, you can skill up you 'traps' detection and disarming ability, only to discover that there is no actual mechanic to allow you to disarm traps. And yes, I've searched the forums! In the end, there are other ways around it, so it's no biggie!

author: {'steamid': '76561197974417125', 'num_games_owned': 118, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3235, 'last_played': 1456580175}
review:
Firstly let me say I'm a big fan of RPGs but I'd never really played a turn based one until Blackguards. My first impression was that I'll get bored playing this very quickly, but they change the dynamics of the battles throughout the game so it's often not as straightforward as killing all the mobs. 

The overall mechanics of the game are very familiar. Collect experience (action points) and use it to buy upgrades to your character. The battles are all turn based so you essentially get a number of action points per turn with which to move your character and perform a single action. Not being used to this type of game I wasn't too sure I would  like it but I ended up really enjoying it.

The graphics are pretty nice, not spectacular, but nice, The voice acting is a little ropey but doesn't spoil the game.

Overall I really enjoyed the game and would recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003132759', 'num_games_owned': 1573, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1456620451}
review:
Some decent ideas let down by painfully bad design. The writing and voice acting are decent, and there are some interesting RPG concepts, but the game is centred around an unbalanced combat system. 

It is so heavily dependant on RNG, and yet many battles are determined by a few key actions - fail the RNG on those, and you may as well re-start the battle. As such, it simply becomes a frustrating exercise in repetition and luck.

There may be some good content here, but it's trapped behind some ill-considered mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013278787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2886, 'last_played': 1456356493}
review:
Bought it in a sale, fought through the weird leveling system (well, if you're a fan of "the dark eye", then you may like it) and wondered about all the different equipments, which you don't need.

BUT:
All in all I would say it was a fun game!
- Story is okay, even if the plot is a bit... well, don't spoiler here.
- NPC companions are funny and maybe the best part of the game.
- You can have fun in the battles. Some of them are easy or straight forward, but it's okay, while other battles will be challenging though. It's a good mix in my opinion.
- Music, sound and speakers are good (played it in german, not sure how it is in english). I liked them.

I think I can recommend the game, though I would wait for a sale to buy it. If you like "the dark eye" you'll feel comfortable with the system, others will have a bit confusing beginning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045512373', 'num_games_owned': 1318, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1270, 'last_played': 1454598789}
review:
A frustrating, boring mess. This is very hard on new players hoping to learn the genre, and will sit you through painfully tedious repeats of battle scenarios and loading earlier saves if you're not experienced or running through without a guide. It actively discourages tactical creativity and I've found through number-crunching that statistically, some spells and approaches to the game are just far better and blatantly optimal than others. Want to play this RPG forging your own path and using your own strategies? Good luck. Play the "meta" way or start praying. 
Beyong that, the plot, characters and voice acting are all sub-par and uninspired. All I can give praise to are the environments and animations, which look great but don't exactly generate fun on their own. 

I really tried to like this game with 20+ hours of playthrough. I'd hoped I would find the fun in all that time, but sadly I didn't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038181840', 'num_games_owned': 972, 'num_reviews': 524, 'playtime_forever': 2369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2226, 'last_played': 1456651426}
review:
Game has awesome concept but is poorly executed.  Horribly buggy, freezes constantly.  Other than spending at least 10 minutes out of every thirty resetting the bloody game, it was strangely enjoyable despite all its flaws.  Recommend reluctantly.

For more niche curation, follow me at: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/27440015-CSH-Picone/

author: {'steamid': '76561198228194212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1524435814}
review: This is for those die-hard fantasy gamers. It has some DnD elements that just makes the inner-nerd happy and superb voice acting. The characters are fun and the story is decent. Combat-wise it's annoying missing attacks that have a 70%+ chance of hitting and this happens a lot. It's also a bit of an adjustment constantly preparing your ammo and healing your characters before each battle since they don't just regenerate fully or have unlimited ammo by themselves. Overall a good game, not worth the price but is a must-have when it goes on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970330814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 249, 'playtime_forever': 2834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2769, 'last_played': 1444928838}
review:
Absolutely great game. Hard as sin too! Some missions I was moments away from quitting but about a few attempts I'd do it. That is satisfaction!

Both a blessing and curse there too making you fight 3 missions in a row. Personally I dont like that being sprung on me because I am time sensitive. If I sit down to play a mission I expect it to take me maybe half an hour so thats what I expect and I really dont want to put up with extreme late nights or the wife nagging because of this. Sure, I could turn it off and use some self control but I expect the games studios to help me out and understand, games are addictive and we want to complete you! 

Loved this TBS. Great story, travelling was new and there was little in this game that was in any way wrong.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974446177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 710, 'last_played': 1454981028}
review: This games had so much potential to be magnifiscent. I liked the graphics, I liked the game mechanics, I felt the voices were well acted and I was excited to get my characters leveled up....but it came to an abrupt halt when my crew got jumped by about 5-6 bounty hunters who beat my guys down before we could really get a shot off.  I couldn't go off and level my guys up any more, I couldn't rest before the second fight started...and I tried several times to get through.  I mean, if I were able to beat half the guys and the other half got me I would think it was just a matter of tactics.  Not the case, I'm afraid.  I want to like this game SO BAD, but I can't.  :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198074048760', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2457, 'last_played': 1454883018}
review:
**Not worth the full asking price, still bugged after 2 years, achievements that are impossible to get and various game breaking flaws even in the main campaign**

-

This game is like... Being stuck with a Dungeon Master that won't adapt to anything you do, and force you to continue on the path it set for you- even if you don't like it.

Usually, when I play a T-RPG, I'll find something that work, blast through the story once to get the pacing right, and then play it again in a harder mode and take my time. Well... it is not possible in this game, and to tell the truth, the story isn't good enough to justify that I ever finish it. 

Let me tell you : You'll not get it right on your first try. 
The game will take away things you put a lot of effort into without you having a say in it.
You'll have to start the game over, or read a guide to make sure you plan your characters correctly. 
You'll have to use these damn consumable I hate to use, put your points in these damn debuff I hate to use.

In short, if you like to play your own way or feel strong, this game is not for you.
If your the kind that like to find the optimal builds, and don't mind a few bugs, buy it for under $10.

=> 5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198001316637', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1627, 'last_played': 1427611044}
review:
Let me preface this by saying this game is definitely not for everyone. The story is terrible imo, and there is lack of documentation about the ruleset within the game. So good luck if you mess up your build early in the game (some talents and spells are useless). But, if you can get around those two factors, there is a nice TBRPG here.

  Blackguards strength is easily its combat. Difficulty of encounters is not determined by the number of enemies nor the amount of hp they have but by the types of enemies and the environmental hazards on the map. Hell, even increasing the difficulty actually makes the AI smarter instead of having cheap mechanics like OHKOs.

  For a first time RPG developer, Daedalic did a suprisingly good job. Unfortunately, Daedelic didn't just decide to make a better Blackguards 1 when making the sequel.

review:
I was looking to play this for a long time.

Fun in the beginning but it gets boring soon.
Story is linear, NPC forgettable, party not interesting. 

Good development of skills but sadly not enough to keep me interested!

author: {'steamid': '76561198117765588', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 5314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5043, 'last_played': 1453780198}
review:
SUMMARY: 8 stars out of 10.  A solid and highly enjoyable RPG!

PROLOGUE: I show as having 88 hours playing this game, as of this review.  I probably actually was playing for 80 hours of that, for ONE playthrough. I am methodical and slow, so most of you whippersnappers who like to cut to the chase will likely finish in 40 hours or less.  I saw a lot of complaints about this game having spikes of frustratingly high difficulty, so I played the EASY/NOVICE setting, which I believe gives more Adventure Points (AP) than the other settings.  In retrospect, I can understand the complaints; but I never had that problem, maybe because of the easy setting, maybe for the most part because I pushed off what I suspected would be the tougher fights until I had more skills under my party's belts.  I ended the game with 1300 ducats (enough to ditch EVERYTHING the party needed and buy it all back again), lots of poisons, potions, provisions, projectiles, traps, and other stuff I never seemed to have the need to use.  I used one potion, and that in the second to last battle.  Perhaps on NORMAL difficulty I would have needed more...

REVIEW:  This game has a main storyline which is fairly linear, but the available sidequests (and locations they open) make it feel less so.  The RPG character development system is versatile and refreshing: You can mold your characters by earning and using AP to buy levels in any of a myriad of basic traits, talents, weapon talents, special abilities, and (for magic users) spells.  You get AP by fighting battles and completing quests.  You do not get enough AP to turn your characters into super heros; but, if you do most of the sidequests, you will get enough to make them excellent in their chosen specialty (magic, melee, ranged) and solid in a second specialty and/or support.  One word of caution: this is not the game for those who want to destroy waves of hapless foes with giant fire or frost balls.  Using magic to buff teammates (and/or debuff enemies) will carry the day. 

There are approximately 180 fights available in the game, for those who wish to seek them all out, with plenty of tactical variety and some light "in-fight" puzzle solving.  In all but a few cases, the game clues you in to what is needed to make a fight easier.  For those few where they fall short, there is the internet: I used it about six times.  There were about three fights I elected to replay because I failed or did not like the outcome.  All in all, I found the combat to be satisfying.

Some have complained of running out of ammo (the shops do not re-stock arrows and bolts); but I ran two archers and one crossbow, and did not come close to running out.  I think someone relied too heavily on "triple shot" and "rain of arrows," which skills none of my characters learned.

The storyline is nothing to write home about; and the ending cutscenes/wrap-up is lackluster.  But the character voice acting, approriate interjection of humor, and plot intrigue that is played out was, in my opinion, quite well done.

Replay value is modest.  The plot twists and intrigue are a lot of what pulled me along the first time.  Your party characters are a mandatory set of (up to) five characters, only one of which you get to roll from scratch, and even HIM not entirely (name, gender and appearance are all set for you).  After almost 90 hours on record for my first run, another one (this time on NORMAL) will have to wait until I am up for it.  But, for the pittance I paid for the game (got it on a deep, DEEP discount), one run was overwhemingly worth the price!

EPILOGUE / HINTS (which some might consider slightly spoilerish, but I will not give away plot.)
-- Screw the game's advice:  Roll your own character from scratch the first time.  It is almost impossible to fail if you buy in as a magic user and start him out good at SOMETHING.
-- Take magic, unless you are dead set on a heavy melee fighter.  the 500 AP cost might seem like a lot, but it is a pittance over the course of the game, compared to the advantages it gives.
-- Continuing this line of thought, a dedicated heavy melee fighter is probably not the best choice, as you will eventually end up having two excellent ones foisted upon you.  You will be much better served with a magic buffer/healer who is good at bows.
-- All your magic users should be good with staffs, or possibly daggers.
-- Study spells carefully before trying to achieve high ranks in them.  For most spells, level 4 is not worth the cost.
-- Hammer Blow (HB), coupled with level 3 "Standfast Catlike" buff is OP.
-- The level 3 buff "Move like Lightning" (or some name llike that) is OP.
-- A fighter simultaneously buffed with level 3 Lightning and Standfast, and also using HB, is beyond OP for most fights.

* On suit une aventure bien Ã©crite et interprÃ©tÃ©e (voix anglaises raffinÃ©es) qui se dÃ©roule d'elle mÃªme, sur rail. C'est le piment de l'intrigue qui prÃ©vaut sur la libertÃ©. Il n'y a pas de libertÃ© dans Blackguards si ce n'est quelques choix accessoires ou...
* La spÃ©cialisation / montÃ©e des personnages touffue.
* La gestion millimÃ©trÃ©e de l'Ã©quipe de persos.

Mais si cette liste vous excite, c'est que Blackguards vous attend.

Personnellement, j'ai tout aimÃ©. Le doublage de haute volÃ©e, pour qui goÃ»te la subtilitÃ© de la v.o anglaise, y fait beaucoup. On apprÃ©ciera Ã©galement le fait de pouvoir faire des sessions de jeux courtes (un combat ou deux avant de reprendre la vie rÃ©elle). 

Quelques hics... mais trÃ¨s peu.

Le dÃ©marrage est assez long; c'est une histoire et un gameplay qui prennent leur temps Ã  se rÃ©vÃ©ler. Soyez patient(e), car Ã§a en vaut la peine. Le prologue est plus long qu'il ne semble mais entrer dans le trip s'avÃ¨re gratifiant.
L'Oeil Noir, univers de base (dans lequel d'autres softs proposent des baroudes, en RPG ou point n'click) n'est pas trÃ¨s accessible aux novices, ce qui est dommage. De fait, seuls les vieux briscards ayant pratiquÃ© ce jeu-de-rÃ´le reconnaÃ®tront des lieux et divinitÃ©s d'Aventurie. Enfin, il faut accepter d'Ã©voluer dans un jeu sur le mode Ã©cran fixe / Ã©cran de chargement / plateau de combat / Ã©cran de chargement...

author: {'steamid': '76561198030744400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1453529121}
review: Just so much failure in this game. I really wanted to like it, but it just does so many things just wrong. Everything is ridiculously expensive, there is zero immersion. For example my guys all have crappy torches, and we have had crappy torches for well over an hour, killing guys with axes and swords. When we defeat said guys, you'd think we get a sword right? NOP! Still stuck with the crappy torches! And still can't afford 1 crappy hand axe, which the game seems to value at 13 gold! These developers are clueless at both medieval history and game balance (a hand axe would NEVER cost anywhere that much) !  Oh, and then the game wants to kill gigantic troll with your crap weapons! It's like the game is trolling you! I didn't even mention that almost everything to do in this game can just fail as it does nothing and waste your turn. It seems the way the developers want you to  get through this game is to save scum your way through, just hope you hit the all the monsters all the time and load if you don't! How fun!  This game is just a package of false promises that ends in dashed hopes and shame; just stay away.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980328361', 'num_games_owned': 630, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 2337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1669857143}
review:
Great graphics, good dialogue.  Decent story.  Great skill selection.  

Two things ruin it for me: 

1. Not able to customise keys. (I have a disability and use a trackball which has no wheelso there is no way for me to change the camera angle.  Minor issue.)
2. Difficulty.  The current trend of overly-difficult games is at work here.  I have zero interset in searching forums for tips or reading an online manual to tell me how to play.  Doing homework is not fun.  Games I can pick up and play are fun. So, this game is not fun.  If you are a "gamer" who likes doing research maybe this is for you.
3.  Spell failure percentage is WAY too high.  low level spellcasters are useless.
4.  When restarting a battle, there is no way to switch weapons.  Why on earth do some battles begin with enemies on top of you and others across the screen?
5.  Swamp apes using battle tactics?  Wth?  They're dumb.  They charge, not wait smartly just out of bow range for you to advance and then get a free attack.  Come on.

review:
Blackguards es un RPG clÃ¡sico, basado en combates por turnos en un mapa de casillas hexagonales. Hasta ahÃ­ todo bien, el problema llega cuando te dicen que no es mundo abierto, que las ciudades solo son botones de diÃ¡logo y que no te mueves por ellas.

Puede que tenga mÃ¡s potencial del que yo le he sabido sacar, pero el juego no me ha conquistado en las primeras horas de juego, y por ello no lo recomiendo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970278929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 854, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 854, 'last_played': 1453239027}
review:
My favourite part of this game was replaying the same battle 50 times because a spell fails even with a "93%" chance of succeeding, and without a perfect turn you just get ground into the dirt (I'm looking at you lizards and your crystal).  

You are RNG's bitch and this game will punish you with near constant spell fails and a brutal difficulty curve.

Divinity Original Sin is a better game in every single respect.  Play that instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147485569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 5511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5418, 'last_played': 1463685674}
review:
[h1]Blackguards Review[/h1]
[b] Overall Score: 6/10 [/b]

[u] Storyline: (1/2) [/u]
+ Fun dialogues to read between characters.
- Bad storyline (I don't see it going anywhere besides a basic story of the advanture itself).

[u] Graphics: (2/2) [/u]
+ Well designed character models and gears.
+ Good looking battle maps and towns.

[u] Sounds: (2/2) [/u]
+ Voices matching the characters.
+ Good sounds in battlemaps and overall.

[u] Gameplay: (3/4) [/u]
+ Easy and basic training progress to let you understand the game rules and mechanics.
+ Main and Side Quests (Each quest is intresting because it gives rewards and you never know who the enemy is and how many there are).
+ Visit each town and meet Blacksmiths/Healers/Merchants etc.. (Inventory/cash is usefull)
- Difficulties: It's good to have 3 level of difficulties but we need to understand the difference between each one because it feels hard even on Easy for a new player in Blackguards.

[u] RolePlay Elements: (4/7) [/u]
+ Different Classes (Hunter/Mage/Fighter)
+ Rich variety of equippment (Weapons/Armor Sets/Items to use on A.I/self/enemy)
+ Happy Mage (A full page of spells only for the mage)
- Special Moves for other characters (You're able to unlock them with a trainer.. But I'm reaching 15 hours and I still haven't found this 'trainer' yet.
+ Talents : A sweet bonus in this game which let you upgrade each talent form level 1 to 5 and give you it's special effect [see below]
*Knockdown resistance *Animals/Humans stats detector *Healing Effect * Traps detector and more...
+- Stats : There are good sides and bad sides about the stats because in one hand you can match the stats to your liking
if you want a spellcaster archer or a dual wielding warrior but if you don't know what you upgrade to your character you might have a weaker character than you've expected.
- Equippment stats are a bit clumsy.
- Upgrade Points: It takes more time than it should be for a player to think about where to invest his upgrade points.

[u] Combat: (4/5) [/u]
+ Each combat is exciting and makes you eager for the next one.
+ Basic turn-based combat rules/moves but more challenging then other TB games.
+ Usefull Objects : You can throw weapons on the enemy, use/disable traps , use battle objects to move them around or use them against the enemy. You can even hide in the bush from the enemy.
+ Satisfaction : For those 100% players, you will re-do the battle until you get it done the best way you want it to be.
- Frustration : In some battles I felt like my characters are over powered by the enemy. Had to re-try multiply times in different tactics.

To sum it up, I'm enjoying my new Turn Based experience with Blackguards.
It offers an addictive experience throughout the game so I recommend on trying this game if you're an experienced TB gamer.
Don't bother playing this if you're more of a classic TB gamer who doesn't want to focus much on character's stats and RPG elements that might confuse you along the way.

You're more than welcome to also check my screenshots for this game [link below] to see what this game has to offer.
http://steamcommunity.com/id/xDMikeW2k14/screenshots/?appid=249650&sort=newestfirst&browsefilter=myfiles&view=imagewall

Enjoyment: (6/10)
Repetetive: (2/10)
Replayability (8/10)
Frustraiton (5/10)
Boredom (5/10)

[b]Overall Score: 6/10[/b]
* Skip it.
** Not Recommended.
[i][b][h1]*** Give It A Try.[/h1][/b][/i]
**** Recommended On Sale.
****** Recommended On Full Price.
Thanks for reading.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014750752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1452693763}
review:
Start the game with two-handed sword fighter, realise everything except one-handed bashing is literally useless because that's all the game is scripted to give you.

Struggle and get to the mission where you have to rescue the Baroness, realise it's literally impossible and just try to finish by killing the enemies.

First few rounds are spent trial and error restarting to figure out there's invisible traps, and you need to start the round with a spell that has a 45% chance to destroy the boxes and set enemies on fire.

First try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Second try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Third try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Fourth try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Fifth try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Sixth try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, 45% chance spell works, dwarf decides to move through 2 hexes of fire rather than one losing 20 health, take two critical hits from archer, in the end only dwarf left with 2hp and archer enemy with 22hp. Dwarf power attacks archer, deals 18 damage, archer attacks dwarf, deals 4 damage.

Stop playing. Look at achivement stats, only a quarter of people finished Chapter 1. I wonder why.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080335466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3923, 'last_played': 1452450082}
review:
In brief: fairly linear hex-map RPG with good character system and decent storyline. You'll enjoy it if you like that sort of thing.

Blackguards is an old-school gaming experience dressed in modern threads, a pen-and-paper RPG brought to life on the PC. The graphics are appealing, animations smooth, sound effects satisfying and voice acting mostly good. You take the role of an assistant to a noble family who gets into trouble at the outset and goes on the run, and your attempts to unravel what's happened ultimately take on a global significance. The story, chiefly told in cutscenes whose animation is best described as economical, follows a fairly linear path, but a wealth of subplots and sidetracks provides a pleasant illusion of free movement which probably won't convince today's open-world gamers.

Your character is provided with several sidekicks and you marshall and move your party on the world map. Movement is essentially the selection of locations and passage of time is not tracked. In towns and similar locations you'll find traders, trainers, inns, healers, and the like, as well as NPCs who advance the plot and give you quests. Party management is done through the stat sheet and inventory of each character, and true to the RPG that gave birth to this game, the system is satisfyingly deep and complex. Your decisions about character development will win or lose you the game, and new players should take note: it is possible to build a character badly and it's very difficult to undo this once you've done it, so take the time to read the manual and the in-game character creation notes (which don't appear in the manual and are very useful).

Quests and plot advancement almost always involve a skirmish, and it's these hex-map clashes where you'll spend most of your game hours. It's clear that a lot of thought has gone into skirmish map design: in some cases it's a straight fight to the death, but often there are environmental factors to deal with and in some cases the map is a puzzle which you must solve to win. In fact you can think of every skirmish as a puzzle which must be solved, as enemies differ in their capacities and susceptibilities and you must apply the right tools in terms of weapons, spells and equipment to prevail. That said, the game depends ultimately on the roll of the dice, so luck is always a factor. Fortunately death isn't permanent and so long as you have the last man standing, you'll walk away with your party intact.

Some reviewers have complained of the game's excessive difficulty. At the time of writing this review I've completed the game on Normal difficulty and have clocked up over 80 hours of play. I think I saw every skirmish there was to see, well over a hundred in total, and more than half of those I completed first time. There were only a handful I had to attempt more than twice. The final battle is difficult, but so it should be â€“ my only gripe is that the plotting, or perhaps the scriptwriting, feels a bit wrong at the end, but YMMV. If you find yourself stymied by a skirmish, see whether you can go elsewhere to level your party up a bit; if not, it's very likely that you're either missing something important in the skirmish (always check the interactive objects) or you've taken a serious misstep in character building. Be careful not to spread XPs too thin on your characters: you can't take all spells and weapons to the maximum in the course of the game, and you do need some top-level skills and spells by the end if not by the middle.

Two things bothered me about this game: loading times, and the ending. My system isn't top-of-the-line but neither is this game, and I saw far too much of the loading screens for my liking (Mengbilla in particular tried my patience quite a bit). The ending... without spoiling things, I was surprised to see essentially the same cutscene after winning the final battle that I'd seen when I lost it. I'm unsure if your choice in dialogues makes any real difference to the way the game pans out, and online chatter suggests that a lot of players were left confused by the denouement. I can't honestly recommend that anyone other than a genre purist buy this game at full price, but if you see it on sale grab it and give it a try, and be sure to get to the top of the bow skill tree as early as possible!

review:
Un gran bel gioco, mi Ã¨ piaciuto un sacco. La trama non Ã¨ il massimo della vita forse, e certo il comparto tecnico non fa urlare al miracolo, ma cavolo, gli scontri sono sempre ben calibrati e difficili al punto giusto. L'ho giocato tutto, con tutte le sottomissioni ed era una vita che non succedeva in un gioco. Migliorabile ma giÃ  molto bello, solo per chi come a me, piace ragionare su tutti i parametri delle battaglie, dalle pozioni alla disposizione sul campo dalle magie.

Avevo letto delle recensioni che lo stroncavano senza pietÃ  invece, l'ho trovato entusiasmante.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044169026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2602, 'last_played': 1389841516}
review:
I wanted to like this game. I was really, really optimistic. And, if I'm fair, I probably have myself to blame for believing the game description and getting my hopes up. But no, I ended up loathing the game to such an extent that when the last chapter of the story was released I didn't even WANT to find out how the story ended.

My main problems are with the story and the combat, which considering how the game bills itself is unforgivable. Both are shallow, boring and slow, which is in no way helped by a quest system and map that seem to conspire to drag things out even more.

I will say that the game could be challenging in interesting ways at times. 

Honestly, if I could refund this game I would do it in a heartbeat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065898339', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5890, 'last_played': 1452257633}
review:
Too complex and not very entertaining.
Pros: a dense story with very cool characters and a very well built enviroment
Cons: game system is just too complex and takes research and dedication to realy understand it. Battles lack rythm causing them to become boring after some time, and some of them can take a really long time.
Conclusion: it's a beautiful game but it just doesn't serve it's purpose. tottaly do not reccoment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055725979', 'num_games_owned': 1326, 'num_reviews': 262, 'playtime_forever': 8784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4273, 'last_played': 1521440012}
review:
Este juego se supone, al igual que muchos otros como Pillars of Eternity, que primero se tienen que estudiar unas reglas hasta comprender el juego y descubrir por donde meterle mano para que nos haga sentir seguros. Yo creo que la seguridad equivale a rol desde un modo ''afectivo''.

Esta recomendaciÃ³n estÃ¡ dedicada a los roleros y no a los ''para vosotros jugadores xd'', sin embargo parece ser que se tiene que indicar algÃºn tipo de aviso para los jugadores excursionistas. Las quejas no valen, los combates se pueden repetir todas las veces que queramos. Si no se tiene paciencia para repetir y estudiar los combates uno a uno o para aprender desde cero un sistema de reglas y llevarlo a la prÃ¡ctica poco a poco a favor de la estrategia y todo esto con muchos conceptos nuevos y de muchas formas no se recomienda.

Asumimos el control total o global de un grupo en todos los aspectos y factores de la jugabilidad que el juego propiamente ofrece y que a su vez no va a servir para tener una base y un guiÃ³n sÃ³lido, para dar forma a toda una historia con muchas tramas, misiones secundarias y libertad en muchos momentos en forma de visitas por los pueblos.

El juego mezcla momentos de libertad con otros en que nos quedamos sin provisiones, por ejemplo flechas de fuego, para acabar todos los combates, tenemos que, por lo menos, estar siempre al tanto de todas estas cosas realistas como buenas decisiones roleras.

Su ambientaciÃ³n es de los tiempos de Roma: ropas y armaduras, armas... con toque fantÃ¡stico: magos, druidas, criaturas gigantes...Y un toque Europeo y de Oriente en general: piratas, gladiadores, sables, cocodrilos...

El realismo y detalle imperan sobre la jugabilidad y la parte tÃ©cnica, sin embargo y entre unas cosas y otras el equilibrio y la jugabilidad parecen no estar afectadas aunque pueda dar la impresiÃ³n de que si.

No es que merezca una oportunidad, es obligatiro jugar a esta maravilla, mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de cualquier cosa que no nos guste o aprobemos. Esto es un tipo muy importante de rol y de aquÃ­ salen las grandes ideas.

El fuerte estÃ¡ en sus combates y es asombroso ver como estos llegan hasta el lÃ­mite con los dos bandos rebentandos, momentos tremendos que, a veces, sÃ³lo se ven en grandes juegos de estrategia como Starcraft. 

Para colmo goza de una dualidad equilibrada entre ataque y defensas en relacciÃ³n a todo: nuestro grupo, enemigos, campo de batalla... Es un equilibrio salvaje entre decidir quienes o como se va a defender o atacar, que no sabrÃ­a muy bien como explicarlo brevemente.

Cantidad de ideas y conceptos fundidos todos bajo la regla y el equilibrio y la personalidad: producto alemÃ¡n.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960806746', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1446933489}
review:
It took me about three hours to be sure that I hate this game, and wouldn't want to play it even if I was getting paid for it.
Which was, of course, too late for a refund.

But at least I learned a valuable lesson - ask yourself "Is this actually any fun?" before hitting the two-hour mark.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026561656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1451665235}
review: Beginning intro quests are long and boring. There are many problems with Hex movements, as in, you believe you are close enough to interact or cast a spell, but something is still preventing it. At one point neither of my mages could cast any spells against the mobs, and there was nothing indicating why. That's when I hung it up, only made it about 90 minutes into the game. It has a lot of potential, but falls short in my opinion

author: {'steamid': '76561198019022165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1451429599}
review:
Wow, i thought it was 1993 and i was playing an old 'Pool of radiance' forgotten realm game! It wasn't that great in 1993 imagine in 2015! 

The game promise strategy, but everything is badly designed. Interface ain't great either. It looks like you have a lot of choices, but ranged bow is just so far better than anything else it's not funny. Even spell that cost you mana regularly fail and are WEAKER than a bow that cost you nothing but cheap arrows and is ranged! Ha!

If you like hardcore dungeons and dragons and are a masochist, then this game i right up your alley! Graphics are bad, the maps are too small, all the ennemy feels the same. It's not a great game and i do not recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198235240888', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1857, 'last_played': 1451619542}
review:
Pros:

The Blackguards storyline is quite enjoyable. I really like the different characters being voiced by different actors (though I'm sure some NPC's have doubled-up).

 I'm glad that players have the option of "creating" their character's base stats.


Cons:

 I'm playing on a 2-year-old  Mac and the game crashes frequently. I restart the game, restart the Steam client -- even restart my computer -- and it's still frequently crashing.

 When I'm in the game, occasionally the screen changes colours / views. For example, I'll see lines across the screen (not just the hexes) and sometimes the screen is entirely composed of solid colours. Another time I was playing the game and all the arrows / NPC conversation icons disappeared. 


Final Thoughts:

 Maybe these troubles are just due to playing the game on a Mac. If you can pick the game up on sale ($5 or less), then it's worth giving a try. I don't recommend paying full price for what can be a buggy experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038494396', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1662, 'last_played': 1451209697}
review:
Liebe Spieler,

dem Kauf ging die faszination des Rundenbasierten Tabletop voraus.
Wer dies schon kennt, weiÃŸ auch in etwa, um das dahinterliegende Regelwerk. Leider wird dies in diesem Spiel nur mangelhaft mitgeteilt. Wer Vorkentnisse hat, kann dies umgehen.

Die Story sollte zwar geschmacksache sein, ist mir selber aber zu zusammengewÃ¼rfelt. Ein Diung zwischen Mittelalter, Elfen und Orgs und eine Mischung aus Psychokram.

Weit aus entscheidener sind die Grafikfehler. Das Spiel kÃ¶nnte eine gute Beta sein, niemals aber ein Verkaufsprodukt. Ich selber kann es nicht mals zuende spielen, da es an einer Stelle keinen Spielverlauf frei gibt und bugt.

Unterm Strich ein netter Versuch mal ein eigenes Spiel zu kreieren. Es sollte nicht gekauft werden.

review:
Blackguards ist ein Genremix aus Rollenspiel und Rundenstrategie, das zusammen mit der verwendeten Das Schwarze Auge-Lizenz eine interessante Mischung ergibt, die ich in dieser Form bislang noch nicht gespielt habe und vielleicht gerade deshalb zu fesseln weiÃŸ.

Entwickelt wurde das Spiel von Daedalic, die mit der DSA-Lizenz ja bereits einschlÃ¤gige (Adventure-)Erfahrungen sammeln konnten und auch sonst fÃ¼r (Spiele-)QualitÃ¤t aus deutschen Landen stehen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143008451', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1597396626}
review: An interesting turn-based RPG with a rare(ish) hex based combat system and intuitive character management, "Blackguards" is definitely a game worth looking at for any fan of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987130775', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 1551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1253, 'last_played': 1450659273}
review:
Dungeons and Dragons meets Xcom. Instead of running from cover to cover, you use your environment to set traps, set oil puddles on fire, or gain health at a fountain. It's the best way to mix the two ideas.

Gameplay-wise, it's too slow in my taste, and it shouldn't cost my character's turn to change weapons or activate a switch; it's tedious. The leveling-up system is overwhelming, and it is too easy to make mistakes while managing your XP spendings. Be warned: XP is a limited ressource and there is no possible grinding. Also, There are some ridiculously difficult fights spiking about. If the game design wasn't all over the place, it wouldn't be an option to change the difficulty whenever I want.

It's not bad, but there's better out there. It's a really hardcore experience and I'm not a big fan of D&D. 

I had crashes and had to reload some games. The achievements are stupid : waste your XP everywhere, use an inn 50 times, run in a circle (not a joke)

author: {'steamid': '76561198043214785', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2324, 'last_played': 1451249878}
review:
Blackguards is a hexagonal turn based strategy game with some fun elements to it. 
The story line is fairly interesting, with many offshoots in the plot to keep you entertained.The graphics are nice and clean and the voice acting surprisingly good, with many humorous lines from the characters as they play off of one another during your adventures together. 
The learning curve isn't too harsh and the tutorial helps a lot during the start.
However it can at times be a little punishing and you will find yourself hitting the restart button on quite a few occasions, especially any levels involving poison, to which there seems to be many. In my opinion the mechanic is used maybe a little too much throughout the game and the effects can start to become a little irritating, so spec to counter this when you get a chance. There are a few bugs, but nothing I would consider to be game breaking, so all in all Blackguards is worth the buy, but I would recommend waiting for it to be on sale and avoid the full price. I picked this up discounted and am more than satisfied with what I got for the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031725194', 'num_games_owned': 1271, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 2401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2401, 'last_played': 1450652779}
review:
Blackguards is a turn-based combat focused RPG, that will most likely frustrate you a lot with the amount of dice rolling in it!

My opinions won't really add much to the discussion, as they're mixed... like almost everyone else's. Also, I'm farily new to the genre, so the min-maxing aspect present in the attributes and skill-trees in the game don't really appeal to me, yet (mostly how of ignorance, but anyway...).

I really like RPGs in general, but I'm not one to read up on the game's numerous systems to learn what the optimal builds are -- I like to shape my characters as I please, leading to some interesting, fun, but not necessarily good decisions. I've done the same in Blackguards and will admit that, for the [i]most[/i] part, it went alright. I played through Normal mode, and never got truly stuck, which was my biggest worry.

Many people complained about reaching an unbeatable point in the game because they had a sub-optimal build. Maybe they were either playing on Hard, or I've simply been fairly lucky in my decision.

I will say that there were lots of details in the game that I simply did not delve into -- potions (offensive), traps, etc. Those didn't seem all important in any of the battles in Normal.

Anyway. It's tough. Some of the battles were infuriating, missing 3x in a row when I had a 90% chance to hit, having some periods of extended battles that far overstayed their welcome, etc.

But I did enjoy it quite a lot. Until I finished the 3rd Chapter, that is. Then the game offered nothing new.

The game is very linear, although it opens up a bit in the 3rd Chapter, giving you quite a lot of sidequests. The following 2 chapters barely have any of those, which felt strange.
It seems like the focus of the game was only the 3rd chapter, the other ones being mostly to build it up or simply carry the story.

The story was pretty bland, and the sidequests weren't too interesting either. Gameplay-wise, it's almost a pure combat game. You move from battle to battle. Other than battles, you just go to cities to buy equipment/heal/train, and get sidequests. Sidequests simply lead you into more battles. You never explore anything, never really find emergent gameplay or anything of the sort. It's very, very combat focused.

But hey... I really have very little to add that would be in any way meaningful. I want to talk about one thing exclusively -- and that is how opaque the game actually was! It was one of the biggest sources of frustration, for me.


Sometimes, the game pushes you into extended battles. Battle after battle after battle without an opportunity to heal, restock, change equipment, etc. These, of course, are a much bigger challenge -- especially because, if you do poorly on one battle, you'll carry that penalty onto the next one.
These battles felt extremely tense, to me. Sometimes they could go on for 2 hours, even if they were just 2 or 3 battles. The game is very slow paced, and a mistake can cost you quite a lot of time, which is frustrating. And the game often likes to pull tricks on you that it never pointed to. They're unwelcome surprises.

This is one side of it. The other, happened in the end of the game. After the [i]point of no return[/i], you're lead into a serious of battles, but you [b]can[/b] heal and re-equip between them. What you [b]can not[/b] do, is buy anything. Every healing potion, equipment, etc. that you can use is what you've taken with you. 
There were a few problems here -- first, you had no idea how many battles there would be, so you couldn't really judge. Second, what the game showed you was very misleading, by having it spread over 2 "pages", but only showing you the first.
Basically, you're expecting x battles, and suddenly, after wasting most of your potions, you're shown that there are actually twice as many. Well, shit.

Thankfully, the game wasn't tricking the player and ramping up the difficulty artifically -- on that second page, there was a healer and merchant that was essentially a safe point. And that was a very nice thing.
The problem is how the game never communicated that beforehand. Every battle I fought felt that much more frustrating because a small mistake seemed like a colossal one. 

Arguably, that the feeling that the game was trying to carry -- I doubt it, though. In this case, it was simply a case of bad communication with the player, it seemed. And similar issues happened throughout the game -- often leading you into "extended battles" without warning, and the like.

For me, at least, it's a huge source of frustration, to have to "judge" something without information. Especially when mistakes can cost hours.

So yeah. That's basically it. The game is a huge "tension" without the "release"...


Regardless, I enjoyed it. I'm not a hardcore player of the genre, so my appreciation is certainly different. It was a good challenge! There was some frustration with the dice-rolls, but overall, I'd recommend it to anyone who is looking for a tough turn based rpg.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022461255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1450589297}
review:
I can sum this entire game up in a sentence and a half. A three or four layered pile of stat sheets that serves to slightly improve your chances of besting the RNG gods on a turn by turn basis. With the odds against you.

If you think this is a dark, or pessimistic way to sum the game up, I can tell you that that is actually the nice way of putting it. To the list of gaming sins this game commits you may a redundant and unrewarding item system, the most difficult to navigate skill system I have seen since the sphere grid in final fantasy X (which is mainly out of your reach anyhow, seeing as it depends on trainers which appear at arbitrary points in the story), multiple attempts at large scale battles which quickly descend into long lines of infinitely spawning enemies dog piling on your phalanx of heroes, percent chance failures on pretty much everything that mean any well laid plan can come to a deadly end at any point in your game, and a difficulty curve that pretends all the random the dice wielding percent chance jockeys whom designed the game smashed into every nook and cranny of the game does not exist at all. 

The end result will leave you hitting the (restart battle) button on the second or third turn of each attempted play because your warrior's power attack whiffed, which you immediately realize means you won't be able to kill the enemies quickly enough to keep up with the level. Assuming none of the heals whiff (yes, your heals can whiff to, about 33% of the time in most cases), which is also a death sentence. I could go into the ham fisted attempts at interactive levels, mysterious and all around dumb line fo sight mechanics that let bows shoot a seemingly infinite distance but leash spells at just a few tiles, impossible side objectives, and lack of actual counter play and tactics, but my ranting would fill three pages.

All this is a shame considering the clear level of effort and passion that went into designing the graphics, story line, and characters, who despite being completely archetypical adventures manage to characterize themselves wonderfully though they're well developed connection to the adventure is set in. If half the effort that went into all that were part of the game, this would likely be a tbs to the caliber of dynasty tactics or r-type command. Instead, you have either a slightly better version of fire emblem, or a slightly worse version of final fantasy tactics, both of which are mind bendingly boring and tediously frustrating to begin with. If you enjoy either of those than you richly deserve this.

If you read nothing else I have written, read this: This game is a pretty face and nothing else. Looks great, plays very poorly. It would be worth about half the forty dollars it costs if it were a graphic novel. Like this, it's not worth the four bucks it was on sale for when I wrote this. WOULD. NOT. RECOMMEND. TO. ANYONE.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002526111', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 7202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6107, 'last_played': 1575069035}
review: Really enjoyed this game. Where other CRPG's will focus on travel, this game eliminates that, the story comes to you and game play is table top turnbased scenarios. I really ejoy the unique take, this is for the tactician that favors combat over all else in their rpg's.

review:
Absolut stressfreies, rundenbasiertes Spiel mit archetypischen Charakteren.
Kern des Spiels ist definitiv das Hexfeld-basierte Kampfsystem, welches an die DSA 4 - Regeln angelehnt ist.
FÃ¼r einen Kampf benÃ¶tigt man hÃ¶chstens eine Stunde Zeit. 

Um die KÃ¤mpfe herum gibt es einen Haupthandlungsstrang mit mehreren Kapiteln. Daneben gibt es zahlreiche, optionale Nebenmissionen. Die KÃ¤mpfe sind mal mehr, mal weniger Abwechslungsreich. NiedergeknÃ¼ppelte Charaktere stehen nach einem gewonnenen Kampf wieder zur VerfÃ¼gung.

Die Bedienung ist leicht zu erlernen und lÃ¤uft gut. StÃ¶rend ist ein wenig die strikte Trennung zwischen Inventar und Charakterbogen. Hier kÃ¶nnten dem Benutzer ein paar Klicks erspart werden.

Die deutsche Vertonung ist gut.

Insgesamt kommt schon ein "Komm! Eine Mission noch! Nur die Eine!" - GefÃ¼hl auf.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973115845', 'num_games_owned': 635, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 16539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4022, 'last_played': 1575773445}
review:
Pro's:
Great voice acting
Very good AI
Incremental difficulty
Good graphics
Good story
Good skill tree's

Con's
Can't pan around battlefield
Frustrating battles (AI very good)
Need better award system for difficult battles

This was one of the funnest strategy games I've played in a long while, even with the frustratingly difficult advanced battles. I would definitley recommend this game.

I'll be purchasing Blackguards II when it goes on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998598944', 'num_games_owned': 2056, 'num_reviews': 1144, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1639147077}
review:
So hex based games are really hard for me to get into.  They are Baldur's Gate or Divinity without the exploration, questing, and dialogue.  On top of that you can't rotate the camera so playing this for the first time in 2021 feels very limiting. 

That being said if you like Hex based games there's a lot of depth here.  Equipment, talents, spells, stats, level ups, cover, destroyable objects, and more.  If you are in love with hex games and haven't played Blackguards, you'll probably like it.  If you just like games in general, I don't think you'll like this.  I didn't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006784126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 400, 'playtime_forever': 548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 548, 'last_played': 1450092828}
review:
Blackguards (v1.5)

[b]POSITIVES[/b]

+ Das Schwarze Auge
+ gutes (auch im P&P) unverbrauchtes Setting im SÃ¼den von Aventurien
+ gut animierte Gegner (auch wenn Morfus und die Iribaarslilien etwas groÃŸ geraten sind)
+ schÃ¶ne Zaubereffekte
+ sehr gute Soundtracks (insgesamt Ã¼ber 40 Minuten)
+ gute deutsche Sprachausgabe
+ keine strahlende Helden, sondern verbrecherische eher dÃ¼stere Charaktere mit dem "SchlÃ¤chter von Neetha" in der Hauptrolle (das ist zwar DSA-untypisch, aber ich persÃ¶nlich bevorzuge bÃ¶se Rollen)
+ Experten Charakter mÃ¶glich (aber leider ohne Vor- und Nachteile wie in Drakensang)
+ stimmige Begleiter (Naurim, Niam, Zurbaran, Takate)
+ rundenbasierende tabletopartige KÃ¤mpfe die (leider) eindeutig den Fokus des Spiels darstellen
+ gelungene Battlemaps mit interaktiven Objekten und dadurch auch alternative LÃ¶sungen
+ keine recycelten SchauplÃ¤tze
+ spielbare RÃ¼ckblenden
+ Lehrmeister die einem Sonderfertigkeiten beibringen, die man erst einmal finden muss, bzw. fÃ¼r die man etwas tun muss, bevor die ihre SF mit einem teilen
+ man sieht direkt welche Auswirkungen Eigenschaftssteigerungen haben, bzw. welche Eigenschaft gesteigert werden muss um etwas bestimmtes zu erhÃ¶hen
+ schÃ¶ne Dialoge (siehe aber auch weiter unten)
+ guter Schwierigkeitsgrad (nur stellenweise etwas zu leicht)
+ maximale Traglast
+ viele Waffen und einige davon auch mit Reichweite oder Zusatzwirkungen
+ gutes KI Verhalten der Gegner die gezielt ihre StÃ¤rken ausnutzen, Heil- und ZaubertrÃ¤nke nutzen, sich auch mal anderen Charakteren zuwenden und auch ihre Zauber sehr gut einsetzen
+ Kampf gegen Fornunfur
+ Wendepunkt in der Handlung
+ interessante Storry (auch wenn es etwas lÃ¤nger dauert bis diese in Fahrt kommt)
+ etwa 40 Stunden Spielzeit (habe es hauptsÃ¤chlich mit der DRM-freien Version gespielt auÃŸerhalb von Steam)
+ zumindest gefÃ¼hlt komplett Bugfrei und keinen einzigen Absturz(!) 

[b]NEGATIVES[/b]

- magere AuswahlmÃ¶glichkeiten beim Aussehen des Charakters
- nur drei Charakterklassen wÃ¤hlbar (im Normalen Modus)
- blaues Leuchten des Hex-Bodens ist etwas unpassend
- UI wirkt zu modern und lieblos (ein RingmenÃ¼ aus Stein oder Metall mit Ornamenten wÃ¤re passender)
- zu wenige Talente und Zauber (ich weiss, dass die bisherigen einigen schon zu viel sein mÃ¶gen, mir jedenfalls nicht)
- Ladebildschirm bei jedem Ortswechsel nervt (auch wenn die Ladezeiten gering sind)
- keine 100%tige Umsetzung der DSA 4.1 Regeln
- StÃ¤dte nicht begehbar
- keine richtigen Dungeons sondern nur Kampfpunkte zwischen denen man wechseln kann
- RPG Aspekte kommen zu kurz
- zu wenig AntwortmÃ¶glichkeiten und kein wirklicher Einfluss
- lineare vorgegebene Story
- wenig Nebenquests
- keine Zufallsbegegnungen auf Reisen (Ã¶de Reisen wie in Drakensang) 
- total unstimmiger blÃ¤ulicher Flammenblitz der anstatt einer Gruppe, Person oder schlichtem rotem Strich (wie in Schicksalsklinge HD) Ã¼ber die Karte rast
- fehlende Ausdauerregel, wodurch viele Kampf SF zu stark sind, da diese beliebig oft einsetzbar sind (ich bin zwar im P&P kein Freund der Ausdauer, aber gerade in einem PC Spiel hÃ¤tte das gut gepasst, da der Rechner ja die Verwaltungsarbeit Ã¼bernimmt)
- kein RS Zonensystem
- statt dessen seltsame %tuale Resistenzen gegen gewisse Schadensarten, was zur Folge hat, dass man seine RÃ¼stung nicht richtig einschÃ¤tzen kann (herkÃ¶mmlicher RS auf Zonen wÃ¤re so viel einfacher und besser gewesen)
- bei den Zaubern in Bezug auf die Wirkung nicht richtig an die P&P Vorlagen gehalten wodurch natÃ¼rlich groÃŸe Ungleichgewichte entstehen
- fixe Schadenswerte der Zauber (dadurch am Anfang zu stark und spÃ¤ter zu schwach)
- Axxeleratus Blitzgeschwind mit seiner zusÃ¤tzlichen Aktion ist zu stark; dass man nun die Kosten fÃ¼r diesen Zauber erhÃ¶ht hat, Ã¤ndert daran eher wenig
- auch bei den SF wurde sich nicht richtig an die Vorlagen gehalten
- SF Dreifachschuss ist viel zu stark und sollte gestrichen werden, oder legt hier Legolas aus Herr der Ringe persÃ¶nlich auf (?); diese SF gibt es auch im P&P nicht
- Flankieren oder Angriffe von Hinten (die nicht parierbar sein dÃ¼rften) haben keine speziellen Auswirkungen
- generell immer noch undurchsichtige und nicht nachvollziehbare Regelmechanik die sich heimlich im Hintergrund verbirgt; die Trefferchancen werden nun zwar angezeigt, aber nicht wie sich diese zusammensetzen (dieser schwerwiegende Punkt zieht sich durch alle FÃ¤higkeiten, Talente und Zauber), ich vermute auch, dass die Regelmechanik nicht wirklich funktioniert, denn die Werte-Angaben und das wirkliche Geschehen unterscheiden sich maÃŸgeblich (vermutlich wird es deshalb verborgen, denn sonst wÃ¼rden noch mehr Unstimmigkeiten auffallen)
- keine sichtbaren KK-ZuschlÃ¤ge, die man sich selbst aus seinem Wege des Schwerts zusammen suchen muss, in der Hoffnung dass wenigstens diese korrekt umgesetzt wurden; man steigert also KK einfach so ohne zu wissen ob man dann einen TP mehr macht (immerhin wird mittlerweile angezeigt wieviele TP durch die hohe KK hinzugekommen sind, aber eben immer noch nicht ab wann fÃ¼r zukÃ¼nftige KK-Steigerungen)
- MR scheint ohne spÃ¼rbare Wirkung zu sein, da selbst Naurim mit MR 15 noch versteinert wird
- zu hohe AE Regeneration, da sogar pro KR (ist DSA untypisch), weshalb man seine Zauberkraft auch nicht mal aufspart, daman nach einigen KR eh wieder voll ist
- zu viele TrÃ¤nke (Heil- und ZaubertrÃ¤nke) im Spiel, die es an jeder StraÃŸenecke zu kaufen gibt, was nicht zu DSA passt, da diese in Aventurien etwas besonderes sind und nicht wie Wasser gesoffen werden (DSA ist kein Diablo)
- keine Alchemie zum selber brauen
- Heilkunde Wunden zu stark (eigentlich heilt man nur die HÃ¤lfte seiner TaP*)
- keine Pflanzen und KrÃ¤uter (wie in Schicksalsklinge HD)
- seltsame Ingame-Ãœberlandkarte auf der auÃŸer den Orten kaum etwas anderes zu erkennen ist; warum hat man hier nicht einfach die sehr detaillieren originalen Karten genutzt?
- Gegner nutzen viel zu hÃ¤ufig Gift, Charaktere sind dadurch andauernd GrÃ¼n, was sehr stÃ¶rend aussieht
- KorspieÃŸ "Aderlasser" hat zu schlechte Werte, dafÃ¼r dass er angeblich aus Schwarzmetall sein soll und zuvor mÃ¼hevoll aus neun Teilen zusammengesucht werden muss...sehr enttÃ¤uschend
- Fallen zum auslegen total unnÃ¶tig
- Wurfwaffen und zumindest ein Teil der Pfeile/Bolzen nach kÃ¤mpfen nicht einsammelbar
- keine unterschiedlichen Roben fÃ¼r Magier (!)
- viel zu wenig RÃ¼stungen fÃ¼r KÃ¤mpfer (Reiterharnisch ist hÃ¤sslich und hat unterirdisch falsche BE Werte)
- zu viele Abenteuerpunkte (AP)
- im Nachhinein verschiebbare AT/PA Verteilung (wodurch man nicht planen muss)
- Echsenlehrer im 5. Kapitel, der einfach alles kann (sehr unpassend)
- wenig stimmungsvolles Ende
- kein Widerspielwert 

[b]FAZIT[/b]

Blackguards 1 ist weder gut noch richtig schlecht. Alles was DSAfremd ist, an diesem Spiel, stÃ¶rt mich aber. Warum benutzt man im Kampf Prozentangaben, von denen niemand weiÃŸ wie diese zustandekommen, anstatt sich einfach ausschlieÃŸlich an die guten alten W20 Angaben zu halten - die jeder DSA-Spieler versteht, und auch fÃ¼r DSA-Neulinge gut nachzuvollziehen wÃ¤ren. Die Entwickler von Daedalic haben nicht nur keine Erfahrung mit Rollenspielen, sondern auch kaum Erfahrung mit der Welt und den Regeln von Aventurien, und das merkt man dem Spiel an. Die RPG-Aspekte kommen bei Blackguards viel zu kurz. Im Grunde geht es fast nur von Kampfbildschirm zu Kampfbildschirm, und im Nachfolger wird das noch schlimmer. Ich kann Blackguards 1 nicht wirklich empfehlen, leider.

Wenn ihr an weiteren Reviews von mir interessiert seid, dann folgt meiner [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10868887-Dark-Chummer%27s-Reviews/?appid=63110]Gruppe[/url].

author: {'steamid': '76561198011333190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2255, 'last_played': 1502901544}
review: They really fucked basic RPG mechanics. Line of sight is the worst I've ever seen in any game and does'nt let do anything. Enemy turn takes hours (especially if there are zombies.) And you will be lucky if your mages are not dead or perma-knockdown before their first turn.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972202331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2475, 'last_played': 1423284850}
review: Forced myself to finish this game. While it hooked me early on, I found the storyline and mechanics to lose their appeal after a while. That's not to say I didn't like the game. I give this game a firm meh. It's a middle of the road game with some nice tactical mechanics and decent storyline, but I can't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009089407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1449612183}
review:
So, Blackguards, eh? Well it is a good idea for a game, but the realisation is missing something.
What could that be?
Well the first impressions were good- the characters have a lot to learn, but somehow for the new players it is unknown could they learn everything, something or just few things? There is no explanation.
The game gives you to chose between 2 options that will define your game- will the main stats of the hero will be automaticaly distrubuted, or you will do everything manualy.
So far for me, my adventure was with 3 heroes, however I was with 2 warriors and a mage. Somehow I did not made a ranger and I found that as a mistake when advansing in the game.
I found myself more frequently repeating and reloading a map to find the best solution to win or get out from combat.
Yes, the combat. 
Well, the combat is Turn Based so you have time to think your strategy, however heroes miss a lot, and sometimes a chance to hit or make a spell of 70%+ is not enough. Every fail punish could punish you really badly.
The maps are not so big, but for that kind of game I guess they are enough, however, for me, they looked someking small.
You could interact with some object in the map or use an object to take a cover from an enemy archer, however, not everytime this thing works. Some archers simply ignore that.
The audio is good. The voice acting is in good level.
The soundtrack is good. I liked it.
I made few side quests, but one of them was really pain in the ass in at the end I even did not finished it. It was horrible. Probably much higher level heroes could do it.
The grapics are nice for the eye.
I did not encounter any bugs, but I can not keep playing the game. It is enough.
So for final- this is avarage turn based strategy with RPG elements, however, there are better ones out there that you can play.
For me- I would not try this game anymore. I really wanted to like it, but I can't give it more time. 4 hours and a little bit more are enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121429906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1449454018}
review: tedioso no lo recomiendo

author: {'steamid': '76561198089943640', 'num_games_owned': 1432, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1449516728}
review:
This is an okay game. Nothing huge but not terrible. It really tests your patience and you will restart battles a lot.

The good of the game is that the gameplay is enjoyable to an extent. It looks amazing and sounds wonderful. Many of the voice acters sound great except the times where they try to fabricate some accents.  Like there is a person you'll meet in the first place to shop at and he is either spanish or french. But all I know if that he meant to say "agility" but he said "agelity." Something small though.

It tests your patience with the battles. See, sometimes some enemies are immune to certain damage. For example, Skeletons are immune to stabbing. Seem obvious right? Well the game never really tells you, if you didn't know other wise then you'd restarting the battle. And the battles are small fights with 3-4 enemies. They take maybe 5-20 Minutes and then give a reward. They are a challenge too. Either I'm bad at this game or they always hit half your person's health while I chip small bits off.

In the end I recomment this game on sale. You can find it enjoyable with the gameplay and design along with problems you need to get used to. Get it for no more than 75% off.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169813455', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1269, 'last_played': 1491242709}
review: great game, if your a fan of turn-based D&D style games you will love this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058380579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1449176986}
review:
This game is the equivalent of Iron Man 3 - plenty of potential, a winning formula but just didnt pull it off where it mattered.

Let me explain..... 
It has a good story that makes you want to invest time to find out what happens to the characters. It has turn based mechanics with lots of flexibility - shall i use the environment to my advantage, shall i switch weapons or shall i just spam the most powerful attack i have (yes. do the latter). Just the WORST thing about the game is when you successfully miss 4 attacks in a row each with a hit chance of 80%. This sort of treachery happens often and really spoils the battle.

The battle map is great and you can easily find your way around the battlefield although in my opinion the user interface is lacking a bit - all the useful buttons are grouped together and are a little bit too small for my liking. You can semi-personalise each character and evolve their skills and attributes to your liking - although unless you want to turn a mage into a bad-boy-brawler (and why the hell would you do that) there isnt that much choice.

All in all it is a better than average game although is only worth buying when on steam sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043777940', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 1484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1281, 'last_played': 1448914885}
review:
This game should be a manual about how to fail a game.

It has been a long time I had not the chance to play a game so frustrating:
- wrong hit percentages (I once missed 99% 3 times in a row and I would say 95% means 70% for them)
- difficulty is scaled not on ennemy becoming stronger but you getting weaker (poison lowering stats, map full of traps) or them becoming more numerous (how great to play a turn based game with 20 ennemies)
- repetitive fights (always the same)
- useless quests (you can forge a 9 element spear which is as good as other one you can find easily)
- mage are useless. You have a low mana pool and will always run out of mana. Mana potions are so expansive you just cannot afford them (but the ennemy can).

This game is just a punition. If you are masochist, go for it. For normal people, it is a waste.
