author: {'steamid': '76561198019334464', 'num_games_owned': 1241, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 1637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1537136493}
review:
[b]Neutral:[/b] There is certainly enough to love in the story and roleplaying of Blackguards, but the combats are pretty painful.  Drawn out mercilessly in some cases and filled with the occasional newbie trap, the tactical combat system is slow, clunky, and makes the game feel like much more of a grind than it needs to.  Nonetheless, a high-production game that is worth picking up on a sale if the slow pace and high micro on the combat isn't something that turns you off (or indeed, appeals to you). 

Read the full review [url=https://www.highlandarrow.com/reviews/191-blackguards.html]here[/url].

author: {'steamid': '76561197970683808', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3044, 'last_played': 1426784513}
review:
Never in my life did I play such a bad designed and awful game. 

While IÂ´m a fan of Das Schwaze Auge /the Dark Eye, I wanted to give it a try. The story was ok, but the gameplay was beyond bad. It doesnÂ´t matter what difficulty level you choose, the bad balancing will do his part. 

What, you maximized your weapon talent and hits on 95%, well the enemy will simply Masterly Dodge 5times in a row. What you got Magical Resitance 20, well the Achaz will still hit you with 100% spell.

Not only that the game speed is very low, some of the level are so bad designed that it will take way too much time to finish it, like a specific Cave level near the end

Then there are some levels like the Nine Hordes, oh how I wish I could punch the responsible person of this ridiculous endfight.

I simply cannot recommend this game, most of the fights were either really boring or setup with some really ridiculous requirements.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975387628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 3236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3236, 'last_played': 1425845775}
review:
I bought this game with a bundle of a lot of games by the same company, and didn't think much of it. I had seen the positive review by TotalBiscuit, but I was not sure I would like the genre.

However, the game surprised me positively. The combat mechanics are well designed and implemented, and it makes the game fun and additive to play. Thanks to this good design, the game doesn't feel repetitive (even though most battles are very similar). It does also help that the battlegrounds are often different and sometimes with additional challenges.

The lack of possibility for level-grinding can make the game sometimes spike in difficult (at one point I was forced to lower the difficulty setting in order to get past one point, as there was no way to level-grind my characters), but for the vast majority of the game the problems arising from this have been largely avoided. (There are many similar tactical games that have no level-grinding where it results in the game being exceedingly difficult, but this game successfully avoids it for the most part.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198037468781', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 11891, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10471, 'last_played': 1426185478}
review:
Difficult game which is reminiscent of tabletop rpgs. The stats and talents are merciless. Keep some saves close, don't expect to do the whole game without dying a few times. There's quite a few surprises. 

I enjoyed it. I can't really find any analogs to this game. It's too rpgesque to be akin to tactical combat, but it's not rpg enough in terms of deciding the fate of your characters to be considered a regular rpg.

Biggest cons:
-loading screens
-Attack/Miss
-Harsh to beginners

author: {'steamid': '76561197975582334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1425773107}
review:
This is possibly the ugliest modern indie game I have had the displeasure of playing in a very long time. Everything from the sound mix to the graphics, down to the skid-mark brown art style. The only reconciliation is that I purchased when it was packaged with other junk and highly discounted. I highly recommend you do some research and watch some videos before buying this. If it wasn't so expensive I'd give this as a gift to people I don't like. It's so bad it makes me want to punch puppies and burn kittens. I mean it is just utterly atrocious. To put all that into context, it should be noted that I enjoy games like NEOScavenger. So yeah, don't buy this game unless your'e a masochist. The only darkness and gritiness here is the quality of development. I'm fairly certain they just dragged their taint accross the keyboard a few times and shipped it as a game.

review:

- Las tiendas son bastante inÃºtiles, termine el juego con miles de monedas de oro, ya que practicamente nunca compraba nada. Las armas y armaduras que venden siempre son iguales o peores que las que llevas.
- El tema del peso (carga) estÃ¡ mal hecho, terminÃ© el juego y a pesar de tener la fuerza de casi todos mis personajes al mÃ¡ximo no podÃ­a llevar nada sin exceder el peso. Solo con las armas y armaduras equipadas ya iba en el lÃ­mite, sin poder llevar armas o armaduras de reserva (se hecha de menos que no haya un baul donde guardar las cosas que no quieres llevar encima).

author: {'steamid': '76561198111263701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1246, 'last_played': 1427151093}
review:
J'aime les T-RPG. J'aime l'Oeil Noir (mÃªme si Ã§a ne me rajeunit pas de repenser aux heures passÃ©es dessus). J'aime bien ce jeu : son ambiance, son gameplay (mÃªme s'ils auraient pu prendre en compte les statistiques d'esquive directement au lieu d'afficher des pourcentages de rÃ©ussite complÃ¨tement erronÃ©s, du coup). Mais non, je ne peux dÃ©cemment pas le conseiller.
Tout simplement parce qu'il est rempli de bugs. Et pas des petits. Des freezes bien gros et bien gras. Depuis le temps que ce jeu est sorti, c'est tout simplement une honte qu'ils n'aient pas Ã©tÃ© corrigÃ©s. Un exemple ? Vous devez aller dans une ville pour remplir une quÃªte. Normal. Classique. Et ben non : freeeeeeeze ! Bon, Ã§a arrive. On recharge sa partie, et on recommence. Freeeeeeeze ! Bon... AprÃ¨s plusieurs essais - recharger une plus ancienne partie par exemple - on (re)recommence. Freeeeeeeeze ! La solution ? Aller ailleurs, et retenter sa chance par le biais d'un autre chemin. Et lÃ , parfois, Ã§a marche. Parfois, il suffit d'acheter quelque chose (n'importe quoi), et miracle, Ã§a marche.
Mais au bout d'un moment, quand vous aurez progressez un peu dans l'aventure, ne vous inquiÃ©tez pas : he will be back ! Freeeeeeeze, c'est tout simplement le boss ultime de ce jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042993595', 'num_games_owned': 348, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 983, 'last_played': 1426351398}
review:
This is not a bad game, and i'd recommend it.

...BUT...
You will enjoy the game if you like the mechanics of Tabletop RPGs, if you are willing to pay attention to everything on the battleground, and if you like games where you have to think before every move.

You won't enjoy the game if you are looking for a simple rpg. 
Or if you don't like complicated skills and traits system.

The game is not perfect, but it's a good game if you like the genre.

The main flaw is the equipment is really weak and almost pointless to change

review:
Antes de comprarlo leÃ­ un montÃ³n de crÃ­ticas negativas sobre el juego, tanto aquÃ­ como en otros sitios web, pero me seguÃ­a llamando mucho la atenciÃ³n asÃ­ que me lo acabe comprando en unas rebajas.

El juego no tienen bugs, puede que al principio pero desde luego ahora no. Hay que ver el historial de combate detallado para ver que es lo que pasa con cada ataque realmente y no fijarse solo en el porcentaje de acierto. El juego es bastante complicado por momentos, sobre todo al principio hasta que consigues equipo y evolucionas a los personajes, con un sistema algo confuso hasta que te hasces con Ã©l y que no te explican en detalle en ningÃºn momento. Es uno de sus puntos buenos el ir descubriendolo tu mismo. La historia es lo suficientemente atrayente como para querer seguir y los combates-puzzles son originales y desafiantes.

No os dejÃ©is llevar por todas las malas crÃ­ticas que se leen y si os llama la atenciÃ³n no dudÃ©is en darle una oportunidad.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989859778', 'num_games_owned': 1840, 'num_reviews': 228, 'playtime_forever': 3839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3839, 'last_played': 1424612267}
review:
Wow, it has been a long time since I played the old "The Dark Eye" - Games. This game brought back some memories.

It has a nice atmosphere and is quite challenging. I really missed the roundbased RPGs, which is, for me atleast, revived in this. Sometimes you have to think ahead, sometimes you can just bully everybody down. Some fights are really stressful, while others are straightforward. The point is that almost no fight is like another one, each requires new tactics and strategies, atleast to a point. Of course you have your base tactics, which, in my case was a mostly ranged combat play style. But pure melee or multiple spellcasters sound interesting too. The good thing is that every character is can mostly do anything, aside the fact that only characters with magic potential can become wizards.

Another interesting thing for was the whole plot. Having played the other TDE games made it easy for me to fit into the world with its twelve gods, its mostly human based civilisation, with much prejudice against other races and of course its bright and wild country side, which makes this world a beautiful place. But the beauty in this is just a mask for all the darker happenings in this world.

All in all, if you love Roundbased Strategy, a good and detailed told story and funny, yet serious, characters, this game is for you. Just bring some time and patience, because the downside of this are the time consuming fights and the kinda missing background story of your secondary characters.

review: This is a very good game, fun to play through and great storyline. Some levels were difficult, but it makes you feel all that more accomplished when you complete it. The only problem was that some of the achievements are glitched and you won't get the achievement even if you do the required task.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004580691', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1417, 'last_played': 1409362981}
review:
It should be noted that I picked up this game in a sale at a discounted price, my opinion is based on me paying about Â£18 for it rather than the full price. I think it is likely that my opinion on this game would change if I had forked out Â£30 for it.

I knew about Daedlic's point and click games like Deponia so I was interested to see what their take on a RPG would be like. As it is something that I almost expect in a RPG nowdays it is important to state that this game is very linear. If you are expecting something like Dragon Age you are going to be very disapointed (to be fair expecting all RPGs to be like Dragon Age will invaribly lead to disappointment). Also I think the game description is a bit misleading, you and your companions do have a slight criminal air about yourselves but at the end of the day it is standard save the world type stuff, nothing too ground breaking.
The game has three main views, the first is the world overview you use for travelling around. This is basically a map type view with marker locations for villages, towns, places of interest etc... To move around you click on where you want to go and jump to that location - so no player controlled wilderness exploration or anything like that. The next view is the "town view". This is pretty much a static view where you can click on characters to buy goods or obtain/advance quests. The final view is the battle view, this is a map split up into small hexagons where the player controlled combat takes place. These battle maps range in size, though none are particularly huge. They consist of different environments and obstacles that sometimes require a change in tactics for some scenarios. Combat is turn based attack and move type stuff with close combat with swords, axes, maces etc..., ranged with bows and crossbows and ranged with magic. The combat can get a bit repetitious but there is enough in there that it does not feel too much a grind.
You get to pick one of three classes for your main character, a mage, a rogue/archer type or a fighter. On levelling up you pick attributes and combat skills and there is the freedom to create hybrid classes by giving your archer some mage abilities for example. I did find though that each class tends to have one particularly powerful skill or skill combo that you will just tend to repeat in combat.
The game itself has a lot of good and bad points, it is quite a mixed bag but there is probably going to be something in there that does end up annoying you, it certainly is not perfect. How much that thing annoys you is probably the defining factor in whether you will ultimately enjoy the game or not. For me it was with the combat, there are some monsters which are only vunerable to one type of damage. However, ahead of the battle you do not necessarily know what type of monster you will be fighting so in my case I frequently had everyone inflicting either piercing or magic damage. That was my best set up given my characters, weapons and prefered skills. However, in some fights monsters will be invulnerable to piercing so you have to quit the game reload and re-equip characters with maces so you can inflict bashing damage. Nothing game breaking but it did really get annoying, you learn pretty early on to have back up weapons handy and make sure your party is at least a bit flexible. You can look on that as somewhat of a positive as my party was really not set up for those particular battles so it did add an extra challenge, making what should have been an easy fight a bit more difficult. I think one other problem that needs highlighting is the party make up. You have a limited number of companions that you can recruit, essentially there is one party for the game. You do not get to deicde if you would rather have a mage or a fighter in your party you get what your are given. I do not want to spoil anything but at some point in the game something happens that means that really to fill a specific gap in your party your main character needs to be a specific class. Luckily I chose this class anyway so it was not a problem in my play through. If I had selected a different class it may have negatively effected my opinion of the game.
On the positive side I liked the story (the ending is a bit meh but nothing too objectionable) and found the characters interesting with some nice back story and different personalities. By the end I found myself invested in the story and felt fairly satisfied with the experience on completion. You do get some "choices with consequences moments" that give you a sense of control over how the story plays out. My play through took me 26 hours and I pretty much did everything quest wise in the game.

I would recommend this game but I did pay about Â£18 for it. if I had paid the full retail price I would probably not recommend it as I think at that price some of the problems I have glossed over would have seemed a lot more annoying. My advice is to pick this up if you see it discounted as on the whole it is a relatively enjoyable experience. However, at full price there a lot better RPGs out there and I would be a lot less forgiving of the game's flaws.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061826908', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1424419319}
review:
A pretty dreadful experience.

Slow-paced and difficult, with too fine a stat/ ability granularity for how clunky and random the tactical combat actually is. The story was ok, just enough to give you a veneer of something to care about, but the beginning crisis was too cheesy and plot-holey, and everything that immediately followed felt really small, unimportant, and aimless. Game difficulty doesn't ramp well... as a starting player I felt always behind the curve, with crappy equipment and not enough gold to do much about it, and I spent more time redoing missions I lost than enjoying any sense of progression or accomplishment. The action wheel adds a lot of friction to the experience... it just took too long to do any action beyond the basic double-click weapon strike. Stores are weird... there's more stuff than I can afford to buy and more stuff available than I would even want, so it's an odd mix of too much/ not enough. As far as your character(s), there are too many skills/ abilities/ talents/ whatever and not enough information on what they are or do or what your starting levels indicate in terms of mastery... just too many knobs on one part of the game and not enough on all the others.

The VO was a nice touch and adds personality. The game looks good, if a bit stodgy.

But it's really just dreadful to play. The user experience just is not polished or satisfying. I like to have a good time, not a frustrating one.

Avoid, go play XCOM or Dragon Age or something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147469502', 'num_games_owned': 453, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 9341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1583983598}
review: Instantly in love with this game.  It took a few battles to get the mechanics down but I didn't feel the learning curve was too stiff.  The story is engaging, the battles are fun and the difficulty scales to stay challenging.  I am glad I got this in a Humble Bundle and would have paid full price for it had I known how good it was.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005087995', 'num_games_owned': 504, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 3120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3099, 'last_played': 1404518843}
review:
Note: While I do recommend the game it's more of a niche, hard core-ish title meant for the more dedicated turn based tactics and rpg fans. 

I read many complaints about the immense difficulty and frustrating rng before playing Blackguards but when I got into it myself I found the complaints to be exaggerated though it's a subjective impression of course. The Dark Eye rpg system can seem strange to those who've never encountered it before and are mostly used to dnd-esque games but if one takes the time to study and understand the stats and skills and plan their characters the game will flow much more smoothly though there are a few missions that can feel overly long and frustrating. 

The most underrated part of Blackguards is the writing I think. While the overarching story is fairly forgettable the characters and their interractions with each other and the world around them are a treat on many occasions and the humor feels fresh and I found it genuinely funny as opposed to meme-ish or pop culture reliant as is often the case. The game setting is gritty and reminiscent of the eastern regions in A Song of Ice and Fire (popularly know as Game of Thrones). It's a place where slavery and blood sports are considered the norm and the Poisoners Guild is the "most respectable" It's a great place for your band of greedy liars, violet thugs, lazy misfits and romantic rogues to have their adventure. I found the English voice acting for the main characters very enjoyable as well. 

I won't go indepth into the gameplay rules since the game is a year old now and there's dozens of reviews and let's plays already. The system isn't perfectly balanced (is it ever?) and certain skills are not so useful to put it midly but it also offers a lot of flexibility in how you build your characters and it's satisfying to see your characters mature into serious ass kickers.

While Blackguards is a bit of a rough diamond I enjoyed my time with it quite a bit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002803441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1512, 'last_played': 1423257864}
review:
Difficult one to call, I think. I was quite hooked over the first 10 hours of gameplay, and the story seemed like it was going places... However after a while I have found the battle-town-battle-town method of progression quite monotonous. 

I enjoy the battle system - but be warned, the amount of misses/parry can become extremely frustrating!

It is a good game. and I am recommending that RPG fans give it a try - but I think it's definitely an acquired taste!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011773013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1424009236}
review:
I did not spend a lot of time playing the game but it was exceedingly hard to get into it due to the bland story.  The characters were very flat and the dialogue was just boring.  There are more than enough tactical rpgs out that I should not be wasting my time on a lifeless one.

The rest of the game (character creation, combat, inventory, etc) was okay but once again nothing that would make it stand out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980786340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1481, 'last_played': 1424058050}
review:
I think this Blackguards has a strong base and may lead to a very good sequel.  The game is flawed though.  For a game that states:

"Your choice of spells, skills and abilities determine your battlefield tactics. Aggressive? Defensive? Tactical? It's your call how to tackle each challenging encounter! "

There is very little choice.  If you want an RPG where you can build your characters and team this is not it.  The game give you a very well defined group to play with.  It makes the game extremely difficult if you do not build your characters to a certain role.  The other characters are far enough down their progression that it makes little to no sense to try and change them.  What is so maddening about this game, is that there is a lot of really cool things you could do.  You are just not able to do them, because they game gates skills, and locks players into roles for you.  If the game just let you have 4-5 characters to build as you see fit it would be far better.  

The story was fine.  The voice acting was ok.  The game is good.  There is no real choice in the game though.  No characters progression choice and no choice in what you do.  That is why the game falls short for me.  It is not worth the full price.  

If you are looking for a decent game that has limited flexibility and is on rails this might be for you.   This game just falls way short of how it is advertized.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010946452', 'num_games_owned': 2426, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1072, 'last_played': 1423734854}
review: I liked the idea behind the story of Blackguards; there aren't enough games out there with 'evil' characters, however this game had a really slow story with frustrating blockages from not being as overpowered as the game expects and no way to 'grind' up the levels.  The middle section of the game was probably the most interesting with its non-linear gameplay, but a slow and boring 8hr lead-up and a slow and boring 4hr let-down of an ending accompanied by its repetitive and repetitive and repetitive fights in between.  The only thing keeping me going was the vague hope that it would get better, or stay as good as the 3rd out of 5th chapter.  Only worth playing if you are *really really* into repetivie turn-based combat

author: {'steamid': '76561198024921869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 3060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2866, 'last_played': 1423416606}
review:
Very enjoyable turn-based strategy game.  Easy to pickup, and a fun cast of characters that make your party. The core storyline is linear, but the battles are incredibly fun.  There is a lot of challenging battles, and plenty of easy battlse without a sweat.  It keeps the game tight toward the battle, because the overmap screen really gives you the chioce of what quests to pickup and what items to purchase, but there is not any unnecessary travel.  Essentially, you fast travel from location to location, and many times entering a battle at the various desitinations. 

There a few main enemies that show up multiple times, and adds to the drama.  However, the story is enjoyable, the battles at the last stage leading to the ultimate battle are quite good, however, the ending is a bit of let down.  However, that doesn't take away from everything they did to make this game awesome. 

If you like controlling your party for turn based D&D battles, you are going to love this game. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198060647227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2062, 'last_played': 1423004670}
review:
Blackguards est un jeu difficile d'entrÃ©e.
J'ai bien failli abandonner dÃ©s les premiers affrontements tant ils m'ont paru difficiles. pourtant le systÃ¨me de combat et les interactions avec l'environnement m'ont sÃ©duits et j'ai donc persistÃ©. Maintenant j'y trouve plus de plaisir.

Le concept est simple : une Ã©quipe de combattants, des adversaires, un Ã©quipement minimaliste et en avant il faut gagner le combat. Parfois la condition de vistoire n'est pas (seulement) de massacrer tout le monde.

C'est un jeu tactique, il ne s'agis pas de bourriner Ã  grand coups d'Ã©pÃ©e et de sorts thÃ©Ã¢traux. Il faut utiliser l'environement, d'abriter organiser les compÃ©tences de chaque personnage etc.

J'ai lu une critique ou le joueur disait qu'il avait parfois l'impression que pour gagner il devais trouver la solution de chaque tableau qu'il n'y avait pas de place Ã  diffÃ©rentes tactiques. C'est un peu vrai, sur certains terrains j'ai eu presque le sentiments d'avoir un puzzle Ã  rÃ©soudre.

L'histoire est suffisamment intÃ©ressante pour qu'on la suive, mais ce n'est pas un jeu narratif et les choix n'impactent pas l'histoire. Jusque lÃ  j'ai perdu un personnage suite Ã  une conversation (et je ne suis mÃªme pas sÃ»r Ã  100% que ce soit liÃ©) et c'est Ã  peu prÃªt le seul Ã©vÃ©nement qui dÃ©coule de mes actes. 

Ne comptez pas non plus avoir des Ã©quipements absurdes qui vous font dire "Hey regarde mon perso, ces Ã©paulettes d'1m50 ont la classe!". Tout est sobre. Personnellement j'apprÃ©cie et c'est rafraÃ®chissant.

L'Ã©volution des personnage est particuliÃ¨re. pas de classe parfaitement dÃ©finie. Tout le monde peut aprendre Ã  manier toutes les armes et la magie. Du coup Ã§a peut paraÃ®tre brouillon. Personnellement j'aime cette libertÃ© mÃªme si au final un mage restera un mage et on ne fera pas de notre guerrier un lanceur de sorts.

Pour conclure, Blackguards est un jeu tactique, de stratÃ©gie qui parfois tire sur le puzzle. C'est sobre, l'arbre de compÃ©tences offre une grande libertÃ© sans limitation par des classes.

J'ai dÃ©plorÃ© le fait qu'on se dÃ©place de combats en combats et en villes sur une carte mais finalement c'est accessoire. 

Un bon jeu, rÃ©servÃ© Ã  ceux qui veulent des challenges tactiques. Et qui n'ont pas peur de recommencer un combat plusieurs fois d'affiler avant de le rÃ©ussir.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009004334', 'num_games_owned': 1017, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 876, 'last_played': 1422819227}
review:
Blackguards has issues. As an avid fan of turn based games, this is severely lacking. Inconsistency is the biggest flaw. The game is seemingly okay for the first few battles however soon after, it quickly becomes a reload and try again, 12-20 times. Go to a prior save, make adjustments and try again. Too often, for instance, my mage character with 80% and above chance to heal fails, too often failure to use the environment will make a battle impossible. Too often your characters will miss leaving foes drooling at another chance to make you reload.
I had high hopes for the game. The menus are not great, the story is rather drab, but it only felt horrible when every map because a reload the game fest. If you're looking for turn based... I HIGHLY suggest looking elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044218087', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4369, 'last_played': 1473382478}
review:
Fast hÃ¤tte ich, aufgrund der vielen negativen Rezesionen, hier, als auch in der einen oder anderen Spielezeitschrift, dieses wunderbare Spiel nicht kennen gelernt.

Wer Aktionrollenspiele mag und sich mit jedem Sieg eine dicke Belohnung erwartet, wird sicherlich enttÃ¤uscht sein. Auch der 'echte' Rollenspieler, der auf eine richtig tiefgrÃ¼ndige Geschichte hofft, wird in Blackquards nicht finden was er sucht, denn all das will dieses Spiel wohl gar nicht sein. Vielmehr ist es eben ein Spiel mit Schwerpunkt auf strategische, rundenbasierende KÃ¤mpfe, eingebettet in einen solide erzÃ¤hlten Hintergrund mit der einen oder anderen MÃ¶glichkeit, Einfluss auf den Spielverlauf zu nehmen. 

Man findet sich wieder, in der wunderbaren Welt des Pen & Paper Rollenspiels 'Das schwarze Auge' die in Ihrem Detailreichtum und ihrer Vielschichtigkeit hier natÃ¼rlich nur hÃ¶chstens ansatzweise dargestellt werden kann. Dennoch erhÃ¤lt man einen kleinen Einblick, ... mehr eine Ahnung... , was man versÃ¤umt wenn man 'DSA' nie wirkich gespielt hat.

Die CharaktÃ¤re sind klassisch. Soll heissen, der Zwerg ist ein Zwerg und verhÃ¤lt sich auch so. Manch einer mag dies negativ, vorhersebar und langweilig finden, ich hatte meine Freude daran und wÃ¤re Ã¼ber alles Andere enttÃ¤uscht gewesen. Auch wenn die Dialoge in den Zwischensequenzen oft nicht die Auswahl bieten die man sich wÃ¼nscht, so musste ich doch oft Ã¼ber die eine oder andere Antwort meiner Protagonisten schmunzeln. 

Die MÃ¶glichkeiten zur Charakterentwicklung wirken auf den ersten Blick recht unÃ¼bersichtlich, doch wenn man einmal das Regelwerk und damit das Kampfsytem verstanden hat, offenbart sich einem die Logik dahinter. Hat man sich dann entschieden, welche Entwicklung der Charakter nehmen soll, ist es aus meiner Sicht kaum noch mÃ¶glich, die gewonnenen Abenteuerpunkte falsch zu verteilen. Auch verringert man durch die richtige Punkteverteilung das so oft kritisierte 'Zufallsprinzip' im Verlaufe des Spieles drastisch. Ein ungeÃ¼bter KÃ¤mpfer trifft eben seltener als ein geÃ¼bter und selbst ein versierter Magier macht hin und wieder einen Fehler. Ich betrachte dies als durchaus realistisch. Zudem erhÃ¤lt es die Spannung, solange es sich in halbwegs glaubwÃ¼dige Grenzen hÃ¤lt.

Die KÃ¤mpfe selbst sind, wie man sie von einem rundenbasierenden Spiel kennt und erwartet. Oft erÃ¶ffnen sich MÃ¶glichkeiten, die Gegebenheiten des Kampfplatzes und die verschiedenen FÃ¤higkeiten seiner Helden effektiv zu nutzen. Auch muss man hin und wieder den einen oder anderen Schalter oder Hebel betÃ¤tigen, um weiter zu kommen. Nicht immer erkennt man dies alles auf Anhieb, deshalb ist oftmaliges Speichern selbstredend Pflicht.

Um nun nicht nochmals zu wiederholen, was meine VorgÃ¤nger schon in oft vortrefflicher Weise geschildert haben komme ich nun zum Fazit:

Blackquards ist ein empfehlenswertes Spiel mit Schwerpunkt auf  rundenbasierende, strategische KÃ¤mpfe. Der 'Rest' ist ein gelungenes, teils sehr liebevoll gestaltetes Ambiente.

Die Charakterentwicklung und das Kampfsytem muss man verstehen um wirklich Spass am Spiel zu haben, ein Blick in's 'Handbuch' mag da eventuell hilfreich sein.

Als negativ empfand ich die etwas lieblos gestaltete Endsequenz und die Tatsache, dass der eine oder andere Ausspruch meiner Helden sich in, auf Dauer recht enervierende Weise, all zu oft wiederholte.

Alles in Allem eine klare Kaufempfehlung. Ich werde Blackquards sicher noch eimal Spielen, denn laut meiner Statistik ist mir doch eine ganze Menge entgangen. Auch auf Blackquards 2 werfe ich schon seit geraumer Zeit ein wohlwollendes Auge.

review: I really liked this game. Fans of xcom won't find it too hard. Make your character an archer/healer since there really isn't another one in the game. For everyone else, specialize, specialize, specialize... Just like any RPG. Lot of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104951146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 6669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6326, 'last_played': 1422531408}
review: I havent had this much fun playing a rpg tactics game since XCOM and Wasteland 2. Story line and voice acting is superb. Gameplay can be quite hard, I had to restart a few times to get my character build right.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976362847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1422506343}
review:
Im going to continue this game because I enjoy it..

But the god. damn. rng. fuck.

Oh what's that?  85% chance to hit?  You miss 3 turns in a row.  Your character is suppose to be a dodgeing machine?  Every enemy hits them.

It's shit like this..  Battles are basically a crapshoot for how it goes, % to hit means nothing.  I've been parried on a 95% chance to hit.  Reaallllyyy frustrating, the developers did a shit job with the combat RNG.

Story seems interesting though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137611607', 'num_games_owned': 823, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2447, 'last_played': 1491089507}
review:
It was one of my favorite games in recent years.
But i can't stand the massive amount of bugs still not fixed so long after release, including in game bugs like dozens achievements not working.
Blackguards 2 just released with day 1 patch fixing game breaking bugs. Seriously?
Adding to all that, that the devs are well known douchebags i had no choice but to give this game a negative.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026319810', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1594412706}
review:
Qu'est ce que Blackguards ?

Eh bien :

- Vous prenez un jeu de la sÃ©rie Drakensang
- Vous enlevez toute la partie exploration isomÃ©trique dans des villes et paysages en 3D pour rajouter Ã  la place une superbe interface digne des derniers jeux flash que l'on peut trouver sur armorgames ou zebest3000.
- Et vous enlevez tous ces autres dÃ©tails qui font le charme d'un bon jeu de rÃ´le : la collecte d'ingrÃ©dients, le craft, les PNJ Ã  profusion etc... 

Vous obtenez Blackguards !

Franchement, autant j'adorais les jeux de rÃ´le au tour Ã  tour (King's Bounty, Heroes of Might and Magic, Dofus... enfin c'Ã©tait avant l'arrivÃ©e de la version 2 !), autant ce jeu a fini de me dÃ©goÃ»ter de ce genre !

Ah oui, j'oubliais, pour compenser le manque de contenu, vous rajoutez une grosse difficultÃ©, hmmm... de la bonne grosse difficultÃ© bien frustrante !

Je n'y ai jouÃ© "que" 4 heures, mais c'Ã©tait 4 heures de pure souffrance... Vous passez des premiers niveaux tranquille, mais vous ne vous rendez pas compte que vous Ãªtes entrain de monter dans la petite camionnette blanche et que vous allez vous faire ... au bout de 2 heures de jeu ! 

Car oui ! Plus vous allez avancer dans ce jeu, plus vous allez tomber sur de l'irrÃ©alisable, des niveaux d'une difficultÃ©... atroce !

Sans rigoler... Trouvez-vous cela normal que dans un niveau, en plus d'avoir une quinzaine de monstres Ã  vaincre (avec 3 personnages...), il y ait des stalactites qui tombent alÃ©atoirement dans un ou plusieurs hexagones, et ce tous les tours, et qui vous tuent en un coup si par malheur, ils touchent l'un de vos personnages ? J'ai rÃ©ussi ce niveau Ã  la 3Ã¨me tentative, mais c'Ã©tait uniquement avec de la chance !

J'ai carrÃ©ment abandonnÃ© Ã  un niveau oÃ¹ il fallait sauver une baronne... Infaisable ! Il faut en 5 tours Ã©liminer (toujours avec 3 personnages...) 6 hommes de main, qui sont Ã  l'autre bout du terrain entrain de vous cribler de flÃ¨ches... et bien entendu, le pont qu'il faut traverser pour venir sur eux est rempli de piÃ¨ges invisibles qui vous font sauter un tour : Evidemment !

Mention spÃ©ciale aux doubleurs (le jeu est en VOST) : Les dialogues et leur voix ne collent absolument pas avec l'ambiance hÃ©roÃ¯que-fantasy du jeu ! (Entre le hÃ©ros principal qui dit "bastard" quand il se fait taper et l'autre PNJ qui te sort des mots anglo-amÃ©ricano-espagnol...)

author: {'steamid': '76561197983929314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 9713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4294, 'last_played': 1504269370}
review:
Bought this on sale, i would say about 40 hours of turn based combat. Perhaps a bit more if you do all side quests and struggle on some fights like i did.

Its not an easy game and there will be battles you will have to do more then a few times to win. The story is a bit linear and battles can be considered a bit repetitive, the bugs with quests seemed fixed since i finished all of them.

But overal i really enjoyed this game and would rate it 75/100.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964214568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 887, 'last_played': 1391451617}
review: If you played the old Fallout series, Divinity and all these round based RPGs and loved them - you will love this game as well. You have a good story and you can literally play for hours without getting bored. Since the game is out since quite a while and it is not that expensive anymore, definitly buy it. For that money you can go watch a movie in the cinema or have endless fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013328690', 'num_games_owned': 680, 'num_reviews': 259, 'playtime_forever': 2176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1956, 'last_played': 1422287099}
review:
Great audio-visual-design, lot's of love when it comes even to small details.
The amazing DSA-ruleset, which is for the RPG-players that love to build their chars and favor depth.
The story is mature, so are chars, yes course there's your usual fantasy-cliche, but there's enough darker, more grown up char-interaction. The english voice-over is amazing and engaging.
Many critics just complain about one fact:
missing spells or attacks

those critics spread a lot of missinformation and if your interested you might want to delv deeper into gamemechanics, the DSA rule-set has shown it's amazing depth already on countless PC-games (Drakensang, the old DSA-trilogy) and some forget nowadays how RPGs can work.
In short
-> under the right circumstance a wizard/witch might fumble his spell
-> rolling a hit (which is symbolized by your hitchance, e.g. 95%) doesn't euqal actualy hittin, your target can still parry, dodge, mitigate the damage...which goes also for your party

All in all Blackguards is a love letter for RPGs fans: deep char-customization, not ur usual "white knightish"-cast, great tactical combat and the list goes on.

must buy

author: {'steamid': '76561197970681902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 778, 'last_played': 1426178138}
review: Un buon gioco, ma sottovalutato. La storia Ã¨ buona, la grafica Ã¨ godibile e il gameplay Ã¨ tutto sommato abbastanza originale rispetto alla maggior parte dei gdr moderni. Tra i contro spiccano alcuni combattimenti veramente frustranti, impossibili da portare a termine se non si sono sviluppati i personaggi in uno dei pochi modi corretti. Questo perchÃ© i punti necessari a sbloccare nuove abilitÃ  e migliorare i propri personaggi sono pochi, e spesso ci si trova in situazioni in cui tutto l'arsenale accumulato nel corso dell'avventura viene tolto al giocatore (laddove non vengono tolti direttamente i personaggi fino ad allora utilizzati). Per il resto Ã¨ davvero un ottimo gdr.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002532000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1422044778}
review:
BLACKGUARDS! 
Wonderful features such as: 
-EXCLUSIVE SUPPORT FOR 16:9 ratio screens, anything else has massive letterbox black bars that ruin immersion!
-Total lack of a 360 degree camera - the visuals might be 3d, but every battle-screen and town is locked to one camera angle!
-Really bad itemization! I made my character a 2-handed sword focused warrior. Turns out 2-handed swords don't exist in the loot tables until the second act (1-2 hours in), holy shit!
-No exploration whatsoever, anywhere that isn't a 2d city is a 2d battle or a load screen. NOTHING IN-BETWEEN.


The only draw of this game is that you play as a group of misfits and bad guys. Except you don't really play as bad guys or misfits at all - in fact, it seems very standard for a fantasy RPG. You are thrown into the utterly predictable universe of The Dark Eye - a German sort of more boring, more cliche version of the already awful pastiche the English world knows as "Forgotten Realms." The entire concept of this game was that you play as the baddies, a somewhat refreshing idea on the extremely tired fantasy adventure. Except you don't - at all. Your character - get ready - wakes up in a prison cell after being tortured, and goes on a mission of revenge against the EVIL badguy with the EVIL artifact. Holy shit, how original. You spend most of your time doing stupid quests like rescuing a damsel in distress and healing the sick. Sorry, what was the title of this game again? Oh, Blackguards? Wait really?

Prepare for a long adventure of boring RNG-decided battles, random and arbitrary interactable objects, and extremely slow loot progression! Repetitive cities, awful dialogue, poor voice acting, and the same 5 load screens 400 times a session. Prepare to reload your game over and over again as your sound strategy falls apart as your heroes miss consistently despite an 85% chance to hit and your mages fizzle their spells due to the shitty standard build that the developers gave them!

I don't even know what else to say about this game. It's an embarassment and a total waste of money. Luckily I got it as part of an inexpensive humble bundle, otherwise I'd be a bit more frustrated. Goddamnit just don't buy it. And probably don't buy the second one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014447387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3298, 'last_played': 1494695855}
review:
I got this game during the humble bundle that was put up a few months ago, so I'm writing this review accordingly. In other words, if I had bought this game at the full price tag of $39.99, I'd probably be more inclined to hit "Not Recommended". But on sale, I think it's a good game that will definitely keep you playing for a couple of hours at a time if you don't have high standards of character. That being said, you will probably not be interested enough to keep playing this on a binge where you spend hours on end.

The tactics style gameplay is pretty neato. That's... about all I can say about that part of the game. It doesn't really add anything to it or really borrow from some more advanced takes on it like XCOM: You've got area-of-effect attacks, you've to melee attacks, you've got ranged attacks. Don't expect to have any innovative takes on cover-combat, field of vision, and so on. 

The characters are decent. Not really involved enough that I'd say I particularly cared about any of them one way or another, but not bland enough that I wasn't at least interested in seeing where they fit in the story. The character you kind of play as doesn't seem to really have a major stance on anything minus how you decide to direct his dialogue, but it's one of those games where you're kind of your own guy and you kind of aren't. 

There's a lot of good side quests here and there that you are definitely going to want to do to keep yourself armed and leveled for the main questline.
As for the main questline itself, there's really nothing that much to it. The game tries to differentiate itself from other RPG-style adventure games by having the cast of characters be completely unlikely heroes. You, the main character, find yourself traveling with two fellows (a stereotypical and somewhat superstitious dwarf and a casanova mage) who collectively break out of a prison. From there, your party's membership includes a drug-addict elf whose pretty good with a bow (I think she's an elf at least. She's got the ears), a tribal dude who was ready to kick your ass before, and a childhood friend who ended up becoming an (alleged) nymphomaniac witch. 
This seems like an interesting premise on the surface, but the game doesn't really apply itself that well. We don't really get much in on the character's pasts, and the interactions with the main character and the story are very limited. For a game that could've very well built onto a unique premise worthy enough of it being a constantly talked about title, the developers didn't really do much to apply themselves here, and I'm afraid that might still be the case for the sequel, Blackguards 2 as well (I haven't played it yet, so I won't judge).

So basically, this game is good if it's on a really, really good sale and you're already into fantasy and tactical games, but aren't looking for anything too innovative on either ends.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999130881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 2052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2052, 'last_played': 1406136750}
review:
There are bunch of reasons I won't going to recommend this game, it's playble and good at some sides, but: 
Some time ago when it came out it was unfairly overpriced and bugged. Time is passed bugs may be fixed but price are still unfair, but you can avoid it during sales and discounts. 
Also it's almost linear and you don't have any real or illusory freedom, optional side quests are mostly required to be completed, otherwise you are going to suck hard without your extra XP and loot, are they really optional?
RPG system and combat touching for a first time, but in the middle of the game you are getting extremely bored of nothing new and doing the same things till the end of the game, watching the storyline which can give some fresh feelings. Personalities of your teammates can give a fresh air too, but it's not enought to be impressed for such a price.
There are not so many useful charcter builds that can help you to variate your game, time would pass and you would realise a few efficient builds to play through game and after that you won't want to replay it at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053070206', 'num_games_owned': 9975, 'num_reviews': 267, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1561705845}
review:
This game have too much variables that it's confusing.
It really is a hard game because of that. You have to consider every step carefully. One wrong move and you can end up GAME OVER. Always save your game after battles.
Characters attribute vary through Base Values, Weapon Talents, Talents, Spells, and Special Abilities.
The environment also play a huge role in the battlefield.

As for the story this game, it's a plain linear story, not like what I expected from Daedalic Entertainment.
They usually managed to pull out a great plot but not with this game.

Well, I recommend this game if you're up to challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960746459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 2404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2037, 'last_played': 1422601054}
review: A well done, to-the-point turn based combat game.  Solid strategic battles with just enough exploration and story to keep you going.  Combat objectives vary a fair amount to keep the battles interesting.  Would definitely recommend

author: {'steamid': '76561198028931964', 'num_games_owned': 5373, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 919, 'last_played': 1421673992}
review: I like Daedalic games, especially adventures, but I cannot recommend this one. The game is not so bad per se, but there are much better games in the similar genre. Battle is too dependent on RNG, and the story is just fantasy cliche and is very linear. If you want to play interesting RPG/TBS combo, you better try Expeditions: Conquistador - it's cheaper and more interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993025077', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2744, 'last_played': 1421781285}
review: Incerdibly annoying game. Tends to cheat whenever it can. I suppose the game's dice-rolling system might be a bit f.cked up. It's very frustrating that any slomo zombie can outrun almost any of my heroes, and the enemy's self healing is somewhat miraculous as well. Makes no sense to reduce the spellcasting chances of higher level spells either since any casting chance under 90% is hopeless. (Not to mention the hit chance with weapons.) The game is average in itself but way below expectations because of these 'rules'. Would not recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968254063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1388715969}
review: My brother gave me this game or I wouldn't have gotten it. I am not a fan of strategy RPGs as it slows down the combat so much. Honestly, that held me back from liking any of it as combat is such a focus. Also, the pie-UI was a bit difficult to read.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994089799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 3189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3014, 'last_played': 1430227072}
review:
Un ottimo gioco di ruolo a turni su griglia esagonale in cui controllerete fino a 5 personaggi. Uno sarÃ  il vostro main, che vi consiglio caldamente di crearvi da soli e altri 4 saranno dei compagni che troverete durante la trama. Il sistema di combattimento Ã¨ molto divertente e benchÃ© non sia immediato capire le regole, con un minimo di lettura del regolamento fornito dalle info in gioco Ã¨ possibile capire tutto anche se non si conosce il gioco cartaceo su cui si basa.

Ãˆ incentrato al 90% sui combattimenti e la storia Ã¨ ridotta all'osso. Anche girare in cittÃ  Ã¨ visualizzato tutto a schema di dove volete andare a con quali png potete parlare. Un ottimo punto a favore se siete in cerca di botte e solo le nozioni chiave che vi servono per proseguire con la trama, cosÃ¬ come puÃ² essere un punto a sfavore se volete trama deepshit impegnativa. In quest'ultimo caso, semplicemente, non cercatevi un rpg occidentale. 

Punto di forza Ã¨ l'uso del campo di battaglia e la strategia che si dovrÃ  utilizzare e che varierÃ  per ogni diverso scenario. A difficoltÃ  normale giÃ  dÃ  del filo da torcere e capiterÃ  di dover ricaricare saltuariamente.
Consigliato l'acquisto, se vi soddisfano i punti specificati sopra e una 40ina-50ina ore di gioco per meno di 10 euro se lo comprate dai giusti reseller ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198070492441', 'num_games_owned': 1800, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1421687336}

Blackguards will take you to the deepest depths of the RNG hell.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961745037', 'num_games_owned': 1872, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1421743026}
review: There is a LOT of good here... but the bad casts long shadows... sadly, the equipment seems very convoluted, everything is just kind of... loosely bound together, and the story is very slow to get going, along with being a little... unengaging. I really want to love it, but I can't give it more than a... 6.5/10. The equipment system is just so ill explained. With quite a few hours in, I STILL don't under what equipment is better and how. I got it as part of a bundle so take this review for what its worth. I probably paid about $1 for this game and I'm still kind of... meh, about it. BUT I'm holding out hope, still putting time into it, maybe it'll hook me soon...

author: {'steamid': '76561197993029077', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1421623780}
review:
With the popularity of Dark Souls at the moment, difficulty seems to be the buzzword of the industry. This can be a great boon and imbues games with a sense of accomplishment and worth when done correctly. Blackguards seems difficult for all the wrong reasons, from an obtuse user interface to mindbogglingly poorly designed stats pages. 
While I appreciate that any game coming from an existing Pen and Paper world will always have a higher step up for the user than most, Shadowrun earlier last year seemed to create a system both faithful and functional while Blackguards seemed bogged down in it's own mechanics.
The story is about par for course and the voice acting is quite refreshing, but it just seems like the clunky mechanics just get in the way of that experience and the difficulty wildly differs so much you bound between feeling elated and cheated every few minutes.
While people howl off the rooftops at the percieved "dumbing down" of videogames, sometimes it has a point. Parts of the design feel snobbish, as if it wants to pat it's faithful on the back and tell them how smart and clever they are while with the other hand swatting away the "casual, filthy masses". Blackguards needs to get down of it's high horse and reduce the barriers to entry that stop it from being the good game I know underneath is has the potential to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038669516', 'num_games_owned': 1842, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 609, 'last_played': 1421529394}
review:
El juego es bastante entretenido, no tiene unos graficos impresionantes ni un sistema de combate muy dinamico pero lo compensa con una historia que, si bien no parece nada del otro mundo al inicio, consigue enganchar a medida que va progresando (lo cual no es extraÃ±o viniendo de Daedalic ya que son expertos en aventuras graficas y, por lo tanto, en contar historias).

Es un juego complicado al inicio, se nos van explicando todos los parametros de forma tediosa pero es mucho mejor aprender el sistema por uno mismo, esto es, jugando y jugando. Una vez avanza un poco el juego, obtenemos mas personajes para el grupo y tenemos algo de libertad nos aparece un mundo extenso, lleno de misiones secundarias y lugares que visitar (todo muy automatizado, eso si), siendo entonces cuando empieza a entretener.

Sin embargo, el motivo por el que me resigno a seguir jugandolo es solo uno: los bugs. Me he acabado cansando de repetir la misma mision una y otra vez porque aparece un bug que me la jode y me imposibilita poder continuarla. Hablo de estar durante un combate y, bugs de la camara aparte (que tambien lo hay pero se puede soportar), desaparecer un personaje repentinamente que provoca que no puedas mover al resto de tus guerreros y tengas que quedarte viendo como mueren... y eso repetidas veces en el mismo escenario, con distintos personajes y sin posibilidad de hacer nada.

Quitando esos fallos (que a estas alturas dudo que solucionen), el juego habria sido muy disfrutable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991888468', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2177, 'last_played': 1404346821}
review: This game got my attention with the hex grid and turn based strategy.  Interactive fighting environments brought tons of potential in being a great strategy game.  In the end this game fell short on every level.  It was a real bust.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047210200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1421406660}
review:
I don't get it why its size is 17 GB, cause the graphics are far from sophisticated. And I don't get it why its price is so high, cause its gameplay is mediocre at best.

There's one basic, huge condition that could "make or break" when it comes to turn-based combats: don't let the random factor be too important. That's the same hugely important condition this game failes completely to fulfill. It says 95% yet it feel like 50, and when it says 90%... well, you'd better skip it, you're screwed anyway. Using the "try again" button a couple of times after some lost battles proved nothing but the fact that random is all that matters. Only based on random I nearly won, I clearly won, or I badly lost the very same battles. Only based on randomness, and not on the decisions I made. And that's simply not Ok.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986581714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1419016309}
review:
[b][FranÃ§ais][/b] Ce jeu est propre et la mÃ©canique de combat est intÃ©ressante. Pour une personne qui recherche uniquement de la stratÃ©gie en tour par tour, il y a un potentiel vÃ©ritable.

Personnellement, je suis assez bon public en matiÃ¨re de jeu. Toutefois, j'attache beaucoup d'importance Ã  l'aspect JDR. Je trouve que les combats ici sont trop rÃ©pÃ©titifs... Or c'est tout ce qu'il y a : des combats. Le mode opÃ©ratoire est : lecture / combat/ combat / ravitaillement / Ã©quipement /combat / lecture / combat / combat / Etc. J'ai Ã©tÃ© incapable de m'immerger dans l'univers et l'histoire du jeu. De plus, comme beaucoup d'autres l'ont indiquÃ©, les pourcentages de rÃ©ussites des actions sont complÃ¨tement erronÃ©s, ce qui gÃ©nÃ¨re une frustration Ã©norme et diminue grandement l'aspect stratÃ©gique.

Je n'ai rÃ©ussi Ã  jouer que 2 heures. Mon avis est donc trÃ¨s subjectif et correspond Ã  une vÃ©ritable difficultÃ© d'immersion et un sentiment de frustration et d'ennui apparu rapidement. Je pense qu'il faut avant tout rechercher du combat en tour par tour pour apprÃ©cier ce jeu, l'aspect JDR Ã©tant grandement minimisÃ©, selon moi.

[b][English][/b] This game is clean and the fighting mechanics are interesting. For people who seek only the turn-based strategy, there is a real potential.

Personally, I'm pretty good audience for games. However, I attach great importance to the RPG part. I find that the fighting here are too repetitive ... But this is all there is: fighting. The procedure is: read / fight / fight / shop / equipment / fight / read / fight / fight / Etc. I wasn't able to immerse myself in the universe and the history of the game. In addition, as many others have said, the percentages of shoot's success are completely erroneous, generating enormous frustration and greatly reducing the strategic aspect.

I have managed to play only 2 hours. So, my opinion is very subjective and corresponds to a real difficulty of immersion and a fast feeling of frustration and boredom . I think you must first seek the combat turn-based to enjoy this game, the RPG aspect being greatly minimized, in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052369785', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5815, 'last_played': 1707606080}
review:
[h1]Blackguards by Daedalic - A promising game with some annoying flaws[/h1]

I've spent 112 hours meticulously stripping down every area, every character and every side quest I could find during my first (and so far only) playthrough of this game. For the record, I'm a seasoned RPG-player and accustomed to the old-school turn based games.

Short version: Blkackguards is an average game which could have been a lot better without some of the bugs and a more intuitively developed story engine.

For those of you who remember the glory days of the genre with Baldur's Gate I and II, IceWind Dale amongst others, Blackguars might still be worth looking into. I enjoyed playing it, but I would also like to post a warning about some of things that knocked down the total score for me:

[olist]
[*]The main plot is... kinda slow. And dull. I actually enjoyed several of the side-quests a lot more than the main story. The ending is very dissapointing (and without giving any spoilers, that is an understatement). I also missed having background stories unfold for the main characters, but perhaps Daedalic are saving those for the sequel(?). 

[*]Several achievements are (still) bugged. 5 of them simply can't be completed at all (confirmed by the steam community) but I've had a total of 6-7 that bugged in my game. It's been more than a year since these bugs were first reported and the steam forums have had no response from the developers yet. Like I just mentioned above, they are currently developing a sequel to Blackguards, so chances are that these bugs might never be fixed. Hence: be warned if you're one of those players (like me) who wants to cross off every achievement from the list. For future reference: I have not bought or played the DLC. 

[*]Some of the game mechanics are not explained (at all) in the manual and I had to scavenge the steam forums to see if they actually worked or not. Armor is perhaps the most obvious aspect, where players have no way of telling if the armor skills makes any difference or if the character is encumbered (and if so, what penalties to expect in battles).

[*]An abundance of spells and skills makes things look very promising at first glance, but in reality, most of them are pretty much useless. Even when taking in account different preferations/play styles, at least 50% of the spells are likely to never be used by any player. Unfortunately, that goes for weapon types, talents and weapon skills as well. I can't shake the feeling that these worthless skills where put only there for marketing purposes rather than adding flavour to the game. It's either that, or Daedalic simply ran out of time/funds and had to release the game without proper (re)balancing tests.

[*]Although you are frequently presented with alternatives and choices in NPC dialogues, it rarely matters what you choose. I guess you could say that they are there to add some RP, but even so it could have been handled with more finesse. Instead you're bound to a main plot that you have no chance of altering the outcome of. 

[*]I really don't want to spoil anything for you, but a frequent bother is when the game removes one ore more of your followers (and sometimes even your main character) without warning. A new player might have to start from scratch halfway through the game. Hint: make sure that your main character is at least somewhat decent in ranged combat.

[*]The 20th time the game presents you with two choices where one gives you a handsome reward (typically the "evil" aligned choice) while the other leaves you empty handed you can't help but wonder why? Most players expect good deeds to add up to some kind of greater reward later on. In my personal opinion, this is perhaps the single biggest flaw Blackguards has, and it feels like the developers rushed the story instead of taking time to plot out great stories. Let me underline that I don't think that "good" alignment should be favoured in any way. The rewards doesn't have to be better gear or more gold, it could for example be new dialogues/NPC's that are unlocked at some point further down the line. For a game that relies so heavily on RPG stereotypes it's dissapointing that karma is pretty much non-existant in Blackguards, And yet, [i]sometimes[/i] the choices you make are actually so important that it could warrant starting over from the beginning. I would advice all new players to SAVE, SAVE and SAVE their game as often as possible. Think of Blackguards as a Bethesda title in that aspect.
[/olist]

With the bad stuff out of the way, let's round things up with the more positive aspects of Blackguards: 

it's an ambitious attempt at rebooting the genre (yes, I'm aware that there are several other similar games on the market nowdays) based on a popular tabletop theme. The graphics are decent and the voice acting is top notch.

Currently priced at â‚¬39.99, I'd recommend potential customers to wait for one of the steam sales before buying. For that kind of money you'll likely to find plenty of better alternatives. Personally I bought it in a [url=http://store.steampowered.com/search/?developer=Daedalic%20Entertainment]Daedalic[/url] bundle and 120 hours of gameplay is more than I expect to get from most titles these days.

[b]All in all I'd score Blackguards a somewhere between 6 and 7 out of 10.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197967506964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1420866165}
review:
Why do I keep buying games that use the TDE (Dark Eye) game rules?  They're ALWAYS SHIT.  ALWAYS.   Demonicon?  Shit.  Drakensang?  Shit.  Drakensang 2? Shit.  This game?  SHIT.   Whatever positives this turnbased rpg has, they're completely negated by the unrelenting terribleness of TDE as game rules.   

If you have no idea what I'm ranting about, imagine picking up Baldur's Gate 2 without ever playing D&D 2nd ed before.   What armor class is better?  What's a save vs. death compared to a save vs. spell?   Multiply all that by 3000x.  That's The Dark Eye.  

It was made by Germans who hate you.   And that's why.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989339658', 'num_games_owned': 1645, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1419630880}
review:
Overall it seemed like an interesting game.
The combat is what I dig for and the huge charactercustomization is just the thing I like.

But it pains me how the companion are handled.
Basically every other character than your main/self-created-one has predetermined stats, which cannot be reset.
So you're more or less stuck with what the game gives you, instead of developing the team that you want to play.
You can also lose companions midway through the game, for the sake of the story, which makes it even harder to have complete control over your team.

The story seems decent and the combat is okay, but It would have been better just giving us overall predetermined characters, included our starting one, and make it fit the overall game, if the story was that important.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960712217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1412843809}

author: {'steamid': '76561198051262673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1469, 'last_played': 1455061692}
review:
Zum Zeitpunkt meines Reviews bin ich mitten in Kapitel 2.

Blackguards zÃ¤hle ich eher zu den Rundenbasierenden Strategiespielen mit sehr starken RPG Elementen.
Im Endeffekt ist es eine Aneinanderreihung verschiedener Kampfmissionen, wÃ¤hrend dazwischen die Story vorangetrieben wird und man seine Chars ausrÃ¼sten und weiterentwickeln kann. Nebenquests mÃ¼nden in zusÃ¤tzlichen Kampfmissionen.
Wer stark verzweigte Dialogoptionen erwartet, wird enttÃ¤uscht werden. Der Schwerpunkt liegt ganz klar auf den KÃ¤mpfen.

Ich selbst spiel das Game auf schwer und hab erst bei einer Mission knapp ein Dutzend AnlÃ¤ufe gebraucht. (Eigener Char ist eine Kriegerin; normal mode Erstellung) Deshalb kann ich den Kritikpunkt bezÃ¼glich des zu hohen allgemeinen Schwierigkeitsgrades nicht nachvollziehen.

Ein SchlÃ¼sselpunkt zum Erfolg ist die AusnÃ¼tzung der Map-Eigenschaften, wie Fallen, PfÃ¼tzen, Kisten, etc... Hierbei ist allerdings anzumerken, dass diverse Wirkungsweisen am Anfang nicht klar ersichtlich sind und es einiges an Trial & Errror braucht. Ebenso sollte man sich die Missionsziele immer vor Augen halten, da APs durch erfolgreiches AbschlieÃŸen von Missionen erlangt werden.

-->Kritikpunkte bleiben fÃ¼r mich die etwas unÃ¼bersichtliche Darstellung der Itemeigenschaften. Hier braucht man ein bisschen Zeit um sich zurechtzufinden. 
-->Die Gegner-KI ist eher schwach, was manchmal zu fragwÃ¼rdigen Entscheidungen fÃ¼hrt. 
-->Die Berechnung der Trefferwahrscheinlichkeiten ist ab und an schwer nachzuvollziehen. Ich selbst hab es schon ein paar Mal erlebt, dass selbst eine 100%ige Trefferwahrscheinlichkeit zu einem Fehlangriff fÃ¼hrt. Ein Treffer kann des Ã¶fteren zwischen Erfolg und Misserfolg einer Mission entscheiden.
-->Auch ist das Spiel schon 2x zwischen Missionen einfach hÃ¤ngen geblieben, was aufgrund der Autosave-Funktion nach jedem Kampf jetzt nicht so sehr in Frustmomenten gemÃ¼ndet hat.
--> User Interface gefÃ¤llt mir nur bedingt. Es ist schon so oft vorgekommen, dass sich mein "Heiler" selbst anstatt den verletzten Krieger geheilt hat. Alles, weil ich mit der rechten Maustaste auf den Heiler geklickt hab um den Zauber auszuwÃ¤hlen. Ist man halt von anderen Games so gewÃ¶hnt.
--> Grafik erfÃ¼llt ihren Zweck. Wobei man ehrlich sagen muss, dass Neverwinter Nights 2 aus dem Jahre 2004 wahrscheinlich besser aussieht.
--> Die Synchronstimmen sind OK, wobei es sich manchmal sonderbar anhÃ¶rt, wenn von einem "MÃ¼tterchen" die Rede ist und diese mit einer sÃ¼ssen mit-zwanziger Stimme trÃ¤llert. Die MÃ¼tterchen in diesem Zeitalter waren zwar schon jung, aber trotzdem... 

Ich spiele im Gegensatz zu ziemlich allen anderen meiner Games Ã¼brigens auf deutsch. Deutsche Filme schaut man auch nicht auf Englisch, genauso verhÃ¤lt es sich mit deutschen Games. Es geht doch einiges an Dialogwitz bei der Synchronisation verloren.

Wieso ich das Spiel trotzdem empfehle? Weil es mir Spass macht, und sich die Frustmomente in Grenzen halten. FÃ¼r "TÃ¼ftler" wie mich, die sich fÃ¼r SpielzÃ¼ge Zeit nehmen und etwas durchplanen ist das Spiel wirklich nett. Man freut sich einfach wenn ein Plan aufgeht. Selbst wenn er aufgrund verfehlter Angriffsaktionen 4 oder 5 AnlÃ¤ufe gebraucht hat. Der Preis von knapp 40â‚¬ ist allerdings etwas happig, so ehrlich muss man sein.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075849015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 244, 'playtime_forever': 704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1420753696}
review:
Divinity: Original Sin ..als ALPHA ..Grafikengine durch Standbilder ersetzt 
.. und alles viel schlechter (Bedienung, Story, Kampfsystem, usw..)

Bei weitem schlechtestes DSA Spiel seit langem:

-keine freie Welt, nur ca 200 Screens
-sehr linear
-Story ist MittelmaÃŸ, viele KlischÃ©es
-sehr knackiger Einstieg!! die BosskÃ¤mpfe sind fÃ¼r AnfÃ¤nger deutlich zu schwer auf "normal"
-pauschale EXP pro Karte
-der Loot ist mies
-Gute Waffen mÃ¼ssen gekauft werden
-RÃ¼stungen, grad fÃ¼r Magier gibt es kaum (wird schwer die Sets zusammen zu bekommen) 
-Viele wichtige Trainer werdet ihr in den ersten Stunden nicht finden!
-Dementsprechend fehlen grad fÃ¼r die Begleiter einige Upgrades, weil ihr die EP nicht so investieren kÃ¶nnt wie ihr wollt ;(
-Absolute Katastrophe ist der Magier.. unbedingter RAT: alle ZaubersprÃ¼che bei Freier Charaktererstellung kaufen
-Magie insgesamt ist in den ersten Stunden fast unbenutzbar, inbesondere AoE.. zu hohe AP Kosten.. und dafÃ¼r zu wenig Bumms.. schlieÃŸlich ist man nach 2-3 Zaubern der Stufe 2 oder 3 leer (oom) .. ansonsten gibt es noch die %Castchance der ZaubersprÃ¼che.. selbst bei 60-70% fizzelt der Spruch 3/4 Mal.. dh euer Held/Begleiter verschwendet seinen kompletten ZUG fÃ¼r jawohl NIX!!
-Die KÃ¤mpfe waren kaum besser als bei Schatten Ã¼ber Riva.. nur eben HD.. eigentlich sogar schlechter, denn Riva hatte eine Handlung und es machte SpaÃŸ.. so vor 1-2Dekaden^^

FAZIT: Unterm Strich zerstÃ¶ren diese Fakten den flÃ¼ssigen Eindruck einer DSA Spielwelt im SÃ¼den
Das lineare System tut ein Ãœbriges.. denn wenn bestimmte Quests (Bosse tÃ¶ten) nicht erledigt werden, gehts nicht weiter!! Manche Bosse (zB Drache) kann man anfangs gar nicht besiegen.. und so zieht es sich fort.
Also noch 8-10Std spielt es sich dann wirklich wie ein Krampf.. nee danke, so nicht!

->Wird wohl lÃ¤nger dauern bis wieder etwas Ã¡ la "Demonicon" kommt.. sehr schade ;(

author: {'steamid': '76561198067289563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5681, 'last_played': 1706147191}
review:
I really tried to like this game, in spite of reading very mixed reviews. Alas, I ended up quite frustrated with a few aspects that are quite game (and immersion) breaking:
1. losing vital companions at crucial times makes party build options very limited. Essentially, once you figure out what will happen to X, you need to rethink your entire strategy for party build. This sometimes means restarting from scratch, or a very earlier save, as party build is very important in some of the encounters (especially the main ones)
2. lack of clothing for non-metal wearing characters - while there are several pretty good sets of armour for warriors, the (complete) lack of mage oriented outfits is a bit mind baffling. I could not fathom that no mage outfits EVER dropped, although you battle many mages wearing unique outfits. And none can be bought. As a consequence, you mage characters have to either wear horrible looking leather armour, or spend a lot of time buffing/running/dying. This is also important for...
3. almost 100% spell failure when wearing metal armour. I can accept offensive spells (cast outward) failing, but having a healing/self-buff spell have a <25% of success is nonsense. So playing as a battle mage/arcane warrior/cleric type role is pretty much out of the question
4. tedious battles - which can go on for a long time, with a lot of time sitting, and staring at the screen while seemingly endless hordes of critters/monsters/lice/etc. go thought their turns. Even tentacles get their own turns, and usually have a higher initiative than your party...
5. endgame decision disasters - going back to #1 - at the end game you find out that you are 'supposed to' have made certain vital conversation decisions with one companion, otherwise they will be lost, which as mentioned before, can be a disaster for the party.

So, if you want to play this:
a) read the guides and build a cooky cutter type that the developers had in mind, and
b) follow a pro-forma discussion template to placate one party member, or lose them at a crucial stage (or build with their loss in mind)
c) have a good book/magazine handy to read during battles, as you otherwise stare at the screen waiting endlessly

Pity, had potential

author: {'steamid': '76561198000739473', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 675, 'last_played': 1420579459}
review:
I decided to give this game a go and said to myself "I'm gonna finish this one"...oh, how I was wrong. The world is interesting, but it gets lost when you fight very samey enemies all the time. Story could be interesting if characters wouldn't change their motivation every now and then, yet they keep being predictable. Also the world is very limited to a 1-3 screens per town.
Battles could be fun - the system has some neat ideas, enviroment has traps and cool strategic placements, but you very rarely get to use that, since you have to attack or you get surrounded and can't move. 

But the major flaw is that the game FEELS UNFAIR all the time (even when maybe it is not really). Instead of making battles interesting, the game more than once takes your whole inventory and offers you bad equipment in exchange, then you have to battle and find out that enemies in that arena are better equipped than you.
Attack chances are random at best  (a number like 90% chance don't mean anything in this game). Damage you inflict is always small unless your character has fully invested in one weapon skill (which I had to change for one character because it had the same setup as my main character and then spent many hours inflicting 3x less damage than the enemies). 
The whole unfairness also applies to experience point requirements - some skills seem very out of reach (I can see the options ahead, but what I can actually afford/choose is 1-2 options and get stuck with that for hours). "Special" attacks make very little difference most of the time and are in no way interesting.
