author: {'steamid': '76561198049245659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 2838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2752, 'last_played': 1420283948}
review:
Blackguards is an tactical turn-based RPG game that brings some new soultions and points of view to the table, that are not always good.

(New feature - Simple city interface.)
If you remember Drakensang, Dragon Age or most other RPGs cities, large, vast, many NPCs, a lot of chests to look and barrels to smash for loot. Nothing like that in Blackguards. City is a simple one screen view with most important NPCs, merchant, healer, trainer, quest giver, tavern, the end. If you have business in the city it takes you about a minute to get it done and leave to get back to action. Some might like it, some might not. I like it, as it saves time, no more need to remember where was that cool merchant or a hidden pass etc.

So you may wonder how does this tactical turn base combat looks like.
(Character summary)
Before we get there you must know that Blackguards are based on The Dark Eye RPG pen and paper system. And character development is very much like in the pen and paper game. If you played Drakensangs before you will be very familiar with the system. 
In most RPG games you have classes to select. There are no classes in this game. When creating character you select if you wanna be spell-casting able or not and then you build character on skills/spells you chose. In that this system is similar to Elder Scrolls. If you wanna be a warrior you can be a warrior, if you wanna be a warrior-priest you can be warrior-priest it's all based on how to chose your skills, not limited by class.
So characters have attribiutes that calculate their base stats like vitality, astral points (manna), base attack, dodge and parry. Attriubutes cost a lot of adventure points to raise. By chosing how to spend attribiutes you craft base for your character, if you invest heavy into strength, agility, courage and constitiution you will end up with a fighter with almost no chance to cast any spell. If you go for intuition, cleverness and charisma you will end up with solid base for mage with poor fighting abilities. You can also walk the path of average, but you must be careful and just select few spells and weapons to invest in those heavy.
Keep in mind that mages are limited by metalic armor - they will not regenerate astral points while wearing even a single piece of it and will have negative casting modifier, so a melee mage is a hard to play, but possible with correct spell investment.
Then are the skills. Skills are divided into weapons, talents (perception, traps etc) and spells. And in that game every weapon is another skills, so if your character is an expert swordsman (18 swordsmanship skill), when he will be forced to use an axe, he will be very poor with ti because he has no skill in axe, he will have very small chance to hit and large to be hit by enemies.
Skills make your characters use stuff. Skills are rated from 0-18. Spells and talents unlock bonusses at 8,13,18 levels. Here you choce which spells your character can cast and weapons to use.
At the end are special abilities - special attacks for melees, ranged and boosts for mages.
The better the special attack the harder it is to hit with it.
Original pen and paper game used three 20 side dices for skill tests, to make it computer game, devs changed that into % chance. So unlike dragon age it is not enough to unlock a spell to cast it, you must unlock the spell and invest points into it.
(Note on spells)
For me spells in this game are net design to be used mainly at blunt offensive magic. Spells play a support role in this game. You can cast offensive spells and they will do a lot of damage, however doing so will deplete your astral points in two shots so after your mage will not be able to do anything else than bash stuff with his staff.
(Note on weapons)
I really love games which make using axe different than using a sword for example. Blackguards is such a game.Every weapon type has it damage type (piercing for spears and fancing weapons, slashing for swords and blunt for maces). Every weapon type also uses a different skill. So if you wanna use few different weapons you must spend points on different skills. Different weapons also have different special attacks, you cannot make armor ignoring attack with maces, but you can make attack that tripples the damage with them.

(Combat)
Having explained the above. Combat is turn based in which your heros and enemies take their turns in order of initiative. On their turn everyone can move a little and make action (attack, cast spell, place trap, disarm trap, spot for traps, use item etc) or move further. You can hide behind objects or other heros to break line of sights of enemy archers to your mages as well, there is no other cover system.
Combat map is divided into small hexes for movement and there can be varius hazard spaces on the map like oil set on fire will deal you fire damage when you cross it, while mud can make your character fall down unless he passes bosy control test.
(Tactical combat)
By using combination on magic and physical attacks you must cripple and defeat enemies. Enemies will usually outnumber you as well and some of them will also cast spells, use healing potions and have special attacks. So this is where tactic comes into place. 
Use your melees to block enemies before they reach your mages, or run to enemy mage to bash on him. Use obejects on the map and magic walls to block enemy movement and shoot them directly. You have options.
Cast damage spells to finish fight quickly, or same astral points for buffing and healing magic.

(Plot - Story)
Unfortunately game story is quite linear and not really involving. Characters are a bit shallow and the only one who really feels realistic is the dwarf who is fun and really combat oriented.
At few points in the game you will be stripped of your gear and forced to make through with given equipment untill you can regain your stuff. So it is goot to invest a little into maces(as you will usually end up fighting with a torch or a club) and offensive magic.

(Flaws)
There are some flaws to the game:
-Horrible mouth work. Unlike other modern games, the speaking animations here are just horrible, you will see heros open mouth like fish trying to catch a breath, it has no connectiong with what is being spoken.
-Very bad equipment comparison system. There is no way to compare one set of armor with another other than noting down the stats, changing set and seeing new stats.
-I have really no idea what in this game make it be 20gb large.
-Game does little to introduce players who are new to the difficult character creating and developemtn system. [there is good help&tips in the menu if you can spend a moment to read and understand it]
-Not involving plot and shallow characters.
-Not intuitive UI.
-No crafting system.

(Merits)
+Realistic when it comes to weapons and armors. Armors comes in sets, so it is no longer find best pieces, but you need to wear a complete set of armor to have best benefits. And I like it that way.
+Deep and difficult tactical combat. I like the games that are not easy.
+Quick cities exploration.
+You are not limited when crafting your heros, you have a lot of freedom in systems without classes.

Overall I would give this game 7/10.
I hope most of the flaws will be corrected in the upcomming Blackguards 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061500159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2253, 'last_played': 1420468579}
review:
Blackguards is a good game but has it's flaws. Mostly I had fun playing the game. 

- The difficulty of the game is quite easy at the begining but later on it becomes really annoying because mostly your enemies use spells that lower your move speed, attack chance and health. Also it will become quite impossible to fight your enemies if you don't finish all of the side quest.

- Interface/Combat  is excellent, but the controls are a little wonky and sometimes quite slow. There are some monsters that take up more than 1 hex ( places on the field) and it's hard to locate the spot to hit but it's not that bad that you will ruin your whole turn.

- Information is a little unclear  but after few hours you should figure it out.

- Loading screens. You will spend some time on loading screens.

- There is not much of different gear and weapons. Don't expect to find a lot of variety of great weapons, few of my characters had the same weapon from the 1-2 chapter to the end of the game. Also my wizards had the same clothes from the 1 chapter to the last part of the chapter 5.

- Opponents. There are a lot of different opponents and interesting ones. There are also opponents that are just frustrating you because they have have spells that lower everything (so yout hit chance isn't 95% but 45%) so they are hell to beat but when you beat them it's beautiful.

- Characters. All of the characters u play have different personalities that are unique. In some dialogues you can choose what your characters will say.

- Story. It's not a bad story at all and has some twists.

- Graphics. Some people might not care at all about graphics but I like it when the game I play has at least deacent graphics. The graphics are not that bad at all but when you talk to some people they will look totally different in the picture then they look in the game. 

- Playability it depends on what difficulty you choose to play but It will surely have around 40 hours (surely more).

- To conclude this review I recommend you buy this game but on sale. You will enjoy it and be frustrated.

review:
Still too buggy!

Die Programmierer haben es leider nach all der bisherigen Zeit immer noch nicht geschafft, das Spiel fehlerfrei und spielbar zu programmieren. Leider kommt es zu oft zu freezes. Dies kann jederzeit vorkommen. Dadurch, dass man im Kampf nicht speichern kann, kann es zu frustrierenden Erlebnissen kommen, wenn nach 10 oder 20 min. Kampf plÃ¶tzlich das Spiel einfriert und man es Ã¼ber den taskmanager killen muss. Dann war der ganze Kampfverlauf umsonst gewesen und die Zeit wurde vergeudet. 

Demnach ist das Spiel leider nicht zu empfehlen, obwohl es fÃ¼r Fans des "schwarzen Auges " durchaus seinen Reiz hÃ¤tte.

Wenn man bedenkt, dass die Verantwortlichen demnÃ¤chst den zweiten Teil rausbringen, kann man dem Studio nur noch Verlust fÃ¼r so viel bisherige UnfÃ¤higkeit und Verantwortungslosigkeit wÃ¼nschen - auf dass sie es mit "Gewalt" lernen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124845616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1441937734}
review: This is a great game.  I have been having alot of fun with it. I would love to give it a positive review; however, the constant freezes and crashes that cause me to have to reboot my PC are very frustrating. Usually, I can restart my PC and get further without another freeze or crash. However, most recently, I have gotten to a point that constantly freezes, not allowing me to progress further in the game.  If it were not for the bugs, this would be one of my most highly rated games. Looking at the forums, there are numerous similar reports. The devs keep asking each user to provide error logs, but you would think they would have more than enough information to correct the problem by now. I reallty want to give Blackguards 2 a try, but worry that it will be plagued with the same issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104368561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 3362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3362, 'last_played': 1412737335}
review:
Blackguards es un juego que realmente me gusto mucho (y termine). Lo que me apena es ver tantos analisis negativos cuando se lo podrÃ­a considerar como un diamante en bruto. No voy a ir al detalle del juego ya que el mismo ya tiene mil analisis (literalmente) pero si quiero poner enfasis en lo siguiente: la primer parte del juego es muy dificil (pero muy) con el agravante de que el desarrollo de los personajes es complicado y no esta bien explicado. Pero, si se tiene paciencia y se superan las primeras horas de a poco se van abriendo posibilidades y vamos entendiendo que atributos sirven y cuales no, donde poner puntos y que es mejor obviar.
 
Muchos se quejan de que los porcentajes de acierto de golpes son inexactos y esto es cierto. No es inusual fallar varias tiradas seguidas con un porcentaje de 80% o mas. Pero de nuevo. A medida que el jeugo avanza y subimos nuestra accuracy esto empieza a pasar muchos menos

Algo que no vi mencionado en la gran mayoria de los analisis es la maestria con la que estan diseÃ±ados los escenarios. A diferencia de mucho juegos tacticos los escenarios tienen muchas veces participacion decisiva en el desenlace de un combate y es importante tenerlos en cuenta al planificar los mismos. No es facil y muchos son un verdadero reto pero superarlos realmente transmite una sensacion de satisfaccion que muy pocos juegos logran.

Para terminar. A los amantes de los juegos tacticos les recomendaria darle una oportunidad a este juego pero entiendo que toma tiempo (unas 5 horas al menos) comenzar a entender el sistema de combate y atributos pero una vez pasado eso el juego no hace sino mejorar. Otra cosa es casi obvio pero muchos creo que no lo recomiendan por esto: graben muy seguido. Algunos combates son brutales y no hay margen para el error. Es mejor volver media hora atras y ver que decisiones revisar en cuanto a distribucion de atributos o items comprar que empezar de cero o insultar porque el juego es dificil.

Una pena que los aspectos poco pulidos opaquen esta gema para tantos jugadores.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963643929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1997, 'last_played': 1420144324}
review:
This is a turn based tactics game where you control (after about 30 hours gameplay) up to 5 heroes who walk between nodes on a world map in a very linear way and follow a more or less entertaining story (At least I found some of the dialogue mildly enjoyable). Some nodes are cities where you may learn skills, buy equipment, and get/perform quests, other nodes are quest nodes that may sometimes be skipped. Most of the time is however spent in  hexagon based maps fighting various bad guys. 

The game has a lot of skills and stats that you may experiment with, but mostly it makes little difference what you chose to skill up (For spells any nuke will do, some early bosses are weak to fire, but it makes little difference for most enemies, a healing spell is pretty much required, you will alternate between those two and auto attacks for the whole game), and as most stats and skills are needed in the end anyway the customization adds little depth to a shallow game. 

The major problem with Blackguards is that fights are mostly based on luck. Want to attack someone? Well, usually you have a 90% chance to hit (not bad, but that's as good as it gets unless someone is knocked down), but if you use a more powerful attack it might drop down to 85%, 70%, or 60% (based on dodge stat vs dexterity I think), further reduced with wounds that are randomly obtained when taking damage (I think your to hit chance can potentially go all the way down to 30%). If you manage to hit at all the damage dealt is then further randomed in a fairly large spread, and rarely it will crit for double damage. The damage is fairly high, so 3-4 good attacks is enough to drop most enemies and heroes.
This means that missing more than a few attacks will result in one of your heroes getting knocked unconscious, and the enemies snowball from there.
It's typically the enemies who get the good dodge stats, so while your heroes will mostly take full damage from anything that attacks them late game, your heroes will miss, miss, miss,miss, and miss some more as you watch them slowly die in frustration. 

The game's "difficulty" slowly ramps up as you play. Every encounter is level (in)appropriate, so every fight is a challenge. Since spell damage is fixed your magic users slowly get weaker after their 2 main spells hit level 3. While this makes sense in a way you will never get to be satisfied with how much stronger your heroes have gotten. Enemies have about the same stats and skills and do about as much damage as the heroes do, so fights vary little in practise between various encounters.

The game could still be a mildly enjoyable grind with the above mentioned issues, but clearly the devs were obsessed with making the game into a never ending series of encounters by a power tripping DM trying to make your party lose.
I got through several unfair fights like Running past all the enemies who get to hit you for free for 6 turns to get to the girl before she's killed, shoot a giant tree with 150 hp to death with arrows that each do 1 dmg because it 2 shots everything in melee range, run through a basement filled with traps to get to the guy you need to kill before he gets away, kill the necromancer who's surrounded by unkillalbe skeletons that block your spells and arrows, and many many more. The straw that broke the camel's back for me was the fight against the tiger lilly where one of your heroes is turned against you, you have to run up to a plant that always has a 60% hit chance, is immune to magic damage, every turn one of your heroes is knocked down, and 5-6 tentacles you're not supposed to kill get to attack your heroes freely while blocking off healing spells you might want to cast on the hero being bullied.
I understand that something like this was necessary to make the game interesting, as the fights by themselves clearly aren't. With a different combat system these fights might have been fun, but in Blackguards you will just keep doing the right thing again and again untill it finally works and you get to go on. 

So, TL;DR: Turn based fights heavily based on luck, little customization in practise despite the wealth of options available, you get weaker as you keep on playing, and gimmicky fights where the devs metaphorically throw your miss chance and weakness in your face again and again by setting up scenarios that force you into doing stupid things over and over untill the RNG gods decide that you may finally pass. If it sounds like your cup of tea then you will probably enjoy Blackguards, but I did not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006191441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1420051477}
review:
So I have only played this game for a few hours, but I think what I have learned already will not change throughout the course of the game.

Blackguards is a hard, challenging game, it is most certainly fun and the voice actors REALLY make this game a story to be part of, I simply love them. 
Now, don't get me wrong here, I'm all for % chances to hit, finding tactical ways to defeat the enemy and such, however I really resent the constant <70% chance to hit, and even at 70-90% I've had several times alredy where I do this action 3-4 times and each hit has missed (or failed)(not including piercing to skeletons etc.)
Therefor this game is very inconsistent in how any battle will turn out even by using the same movements and actions each time, and this kind of (almost) luck based combat makes Blackguards very hard to want to play again.

HOWEVER, I would recommend this game to anyone with the inclusion of this shortcoming.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998755666', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 3415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2740, 'last_played': 1419952498}
review:
First of all I want to say that I dont regret buying the game (discount) . 8 / 10

Pros:

- challenging

- good variety of battles (win conditions, interactive objects, environment, enemies)

- multiple ways to win battles depending on your party

- amusing dialogue

- not a single crash the whole time I played and no other bugs

- good length

Minor Cons:

- awkward character development / training and AP gain curve (the currency you improve your charaters with)

- small selection of armor (lets just say I didnt equip my 2 casters with new clothing until the last chapter)

- not many weapons either (many special spears, only 1 or 2  improved versions of other weapontypes)

Tipps & Tricks (light spoiler warning):
[spoiler] 
- do not rely heavily on the Niam character

- make sure your fighters are good with secondary blunt/slash weapon set (for skeletons and crystals)

- make use of the ability to delay your actions with a character by using the space-key (sometimes being the first to move is critical, but other times you want your enemies to move first, so you can move then and hit them

- dramatically increase your chances to hit enemies via wounding them, poisons, knock them down / incapacitate them, attack them with a weak character first so they lose their parade

- have a caster who can cast axxeleratus level 3

- poison your weapons before entering a hard battle (you dont want to waste a turn to poison your weapons in battle)

- use savegames to try out different spells if you have a lot of saved up AP, some are turds but others can really shine / decide a battle (the beserk one can be very good, lightning cloud too)

- get your casters best possible manaregen via gear / talents, maybe archery as a secondary profession
[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561197990086823', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1419899367}

author: {'steamid': '76561198062237876', 'num_games_owned': 4574, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 4150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4150, 'last_played': 1420141951}
review:
To be honest, I don't know where the mediocre ratings come from. I had huge amounts of fun with this game. Since update 1.3 you get all the combat feedback you need.
If you like turn-based strategy with a touch of RPG you owe it to yourself to give this a shot. The Dark Eye might lean more towards a generic fantasy setting, but I really like the European "style" and love the level system. You will probably have to get used to it, if you are unfamiliar with it, but it gives you great depth and customization opportunities. 

I for one, can't wait to get my hands on Blackguards 2 in 2015!

author: {'steamid': '76561198028694331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4119, 'last_played': 1419808217}
review:
The real trill is to lose your companions in one moment for some (already scripted) story line.

The game is fiddly, full of unuseful choices and abilities (unless reaching the best level).

Annoying combat visual and commands, it's really difficult even to find the right point to click. Absurd.

Really poor level design, with some level with mandatory actions and skill to use, living the risk to lose your game if you didn't upgrade the right ability. Etc.

Played 'till the end to find the worst ending story ever (not even a real story nor ending).

author: {'steamid': '76561198021970613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 3605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3605, 'last_played': 1419605673}
review:
Good intro game to the Dark Eye universe. 

Positives:
- fun tactical combat 
- interesting characters and OK story. 
- character customization according to the dark eye rules
- fast traveling from combat to combat, always in action no pointless roaming
- the best part of the game is probably early mid game when you are forced to fight in the arena. It's a nice change of pace. 

On the negative side:
- RNG is sometimes really strong, like missing 95% hit chance 3 times in a row
- difficulty spikes, although end game boss was too easy
- low variety in armors for mages
- poisons everywhere

author: {'steamid': '76561197993376396', 'num_games_owned': 292, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4027, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4027, 'last_played': 1419575415}
review:
I played this through to the end, but I'd have a hard time recommending it even to fans of the genre.  I'm just stubborn, but the gameplay was gimmicky and tedious.  The UI and quest tracking left a lot to be desired.  Your characters stop progressing in power about half way through the game, after that it's just rounding them out.  

There was almost something here, but not quite.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038506457', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2123, 'last_played': 1481811998}
review:
7.5/10

Blackguard is a very fun turn-based strategy game. You will come to love most of the characters. The dialogues are simply amazing. Your party members are exactly what you expect your most extreme type of role-playing friends to be during a sesstion of a tabletop game like DnD.

"I AM A MAGICIAN OF LOVE. I WILL SEDUCE EVERYONE!" and then you get into battle because he fails all of his seduction.

Everyone takes it to the extreme. One is hella dumb, funny and racist toward the elves. Another is just always sarcastic and mean most of the time.

That covers most of the story telling. Let's get into the gameplay.

THE
DARN
THING
WILL
TRY TO BREAK YOU.

The hex-based map is great.
The game using the "automated diceroll" system as if you were playing an actual table top is great.
Problem though is that the other side cheats way too often for you to really enjoy the combat.
Somes of them are insanely easy.
And the next one is just demanding you to either get the spell to work on a 50% rate at the start of the turn with the follow up attack from your friends hitting everything on the first turn or you might as well retry the battle.

And to make it worse. Everything, except for some of the weak fodders, are either as strong as you or much stronger than you. It's funny the first few time you see a lizardman sniping your team with a javelin better than your archer can shoot someone with his bow but after about 2 to 3 hits, it stops being funny because they deal much more damage than you do and even has additional effects until you manage to get to a certain point where you can finally learn your cheap spamming moves too just to destroy everything.

And "HARD" mode isn't even hard. It's just frustrating and cheating. Usually, in a strategy game, repeating the same failed strategy oftens lead to the same fail result. However, in Blackguards, repeating the same strategy is what you do until you finally roll enough damage and hit rate to actually carry out that strategy, and that the environment isn't messing with you. 

RNG governs everything. Mobs are predictable but overstat as heck that they will deal your critical-like damage on a normal hit so you just have to retry over and over until the 35% hit rate on them actually miss instead of hitting 3 times in a row while your 90-95% are still missing over and over, or dealing minimal damage when it actually hits, leaving the mobs with 1 hp.

Because this game offers no between-combat regen so sometime, delaying a battle to 60 turns + is necessary although you can end it in 7. It wasn't challenging. It was just the game forcing me to repeat the "Whole map kite" for the next 10 minutes just to full heal the whole team. At normal or so, this isn't always necessary. I can try with 75% health and mana on the next map. On hard? You better be full or you might as well restart the whole battle chain.

But that's really the annoying part and it can easily be somewhat remedied by just setting the mode to "Normal" unless you're ready to go through pointless self-torture that makes you want to ragequit because of a single crit or a slip on an overstat mob forcing an instaretry. Other than that, I see nothing wrong with this game. People often makes fun of the voice acting but it's only horrible on the trailer. The in-game voice acting is so much better and really fit the situation when the characters are trying to be mean or sarcasting, which isn't really something you can see on the trailer.

I also recommend getting the big pack. The artbook is simply amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088701289', 'num_games_owned': 1521, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1473982801}
review:
No puedo recomendar un juego donde he acertado mÃ¡s veces con una probabilidad inferior al 20% que con una superior al 85%. Y ojo, podÃ©is pensar que tal vez haya sido una sola vez, pero desgraciadamente no, cualquiera que lo haya jugado puede darse cuenta de lo que hablo, te da la sensaciÃ³n de que las probabilidades que te muestra el juego NUNCA suelen cumplirse.

Y curiosamente (esto lo achaco a un bug, pero no deja de ser otro fallo gordo del juego), he llegado a fallar un golpe con un 100% de probabilidades.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087482136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3447, 'last_played': 1419202843}
review:
Finished this game about 2 weeks ago.  Wish I had reviewed it sooner when it was fresh in my mind but here it goes.

The difficulty is very high and there is a ton of content to explore over 5 chapters.

Can't stress this enough.  If you are easily frustrated you may not enjoy this game.

But it sure does feel good when Naurim wins the battle with only a few points of health left, or when you manage to outrun that damn poison mist :)

Story is good, I got really into it from the beginning.  You are trying to investgate the murder of the princess and its possible you are the killer.  As you play more of the story is revealed.

Some good walkthroughs can be found online if you feel the game is too hard, but basically whatever character type you go for you need to invest in one weapon skill to at least 14-16 to avoid missing most of the time.  Also its a good idea to save your experience points until you absolutely need to spend it, and its a good idea to plan ahead what kind of skills and spells you want to invest in as experience points are limited and there is no going back once you purchase a skill.

Don't be afraid to turn the game to easy in order to enjoy the game :)  I did in some parts and its a great RPG experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977632063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1419748526}

author: {'steamid': '76561198085832254', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1848, 'last_played': 1425850053}
review:
Great game - FUN. I recommend this game if you like turn-based tactical RPG's. Overall the game is a fun experience. The biggest aspect of this game is gameplay and story. Other strengths such as atmosphere and tone create a nice world. Great soundtrack as well. 

Couple things to point out. The world map movement is point and click/adventure, which I did not expect to enjoy so much at first. This creates a little slower pacing then I am used to in other RPG's. Just kick back and relax during world map movement and you'll learn to enjoy it. 

Customization can be a "gift or a curse," depending on your personality. Personally, the party customization screens were cumbersome and confusing for the first 5-8 hours. If you get overwhelemed at charcter customization screen, I recommend going with the default builds, or research other builds online for direction. Try not to waste allocating points until you decide on a main build. By the end of Chapter 1 you can handle all of the customization options though. If you love stats and numbers, you will no doubt enjoy the customization. Sometimes battles take party-management prep work before you engage. 

Overall the game is a good experience and I recommend it if you enjoy turn-based RPG's. Great story involvment. The game has a slower pacing, but this is not a bad thing. Just relax and enjoy the world, story, and gameplay!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011604006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 4287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4287, 'last_played': 1405170255}
review: A good turn-based RPG game. Graphics, sound, music and story are good. This plays similarly to X-Com combined with Original Sin (and is about as difficult as X-Com, with a mercilous RNG).  Lots of puzzle maps to figure out, and battle maps are very unique, and beautiful. There are a few things to look out for: it's totally possible to build your character in a way that will make it difficult, if not impossible to finish the game. Each character needs to focus on their strengths and ignore superfluous stats/abilities. The kicker is the stats on your characters, and the gear do not make it abundantly clear how you should build characters, what stats do, how much better gear Y is than gear X, etc. I suppose if you are familiar with the system this game is based on, it all makes sense, but if not, you will be confused and probably have to rely on guides and forums.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005405918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1723, 'last_played': 1464277974}
review:
I never really liked the whole "Yes/No" recommentation. A game shouldn't be decided if it is loved or hated solely based on other's experiences but rather on if it is appealing to you. With that said I gave it a Yes since even though it does has it flaws, I personally enjoyed it. Now to the nitty gritty part.

What this game is (if you couldn't tell already) is a turn based DnD style type of game and it is heavily based on DnD mechanics. For those that don't know DnD, Here is a quick breakdown on how combat works: Roll for initiative (i.e. RNGesus happens at the beginning of each battle to determine who goes first), move characters around the map and you can do an action like attack, cast a spell, drink a potion or place a trap. Or you can just wait until your next turn. This process continues until every character has made a move/action. Then it is back to the top and you keep taking turns and making actions until either you or the enemy is dead.

Now, keep in mind that this game is RNGesus based and that even though you have 90% chance to hit that doesn't mean you'll hit..just like DnD. 

To keep this short...also my spelling is bad...

Pros: Interesting characters, combat is intuitive and changes per environment (i.e. environment interaction), very challenging scenarios (for those that like to get kicked around). 

Cons: Very challenging scenarios (for those that want to get spoon fed victory), Character customization is limited (you can create a rouge/mage or a hunter warrior but you can't create something like a palidin where you hit people in the faces with maces and then cast cure. Reason being is that wearing heavy "Metallic" armor takes away your ability to cast spells and regen mana. This is a con for me because I wanted to roll a palibro). Keep in mind if you do a split class like rouge/mage you will have more skills/abilities however you won't be as strong as a pure rouge or a pure mage.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962087492', 'num_games_owned': 1242, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 615, 'last_played': 1395522443}
review:
"Blackguards is a wonderful tactics game with some rough edges. The core gameplay and character progression elements are easily some of the best in the genre, but as battles tend to drag on and more and more enemies scream â€œowAUGH,â€ the interest tends to fade. The story is easy enough to follow and interesting enough to keep players interested, so fantasy buffs should feel engaged the entire time. Even if the sound effects weren't satisfying, the gameplay itself more than made up for that, and itâ€™s easy to see that Daedalic Entertainment has a bright future ahead of them in the strategy sphere."

In other words, a great game for fantasy/strategy fans! Full review here: http://www.destructoid.com/review-blackguards-272333.phtml

author: {'steamid': '76561198028395313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 3711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3711, 'last_played': 1419429672}
review:
Un gioco di strategia a turni di genere fantasy 

Punti di Forza:

- Ottimo sistema di avanzamento dei personaggi
- Trama piacevole
- Dialoghi divertenti
- LongevitÃ  eccezionale (l'ho finito dopo 60 ore di gioco)
- Ottima varietÃ  delle mappe di gioco (ogni combattimento aveva una mappa diversa)
- E' possibile interagire con alcuni elementi nella mappa per ottenere un vantaggio in combattimento (esempio: attivare una leva per far scattare una trappola, incendiare i barili per creare dei muri di fuoco, ecc.)

Punti di Debolezza:

- Livello di difficoltÃ  non calibrato 
- Graficamente datato

Consigli:

- Giocate a difficoltÃ  " Normale "
- Accumulate pozioni e veleni potenti 
- Sfruttate la balestra o l'arco
- Gestite bene i punti dei personaggi 

Voto: 6

author: {'steamid': '76561198013721985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3538, 'last_played': 1419432297}
review:
Good but could have been a lot better with a couple of tweaks.

I've played turn based games where you can speed up the AI's turn  - this would be a welcome addition to Blackguards... I LOVED it for first 20 hours, but my enjoyment of the next 20 slumped,  and I resented the final 20. 

I have since deleted it from my hard disc without completing it - this is becasue I was beginning to feel it was a imposition on my time which I was only continung with out of an obsessive-compulsive desire to complete the campaign.

That said, I got this in the humble bundle for Â£cheap, and the game if definately worth it for a couple of quid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023383251', 'num_games_owned': 118, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 831, 'last_played': 1432146330}
review:
Black Guard kann nicht viel, aber das was es kann kann es herrvorragend. 

Ich meine damit, dieses Spiel besteht aus KÃ¤mpfen. Zwischen den KÃ¤mpfen wechsle ich die Standorte auf einer Weltkarte wÃ¤hrend die lineare Story in sehr gut vertonten Dialogen und gelegtlichen Zwischensequenzen erzÃ¤hlt wird. Die Verschrobenheit des ganzen verleiht ihm einen ungewÃ¶hnlichen Charm. Die Charaktere wirken am Anfangs wie RPG Standart, man tÃ¤uscht sich aber den sie sind so verschroben wie die Story und transportieren durchaus DSA-Flair. StÃ¤dte verfÃ¼gen nur Ã¼ber eine sehr eingeschrÃ¤nkte Ansicht eines Marktpaltzes und rudimentÃ¤ren Optionen, was Schade ist den da hÃ¤tte die DSA-Welt viel mehr zu bieten. 

Nun zu den KÃ¤mpfen.  Die sind schwer und erfodern oft eine bestimmte Taktik, so dass man die wichtigen KÃ¤mpfe meistens wenigstens einmal wiederholen muss. Brain-Off geklicke kann man sich sparen. Das Kampfsystem basiert auf dem DSA-Regelwerk mit einigen Modifikationen. ( Die Modifikationen betreffen ManÃ¶ver und Zauber: Sie wurden so verÃ¤ndert, dass Magie und Nahkampf ausgeglichener sind. Wer DSA kennt weiÃŸ, dass Magie eher durch Ressourcenknappheit gebalanced ist. In BG findet ihr eine Regeneration von Astralpunkten mit einem Punkt pro Runde dafÃ¼r  wurde die Wirkungsdauer von zaubern massive verkÃ¼rzt und sie haben nur eine Aktion Zauberdauer. ManÃ¶ver und Zauber skallieren wie in Darkensang in einem 7 Talentpunkte schritt. Eigene Ansagen gibt es nicht) => Quasi eine Mix aus Ad&D und DSA). Einige VerÃ¤nderung kann ich Nachvollziehen andere nicht. Der Nachteil an dem ganzen ist klar, dass die FÃ¤higkeiten mit allen 7 Talentpunkten massiv besser werden und so dass progressive DSA 4.1 SteigerungsgefÃ¼hl auf der Strecke bleibt. Man spart sich aber das QualitÃ¤tsproben Prinzip und verhindert so, dass man immer aufs Kampflog starrt. 
Die Magie-Modifikationen sind auch klar, das RAW system wÃ¤re fÃ¼r ein Spiel dieser Art einfach zu Ã¶de. Positiv an der Magie ist die implementierung von Zaubern wie dem Fortifex Arkanewand oder degleichen, die EinfluÃŸ auf das Kartendesign haben. Im wesentlichen hat aber die Reduktion des DSA-Regelwerks den Sinn, dem Spieler das Studium des DSA-Regelwerks zu ersparen und die Aktionsdichte zuerhÃ¶hen. 

Fazit: Black Guards macht einiges anders und das ganz Gut. Es ist mehr ein DSA Dogfight Game mit nem RPG Charaktersystem und kein Rollenspiel. DafÃ¼r ist es aber sehr gut.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063967022', 'num_games_owned': 1015, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1418899304}
review:
Rundenstrategie? CHECK!
Gute Lizenz? In diesem Fall DSA? CHECK!
Grafischer Auftritt? Solide! CHECK!

Dann mal auf in ein RollenspielvergnÃ¼gen? Mit nichten... Leider verpasst "Blackguards" fÃ¼r mich das "erzÃ¤hlen". Die ErzÃ¤hlung will nicht so wirklich Ã¼berspringen und aus irgendeinem Grund wirken die KÃ¤mpfe nicht berechenbar, die DSA Regelwerke kaum bis schlecht in das Spiel eingebaut. Schade...

FÃ¼r Hardcore RPG-Fans bestimmt ein tolles Spiel. FÃ¼r den "Rollenspieler" der gerne was sieht und auch geboten bekommt wie mich? Nein.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982000668', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 1823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1052, 'last_played': 1573295646}
review:
Tough but rewarding. This is (luckily in my eyes) a typical The Dark Eye game. If you do not know this RPG system: it's Germany's biggest and probably oldest Pen & Paper RPG system that is still maintained. And as many things from Germany it is deep and complex, but needs a certain degree of dedication. 

You will not be able to simply start this game, kill some enemies and have fun. You really need to have a look at the rule system and how all the character values influence your fighting, casting and other skills. The same goes for spending your experience points, if you simply raise a stat here and there you will find the game very hard and probably quit. If you decide what role a character will have and raise the necessary stats and skills for this you will have a much easier time and will be able to enjoy the very complex fight options.

One definitive pro from my point of view are the really varied battle maps. Most maps have unique interactive features that you can use in the battle, like alchimistic tables that will poison bystanders when smashed. Or drawbridges that can be raised or lowered. Or cranes with crates that might smash your heroes from the docks - or the enemies if you position yourself smart enough.

Alltogether it is a clear recommendation for me if you like complex strategy games with RPG-like character development. Do not buy if you look for Diabloesque casual RPGs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087870222', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 840, 'last_played': 1593830952}

author: {'steamid': '76561198048042029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1989, 'last_played': 1419355537}
review:
I really enjoyed this game!
There are a lot of missed opportunities, but I got a nice introduction to the Dark Eye universe.

I got it for $5.5 and played for ~30 hours (and to be fair I didn't look for a super long challenge, I wanted a game I could finish in less than a week, so I played in easy mode).

The biggest frustration I've had, came from the loading screens. Simply put, any change in location (Map, Street, Battlefield) will have to go through a loading screen. It gets old very quickly.

The character customisation is not necessarily the strongest point of this game, with only one character entirely customisable (the main character), and a few different companions pre-defined, there won't be enough room to craft a custom team.
That being said, I understand that it is better suited for someone new to the genre. Personally I didn't mind it too much.

I enjoyed the introduction to the Dark Eye's universe and while I would probably not play through this game a second time, I got a fair share of entertainment for a very low cost and I am considering getting into the tabletop version.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018621644', 'num_games_owned': 871, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4421, 'last_played': 1454720493}
review:
This game gets so close that with a few tweaks it really could have been something special. The combat would be great if it wasn't so RNG dependent. Attacks are more limited by being able to actually hit stuff than they are about causing enough damage. Chance to hit of 65% or lower is normal for everything but a basic melee attack even when you've pretty much maxed out your character's relevant stats and weapon skill, and that 65% is actually more like 30% chance to hit because the percentage shown is just your character's accuracy. Your attack can and will still be parried or dodged half that percentage again.

You have to buff your characters with magic before they're worth a damn, but guess what. The magic has a chance of success too. So until you spend a few thousand points levelling up your mages' stats and getting them a certain ability, the highest chance of success with casting spells is ~85%. But I don't know how many times I had a mage miscast 4-5 times in a row even with a (supposedly) 80-90% chance of success.

You lose more battles because of unlucky streaks of whiffed attacks and spells fizzling out than you do from anything else.

In short, it was fun for a while, but became tedious by the end. It's worth picking up for $5 or so, because I really loved the battle set ups (there's very few boring battles because most try to do something unique and no two are the same) and the style of the game, but there's just too much wrong with it to be worth full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031677050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2967, 'last_played': 1419034807}
review: I was really excited to play this hoping it'd be XCOM in a fantasy world.  While the combat and graphics are similar, this game just lacks a lot of the depth of XCOM.  There's almost no point to the skill trees because each character will just use the same attack skills for the whole game, most skills are passives anyway, and the others are so situational it's not worth it.  There's really no role-playing choices outside of your character "build" which is pretty shallow and one decision at the end.  The few characters that you get to play with have some personality which is cool but there's too few of them and one of them is taken away almost immediately.  The combat is pretty simplified with basic line of sight rules and dice rolls which almost never go in your favor if 60% or less.  Also, as a completionist, it was really annoying that some of the quests / achievements are bugged.  The only reason I recommend this is if you are like me and itching for a Tactical Turn Based Strategy RPG-lite game this will hold you over but don't expect to get blown away.

review: Richtig gutes rundenbasiertes Strategiespiel, welches im Schwarzen Auge Fantasy Universum angesiedelt ist. Freunde des fast ausgestorbenen Genres werden hier mit Sicherheit auf ihre Kosten kommen. Daedalic liefert hier ein Spiel mit hervorragender Story, einem cleveren Kampfsystem unter BerÃ¼cksichtigung des DSA Universums und Ã¤uÃŸerst gut entwickelten Charakteren, die zusÃ¤tzlich noch von den hervorragenden Sprechern profitieren. Ich habe jetzt selber erst knapp 20 Stunden gespielt. Zum Highend Content kann ich daher bislang noch nicht viel sagen! Aber auf Youtube sah auch das sehr vielversprechend aus!

author: {'steamid': '76561198080430621', 'num_games_owned': 464, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 3311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3282, 'last_played': 1451673186}
review:
Let me just start by saying that this game is really great but the devs DON'T deserve any bit of your money!

Pros:
    -Story was really good
    -Loved the gameplay(turn based combat and how cities were handled)
    -Lots of sidequests
    -Really nice char development "tree"

Cons:
    -There are known bugged achievements(0.2% players have this) that noone can seem to get and also there are some achivs that some ppl get and other can't get even tho they did the same things that ppl who got em did..
    -Forums are full of achiv problems and noone has heard anything from the developers for a long time(for at least 6 months if not more)
    -The world map is huge wich is really great BUT this game takes place on only like 30% of the map the other 70% might be used in the sequel so that kinda sucked cos I was really looking foward to playing even more of the game but then I just went to the last chapter
    -The main hero has 4 male and female char models, they could have made it a lil bit more customisable

Conclusion:
A great game sadly ruined by sh*t developers who dont care. I would totally recomend this game and definitely buy BG 2 when it come out in Jan 2015, but with devs like this there is NO WAY I'm getting BG 2 or recommending this cos they deserve everything but your money! -.-

author: {'steamid': '76561198027809020', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2157, 'last_played': 1421821846}
review:
This game somehow made me feel nostalgic for the first turn-based combat rpg I played as a kid, which was Farland Tactics 3. This is a good thing since I can hardly get into most games these days, but this one sucked me right in.

I happened to love the town overview and simplified map where I only need to click the things I need without needing to walk around and finding things. This helped me to focus on combat, while the town illustrations and some dialogues from the overview gave me a sense of adventure at the same time. 

The difficulty is perfect when I played this on hard - a little challenging but rewarding. Also, the combat does depend on luck quite a bit, but I felt like this kept me at the edge of my seat. 

Character creation and development was simple and intuitive. I didn't need to spend time trying to figure out how to build my characters by looking up at numerous guides, so it made me focus on my own game. 

All in all, this game was what I was looking for. If you love turn-based combat while being able to have some rpg experience without certain tediousness that comes with rpgs, this would be it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019405394', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1413890201}
review:
The term tensile RPG was once a very common and well-known, but in recent years, these games almost completely disappeared from the gaming scene. This year is fortunately again fruitful for this style and is experiencing a minor revival. How, then turned one such RPG from relatively unknown Daedalic Entertainment?

Right at the beginning, after selecting a new game in the menu, the player can choose either the simplified selection of attributes, or expert, according as it is familiar with the style board game The Dark Eye. In the selection of the division are three different professions, namely Warrior, Magician and Hunter. In addition, it is possible to choose from several preset face and sex. Already here, I have to criticize that particular types of female faces look sometimes very belligerent manner and at the same time from each other and a little different. Overall graphics page, especially dealing with details of the figure was weaker.

The second setting, ie expert player allows much more extensive treatment of the characters and follow the rules of points. Basically, a player has a choice to 10,000 points, labeled BD from which you can then has any assembly dream champion. At the outset, it must pay 500 if you want to have a magical character. After this selection opens a few talent trees, which can be additionally porozdeÄ¾ovaÅ¥ points to a maximum of up to 14 properties, the talents and spells 8. However, while playing and later acquire new levels of these attributes can continue to accrue. Points can be reallocated in several areas, namely core values, Fighting talent, talents, spells, and finally special skills. It is important to all of these points divided as effectively as possible, because after creating new characters and the plot itself enters into all the remaining points are canceled.

The core values are called major modifiers in creating characters, namely strength, charisma etc., these in turn affect many elements such as the capacity of heroes, the number of lives, or the ability to communicate with the outside world and the characters in it. Between fighting talent then there are various weapons from daggers, crossbows over, after two-handed swords. By investing points into the player's weapons of course increases the attack or the defense of a given type of weapon, depending on how it is set. Among the talent is also possible to choose from nine different talents. For example, the ability of the trap, which allows the player to identify, considered, or even defuse traps or RanhojiÄstvo, which in turn allows the player to heal from injuries. We walk the kids, which are of course only applicable if a player chooses a character magician. Spells are divided between the offensive and strengthening and debilitating. Found them quite a decent amount of fans and fiery, respectively. ice magic school here will surely enjoy. Finally, we get the special abilities, which are different upgrades for close combat, ranged or magic, or even passive abilities.

Edit character is indeed fairly complex and enthusiasts making such tailor-made nature of certain very pleased. Conversely, players who want to jump into the story as soon as possible to be able to circumvent these adjustments using automatic reallocation of points in the selection of the games.

Whether a player chooses to basic or expert mode, after completion of the selection starts intro and the player is familiar with the mysterious death of Princess Elanor. Here are gradually unveiled on different battle tactics such as moving figures after hexagonal boxes, or attacking. However, the main protagonists are caught in a stationary body guards pathetic Princess and cast him into prison. The initial steps of the story thus seek out of this place and the run will help the player and other figures rough dwarf Naurima and individually mage Zurbaran. Later, therefore, the player will control the widening of the characters, and it is therefore important to learn the capabilities and advantages make the most of the fight.

It should be noted that the combat encounters tend to be really hard sometimes, or vice versa, sometimes very simple. At times it can be unpredictable for the game, which depends on various calculations, attack, defense, and to recover the attack power of intervention, and the like. Another element is the very place where the fight takes place. You should be commended on one side of the creators, because these so-called arenas are interactive and can be, for example, to hide his magician for any obstacle from enemies and calmly zosielaÅ¥ healing spells at his comrades, or even drop, for example luster on unsuspecting opponents. On the other hand, sometimes these interactive game environment, they can do very easily, so will everyone else struggle and it's up to the player as will be careful to monitor the area in which the fight takes place and whether it will be able to benefit or not.

After deliverance from prison pending player main story line, which is of course finding a clarification of the death of the Princess, in which the main character was involved already. Later, however, the procedure of the story in five different chapters player looks at different places of the world and in addition to the main storyline is of course possible to perform a secondary task, which can be obtained, for example, also visited cities around the world.

As regards the visual side of the game is not any graphical champion, but what should be on-screen instructions, it handles. The environments are quite varied and dark stomp the player gets to the green meadows, respectively. in different forests or cities. After zooming in, however, and examining the details of the characters come often unpleasant experience, which is especially noticeable when prestrihovÃ½ch animation. The game simply can not cope with these details, but I must say that in this type of RPG is not a graphics page and so important.

Audio is contrary to the relatively high level of quality musical accompaniment and a good dubbing. The only thing you can criticize the common neprecÃ­tenie some situations Daberas (initial torture when choosing a female protagonist in the prison).

Blackguards is certainly an interesting title and if you're a fan of tensile RPG, or even know the style of the game The Dark Eye, you will not be disappointed. For other players, the game offers many hours of tasks in an interesting world where the most important temporize and think through each move before the player how to fix it. Playing on the other hand suffers quick repetetÃ­vnosÅ¥ou and certainly not for hotheads who like to do so and then they think. Through it all, however Blackguards among the titles above average and certainly have their supporters and fans found.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007300752', 'num_games_owned': 537, 'num_reviews': 237, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1418695876}
review:
Blackguards is an interesting concept with quite poor execution. The main problem is that it's built around an obscure role playing system that is both punishing and not fun. It's based on the Dark Eye role playing system in Germany. It's a fairly punishing system that gives too much power to the RNG and not enough to the player. 

What do I mean by that?

It's just no fun having a 50/50 chance of casting a spell fail 6 or 7 times in a row and that costing you a battle. It's luck, not tactics or skill, that will get you through battles and luck doesn't make for a fun game. The "tactics" are minimal and your choices in leveling a character are severely restricted because if you don't take certain paths with certain classes you simply won't be able to proceed through the battles. This is the core problem with the game. It's like playing chess with an RNG. It simply defeats the purpose.

The game wants you to play it one way. It discourages experimentation and creativity while demanding that you play it the "right" way with the "right" skill and classes or woe to the user. This isn't a strategy game but more of a puzzle and one that's not fun to piece together. Either you read a guide or you will be forced to start over at some point. That's just really poor design.

As for the other aspects of the game, consider me unimpressed. The voice acting is truly horrible and the plotline is both forgettable and so dumb as to be insulting to the player. You can't rotate the camera and often enemies are obscured. The graphics are decent but nothing fantastic. The videos stutter and tend to happen too often. 

When it comes right down to it, there's really nothing redeeming about Blackguards beyond the fact that when you finally uninstall it you'll clear up 17GB of hard drive space to use for something better. You'll get better tactics out of King's Bounty and Divinity: Original Sin than this game plus better exploration and more personality. Save your money, buy those and you'll have far more fun than you would with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030839836', 'num_games_owned': 1407, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1418573499}
review:
This game is quite tough, but a lot of fun.  I am still really early in the game but here are my thoughts so far.

Money is sparce at best and you can never afford anything but the essencials.  If you picked a ranged charcter like I did, assume all your gold is going to provisions, healers and arrows.  

No farming, since you can't just go get in an random battles, if you have an area to explore it is best to visit every location to get all the EXP you can.  

Make sure you save in multiple save slots, you can get yourself in a chain of mission that you just can't win without an extra provision or something.  If you don't have that save game from before you trigger the chain of events you could be stuck.

One last thing, don't be afraid to click end turn 50 times in a row if monsters aren't activated to get your magic points back and heal everyone and then get them back of to be ready for combat.

Overall, I am really enjoying it so far.  I'd recommend a play.  I'll updated the review it if I feel the need later.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979007367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2343, 'last_played': 1418556765}
review: Devo dire che a prescindere dalle diverse recensioni questo Blackguards Ã¨ risultato essere un ottimo gioco. Non eccelle dal punto di visto tecnico ma la storia e il sitema di combattimento sono un punto a favore, anche se a volta Ã¨ snervante fare un miss con il 95% di percentuale di colpire (ma ci sono giochi dove missi anche con il 100%). Il sistema di avanzamento dei personaggi Ã¨ abbastanza libero e mi sono trovato con il personaggio principale ad essere al massimo con dual-wield, spade e due mani ed arco. Ãˆ un gioco difficile e tattico dove ogni mossa va studiata a dovere e a volte puÃ² essere frustrante dover ripete alcuni scontri, ma preferisco cosÃ¬ piuttosto che un'eccessiva semplicitÃ . Se non fosse per il prezzo lo consiglierei senza remore. Probabilmente dovrebbe costare la metÃ  per essere veramente appetibile, in ogni caso Ã¨ un gioco che mi Ã¨ durato quasi 40 ore, che non sono affatto poche.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022804816', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1852, 'last_played': 1418554897}
review:
Sehr gut! Vor allem weit besser als erwartet.
Das DSA Kampfsystem eignet sich nicht sehr gut fÃ¼r ein reines Kampfspiel und trotzdem gelang ed Daedalic ein solches auf die Beine zu stellen. Mehr noch als die KÃ¤mpfe begeistert aber die saugute Vertonung, sowohl Musik als Dialoge sind 1A. Die Geschichte bietet Wendungen und ist auf gutem DSA-Roman Niveau. Man merkt das Daedalic sonst eher Adventures macht. 
Eine sympathische Heldentruppe, harte, aber selten frustrierende KÃ¤mpfe, massig Nebenquests, gute DSA AtmosphÃ¤re - klare Kaufempfehlung!
9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197995407093', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1514517136}
review: This is some kinda horseshit. In like the fifth battle, you miss 65% of the time with magic and ranged attacks. The dwarf does 0 melee damage because he's fighting with a torch because you can't afford an axe. Defeating an enemy means another crawls out of a hole, so one character (out of three) has to spend at least seven turns closing holes while your useless mage (53% chance of doing 5 - 10 damage) and worthless dwarf are swarmed. Who the hell is stupid enough to keep playing after such a horrible start? Screw this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035553821', 'num_games_owned': 241, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 2262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1840, 'last_played': 1599956246}
review:
My review was going to be positive, it's a fun game and has nice combat play. The issue is that the combat is just truely unbalanced and the hit odds are not correct. Either the battles are fine or they are incredibly lopsided nearly impossible (just turn it to easy and grind it out). 

The issue with the hit odds is gamebreaking.
I've missed 3 100% hit shots. I routinely miss 80% shots. "But bwag, 80 shot chance still has 20% of missing!"
Yes thank you mother fucking genius. Help me explain how on two mission tries I missed a chain of 8 60% shots all in a row and then restarted to miss 11 60% shots in a row. Fuck this odd system piece of shit. 

Odds of 8 misses 1.7%
Odds of 11 misses .36%
Odds of 19 misses .0061%
(in a row)

Odds of missing on a 100% of the time shot
(Apparently not 0%)

author: {'steamid': '76561197985759196', 'num_games_owned': 1384, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2802, 'last_played': 1418442232}
review:
I won't repeat what the other reviews already said, so I keep this short:

[b]Pro:[/b]
-Round-based strategy game (its like X-Com but with an actual story!)
-complex character builds are possible and a lot of content (there are 5 chapters but I am still in the middle of chapter 3 after 19 hours of gameplay)

Unfortunately the negative points are too much of an issue to recommend this game

[b]Contra[/b]
-all towns kinda look the same and it gets repetive if you don't love grinding and collecting item sets
-incredibly difficult to play because of unbalanced setup ( since you can build every character the same, you basically choose between characters that can use magic and characters which dont)
-RNG makes your game so much more painful and very frustrating ( e.g. you have 2 casters who got a success spell cast of 93% but both still fail 3 times in a row which leads to an abortion of the spells; similar cases also with 95% melee hit chance and still missing several times)

I don't know what the numbers of these probabilities are for, since they do not reflect the actual probability of hit or miss, but probably its a feature and not a bug. As long as this issue is not fixed, I cannot recommend at all.

Update (after finishing the game):
Another negative point: story is extremly linear. Your choices make no difference at all, because the outcome is always the same. The choices only affects the ending you may get but you notice this only at the very very very end (if you can keep playing that long that is...)

author: {'steamid': '76561198019181288', 'num_games_owned': 657, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1447806308}
review: You mike like this game if you're a huge fan of classic table RPGs, but otherwise, I highly doubt it. Too focused on the story (which is kinda annoying to skip) and the combat really didn't seem fun to me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998268521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1288, 'last_played': 1418676058}
review:
This is a good game.  

For those, who don't like it - you just don't understand the game mechanics.

The best thing is, that almost all things in the games feels right. There is non of frustrating moments, that was created only for blockbuster effects. All seems to be suited within game story and logic. It's rare in moderns games.

The battle system, voice acting, music, story and the atmosphere is also good. 

And the best part - the challenge. It's quite a conundrum at the normal level, and hard puzzle in hard. That's great!

I liked this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042232956', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1417992744}
review:
Almost a fun game, but when you have 95% chance to hit attacks missing half the time, then it gets extremely frustrating. Some battles you just have to reset if because of absurd rng going against you. Way too much rng and luck involved in this game. It's like the game tries to make things difficult by adding frustration and bad luck. 

Character skill/stat progression seemed like an interesting sandbox you can play with at first, but it just allows you to mess up your stats and totally gimp yourself for fights, making things more difficult. Would be nice if you can just farm AP and get your stats up, but you can't, so you just have to fight with half ass stats you end up with if you haven't figured them out and thought it out perfectly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995311326', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1416875831}
review:
Blackguards has a pretty standard premise, in that it is a save the world fantasy story.  Unfortunately, the dialogue is stilted and often disjointed and the gameplay is dense and perhaps overly complicated.  I can forgive the voice acting, and odd story easily, but it is the game mechanics themselves that perhaps need tweaking.   

The dice rolls are punishing and heavily weighted towards failure.  It is laughably common to miss 3 75% chances in a row and taking a risk on anything under a 50% chance is pretty much a guaranteed miss.   It has been said on various forums that there are many mechanics that are affecting the probabilities that don't appear in the shown hit chance.  That sounds to me like a User Interface failure and a pretty important one at that.  

Perhaps the most glaring issue of this is the arena fights at the beginning of Chapter 2.  When you have to pull off 6 hits in a row to kill the first enemy and then another 8 hits to kill the second.  Unfortunately you A) will die in 3 hits, B) Will get poisoned if you take a single hit, and C) the NPCs don't have an issue with the weighted hit dice.  Add to this the fact that you can't go back and level due to your captivity, can't buy potions (though the enemy gets 2 or 3) and lose all of your items means that you are pretty much screwed.

All in all I was pretty disappointed.  It was exactly the kind of game I wanted.  It just wasn't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044982953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 1759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1708, 'last_played': 1419818315}
review: Still havent beat this one....careful of the choices in character specs you make, it really makes or breaks this game. This game is also super hard......ive played a lot of games, and this one is extremely unforgiving if you make stat mistakes. Definately give this one an 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197965422155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1649, 'last_played': 1418346426}
review:
This might be a fun game.

I wouldn't know, since no matter what I do the game crashes after I try to create a character.

Edit: re-installed the game a couple times. It finally works. Changing to a thumbs up.

The combat is hard enough to present a solid challenge, but not so hard that it's unreasonable.

You'll miss a lot of attacks that say they have a 95% chance to hit. I feel like the hit chance indicators are inaccurate.

Other than that, the game is a ton of fun.

If you like turn based, strategic combat then this is worth a play, especially for 80% off.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028583875', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 3356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3106, 'last_played': 1417833960}
review:
I thoroughly enjoy Daedalic Entertainment's point-and-click adventure games so when I heard that they would be making a turn-based RPG I was super pumped.  I love the Dark Eye world and the gritty fantasy found therein and I feel that this game does not disappoint.  

PROS

1) THE CHARACTERS! I adored the main characters and genuinely felt that each line of dialogue between them was solid gold.  Every one of them had a great personality and contributed to the overall value of this game a great deal.

2) The Dialogue and Story: You can take it or leave it but I what I came across I enjoyed.  While it is true that the story is linear and doing side-missions does nothing but help you grind this was never an issue for me.  I liked the story and the direction it was taken.  You're a bad guy doing bad things for the right reasons and it is not often to come across something that does this trope well.  The game does a great job of putting you into the "antihero" mentality.  

3) Combat: This game does not hold your hand.  You WILL redo fights, you WILL get frustrated, and unless you know how to build your stats and abilities you WILL fall behind but as long as you play your hand correctly you will always be able to win the next fight.  Similar to older iterations of D&D (which Die Schwarze Auge/The Dark Eye is the German equivalent of more or less) there are weapon AND damage types to consider.  Knowing what kind of weapons and what kind of damage types to use are crucial against certain enemies.  For example, DON'T USE PIERCING AGAINST THE UNDEAD!  They are completely immune to anything that doesn't impart massive physical trauma to their skeleton like slashing or bashing weapons would.  Some enemies are immune to poison, some to magic, and some to physical damage.  It will be trial and error to figure this out but this is also why you can equip each character with three different weapon load-outs which you can cycle through in combat so as to avoid being harmless to a specific enemy.  Other things to note about combat include the diversity of places you will fight in (it makes you feel like you're actually traveling from place to place), the importance of positioning, the use of environmental effects to your advantage, and bottlenecking.  Combat is the meat and potatoes to this game and after 50+ hours of this game I, for one, can say that it does not get old.

4) Stat Systems and Leveling: DO NOT RAISE BASE STATS! At least not at first.  This game offers a wide variety of upgrade paths with which you can take your party in a multitude of directions.  Wanna be a crazy hefty tank? Upgrade Warcraft, Body Control, Willpower, Strength, Vitality, and the proficiency of two weapons of your choice.  Wanna be everywhere and piercing armor? Upgrade Agility, Body Control, Spear proficiency, Dexterity, and Vitality for that damage you are most certainly going to take.  Wanna mage it up?  Take Bow proficiency, level your spells like crazy (a hefty investment), and make sure you have a tank or two between you and the enemy.  While some might bemoan the lack of class options with there only being three, Warrior, Ranger, and Mage, it isn't that large of an issue.  This is not a game about diplomacy or sneaking around (ignoring two or three AWFUL missions that can be solved with fighting), it's about slugging it out with the enemy.  To play something that doesn't contribute to the fight directly is to take a difficult game and make it impossible.

5) Grittiness: I consider this a plus because I like games that force you to be aware of the number of arrows in your quiver, how absolutely vital healing can be, and how huge a difference is made when you finally buy that new axe that does ONE MORE DAMAGE.  This is a game where all the small things add up over time to take your party from bandit npcs to gods on the battlefield.  Throughout the game you can also learn special attacks which give you advantages in certain situations such as inflicting wounds (Wounds and HP Damage are totally separate things), knocking down enemies, or doing more damage from a distance with ranged weaponry.  The larger and more valuable the effect the more costly the attack will be in terms of accuracy so a very effective trade-off between damage/utility and accuracy is established.

6) The World: Not much to say aside from how much I enjoyed it and all the people you come across.  It is VERY uncommon for you to run across nice individuals so when you do you instantly grow attached to them.  Even then most of the "nice" people you come across are still awful by today's standards due to their desires to brainwash, enslave, or kill off rivals for a plethora of reasons.  Aventuria (the world) isn't a great place and it's heroes reflect that, but maybe, with a great deal of effort, you can change that.

CONS

1) The Probability System: IT LIESSSSSSSSSSSSSSS! Never in a game have I missed five consecutive instances of hitting with a 95% chance of my attack succeeding each time.  It is without a doubt the single most irritating and detracting point to this whole game.  Until you play Blackguards you will not understand how infuriating it can be.  It doesn't just apply to physical attacks, though.  Your spells will fizzle out and do nothing, your arrows can randomly vanish, you will fail body tests where you have a 99% chance of passing and fall down.  This was a HUGE oversight on the part of the developers and if they would just release a patch that made these percentages more accurate I would have nothing against this RPG.

2) POISONS and Enemy Buffs! In the latter half of the campaign in an attempt to balance the gameplay the developers just decided to either give the enemies a flat magic stat buff or give all of their attacks the poison quality which will do continuous damage or give you a stat debuff for the rest of the fight.  Not nearly as irritating as the percentage issue but it does somewhat cheapen the joy you get when your party goes into an encounter that you should faceroll only to discover that the enemy basically leveled up with you.

3) Stat Building: While I did mention this as a plus earlier you can very easily destroy your game by building poorly.  Seeing as how there is no way to undo this it can prove to be game ruining.  

Overall, I would give this experience a solid 8/10.  Fun from beginning to end and if you see it on sale for less than 10 you should instantly snatch it up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132998478', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1417016915}
review:
Sadly, I am very disappointed, though its battle system is not bad,
and storyline is actually good.
But, It is nonsense that this kind of game supports only 2 class, isn't it?
Spellcaster or Non-spellcaster. oh well...
there are many games which have many various classes, skills, items.
and yes, they are good points of interest.
Blackguard is suffering critical lack of those contents!
I am very glad that they support Korean, but they missed more important things...

I have no intension of blame Blackguards,
but there are so many other good Strategic RPGs you can enjoy,
so you don't need to play this game I think.
