author: {'steamid': '76561198031828536', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 3522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3522, 'last_played': 1417796855}
review:
No entiendo como ha tardado casi un aÃ±o en bajar de 40â‚¬ a 10 si aun pagando esos 10 es para sentirse estafado.

Ok, mi anÃ¡lisis personal y subjetivo del juego, primero lo bueno:

- El mundo que plantea.
Aunque el entorno en el que se desarrolla el juego son un puÃ±ado de ciudades y no vemos nada global, es suficiente para ver que tiene potencial y una bonita fotografÃ­a.

- El combate.
Tiene algunos aspectos positivos a resaltar:
El tablero es Ãºnico en cada batalla.
El Ã¡rbol de posibilidades tÃ¡cticas es muy amplio, aunque no se pueda explorar en una Ãºnica partida.
Hay diferentes misiones de combate que amenizan la partida.

- La historia.
Un aprobado por los pelos sigue siendo un aprobado, tiene escasas opciones de dialogo que afectan poco o nada al resultado.
El final te deja con tal cara de tonto que yo lleguÃ© a pensar que a mi juego le faltaban trozos.

Lo malo:

- La cantidad y frecuencia de cargas es absurda.
- La IA en combate es de las peores que he visto y al carecer de modo multijugador se desperdicia la mejor baza del juego.
- Es corto.
- Buscar las misiones secundarias con tanta carga entre pantallas es muy molesto.
- Es muy simple:
Tiene tres pantallas bÃ¡sicas, tablero de batalla, cuidad y mapa. Todo el potencial del juego estÃ¡ en el combate y, como ya he dicho, la IA no estÃ¡ a la altura ni hay modo multijugador.
- No es juego para mÃ¡s de una partida, por lo que sus arboles de habilidades se desperdician.

En general le pasa como al Omerta, juegos con potencial que ilusionan al principio para terminar cayendo en barrena.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040542645', 'num_games_owned': 1551, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1415992511}
review:
Want to smash your monitor? than buy this game.

if you have any range of spells they'll fail more often than not, also the percentage that it gives you as you casting chance means nothing, a 70% casting chance but it will fail four out of five times. rage quits everytime, especially when you get hard missions and your success is completely based on luck not tactics.

so i restarted the whole game (because you have to max 3 specific stats just to make one spell actually work) and made a character that could cast 2 spells. how quickly does that get repetitive. 

you can't go and level your characters, there are no optional quests because the apparently optional ones are nessesary for you to get xp. it takes for ever to actually level enough to make it worth it to attempt casting a 3rd spell.

i love rpg and turn based because it is about tactics not button mashing but the messed up casting just makes it all about non existant luck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118919335', 'num_games_owned': 797, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1699, 'last_played': 1416554696}

review: One story, no way to alter. Mechanics in battle are iffy at best, you will miss A LOT. Got it personally in a bundle so I'm not worried about it. author: {'steamid': '76561198003959029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 2401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2207, 'last_played': 1417754720}
review:
Has a nice start, but falls short quite fast.
It gets repetitive. Xp aren't so fun to get since it's hard to know what worths it, fights seem to be mostly the same thing over and over, the story is not much to be impressed about, the difficulty of fights is inconsistent and some fights have super easy puzzles and others are just frustrating. author: {'steamid': '76561198159570795', 'num_games_owned': 390, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 18535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12923, 'last_played': 1626643408}
review:
TLDR -- A lot of good ideas, but iffy execution.

I used to recommend this game, as I really liked it. After I got it, I played through several times, and despite some overly complex -- and not well explained -- aspects, it was a (mostly) fun game. I especially liked the humor, the fact that there wasn't always a clear "good" choice, and that even when there was, it wasn't always mechanically superior -- i.e. better rewards for being "good". It was refreshingly muddy on morality.
But, recently, I'd seen some comments online referencing "crashes" being the reason people stopped playing. So I just played through again -- and it crashed a half dozen times in my playthrough. I still enjoyed going back through this game, but I had the benefit of already understanding the confusing character sheet and knowing how to budget my xp and  money well -- what to buy and when.
I think it's more than likely that most people who ran into the random -- and seemingly non-reproducible -- crashes I did won't get very far, especially with all the other aggravating factors.
If you can get past the crashes, and remember to diversify the party, while focusing each character, you can have a lot of fun with it. But if you want a quick dive in for fun, go elseware.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976348074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3237, 'last_played': 1417723790}
review:
Wow, what do you get when you combine an entertaining story, colorful characters, and turn based combat with absolutely BROKEN game mechanics?  You get Blackguards!

Blackguards is another in a string of games recently that have such wonderful aspects about them and yet have some fatal flaw that sabotages every good experience you have with it.  That flaw is that the game straight-up cheats.  Now I'd normally be the first person to say "suck it up you sissy, it's meant to be challenging."  But there's a big difference between something that is genuinely challenging, and something that cheats.

-I can't tell you how many times I laughed my butt off watching the number of ways the game abused my characters.  Character killed before anyone can act in a battle.  No problem, reload.  Character recovers from knock down only to be knocked down once more with no apparent cause?  No problem, reload.  The game is full of this kind of stuff.  Prepare to be "loved" in the most brutal way by this game.  There's little else that you can do other than laugh about it...it's baked in.

-Ignore any percentages to succeed on anything you do.  They're meaningless.  You'll realize it's all BS after your 10th time of failing when it says you have a 100% chance of success.  This will be driven home even harder when you see your character who has maxxed out stats in his chosen weapon, the champion of the arena, outfitted in the best gear, and still being unable to hit some highwayman in leather armor.  And if you do, it will be a small percentage of the damage that guy can do to you.  It's depressing, really. 

-Forget tactics.  They really have no place here.  You'll find some style that works with your approach to games and work it over and over again (as best as the broken mechanics will let you of course).  The game doesn't give you much reason to try anything else, and you won't want to because you're just trying desperately to win some battle.  

It's like the designers were unable to find a way to make the game challenging besides giving the enemies a wholly unfair advantage.  And that's what it feels like...cheap and dirty hits.  That might be ok if it was built into the story and somehow made sense.  But when it's the developers that are doing it, you really don't feel like supporting them again.  

Which is a shame, because if they tweaked just that one thing...that one small thing...to play by the rules...it would be pretty enjoyable.  There's a lot of content, some really funny breaking-the-4th-wall comedy, amazing production values in some areas (the world map), and combat with some moderate depth. But alas, it was not meant to be.

Frankly, as much as I want to I can't recommend this game.  I got it super cheap as part of a Humble Bundle, and I still can't recommend it.  I don't know if I'll ever return to the game again, but if the developers fix these problems, I'll certainly update my review.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984505297', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4512, 'last_played': 1483880201}
review:
Die meisten Bewertungen der Fachpresse und der Community kann ich kaum nachvollziehen. Meiner Meinung nach ganz oft GenÃ¶rgel auf hohem Niveau. Fast hÃ¤tte auch ich mich davon abschrecken lassen.

Gibt es Blackguards irgendwo im Sale, bekommt man fÃ¼r wenige Euro ein fantastisches Spiel. Daedalic kann einfach Geschichten erzÃ¤hlen und Daedalic kann uns knorrige Charaktere prÃ¤sentieren, die einem wahrlich an Herz wachsen kÃ¶nnen. So auch bei Blackguards.

Die Geschichte folgt  einem kringeligen roten Faden, soll heiÃŸen, dass die ErzÃ¤hlung nicht strikt linear verlÃ¤uft, sondern hie und da mal ein wenig abschweift, was dem Gesamteindruck aber eher zugute kommt. Die Vertonung der Spielfiguren ist auffÃ¤llig gut gemacht. Man hat professionelle Sprecher engagiert, die ihren Job grÃ¶ÃŸtenteils sehr gut machen. Kaum ein Spiel hat solch eine schÃ¶ne (deutsche) Sprachausgabe.

Die dynamische Hintergrundmusik ist ebenfalls von allererster GÃ¼te. Sehr stimmungsvoll, abwechlungsreich, teils orchestral, teils verspielt. Manches Mal habe ich den Sound aufgedreht, um diese tolle Musik zu genieÃŸen. Sonst habe ich die Spielmusik immer gern auf minimaler LautstÃ¤rke, nicht so bei Blackguards.

Die KÃ¤mpfe sind allesamt hochspannend, Jeder Kampf findet auf einem eigens designten Spielfeld statt. Mit jeweils eigenen Herausforderungen und Taktiken. So viel Abwechslung findet man selten. Ganz das Gegenteil von Level-Recycling a'la DragonAge2. Mit fortschreitendem Spiel werden die Gegner weder Ã¼bermÃ¤chtig noch langwelig.  Schwache Gegner finden sich plÃ¶tzlich in einer, fÃ¼r sie sehr vorteilhaften Umgebung, starke Gegner lassen sich oft durch geschickte Einbeziehung der Umgebung doch noch besiegen.

Das oft kritisierte Zufallsprinzip, der DSA-WÃ¼rfel,, ja, das gibt es und ja, es nervt bisweilen und ja, auch ich habe schon in die Tischkante gebissen, wenn mein Flammenzauber im entscheidenden Moment versagt oder mein Held danebenhaut. Oft bleiben Gegner mit nur einem einzigen HItpoint Ã¼brig, die in der nÃ¤chsten Runde dann ebenso derbe austeilen, als wenn sie noch ganz gesund wÃ¤ren und dummerweise einen meiner Leute binden, der dem DÃ¶del dann in der nÃ¤chsten Runde den letzten Punkt wegkloppt. Allerdings .. und das ist immer wieder Grund schadenfrohen GelÃ¤chters, die KI haut auch daneben oder versemmelt irgendwelche Zauber. Wenn ein Kampf mal ganz blÃ¶d lÃ¤uft, manchmal entscheidet es sich im ersten Zug, ob der Kampf gewonnen oder verloren wird, kann man ihn wiederholen und bei jedem Start, werden die Ausgangsparameter neu ausgewÃ¼rfelt.
Ganz ehrlich, grad auch dieses Zufallsprinzip auf beiden Seiten macht die KÃ¤mpfe sehr spannend. Nicht selten gewinnt man einen aussichtslosen Kampf trotzdem noch, weil dem Gegner die entscheidenden Aktionen misslingen und man selbst ausnahmsweise mal unverschÃ¤mtes GlÃ¼ck hat.

Neulinge wÃ¼rden sich in dem verwirrenden Skill- und Talentsystem vielleicht nicht auf Anhieb zurechtfinden, man kann sich ohne weiteres total verskillen und hat dann spÃ¤ter wohl kaum noch eine Chance, KÃ¤mpfe fÃ¼r sich zu entscheiden. RPG-gestÃ¤hlte Spieler finden sich schnell zurecht und wissen wohl auch intuitiv, worauf es ankommt. Da ist Blackguards ganz klassisch und nicht Ã¼berraschend. Ein kleiner Hinweis fÃ¼r den Spielanfang: die passiven Skills wie Ausweichen und Parieren werden erst im spÃ¤teren Spiel gern mal das ZÃ¼nglein an der Waage sein, hier ab und an mal ein Ã¼briggebliebenes PÃ¼nktchen zu investieren, wird sich spÃ¤ter auszahlen.

Fazit:
Alles in allem kann ich Blackguards jedem wÃ¤rmstens ans Herz legen, der der Rundenstrategie im Fantasy Universum etwas abgewinnen kann. Es erwartet einen eine liebevoll erzÃ¤hlte Geschichte, stimmungsvolle Begleitmusik, den ein oder anderen knorrigen Charakter, spannende und immer wieder einzigartige KÃ¤mpfe und ein sehr stimmiges Setting. 
Zu bemÃ¤ngeln wÃ¤re, dass man oft erst selbst herausfinden muss, wie etwas funktioniert und man ab und an mal in eine "Try&Error" Phase gerÃ¤t, aber das hat auch sein Gutes, denn allzu leicht - allzu "casual" - will man es ja vielleicht auch nicht haben, dann kÃ¶nnte man ja gleich irgendeinen der vielen weichgespÃ¼lten Blockbuster spielen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052648960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 12088, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6240, 'last_played': 1663190590}
review:
Blackguard is a good game. Nice roleplaying sensations, interesting fights (lots of combination), sweet graphics, cool sounds and music, good scenario (with shocking twists^^). Although there's a real lack of polish on cinematics, and the story ends a bit brutal in my opinion. Maybe a longer story would have been nice, or a faster character progression to overcome this.
As a fan of turned based game, I can only recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005091437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 3713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3713, 'last_played': 1417096579}
review:
7/10.
A solid turn-based combat Roleplay game, with interesting fights, varying win scenarios, and no game-changing +50% damage trinkets.


[u] The way the game played out for me. [/u]
[list] 
[*] First, customise your character with a wide variety of spells, talents, and stats. There are quite a few options, here.
[*] Next, crawl through a vast variety of well-designed maps and interesting combat scenarios, in the turn-based strategy style.
[*] Marvel at the lack of decent gear... even in the final chapters. :P
[*] Get frustrated by missing 3x 90% (incorrectly labelled ~ more accurately 50% chance) hits in a row >  [b]adapt by using weaker abilities with 95% hit chance[/b]. Win.
[*] Use reasoning skills to work out the win condition, when the game doesn't spoonfeed you how to succeed > Win.
[*] Delve deeper into the well written storyline.
[*] Contemplate right vs wrong, and the way human societies functions.
[*] Watch a few thrown-together and anticlimactic final cutscenes.. (due credit to there being a few alternative endings).
[*] Decide not to make another char and start again, because you're intimate knowledge of the skills/talents/stats would make you a God on 'normal'... and increasing the difficulty level would just cause the more annoying aspects of the game to become too much to be enjoyable.
[/list]


--------------*[i] See last paragraph for a list of helpful hints [/i]**--------------------

[u]The pro's and con's:[/u]

[b]Pro's:[/b]
[list]
[*] Interesting maps, and scenario's.
[*] Great range of character stats to customise. These stats actually made a significant difference to how your character could be played.
[*] Sometimes required me to stop - think about why I just lost - adapt. Rather than just steamrolling through every scenario.
        Especially, when 2-star enemies start appearing.
[*] Sometimes required me to work out the puzzle of how to win the map. (Despite some other reviewers' comments, this rarely required chain-learning trap locations *but even when it did I could have put points into Traps (talent) to over come this* - see above point about actually [b]strategising[/b] instead of gratuitous wins).
[*] Well written story, and voice acting. Particularly, the wide range of accents.
[*] The overarching theme of the dialogue was thought provoking, with concepts of anarchism, liberalism, and competing social values.
[*] [i] No "+50% damage trinkets." [/i]
[/list]

[b] Con's: [/b]
[list]
[*] [i] No "+50% damage trinkets;" in fact, upgrades were very hard to come by, with the best gear in the game being only marginally better than the starting level gear. [/i]
[*] The lack of gear-based character improvement makes Adventure Points essential for creating an effectively optimised end-game character. It's important to get it right on the Character Creation screen.
[*] There's almost nothing worth buying, especially because main quests give you free full armor sets in Chapters 2 and 3. By the end of the game, I had over 1000gold and nothing to spend it on (the top level chest armor cost 50g) <- [i] This was only exacurbated by the need to regularly clear your inventory of unnecessary weight[/i]
[*] Around the second half of Chapter 3, 2-star enemies suddenly begun appearing - much stronger than 1-star enemies - receiving a huge buff to their stats and global buffs. (E.g. +8 attack, +2 dodge +20% Magic Resist buff for all enemies!!).  [i] their strength increased too much, too suddenly.[/i] 
[*] [u]Melee Hit chances are too low. Even with maxed out Attack from stats, Weapon Skills, and weapons/shields.[/u]
[*] By the end of the game, poorly scaled hit chance forced me to abandon my expensive big-hitting melee attacks (ie Hammer Blow - which I had spent over 3000 Adventure points in meeting these abilities' requirements). Was forced to use weak high hit chance abilities to even hit anything.
[*] By the end of the game, [u]the game forced me to abandon my dreams of a badass melee build[/u]; opting for 1Hander axe and sheild, instead.
[*] Boss enemies in the 4th and 5th Chapters regularly potioned to full health when falling below ~30% health.  Combined with the fact that I rarely hit melee attacks, it became frustratingly difficult to get through the last 10 or so damage in a single turn before they 100% healed.
[*] The game kept messing with my team synergies by [spoiler] taking away one of spell casters for long periods of time [/spoiler], and [spoiler]killing off my ranger[/spoiler].
[*] There are a few spells pretty much beat any enemy (example: [spoiler]Karnifilo Frenzy - the insane rage spell that makes groups of enemies kill each other[/spoiler])
[*] [u]Maps with many enemies became very slow due to the inability to skip enemy movement and attack animations.[/u] Even enemies that couldn't reach you due to blocked paths would run in this painfully time-consuming circle, in order to use up their movement points.
[*] Back-to-the-past missions took away your well synergised gang of fighters; instead, leaving you with a lone character that wasn't optimised for solo play. (I felt sorry for any spell-casters, here).
[*] In-game decisions make minimal differences to the actual gameplay - mostly just affect the cutscenes.
[/list]

[u]Helpful Hints:[/u]
[i]- Probably wouldn't put points into Treat Wounds (talent). Instead, get 13 points on one of your party member's Healing (spell), because it heals all wounds as well as being much more convenient.
- Don't allow you characters to remain wounded. 3 wounds will severely weaken any character.
- Team buffing & enemy debuffing spells are game changers!
- Rangers are actully pretty decent in this game, so long as you have a tank or two to keep enemies 5 hexagons away.
- If melee, don't bother going for Hammer Blow (tier 3 Abilty), nor Death Blow (tier 3) as their hit chances are way too low to provide reliable damage in the second half of the game. Tier 1 melee abilities remain viable the whole game due to their high chance to hit.
- Minimum 8 points in Body control (talent) for every character is ESSENTIAL; 8+ points in Willpower (talent) are helpful for every character. 
- 8 Points in Warfare (talents) and 8 points in Animal Lore (talents) are very useful for melee  and ranged characters.
- Defensive characters & spell casters should have relevant Weapon Skills of at least 8 points, and set to full defensive mode (for example, Zurbaran with 8 points in staves, with the sliding bar all the way to the left).
- Gear is so hard to come by in this game, so you need Adventure Points in order to improve you characters. Didn't bother putting any points into Charisma as it seems counter-intuitive to effectively reduce your Adventure Points just for easy conversation options.
- Finally, using poisons on you weapons is a great way to get through some impressive damage.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197991008389', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 2274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2238, 'last_played': 1417009125}
review:
It is not the star and it has some bugs. But there is something in this game that I like. The atmosphere itself. I'm not a big fantasy fun but somehow I like all of this - visual style, music, story and characters - despite of minor bugs and small story fails. 
And it is turn-based squad strategy with a strong RPG element - can't say nothing bad - the gameplay is good (and I like such games since the very first X-COM :). Blackguards may be not polished enough but definetely has a potential - will look for Blackguards 2 for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070774848', 'num_games_owned': 1504, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1416994445}
review: Boring tedious combat. They tried to make it interesting with gimmicky environmental interactions that just feel unneccessary and at times annoying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038604011', 'num_games_owned': 914, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1416870487}
review:
I have not been so bored with a game in a very long time. Blackguards is a hex turn based rpg type game, with much less of the traditional rpg feel and much more of the board game elements. As a genre, itâ€™s not my cup of tea but I can see why people enjoy the thoughtful strategy of it.

Playing Blackguards felt sort of like playing a chess match over and over again with the outcome being nearly entirely based on luck. Perhaps it boils down to the visuals not being all that visceral, but even things like positioning relative to the enemy seems to have no effect on combat outcomes. In the hour and a halfish I played I did little more than click on enemies and wait to either win or have to reload. It was as if the game was trying to distance itself from me.

Definitely not a recommendation on any of my lists; if I wanted a strategic RPG Iâ€™d reinstall Neverwinter Nights, if I wanted a board game Iâ€™d find a free online chess game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977211401', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 7794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1948, 'last_played': 1665623792}
review:
Everything that can be wrong about this game is wrong.

The mechanics are broken (IE you get 1 parry a turn except for when you dont, that guy who has parried 3 attacks already, well your 100% to hit which you should never even have got because a 20 is a crit fail, he parried it because he also rolled a 20 on his parry roll, 4th parry out of the 1 he has per round),
They are also counter intuitive (fairly normal for a D&D clone),
And outright stupid (Why do shields give no bonus at all?  Why can you only switch your melee skill between offensive and defensive outside of battle, why does changing it make no difference?  Why can I get 100%s to hit when 19-20/20 is always a crit fail? etc.),
Random to an excessive level (Nothing you do means anything.  Your completely non melee focused mage can work better as a tank than your completely tank focused sword and board char.  Your spell which does 8-18 dmg (firebolt 2) actually rolls for between 3 and 27, before factoring in resists/weaknesses)
On top of that, the AI cheats (They get 100%s to hit fairly regularly, they can parry a seemingly infinite amount of times, they parry your 95%s to hit about 95% of the time, they still maintain accuracy despite having every possible debuff put on them, they get access to things like potions in fights where it is explicitly stated no one has them, they succeed/fail skill checks in a completely disproportionate amount to thier displayed chances of success (etc)),
The story is both unoriginal and bland,
The world is completely nonsensical, you can walk across what is described as a "Vast empire" and back in less than a day,
Apart from your PC, Naurim and the fat mage, all of the voice actors are phoning it in, especially Neera (or whatever she is called),
The game is ugly as all hell, yet still has horrendous loadtimes and FPS drops (I am on a 4GHz 3770, a GTX680, 16 GIGs of DDR3, and a high speed SSD, yet it still drops to below 10 frames per second at times, seemingly randomly),
The UI is shit (IE every spell has 4 levels, each needs to be put onto your hotbar at a set level).
The progression is shit (no matter how difficult the fight is, you get 23 or 45 exp),


Probably more, but this game is so painful to play through.  I wish my kindly friend hadnt bought the humble bundle for me, as then I would have bought it myself and could have just never played this game, but since someone bought it for me I HAVE to finish it so as to not waste thier money.

Heres hoping it stops being shit at some point... Here is hoping it isnt 40 hours in...

*Edit, I didnt quite force myself to 40 hours, close enough though, and I did give up in the end.  It never got good.  Its entirely possible the story gets good later on (though from comments I have seen it doesnt, BG2 supposedly has a good story if still unoriginal, and it having a good story is always mentioned as a positive comparison to BG 1), but if the gameplay is tantamount to pulling your own teeth out through your arse, why would you even bother getting that far?

In conclusion you like the stuff listed above this may be you new favorite go to on steam I have a hard time finding good turn based tactics games this is not Disgaea in terms of comedy but it is a good go to on steam

author: {'steamid': '76561198004209857', 'num_games_owned': 970, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1204, 'last_played': 1417119790}
review:
In short words: "Linear but fun"... oh and "extremely imbalanced"

The game is hard for an average gamer, but some of the combats, especially the Nine Hordes combat series and Iribaar Lilly battles are plain bullshit. Other than these exceptions however, it's fun-level-challenging for a decent RPG gamer.

Have quite a few bugs that made me rip some of my hair off of my head and a ridiculous success chance randomizer. If you miss 95% chance to hit a guy three-four times in a row, it means it's a normal day in Blackguards.

Has some companion-NPCs with "character" but also has filler/meat/dps guys too (Yes, i'm talking about Takate)

All in all, if you are looking for a challenging tactical-rpg and ready to rage quit multiple times, this game is just for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007904525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4856, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4450, 'last_played': 1424160403}
review:
As of this writing, I am at a point where I believe I am close to completing this game on the hardest difficulty. My experience thus far is that the game is well worth while, and I would recommend it to any fan of tactical RPGs. This review will cover positive aspects of the game, negative aspects of the game (and why they don't matter much), and advice for potential adventurers.

Positive aspects:

First and foremost, the leveling system is vast. You are confronted with tons of options right at the outset, which provides a good degree of clarity about how to plan your path. It is definitely viable to create hard class archetypes, and is likely also viable to create more versatile heroes. There is a solid mix of cheap levelling options that help do what you want your character to do now, and choices that allow you to transition to new skills later.

Second, the tactical combat is varied enough to prevent approaching all battles in the same way. Differences in enemy types  and compositions, apparent environmental attributes, hidden environmental objects, and varied victory conditions  all help to keep things fresh. Depending on these scenarios, I've had success with tactics involving methodical advancement, bait and run, divide and conquer, run and gun, and defensive walling. I imagine that if you built for it, you could plan to finish some battles with ranged attacks before the enemies even reach you.

In addition, it is worth mentioning a few things other than the core gameplay. The story is well-told and evenly-paced, and is compelling enough to justify the  constant fighting. The music is solid (though repetitive). And the world map is easy to navigate.

Negative aspects:

First, the graphical quality for character models is a little poor when seen up close. Characters don't look quite right facially, and when they talk you can even see that they don't have an inside to their mouths. Character portraits look little like their polygonal counterparts. While this can be offputting, it is not so apparent in battle view, and is not a major detriment.

The only other negative point is the tedious exploration. While map exploration is simple, it is a tedious point-and-click affair. Finding a quest sometimes means visiting each town (many of which look and feel the same) on the off-chance that it will have one, and clicking through each of the people to make sure. Because this is quickly accomplished, it is not a huge drawback, but it is a boring aspect of the game.

My advice:

Some helpful pointers for those who do choose to buy this game (my first piece of advice is that you do) are below:
- Start with a notion of what you want each of your characters to do, and focus solely on that at first (melee vs. ranged vs. magic, choice of weapons, choice of spells). Plan to branch your characters out later.
- It is probably best to make your starting character a magic user, even if you don't plan to focus on spells right away. I don't feel particularly disadvantaged by not having done so, but I can see how an additional magic user could be helpful down the road.
- Don't focus on magic for your starting character, even if you make them a magic user. You will get other characters, and you probably don't need more than one pure mage.
- Magic users aren't great early on, but focusing on healing first is a big help to boosting their early-game usefulness without taking away from long-term viability.
- You will want at least one ranged character, and it will be obvious at a few points in the game who can fill that role.
- Stats and skills that accomplish more per turn/action are more valuable than capacity stats like HP and Astral Points.
- Gold matters a ton in the early parts of the game, and not at all after. Your priority spending should be on the best weapons you can find, followed by set armor.
- It is okay to skip a quest you're not ready for. Some builds can't handle some scenarios, and you may need to level up a little more to take it on. This is a likely but infrequent occurrence. As far as I can tell, quests don't disappear just by waiting.
- Don't be afraid to re-roll and start over. It is tempting to try different things, and you may discover early in the game that your build isn't working like you wanted. Your second try will be much improved.

Thank you for reading, I hope it was helpful, and please let others know whether or not you found this review informative.

Peace!
AFoolToFollow

review:
Thank goodness I got this for next to nothing in a Humble Bundle, because it's unmitigated trash. The game is unbalanced, the graphics are uninspiring, the combat is dull - which is awful because combat is ALL the game has.

It's depressing that all the modern Dark Eye games are terrible, the last good Dark Eye game was the original Realms of Arkania trilogy 20 years ago!

Absolute trash, please avoid.

review:
Blackguards is a game for all who are at home in the dark eye realm (pen and paper version 4). I personally played the pen and paper role game a lot and think Blackguards is very close to it, well sadly limited just to fighting. But the story is typical for DSA (German term for dark eye rolegame) and there is no unreasonable fighting. Everything is explained, if you (can) read the dialogues. 
Resume: Good game for fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976132876', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3502, 'last_played': 1452145522}
review:
I was not certain whether I will like it or not due to some negative reviews on the  board complaining

1. random battle results
and 
2.  the difficulty of the game. 

However, it turns out that this is one of the top 5 games I played in 2014 (including Last of Us, Distant Worlds, Dominions 3, and Tomb Raiders). If you like turn based combat in a fantasy world, this is a must. I enjoyed this game far much more than I did for UFO Enemy unknown.  

I do not have any experience with the dark eye world so I browsed steam community guides (class guide was most helpful) and some forum posts. Concentration (on certain skills or spells for a character) was advised and it is really important.  I tried to max weapon talent, base stat and skill which are matched (refer community guide). Chapter 1 was a bit difficult since the system was new to me but the remaining chapters became more comfortable as I learn combinations of spells and base stats (for example, one of the  spells that I specialized requires cleverness and constitution). All the information is well presented in game. Carefully building your character not wasting points here and there is crucial. (Dont be afraid if it sounds complicated. If you play 3-4 hours, every thing becomes clearer). 

Certainly, randomness is there but every RPG has that element. So it wasnt a big deal for me.

I am looking forward to Blackguards 2. Congrats Dev for a quality game.

review: Gioco interessante, mischia le meccaniche a turni stile Wasteland 2, Divinity Original Sin e i vecchi Fallout ma non Ã¨ di certo a quei livelli. Da comprare solo ed esclusivamente in saldo e non spendere piÃ¹ di 10 euro.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967973198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1416698669}
review:
Got from humble Bundle. If I would have paid for it alone I would have been disappointed. As it is its a very basic turn based fantasy game with little to recommend it. Small uninspiring maps and dungeons, bad dialogue and storyline. Graphically its more like NWN1 and spell effects and melee moves arent great looking. 

Its not all bad though. Tactical battles are its only real saving grace.

To many other games offer more for your time though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005919137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 341, 'playtime_forever': 2254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2254, 'last_played': 1416619613}
review:
Ok, this one is a little hard to review as the pros and cons of the game basically cancel each other out.
Pros: game play, variety of tactics, visuals and hand made maps
Cons: game mechanics (yep, only in this game you can mis a hit that has a 100% hit chance),  very linear character progression as it is easy to identify the best tactical combination.
And the story is so-so.
I personally enjoyed the game with some frustration over the battle mechanics.
My final conclussion is the game does not worth its full value and does not have much replayability value, so I would recomentd it as once off product

author: {'steamid': '76561198084414450', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 4032, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3951, 'last_played': 1450911961}
review:
Really good game, one of the first turn base games i've enjoyed in a while.

Pros:
-good story
-interesting characters
-good combat
-good amount of weapons,spells,armor
-Difficult but in a good way, actually makes you think.
-Very fun tactical gameplay with a ton of traps to really make things interesting

Cons- Really aren't any, their was the occasional bug but most of those were fixed already. Loved the game actually started a second playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007675562', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 2450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 877, 'last_played': 1686220514}
review:
Kill the beast !

no more secrets .... ofcourse i recommend it, its the reason why i bought the hubmle bundle

see, when i was like zero there was this machine with padles i later came to know as an atari 2600, and the game was yar's revenge

shortly after, an old man who wanted to be on edge bought a machine he never touched that changed my life, id been a simple gangster otherwise
it had asmyr adventure, wonderboy, duck shoot, spelunker, simons basic, geas and a power cartridge

a little while later when i was like twelve the old mans friend sold me his atari, i was twelve yes, he sold me and i paid for it with my money

now that

that had a demo of a game named civilization

i cherished it for many turns

rented a p.o. box and had the game imported, found out i could just import more and sell them

no one knew the word copyright and no one gave a shit

my first real turnbased strategy game after asmyr adventures

then 

i grew a little older

i found out my dick could be used for more than jerking off

a friend of mine i met somewhere took me home to smoke a fat one

wanna play a game ?
yea sure, i LOVE computer games

warlords ... a personal computer

warlords

turnbased

modern chess

only more options

so because of that i bought one

a pc
pentium 60

it cost about 120% of a wage thats considedred average today

just to play that game

and di loved it

and all the weedies in the hood loved it
and all my friends loved it

and we spent many hours on a few floppies

smoking criminal shit

which we got cheap cos it was close to the source

we are the local version of favela after all

then came 
XCOM

never seen or done before

now

you ask me why i like this game ?

TBS is rare enough but this one is actually GOOD

although

there seems to be a little problem

i bought it cos it said FULL controller support



it doesnt have that

i want my money back and  i want to keep the game cos thats how paper law should work for real

its a great game but i wouldnt have bought the bundle if it didnt promise me full controller support

so once more the marketing section is nothing but leeches and scum that should be treated like pariahs or police

author: {'steamid': '76561198138353915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1320, 'last_played': 1416523888}
review:
I hate it and I just want to finish it but it's hard

In all seriousness, it is a fun game to play at first.  It's a fun strategy game and it's hard to mess up too much at first.  However, if you do not build your team correctly, you might have to restart the game.  Some of the battles are just impossible if you do not have the right build, which is frustrating.  

It does have a good story and I think the different classes are well balanced and fun, but overall the game is just too tedious for me to recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006447370', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 807, 'last_played': 1416368844}
review: Glad I got this in the humble bundle and didn't actually pay for it. After muddling through some quests and putting up with the seriously terrible random number generator (honestly, the RNG is reason enough not to play this game, but I gave it a shot anyways), I was starting to have some fun and enjoy how my party was shaping up. Then I was suddenly rewarded with the death of my best ranged damage dealer for no reason at the start of a boss fight. Not death as in incapacitated in combat, but a scripted event that apparently just takes the char away from you. Gee thanks. Uninstalled.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006247563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1016, 'last_played': 1416345026}
review:
RNG is godawful. There is no way to properly strategize, because you can miss a 90% chance to hit 3 times in row. It's all luck and restarting a battle hoping the next time it all works out better. I finally gave up on this game when, in the second chapter, after a long, long series of battles, I had finally defeated the boss and only had to kill off the trash mobs when a gamebreaking bug made me unable to move or act with one of my characters. I couldn't even have him wait or end his turn.

Even if you got this game for free, don't waste your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011635974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1416403059}
review:
I am glad I only got this as part of the HumbleBundle (Side note, support Humble).
This is a turn based, hexgrid, dungeon crawler, rpg based on a not unheard of tabletop system.
It plays like a fan created mod to another game, in every way this game screams its lack of polish, it's terrible design and its aweful assets. This game makes NWN 1+2 look cutting edge

*FLAWS*

1) Inconsistant Mechanics; in short, they're half baked. An early mechanic is terrain tiles (water is slippery, bushes are flammable etc) and in theory these could make for some more complex tactical play, but sometimes thats not the case, water may just be a watery looking tile, or it may cause you to fall on your ass and be prone for a turn. Enemies never use them either, they just move to attack range throw fire, ice and poison.

2) Incorrect RNG; this is a tabletop system adapted for the PC, so of course its simmulating (with a pretty bad generator I might add) die rolls under the hood. You get told a percentage chance to hit (and can level up enough to see other stats) but the percentage shown is WRONG. That's right, the game actively lies to you because its number generation system isn't implemented right. 100% chance is actualy 90%, 65% is actualy 40%. You will also see the same resualt consistantly for mid range %, every time I fire an arrow at a humanoid enemy with a 65% chance to hit I would miss without fail. same goes for 50% with melee, this makes me think the random generator isn't so random after all.

3) Atrocious Voice acting; Dear gods is it terrible, it's not even laughably bad, the actors are often re-used but its like no-one told them they were doing different characters so everyone they voice sounds identicle. They were also clearly recorded completly seperatly without any lead in or practice because they're all delivered with the same dry detatchment of people with a full frontal lobotomy.

4) Poor story telling; The plot may improve as time goes on, but from what I've experienced so far I can already tell you my version "And so it was that the brave ranger stabbed the annoying sidekicks while they slept and went to live away from the continent full of madmen". Honestly it started out bad enough with the giant wolf having killed (or having been eating) a random damsel, you kill the wolf and then get arrested for her murder. The wolf was right there, you kill it, its body is lying on the ground next to the corpse, yet they arrest you for her murder. The rest of the story was following a bread crumb story into a veriaty of linier dungeons, speaking of which.

5) Dull Dungeon Design; if you're making a dungeon crawler then you need decent dungeons, so far everything has been a straight line with preset encounters, no element of maze, mystery or surprise. You know you will need to enter each point on the dungeon map, you know that each point is going to have an encounter, and you know that you will want to save scum the hell out of it just to preserve your precious resources.

6) Cheap assets; It's ugly. Very Ugly. There is no sense of unifying aesthetic. Everything is the same blocky 3d models with dodgy shadowing, terrain detailing can actualy conflict with mechanics "is that shoreline tile a water tile or a land tile? You won't know till you step on it" the models are barely detailed, only slightly more complex than the 3d models used for CIV V (the ones designed to render quickly at distance and not be looked at too closely). Combine this with a lack luster muZak score and it just doesn't feel good to experience.

7) Poor Performance; for a PC game, its not offering much in the way of performance options. You can set nebulous graphics quality but get no fine choice, you can pick a resolution but theres no windowed mode. In game I've seen multiple graphics glitches caused by lighting effects, flickering textures and even the Hex Grid breaking and flashing at the bottom of the screen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037198727', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 1786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1563, 'last_played': 1447747326}
review:
SchÃ¶nes Hex-Feld Kampfsystem, gepaart mit interessanter Story, die jedoch gegen Ende abbaute; das Ganze verpackt in eher durchschnittlicher Grafik, tollem Level-Design und atmosphÃ¤rischer Vertonung liefert ein mehr als zufriedenstellendes Gesamtpaket, das sein Geld auf jeden Fall wert ist.

Negativ anzumerken wÃ¤re noch, das einige der Steam-Achievements sich nicht richtig freischalten, was mich persÃ¶nlich jedoch nicht sonderlich stÃ¶rt. Viel enttÃ¤uschender ist fÃ¼r mich, wie bereits weiter oben erwÃ¤hnt, das Ende, welches selbst mit viel gutem Willen maximal erzwungen und viel zu hastig wirkte.

Dennoch ist das Spiel seinen Preis auf jeden Fall wert, wenn man auch mal etwas ruhiger angehende, taktischere Gefechte mag.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040712186', 'num_games_owned': 594, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2515, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2095, 'last_played': 1400161289}
review:
I played through the entire thing, and let me tell you it's not really good. Sure the first couple of fights are cool but after a while it gets repetetive and boring. There are certain combination of spell which make you nearly invincible.  Which is probably a good point because if you visit a new location you can be 90% sure there will be a fight. It's not as much a roll playing game as a fighting simulator with fancy spells.
The worst part is that the entire thing is just so freaking linear, and oh boy is the story predictable.
It's kinda fun but certainly not for 40â‚¬. at the moment of writing you can get it from humblebundle for around 6â‚¬ which is more appropriate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019131071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1416156576}
review:
I really didn't like the "hit or miss" system. You can't have 65-75% chances and get SIX MISS in a row. It's just frustrating. Would have been much better if the misses still inflicted some damage (ie. normal damage 7-8, miss damage 1-2) to avoid crazy reloading.
The rest of the game is nice, but because of that issue I've stopped playing after the 9-10th times I was defeated by the random number, and not by strategy or tactics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032183811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1416156019}
review:
Blackguards is a tatical rpg set on the Dark Eye universe with dungeons and dragons rules. I can't recommend it though. I am a long time fan of turn based tatical RPG's, since Shining Force, and this game has nothing special going for it, quite the contrary. I can't really tell you about the story, mainly a generic one with some plot twists. But as any good tatical rpg fan would tell you, the juice of the matter is the gameplay and theevolution of your party and it fails. Gameplay is soooo boring and minimalistic, and the inventory and hero atributes are a mess.

Stay clear.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030017547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3134, 'last_played': 1416255514}
review:
I enjoyed this game (hence the recommendation) but I really must caveat this, because this game is a cruel mistress.

Pros and cons as follows, because how much each point sways you will govern how much you get out of this game. 

On the whole I enjoyed it.

Pros:
- Funny dialogue and interesting characters. Naurim might be the greatest character in Western RPG history
- Deep strategy. There are lots of environment effects, ways to optimise and spells to learn.
- Good voice acting. Genuinely good and a nice array of accents. Apart from the main characters female voice
- Dark, gritty artistic direction. Few games capture being and anti-hero so well, with murky non-binary decision making
- Challenge. Good god the challenge.

Cons
-  It's a bit... broken. Little things that seem to have been left incomplete, or lack polish. This includes a few bugs with quests and achievements. A good example is that the combat controls list auto-save, but if you try to use it, the game says you can't.
- Not explaining things. Sometimes you will see environmental effects or objects, but have no idea what they are or do until they kill you. Sometimes it will drop you in a level with a special win condition, but it won't be clear what it is. This is fine once you work it out, but causes a bit of trial-and-error frustration
- The ending is, well, balls. Quite simply. There are apparently multiple endings, but to me the last chapter and ending felt a bit rushed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014863733', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1416157034}

author: {'steamid': '76561198007463835', 'num_games_owned': 989, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 1064, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1064, 'last_played': 1416230268}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198026788545', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1398038542}
review:
Buggy and poorly designed game with a lot of promise, that falls kind of flat. And that "Italian" character is super annoying. 

I stopped playing because I got stuck somewhere along. I got my team wounded without chance to heal them and so lost the next battle right at the beginning, where it so conviniently restarts when you are defeated. And that is it. I love turn based strategies and fantasy, but this does not work out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998120291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1417381590}
review:
Saying that this is an easy game is simply a load of arrogance. This is an easy game to get into but a hard game to master. Unlike many games of this genre, Blackguards is very unforgiving and will teach you a solid lesson for every mistake you do. Every action, moves and attacks you do should not be taken lightly. Even if the odds appear in your favour, not using cover, trying to get an attack on every turn and forgetting to equip valuable potions and such will quickly turn your battle sour. 

While a bit frustrating at times, I rather find this game a lot of fun. For the few hours that I've played, the storyline isn't bad and the characters are interesting. This basically a straight to the point, no BS RPG. There's no running around a village 2 hours just for the scenery. You get somewhere, talk to the npcs, get quests and you're in battle. 

The difficult battles are what keeps you hooked and satisfying. This is probably more of a 90s generation type of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115374089', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 7132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6248, 'last_played': 1441733534}
review:
Graphics: 7/10
Music: 7/10
Animations: 6/10
Story: 8/10
Humour: 8/10
Replayability: 9/10
Naurim's voice acting: 11/10

I'm so glad I bought this game even though it had rather mediocre reviews on Steam (don't know rly why). 

Blackguards is a turn-based RPG taking place in Aventuria world (Dark Eye franchise) where the main protagonist is accused of murder and must find a way how to redeem himself.

I have played 80 hours so far and still have not finished the game (which is huge).. but I must admit I rerolled my main character couple of times just to try out new skills/approaches. :)

I love the story. I love the quests. I love the in-game humour - I dare to say the humour is even better than in Borderlands 2. It's not so forced and it's generally cooler. :D

You lead your party of loveable outlaws throughout a dangerous world and you are balancing on a narrow edge of legal and illegal behavior. Don't expect any clichÃ©s. These guys are not your normal do-gooders, but you will love them. :D

Chapter 1 and 2 are very linear but that changes in Chapter 3 which is huge and has lots of side quests. The game can be  (sometimes) pretty difficult even on normal difficulty and you WILL have to use your brain (or Google). :D

The game is not likely worth the full price (39.99 EUR) which is a bit overpriced but I would definitely recommend buying it for 15-20 EUR on sale. You will spend hours and hours playing it.

Even though there are only 3 classes in Normal game mode to pick, you can always switch to Expert game mode and create a new game and a hero from scratch.
You will be able to create your champion as a mix of warrior/mage/hunter with emphasis on various skills/abilities and talents of your liking.

If you like turn-based RPG's or strategies with a good story, I highly recommend you buying this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002990097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1416007002}
review:
Blackguards is at first an interesting turn based RPG, with combat occuring on premade hex grid based maps. It is interesting because it does away with most of the filler that comes with most every RPG. You do not control your characters in any way outside of combat, you simply shift to a different spot in a city where you can talk to a couple of NPCs and that's it. Outside of towns you travel on the world map by clicking on a selectable point on the map and you are instantly transported to a town, or into combat if you have a quest going on outside of town.

This makes the game more fun at the beginning, because you always get to the important parts of the game instantly, that would be the combat and the story. However as you progress through the game the positive turns into a negative because you never start feeling a connection with any of your characters. The only time you control them is in combat and in combat they are simply damage dealing stats.

So the game becomes tedious as you start clicking through all the dialogue to just pick up the quests and then you do the quests, almost always by going into combat and you soon realise that the primary things you do in the game are combat and clicking through the story, which I might add is very simple and not at all interesting.

The combat at first is satisfying, especially for me since I am a fan of turn based, tile based combat. However you will probably start getting more and more annoyed with it because of its randomness (nearly every action has at least a small chance to fail and it seems to happen more often than it should). And also because of the lack of data while in combat, the battlelog is very nearly completely useless so you have to constantly pay attention to know what is happening, since the camera can jump around a bit if it's a larger map and you can lose track of the enemy actions. And there isn't enough contextual information with the game for when you move your characters. For example I'd like to know if one of my characters will pass through where an enemy can do an attack of opportunity on him, it's true that it isn't too hard to figure out for yourself if that will happen, but honestly you probably won't have the patience to do it after you are controlling 5 characters and have 5+ enemies each taking their own turn. The combat just becomes too slow at that point.

Outside of combat you also manage the equipment of each of your characters, which isn't really that interesting because there isn't much choice of weapons or armour and what little there is it's always a straight upgrade or not, so there isn't much thinking involved. Somewhat more involved is improving the skills of your characters, but even that becomes straightforward after a while, since you get an abundance of points to allocate throughout the game and you soon pick up the more desirable skills.

So to summarise my main points: no filler makes for a fun start, but it also destroys any potential character building, the story is very simple and not at all interesting, the combat is at first fun but it becomes tedious after a while, not much variety in equipment and finally not enough interesting skills which are worth putting points in. Definitely try the game if you are into turn based, tile based RPGs however be warned that the game can become tedious to play and it did so for me.

5 / 10

author: {'steamid': '76561198047210545', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1438416966}
review:
Good: no classes, nice array of spells and skills, use environment in combat, tactical rpg / hex / tbs combat, dialog is sort of funny sometimes, some quests are interesting

And now for the utterly horrible stuff that just makes this game unplayable even if you try really really really freaking hard to like it:
- RNG is just insane, to hit 90% actually is more like 50%, you can fail a 44% skill check 20 times in a row while the enemy will win a 57% skill check 20 times in a row, it's just BAD
- voice acting is sub par, when they're not trying to be funny and want to be taken serious the actors sound just ridiculous with their goofy accents
- graphics look much worse than they did in the trailer with everything maxed, environments are too dark and there's no brightness setting
- the "towns" get very repetitive very fast
- some battles are insanely hard unless you pass that one critical skill check / land that one critical spell making you restart over and over because of the damn RNG even if you did figure out how to win it
- there is little to no direction in the story, and worse still there is no real way to tell (aka not even a hint) of when you will arbitrarily loose all your gear / won't be able to rest for an extended number of battles / bunch of other stuff that suck the fun out of the game

author: {'steamid': '76561198015459605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1415975945}
review: Terrible. Uses old 1990's hex based combat system. you have to walk on actual hex grids  on the ground to move and them take turns for your combat. Complex circular menus for combat modes. This game is a complete waste of time and money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041163297', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 6846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4738, 'last_played': 1416223866}
review:
This game has some good concepts, but unfortunately it simply balls it up. It commits every sin in the CRPG handbook. 

Ultimately this game is NOT an enjoyable experience. The first mistake the developers make is confusing complexity with challenge. The character system in this game is needlessly complex and completely opaque. The fights are incredibly unbalanced, and while it is possible to scrape your way through using tactics, it all comes down to luck.

The combat system is absurd. My archer has repeatedly missed 100% chance to hit shots. Not parries, mind you, just completely missed. When you miss 5 90% shots in a row, against an opponent that has no special buffs, and meanwhile the enemy are not just hitting you but criting away, leaving you wounded and dying.

Twice now the game has committed the cardinal sin of CRPGs of taking away your progression for the sake of a gimmick. Too bad if you were trying to make an archer, here's a club, go knock things on the head for 2 damage. See, the thing is, unless you picked the fighter class you won't have power attack, which makes melee weapons as good as useless since you'll just be scratching the ticks of the enemies back. 

You can play as skillfully as you want and you will still be screwed over by RNG and the absurd combat mechanics. Here's an example: My archer just missed 5 90% shots in a row on a target. Missed. Not parried. The target was not buffed with dodge enhancing stats. Now, in some games that would be okay, you'd curse your luck but recover and reorganize your strategy. In Xcom you might pull back and try to lure the enemy into an overwatch trap while you heal up your guys. In this game, every shot you miss, every hit you do not land sets you further and further behind and it is completely out of your hand due to the level up system and comparitive enemy strengths.

This is not fun. The game itself is boring enough without having to go back and redo every freaking fight over and over trying to find some way to have just one of your guys survive. 

The loot drops are hilarious. Fifty pairs of hardened leather boots. Not one usable piece of armor. Boots. Boots all day. But don't think you can just buy armor for your party, the gold costs of the items mean that at best you will have one reasonably equipped and maybe leather pants on your other guys. 

And why on earth do the combat percentages change every round? Why when nothing else has changed does my warrior go from 90% to 50% then back to 85% ... if anything, im hitting the enemy it should go up. None of this makes any sense, it makes tactics pointless. Nothing is every explained.

Honestly do not waste your money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061747646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3728, 'last_played': 1415899187}
review:
Daedalic's Blackguards........Where to begin......I like so many others was rather excited by this title from the content shown here on steam. As a result i purchased this in the sale at 1/3 of its retail price for Â£10.99.  So a turn based dungeon crawler with rpg character development.  Right now the nitty gritty there are some details of gameplay but i shall not spoiler you on plot etc

Shortfalls in my opinion 

1) The Overall story of the game is linear there are very few opertunities to drastically alter the outcome of the game, there are a bunch of side quests which are optional? (but not completing these for the extra loot, gold and items will make your playthrough a nightmare in its own right! as enemies will be VASTLTY superior to your party of characters. I completed all the side quests and optional dungeon choices.  

2) Character Creation is shallow at best  you have a choice of TWO classes! the game does suggest three but its a joke you have the choice between spellcasters and non spell casters! There are no merchants, no stealth options, just pick a close combat weapon or a ranged weapon, or spells if your the former mage class. oh and all chracters can basically become cookie cut clones if you want them to be exactly the same. 

3) At Certain points your party composition will be radically altered i.e random members of your party will be unavailble to you for fights following the storyline (so all that time and effort spent developing a character for a specific niche,  those skills to help your party become less brittle will be for nothing making certain fights hellish to complete. 

4) The world map has a mere dozen locations for you to explore consisitng of the exact same format towns with the same vendors selling almost identical gear! Black guards is not like diablo where you can expect hoards of loot and mindlesss array of weapons, there are so few it makes you wonder if your ever going to have a badass looking character. 

5) Most of my game time was spent on loading screens........ugh i cannot stress how mind numbing this was!
The Aquisition of items and gear is extremely tedious especially at the start of the game those life saving potions are almost unobtainable and forces you to either sacrifce weapon and armour or go to battle injured. Later those same items become useless which makes you wonder why you invested so much in the first place. The interface is clunky and at times often difficult to direct your actions.


6) The variety of enemies was also sparse to say the least the same foes  cropping up again and again made killing them a real chore, I should also mention that there is NO level grinding in this game to improve your characters stats  for that fight you are having trouble with. 

7) THIS IS THE BIGGY The chance to hit modifier is The MOST ANNOYING PART OF THIS GAME!!! YOU WILLL NEVER BE MORE FRUSTRATED, NEVER MISS AS MANY ATTACKS OR FAILED CASTING ATTEMPTS  AS YOU WILL ENCOUNTER IN THIS GAME,  It has rusulted in me personally restarting hundreds of encounters because this game is COMPLETLY GOVERNED BY RANDOM CHANCE! it will try to break you!!!!!!

8) There are multiple battles linked together resluting in sometimes impossible to win situations as you have been thumped so bad due to unlucky attacks you've misseed ten times in a row or the enemy lads a whole slew of critical hits forcing you to use all your recovery items. (but....i hear you say what about your inventory?? yeah invent items can only be equiped outside of combat, also quicksaving is the same! only outside the dungeon! 

Basically the ENTIRE game is fight, FAST TRAVEL to location,  distribute stats, rinse, repeat, load, load, load, load,  get lucky, Save. 

Positives

The Dungeon maps are varied and are pretty to look at,  there are interactive objects to help you, most maps have a stratagy behind them to make things a wee bit easier but a couple of crucial misses will send that plan right out the window. 

There are moments of satisfaction when you drop that enemy who has forced you to load a dozen times and you complete the fight in no time flat. 

The Dialogue can be entertainig at times and you do find your characters personalities are pretty unique. 

Im Struggling to come up with more positive points! in all honesty i personally thought this was going to be a bit like a fantasy version of  x-com enemy unknown  (which is a fantastic game i do highly reocmmend) needless to say i was sorely dissapointed!  only die hard fans will see any replay out of this title. even at Â£10.99 i felt robbed and yes i did pour 60 hours into it but most of this was due to the snails pace of the combat system.

Brutally Honest review Hope someone finds this useful? 

Ryan :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197998097848', 'num_games_owned': 1368, 'num_reviews': 228, 'playtime_forever': 2339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2226, 'last_played': 1415880686}
review:
Blackguards - tato hra resp. tahove RPG je od zacinajuceho maleho (garazoveho) nemeckeho studia Daedalic Entertainment. Hra si nekladie velke ambicie ani nejde utocit na velke znacky, ale je to RPG zo starej skoly a dnes uz aj skoro rarita, lebo tento zaner v case rozmachu konzol takmer zanikol. Blackguards je spomienka na stare casy...

Po technickej stranke ma hra zopar technickych chyb, graficky engine asi tiez nie kazdemu pride po chuti, ale ak vezmeme ako hra vznikala a od koho tak predovsetkym velky respekt a potlesk. Pribeh je bezne klise boja dobra nad zlom v tomto pripade aj medzi bozstvami. Lenze hrdinovia prave niesu vzorom bajnych mytickych hrdinov dobrych mravov. Charaktery su dobre napisane a celkom dobre skombinovane. Trpaslik Naurim ktory svojou postavou a charakterom pripomina Gimliho s LoTR. Ale to len ako priklad. Kazda postava ma svoj pribeh a osobity charakter a je len na vas ako si ktoru oblubite. Co musim ale velmi vyzdvihnut je poctive kraftovanie postav do puntilku ako za starych cias, krvava obtiaznost ako sa patri (kde jeden spatny tah moze rozhodnut celu bitku) Co by som snad viac uvital, tak asi viac rozhovorov a v mestach viac interakcie. Proti 2D faceliftu nic nemam ale je to istym sposobom moc staticke. Zato boje su  dynamicke, akcne a oku lahodiace.

Verdikt: (hodnotim za seba ako nadsenec daneho zanru - 9/10)  Technickejsi pohlad na vec 7/10

+ tahove RPG zo starej skoly, charaktery, obtiaznost, kraftovanie postav, nadherne a akcne boje na mapach, pribeh i ked je klise, ale to k dobremu RPG predsa patri...

- nedotiahnute veci ako neprakticky subojovy system, obcas zle snimanie kamery nad bojiskom, sem-tam pokulhavajuca AI, suboje casto na nahodu, trocha zamrzi vlazny koniec.

dodatok: Stale ale ostava fakt, ze Nemci vedia robit spickove RPG (Viva Gothic) Ak prehltnete zopar tych nedostatkov a ste PCckari zo starej generacie, tak pridete tejto hre samozrejme na chut. Ja ako nadsenec vrelo odporucam a tesim sa na pokracovanie (kde uz autori slubuju ze podobne muchy vychytaju) co budem len rad a BG2 dam s cistym svedomim 10/10. :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198003996183', 'num_games_owned': 1415, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1499131971}
review:
I have really been enjoying Blackguards.  I love turn based combat but most of the other similar games I've found have you manage squads.  Here you manage a band of adventures with your main focus on a single party member.  The combat is challenging and the graphics are beautiful.  Between combat it feels like more like a point and click adventure which is a novel concept I really enjoy.  The story isn't particularly complex but feels well told and engaging.

There are a few small bugs in the UI I've come across but nothing that impedes game play.  I'm hard pressed to think of any other game like it and I'm looking forward to future DLC's in the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061973018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2088, 'last_played': 1418166778}
review:
A little difficult to get to grips with at the start but all in all a very enjoyable game (thus far). The game has managed to stay at a very good difficulty level so that it is challenging but not impossible which serves to keep it engaging. There are also lots of little quirks and a well written story which really adds to the experience and keeps things fresh. I feel like I'm part of a story when placing this game as opposed to just playing a game. 

One small thing that annoys me is that there are no concequences of dying which I feel always takes away from the suspence of a game. Also comparing equipment with your current equipment or just reading the stats of things in general is a bit of pain. But apart from that it's a pretty darn good game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994248416', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 22077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4411, 'last_played': 1489953928}
review:
I had a lot of fun playing this game. A lovely mix of turn based strategy and plain old rpg. --7/10
All proÂ´s and conÂ´s are, ofcourse, from my viewpoint. (As an old school rpg player and fairly hardcore computer gamer.)

PROÂ´s:
* No over abundance of +5 Swords of the destroyer with bells, whistles and a blowtorch. A quite minimalistic level of "Magical" weapons and armor. 

* Some great battlegrounds with nice scenery and interactive gadgets.

* Likable characters.


CONÂ´s:
* Some dialouges seemed slapped together in a hurry with no "own" background and a lack of engageing content.

* Hexagon focus reacts to creatures. i.e. Animated inhabitants of said hexagons neighbour can interfer with what tile you click. Very frustrating ending up clicking the wrong tile while attacking. Forced me to rage quit 3-4 times. :) (Can be avoided by setting camera angle 90 degrees, but then the visual experience is lost.)

* Would have liked to be able to configure the apperance of my main character a lot more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043307078', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1415410322}
review:
I really don't like this game.

Confusing for the sake of confusing doesn't make a game complex or interesting.  The character stat screen tells you very little of the impact that your leveling decisions make.  So much of the directional choices you make with characters appears to be hidden.  The hit percentage system, how to recover health/mana efficiently and the effects of decisions are just a few examples of this.

I understand that a fair amount of people believe that this hidden veil makes the game more complex, and that they consequently are "more intelligent" because they "figured it out".  I would argue that they wasted their time fiddling with a poorly designed game when they could have been playing a game that isn't a waste of time.

I should have played the friggin' demo first.  So for that, I entirely blame myself.

Manche KÃ¤mpfe sind extrem leicht, andere extrem schwer, andere widerum ohne gutmÃ¼tigen RNG nicht zu schaffen (ich sage nur: Iribar-Lilie ... WTF?!) author: {'steamid': '76561198032073879', 'num_games_owned': 1315, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1409674824}
review: I really wanted to like this game sooo bad.  But I just couldn't get into the story, the repetition and the leveling system.  It's also very linear, and doesn't have many extra goodies you can run into by accident that you'd expect in some RPGs.  I haven't logged a ton of time into it, but I can tell after 3 and a half hours, this definitely isn't something I'll ever be able to get into.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971458919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1413, 'last_played': 1415576191}
review:
I don't even know how to explain the lackluster gameplay. Simple put, if you enjoy games where you have to lose battles a dozen times to memorize trap locations, constantly fight unbalanced matches and only like to stick with non-intuitive,  cookie cutter builds, then this game is definitely for you. 
If you want to experiment with unique builds, play melee or just want some fun battles and original gameplay, look elsewhere, this really isnt for you.

Not even a couple of hours into the game and I realised that the battle mechanics are absolutely one of the worst i've seen, in over a decade of playing turn based strategy games. It's another perfect example of developers compensating for horrible AI, by overpowering the player.

A few other problems: This isnt tactical, it's nearly impossible to be tactical in this game because the maps are way too simple, if you're looking for XCOM style tactics, this is nowhere close. Most of the obstacles can be shot through and they provide no additional defense(unless of course the enemy is behind them, in which case they will shoot from behind their obstacle and also through yours and still knock you down with an arrow, from the other end of the map), even with 90% hit chance you will constantly miss.

I've never once wanted to give up on a game so fast but I already see no incentive to continue with this game, it's just so boring and unrewarding for the difficulty. I regret buying it, even at the sale price of $15.

Please, for your sake, ignore the steam reviews and do some proper online research before buying this game.
