author: {'steamid': '76561198083092650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2830, 'last_played': 1414916356}
review:
First, let me just say that (spoiler alert!) despite the title and hype, the game still ends up with a cliched save-the-world scenario.  Which was a bit of a disappointment.

All right, so there's some good points to this game: The combats are each well-designed (often frustrating, but that's part of the fun), and almost every combat has some interactive environment object you can use to either help or hurt you.  This part of the game works great.  I wish the rest of the game was better so I could take more advantage of it.

Further good news: The game isn't ridiculous easy, even on the easiest difficulty level.  I had to switch down from Normal in order to make any progress past the first chapter.

Now for the bad news.

First, the combat system is incredibly complicated.  The rules for combat are mostly invisible, but reading through them (on the help screen) made my eyes cross.  This coming from a guy who plays tabletop D&D, HERO System, Shadowrun, Traveller, and Legend of the Five Rings.  This might explain why the chance to hit an opponent is vastly different from the chance marked on your screen.  Anything under an 80% chance to hit will miss at least 2/3 of the time.  And there's one enemy in particular that you won't hit more than about 1/20 of the time, despite the fact that your hit % is shown as 60.  Always.  I'm not sure if the hit chance is failing to take into account about half the combat rules, or if (as some others have suggested) the random number generator is just broken.  Either way, this drops my enjoyment of the game by quite a bit.

The other problem is that there's really no actual "role-playing" involved in the game.  There's little to nothing you can do to direct the game, except in some of the sidequests.  And most of that involves giving up a sidequest instead of finishing it.  Sure, you have dialogue options, but they don't really *DO* anything.  

Overall, I'd probably rate this something like 3/10.  The combat scenes are great, but the combat itself fails, and everything else is boring as hell.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974622265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1414878004}
review:
I have to admit that I bought this game blindly: Daedelic had such a good name with me that I didn't read any reviews. So maybe this is just a case of disappointed love. Anyway: I only played a few hours and then stopped, because:
- imho the dark eye rpg system is clumsy and makes for rather boring fights
- the game restricts you to fights on small hex fields without any exploring or experience of a world, to small towns (basically a static screen which allows you to click on merchants and trainers), and static travel screens. 
- the story and the characters are stereotyped, especially strange from a company wellknown for its storytelling.
- the interface is very counterintuitive (fighting, selling etc.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197994230683', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1320, 'last_played': 1414781815}
review:
Blackguards ist ein spaÃŸiges Rundenstrategiespiel mit einigen Problemchen.

Die Grundidee, detailreiche TaktikkÃ¤mpfe Ã¼ber eine rudimentÃ¤re Weltkarte zu verzahnen, funktioniert super. Auch die eher simpel gehaltene Story wird mit kurzen Cutscenes und ebenso Ã¼berschaubaren Dialogen gut erzÃ¤hlt. Blackguards holt aus einfachen Mitteln viel raus - das ist mir wesentlich lieber als das oft unnÃ¶tig aufgeblÃ¤hte Storytelling, das man in vielen RPGs findet.

Hauptkritikpunkt ist ausgerechnet das DSA-Regelwerk. Ich mag DSA im Allgemeinen und den gigantischen Regelsumpf im Speziellen, aber in einem solchen PC-Spiel funktionieren diese Regeln nicht ideal. Als Nicht-DSA-Profi wird man das Spiel ein zweites Mal starten wollen, sobald man das System grundlegend verstanden hat. Und selbst dann kann man sich aufgrund der vielen MÃ¶glichkeiten gnadenlos verrennen. Ich habe beispielsweise erst kurz vor Schluss gemerkt, dass es einen Zauber gibt, der einem Charakter eine zweite Aktivierung pro Runde erlaubt - hÃ¤tte ich den mal frÃ¼her genutzt, das Spiel wÃ¤re nur noch halb so schwer gewesen.

Zweiter kleiner Aufreger sind einige seltsame Designschnitzer:
[spoiler]An Niam hat man sich kaum gewÃ¶hnt, stirbt sie auch wieder. Man ohrfeigt sich, dass man sie diese vermaledeiten Drogen hat nehmen lassen - nur um dann in Foren oder im zweiten Spieldurchgang festzustellen, dass es daran gar nicht lag und sich der Tod der Dame gar nicht verhindern lÃ¤sst.
Noch schlimmer ist die Aurelia-Geschichte - die wird lange und hervorragend aufgebaut, dann haut Aurelia am Ende plÃ¶tzlich vÃ¶llig unmotiviert ab und tritt wenig spÃ¤ter als Gegner auf. Warum das passiert ist und wie man es hÃ¤tte verhindern kÃ¶nnen, erfÃ¤hrt man nicht. Da hÃ¤tte man sich die ganze Vorgeschichte sparen kÃ¶nnen.

Wie sich solche Seltsamkeiten in einem ansonsten sehr, sehr fertig aussehenden und gut getesteten Spiel in der Release-Version finden kÃ¶nnen, ist mir schleierhaft.[/spoiler]

Die Negativpunkte sind vor allem deshalb Ã¤rgerlich, weil sie nicht zum sonst hervorragenden Spiel passen. Das heiÃŸt aber auch, dass Blackguards trotz dieser Ã„rgernisse viel SpaÃŸ macht. Zurbaran und Naurim sind mir auÃŸerdem richtig ans Herz gewachsen - von den beiden wÃ¼rde ich sogar... Ã¤h... PlÃ¼schfiguren kaufen und in mein Regal stellen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977165692', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1414867732}
review:
so first of game is extremely liniar, doesnt do anything we havent seen before and it does everything worse then we have seen before...
secondly which idiot thought it was a good idea in an RPG to keep on taking away ALL the players gear?....

seriously!! i have only played for 5 hours now and because of "plot sht" all my gear have been stripped from all the chars 3 times untill now -.-
it is infuriating when its an RPG with focus on finding gear that the design keeps on stripping all your gear away -.-


when that is said there really isn't much too it, everything is very generic and not very well made...

anyway the gear stripping was what really got me to rage quit at the end -.- (scenario: so dwarfs refuse to interact with you unless you allow them to drug you and steal all your gear (first of seriously who came up with the "either get drugged or they aint talking to you"-.- the fact you got no other choice and cant continue the quest if you dont is completely stupid...)), then all your gear is stripped for the third time and now you have to fight fully geared people on their terms -.- seriously... soooooooooooo annoying....

i can't recommand such bad design decisions to any one...

author: {'steamid': '76561198027100899', 'num_games_owned': 673, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2218, 'last_played': 1426443215}
review:
Good tactic RPG, fairly hard, especially at the beginning where it is confusing.

There are a lot of side quests and what is really good is that most maps, if not all, are differents.

Any recommandation for any new player: specialization is the way to go.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971557606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 2360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2125, 'last_played': 1436746716}
review:
A solid strategy RPG that focuses on the combat and doesn't weigh you down with walking back and forth through the same areas. Cities, dungeons, and world are travelled by point and click and I enjoyed the simplicity of it. 

Combat is done with an isometric view on hexes. Each combat area is unique. Melee combat is fairly straight forward. The magic combat really shines with up to 4 levels of each spell, each level unique, allowing you to pick any level you have unlocked. So later in the game, a mage can have quite the variation of spells to choose from. 

I felt the game started a little slow, took off and didn't slow down until the anticlimactic ending. I was able to beat the game with over 30 hours which included the DLC. The DLC was integrated into the main campaign, which was nice. I like a game that doesn't overstay it's welcome.

Regarding difficulty, I felt many previous The Dark Eye games were much more difficult and appreciated the fact that I was able to get through this game with minimal issues. It is a strategy game, so if you pick poor weapon and spell combinations,you will hit a brick wall you can't pass. If you are having difficulty with the game, lower the difficulty. I like that difficulty can be changed. 

Another bonus is the game starts up quick and you can skip the intro and get right to the menu. It is worth mentioning with so many games forcing you to wait through minutes of unskippable logos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037357666', 'num_games_owned': 177, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1977, 'last_played': 1411291641}
review:
Blackguards would be an overall very good game if it wasn't for a few but very impactfull flaws.

I wont indulge in the pros, you can read on for that, I'll just briefly explain why I abandoned a game that I mostly enjoyed at the beginning of the final chapter.

First it lacks an element that should be at the very core of a game of this genre: character/team customization.

You get a very limited number of characters which is 4, one of them will be swapped with another at a point in the story leaving you with an underpowered character as well. You don't really have a real choice on how to develop them, there is a few things you can decide but since mages are defined by their magic and one of the fighters comes in already half trained the tactical phisionomy of your team is pretty much decided before you start the game. You can customize your main character a bit more but you'll realize that the only role lacking in your team will be an archer which is also the stronger dps in the game... 

Second and most important: everytime a loading screens appears cross your fingers because there's a good chance the game is gonna crash. This is most definetly something that can be fixed and it's also something that didn't affect every player,  but given how frequent and long the loading screens generally are it really ruined my experience with this game.

Third: devs brag a lot a about the depth of the story, they also use it as an alibi to justify things like killing fresh characters for no reason and the impossibility to farm. But the truth is there is not much of a story at all, the most of the game is a barely engagefull hunt for clues to unveil the mistery of what happened at the beginning, very linear, not interactive at all, if you're into powerfull story-driven stuff this game will strike you as trivial and stupid at some points.

Also given the price nowadays there's plenty more games of the same genre you might wanna give a shot to on steam that look much more promising.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996332121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1407011957}
review: Beautiful turn based rpg, interesting linear story and tactical fights

author: {'steamid': '76561198002916357', 'num_games_owned': 1988, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 2210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2149, 'last_played': 1413059097}
review:
Really interesting story with many choices when it comes to weapons and spells, but that's also the biggest downside. All attacks and spells success rates are dependent on how many points you put into the spell. This makes you not want to spend any points on more than one spell unless you want poor hit rates.

You also can't grind in this game. I managed to finish the story first time without much thought into where I put my points, but I can see how someone can squander their upgrade points in a way where they are too weak to finish the story. I think a new game plus would be nice for those of us that would like to go back through the game choosing alternate story options and destroying enemies with new unused spells.

I only played the base version of the game so maybe the expansions  add more than what I've experienced. I'd say it's worth playing but not for $40. Wait for it to be on sale. I wouldn't spend more than $20.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007312747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1176, 'last_played': 1413140995}
review:
For all the hype this game received it truly is infuriantingly awful!
The story is trope-ridden and uncompelling, a flaw which is compounded by the lack of any sense of progression due to enemies quickly becoming ridiculously overpowered (don't even get me started on the Iribar lily).
Combining an AP system with the need to locate a highly specific trainer to attain certain special abilities really damages the game, if you save up your AP hoping to find a trainer for a particular you find the enemies outclassing you due to the lack of uninvested points. When even a single missed hit can cost you the battle (which are frequently overly long) it seems counter-productive to have such low hit chances even when the relevant weapon skill is maxed out and complimentary stats are high.
I'm sure if you are a veteran of The Dark Eye, the choice of character build could be optimised such that the battles are easier; on the other hand the highly repetitive battle sequences, lack of character placement pre-battle, dreadful story, and lacklustre town interface probably wouldn't make the game enjoyable.
I was genuinely looking forward to this game heralding a new wave of turn-based/tactical rpgs (of which i am a great fan), but now I am left sincerely hoping the publisher never curses the world with a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969467785', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1505312040}

author: {'steamid': '76561197977433760', 'num_games_owned': 1029, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 1097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1097, 'last_played': 1399355821}
review:
A very difficutl game that will test your patience... not for the weak. 

You will probably restart your party 4-5 times before you leave the first zone. There is so much going on in this world it can be overwhelming. The skill tree alone is insane. Overall a very brutal game with one of the hardest play throughs yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008233171', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 945, 'last_played': 1414511018}
review:
Blackguards is a flawed game. But one that I have thoroughly enjoyed my time with so far.

Let's go over the problems first.

1. Difficulty. Particularly early on, the difficulty of each encounter can be horribly inconsistent. There's a reason why there is a "try again" button during fights - you're going to use it. Quite a lot. A lot of the more difficult fights have some kind of trick to them that might a try or two to figure out, and a lot of the time said fights require an element of luck too. One or two bad rolls or a few fizzled spells and it's time to try again. Anyone familiar with D&D probably knows that it's hard to create a balanced party with only three characters, which is all you start off with in this game: A mage, a fighter, and your main character who you can build as you wish. After a few hours you pick up a ranger too, who happens to be pretty good with traps, but until I acquired her, any map with hidden traps was a real pain to deal with. There was one fight where I had to memorise the location of the traps through multiple attempts before I could succeed. Additionally, sometimes quests force you through multiple fights with no escapes, and no warning beforehand, which can catch you off-guard if unprepared. In summary: Save often, and be prepared to try again.

2. The interface. The combat system is excellent, but the controls are a little clunky. There's some oddity to the character models which can make it hard to target enemies at times, and the camera is rather awkward at times too. It can get quite frustrating, but it's not so bad that I find myself making accidental moves or anything like that.

3. Information. The game can be very unclear about things. If you're not familiar with the RPG system the game is based on, trying to figure out how it all works is awkward, and the game basically only tells you things once. Being able to mouse over raw stats to see how they affect things would be nice. I have a parry rating of 7 on a character, what sort of parry chance does that actually equate to? How are these stats modifying dice rolls? You can get a rough idea of how things work over time, but I'd like to be able to see exactly what's going on. Contrast with, say, the original neverwinter nights, where if you wanted you could see every single roll being made.

So those are the negatives.

And the positives? Well, the combat system is fantastic, the RPG system, while incredibly deep and unclear, is also very flexible, you have a lot of freedom to let your characters grow in any way you want them to. The quests are enjoyable, the story is simple but engaging, the characters have some actual personality to them.

If you're willing to get over the initial hurdles of an incredibly complex system and some very frustrating battles, there is a deep and enjoyable game with a wealth of content available for you. The world itself is pretty unique, it does a good job of avoiding a lot of fantasy tropes and creating something a little more engaging, and there's something rather refreshing about having a party that aren't a bunch of do-gooders.

You're blackguards. My party consists of a wrongfully imprisoned warrior, a dwarf arsonist obsessed with dragons, a pompous upper-class noble from the south, and an elf who got high on drugs and owes everyone money. You're not evil, but you're certainly not good either. You're labelled scum by the people around you and hunted across a kingdom, adding to your list of crimes on the way.

I've completed chapter 1 and am partway through chapter 2. I'm eager to see how the game develops from here. If you can handle some difficulty and frustration at the start, this game is well worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066219042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 610, 'last_played': 1413474938}
review: Very decent turn based combat, and screen based towns and rooms is done nicely. The problem here is that it is seriously difficult even in Normal. It makes XCOM Classic Mode look easy. I also prefer easy-to-understand games, so its fairly complicated stat and skill system isn't quite my cup of tea either. I do recommend this game if you're very good in RPG and turn based games, since besides the absurd difficulty it plays nicely, but be warned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030734193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4733, 'last_played': 1412753513}
review: Never played any P&P game before, but this was awesome. Great RPG mechanics, good story (some parts shocked me, some parts were very funny) and graphics. Some battles were very hard (played on hard) and the only way out was to "rush" it, like killing the boss fast enough, which is not my playstyle. Otherwise you can do it in your own pace. Also had a feeling that there is a lack of gold so I never bought anything except arrows, bolts and magic books and ended the game with a quite a big amount of money :), so dont worry to spend it on smaller upgrades.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075904582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 829, 'last_played': 1413449484}
review:
I bought the game on sale last week because I never really played a turn-based RPG before and wanted to give this genre a try. As it wasn't too expensive it seemed like a choice without too many risks. I never heard of the game before and didn't read up on any tips to be able to start with a clear and unbiased spirit.

So far I have to admit I am really enjoying it. The story, characters and global setting don't appeal that much too me, although everything is more than correct. The story isn't that special, but forms the perfect background for the many fights I encountered so far.

And it's in this domain that the game really shines for me. Every fight (or almost every) I had so far really left some room for your own tactic. At the very start of the game I was a bit overwhelmed by the turn-based approach (as I  never played it before), but after a while you really get the hang of it. I like the fact that you have to think about the placement of every character aswell as which attack to use. The fact that it's turn-based also allows you to really plan your next move. Some fights were challenging, but I never got the feeling that it isn't fair so far.

I also really appreciate the fact that you can upgrade and shape your characters as you like it. The game allows you to create your party like YOU want to play it.

I only spent about 6 hours in the game so far, but I am sure many more will follow.

review: It took 26 hours to play until deleted.Iam Turn Based RPG fan.I really wanted to play Blackguards but game is unbalanced.Some fights are too hard and some classes are too weak.For example your mage's mana becomes zero after 3-4 spell cast and u need 1 turn to drink mana pot and mana pots are too expensive.Another example; there was a fight which there are 6 zombies and zombies were immune swords and bows.After 2-3 tries i just deleted game and i will never play again.I recommend you go play another game dont waste your money and time at Blackguards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006210523', 'num_games_owned': 393, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 1366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1366, 'last_played': 1412030650}
review:
L'ho gia' detto ma lo ripeto: Le tre parole "Rpg", "Turni" ed "Esagoni" suscitano in me brividi erotici. Ecco perche' quando ho visto questo Blackguards l'ho subito messo nella mia wishlist steam; E quando poi ho letto che il protagonista e i suoi compari sono delle canaglie di primordine l'hype e' montato subito alle stelle.
Ma come troppo spesso accade, ad un hype eccessivo segue una cocente delusione e Blackguard purtropo e' appunto uno dei tanti casi in cui le molte aspettative che abbiamo su di un titolo si rivelano prontamente deluse.
Il gioco utilizza il sistema ruolistico The Dark Eye, che prima dell'avvento dei vari Drakensang era conosciuto in pratica solo in Germania: Non sono un esperto di questo sistema (conosco molto meglio AD&D avendoci giocato e videogiocato per anni) per cui mi limito a dire l'implementazione di Daedalic sembra essere parecchio confusa e difficile da comprendere (sebbene abbia riscontrato la stessa confusione e difficolta' anche nei Drakensang).
Ma la componente ruolistica del gioco si limita in pratica alle sole statistiche del personaggio: Infatti, tutto il gioco e' una interminabile sequela di combattimenti a turni. Ci saranno si quest principali e secondarie ma il 99.999% di queste si risolveranno in uno scontro (le eccezioni sono veramente poche).
L'esplorazione e' praticamente assente, a meno che non consideriate "esplorazione" l'andare a combattere in aree nascoste che troverete strada facendo.

Viene da se che il cuore di questo gioco sono appunto gli scontri: Ambientati in arene ad esagoni sempre diverse (e qui devo fare i complimenti a Daedalic) vi terranno compagnia per la maggior parte del tempo che passerete a giocare a questo titolo.
Anche qui pero' sono gioie e dolori: In effetti devo dire che sono stato messo in difficolta' piu' dai problemi "ambientali" (le maledette trappole o i corridoi stretti all'interno dei quali e' facile finire bloccati dai nemici) o "situazionali" (in una delle primissime missioni e' necessario raggiungere una certa locazione in un certo numero di turni) che non dalla IA dei nemici, cosa questa che mi ha fatto decisamente storcere il naso: In un gioco massicciamente orientato al combattimento come questo mi sarei ragionevolmente aspettato una IA avversaria con il coltello fra i denti.
Idem l'IA alleta: Sebbene siate voi a dover comandare i compagni e' necessario usare opportue cautele o questi finiranno per passare immancabilmente sulle stesse trappole sulle quali siete gia' passati voi (sig!).
L'IA scadente, lacuna gia' di per se grave, non e' putroppo l'unico difetto di questo gioco: Ci sono infatti delle scelte di design e gameplay che mi rimangono incomprensibili (WARNING: semi spoiler piu' avanti!)

Non capisco infatti come sia accettabile che di 3 possibili classi per il personaggio principale: Guerriero, Ranger, Mago, quest'ultima sia resa completamente inutile dal fatto che ne avrete ben presto altri 2 nel party.
O come sia stato possibile decidere che l'unico personaggio ranged-combat oriented venga inevitabilmente ucciso nel terzo capitolo del gioco.
Insomma, sembra quasi che nessuno si sia preso la briga di pensare che il party  del player deve essere composto in maniera equilibrata e non alla "scegli una classe e poi sono cavoli tuoi"...
Infine, sarei grato se qualcuno mi spiegasse perche' l'equpaggiamento base costa una fortuna in rapporto al quantitativo di denaro che si raccoglie per missione (mi ci sono volute diverse quest per poter acquistare una armatura scarsa ad inizio gioco).

In conclusione, sto' Blackguards e' una enorme delusione: Peccato perche' con un migliore bilanciamento, una IA decente e qualche scelta piu' coraggiosa di gameplay sarebbe potuto essere un buon gioco anche senza stravolgerne l'essenza.

Dimenticavo: Avevo anche acquistato il DLC "Untold Legends", che in teoria avrei dovuto giocare nel corso della campagan principale del gioco. Se l'ho fatto non me ne sono accorto (e davvero non ho la voglia di indagare in merito).

author: {'steamid': '76561198052358899', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 628, 'last_played': 1412210900}
review:
I really wanted this game to be fun.  Only 6 hours in doesn't make me an expert by any means, but 6 hours of frustration and boredom is enough for me.  

The towm screens are all static,  with certain activities highlighted.  You can shop which doesn't take long as everything costs allot of coins and what the player gets on drops is insignificant.  Weapons drop and they are all inappropriate for the "basic" games preset skills.  For example, your warrior is proficient in single handed axes and the only bladed weapons that drop, initially, are swords.  So, in order to even hope to survive any of the battles you have to pump AP ( which are earned by combat and quests) into a weapon that you have found, rather than saving them for other talents.  Armor is virtually non existant as drops so you have no defense really.

There is virtually no game here other than scrounging for gear and combat.  Your path is pretty much preset with no real exploration and each location is either a static town or a combat grid.  

The other really stupid mechanic is your starting companions.   You get a dwarf warrior that is pretty good and a mage that is as useful as a box of combs for a bald man.  Now if you choose a mage as your class, the party has great ranged dps ability and very weak melee.  If you chosse a warrior its the reverse and you are in even worse shape as the preset companion mage is useless.  When looking at the mages's stats, you wil see he has the best "ranged weapon" skills of the three.  He also has the most Astral Points ( mana ) of the three.  Yet when equipped with a ranged weapon like a bow he misses every time.  His casting skills are not bad but the only really good spell is an AoE fire attack that does little or no damage and uses up all his mana in 3 turns.  Oh, your mana regens at the alarming rate of 1 to 2 points every 5 turns.  You are long dead by then as a mage can't wear armor, has little or no melee skills and now cant use magic.

Casting is a thrill, the effects are nice especially the failures which occur more than 50% of the time and the melee companion will miss 80% of the time on the only attack that does decent damage and the attack that has a high chance of hitting does insigificant damage.

Now I know that any starting party is releatively weak and there is an expected number of failures in any combat until the combat system is learned.  However, the punishment vs reward system in this game crucifies a new party.  

The typical battle has the odds at 3 or 4 enemies to 1, so you have 3 party members that miss and fizzle spells most of the time with no armor and medocre weapons against 6 or more enemies that miss maybe 1 in 10 times.  Your mana is used up pretty quick and the regen might let you cast one 10 pt heal just before the 3 enemies around you hit for 10 pts of damage each.

There was one battle in a cave of sorts, the 30 odd enemies were seperated from the party by twisting tunnels, but you can see them, so you know what is up a ahead.  After killing the 1st batch of enemies, about 10, I got to sit there mindlessly pressing the space bar until our mana regenerated enough to heal.  Yes heal pots, well they are  very dear, almost never drop and best saved for combat.   After healing the party I sat there pressing space bar for another 40 turns to regen enough mana to move forward and take on the next batch of enemies.  Needless to say that aside from the very deep skill system this game is visually boring and the combat is more so.  

Quite a few words come to mind for this game:  Dark, Dismal, Uninspirering, Frustrating, Boring.  It seems that the publisher is punishing the player for being stupid enough to actually give them money for the priviledge of being bored!

Blackguards is the sort of game that if you had a choice of getting a root canal or playing the game, you'd rush to your dentist with a smile on your face rather than load this game up!

I may get back into it, but there is no desire to spend many hours in this mess as there are other more rewarding games out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024444068', 'num_games_owned': 1457, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3015, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3015, 'last_played': 1411950733}
review:
Blackguards is great. Based on The Dark Eye setting and tabletop roleplaying game rules this game really captures those rules and lets them shine in a way previous real-time titles have not. The turn based nature of the combat system in the game really lets you see the benifit of the various different builds of characters where in a realtime combat game such as Drakensang based off of the same rule set does not.

The plot is engaging, lengthy, and at times really does feel like a transcript of a tabletop campaign, which is great for someone who maybe used to tabletop and just doesnt have the time to, or doesnt get the opportunity to as often as they would like.

All things said, I paid full price for the game, and don't think I spent even a penny more than the game was worth.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978802116', 'num_games_owned': 423, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1517, 'last_played': 1392424157}
review: Though it has some severe spikes in difficulty and has a system that, like Drakensang, is very hard to get a handle on quickly...it's remarkably good if you want oldschool turnbased combat. Long story, sharp dialog and some very cleverly planned-out combat scenarios. Can't go wrong if you have the skills for a real CRPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028615861', 'num_games_owned': 1136, 'num_reviews': 650, 'playtime_forever': 2144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1816, 'last_played': 1411333719}
review:
Blackguards es un muy buen juego de estrategia por turnos, que consigue con Ã©xito abordar prÃ¡cticamente todas las facetas de su diseÃ±o. Por un lado, tenemos unas batallas que estÃ¡n llenas de opciones estratÃ©gicas, cada una con un mapa Ãºnico que ofrece diferentes retos (trampas, cuellos de botella, lÃ­mites de tiempo...) y cada una con su propio objetivo (llegar a un sitio, matar a los enemigos, aguantar oleadas, cazar a un boss, pasar en sigilo...). La IA la verdad es que logra, ademÃ¡s, complicar muchos de los combates, haciendo un uso relativamente acertado de sus poderes y habilidades. A esta variedad en el diseÃ±o de las batallas se les une un desarrollo de personajes bastante complejo y personalizable, donde es fÃ¡cil escoger entre las diversas posibilidades sin estar atado a clases de ningÃºn tipo, y donde la combinaciÃ³n de habilidades de combate y magia se vuelve imprescindible. Todo ello se maneja desde un mapa de la regiÃ³n donde tenemos libertad para ir visitando las distintas zonas de combate, las ciudades donde aprender nuevas habilidades y comprar equipo, asÃ­ como los distintos lugares de conversaciones. Las conversaciones no tienen demasiada profundidad, es cierto, y la parte de roleo y la trama flojean un tanto, pero se perdona ante una jugabilidad tan sÃ³lida como la que tiene Blackguards.

A nivel grÃ¡fico Blackguards se nota que no es un AAA, pero el diseÃ±o es colorido y que todos los escenarios y localizaciones sean Ãºnicos les da un gran encanto que anima a explorar las diversas localizaciones. Los personajes son probablemente lo mÃ¡s flojo, especialmente cuando se hacen zooms durante las cinemÃ¡ticas o asÃ­ y se nota que su carga poligonal y detalle son un poco bajos, algo que pasa relativamente desapercibido el resto del tiempo al estar la cÃ¡mara cenital relativamente alejada. El sonido de las voces estÃ¡ bien, y los efectos cumplen tambiÃ©n adecuadamente aunque sin aspavientos; la mÃºsica es un poco mÃ¡s floja, en la medida en que hay una cierta escasez de canciones y las que hay a mi no me acaban de convencer. 

Pero, si eres capaz de ver mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de su apartado tÃ©cnico, Blackguards probablemente te convenza con su profunda y compleja jugabilidad. Un 8,5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009244297', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2983, 'last_played': 1411859102}
review:
Highly recommended for fans of turn-based fantasy and role-playing games in general.

Pros: The adventure system is a welcome relief from wandering around huge towns of useless NPCs. It's similar to point-and-click adventures of old. Let's you get to the story and/or combat quickly.

Cool level-up system. Characters really start to feel powerful at later levels.

Attractive graphics and runs smoothly.

Neat battle set-ups. Battles have traps, special objectives, secrets, and ambushes. There are a good number of straight up fights, but the set piece battles really spice things up.

Interesting (but not completely original) story with an compelling (but really not original) cast. It keeps you interested enough to follow along rather than just clicking through the dialogs, and the cut-scenes are simple but well done.

Cons: I strongly recommend starting on "Easy" difficultly. This really feels like it should be the default and is best for first-time players. The mechanics of the game are a little obscure, and having one play-through under your belt is best. Easy offers a good challenge without being frustrating, and gives you freedom to explore the game.

Again, obscure mechanics and no way to respec makes the game progression rather unforgiving.

Sparse loot. Don't get me wrong, I think it is a nice chance of pace to have magic items actually be rare and not drop 11 times each battle, but it feels like the game is really stingy with the rewards. It does make the few items you get feel more special but, unfortunately, they're not even that much better than the standard ones you can buy.

The characters you get aren't very customizable in their roles. But they do what they do well. 

Low replayability. You could replay the game on a harder difficulty, but why? It's a long game and nothing is really randomized. It's not really much of a con though since the game is so long with lots of optional quests.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078387587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 952, 'last_played': 1410742799}
review: This game is fantastic. The voice acting for the most part is well done, the environments are all varied and offer unique ways to defeat the enemy as opposed to the traditional way which is also a neat touch. I absolutely love turn-based combat so if you guys keep this up I will happily buy from you again. Anybody who likes grid tactics games like Banner Saga or XCOM should have no trouble jumping head first into this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993757990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3288, 'last_played': 1410653326}
review:
This game was terrible.

To elaborate, the game draws you in with the idea of a turn-based RPG with an unkown and intersting story and encourages the idea of character customization, dialogue options, and all that awesome stuff.

Its lies, simply said and done its all lies.

1. You will be stuck with a pre-determined 'party', with pre-determined skillsets, there is no 'designing a party'.

2. The story is predictable, you loose your memory and gotta figure out what you forgot...

3. The 'dialogue/charisma' options  while changing minor things are so few and far between there is almost no reason to do anything but SMASH and kill everything.

4. Mages can't learn new skills until you purchase books for them (which are extremely expensive, so you won't learn any new magics till mid-late game.) While I am on the topic of mages there is a checkbox at the start of the game which effective says 'magic abillity' if you select that, you get mana and can be a mage- otherwise you'll never have that option.

5. The skill tree is the same for everyone, so your sword wielding guy will go into swords and use the same 1-3 skills the entire game. (but will have extra points so he can get the same skills as your... archer!)

If you haven't decided to quickly run away from this game yet, there are more 'great' things about this game I can only hope you never find out. The ending is as bad as you think its going to be about half way through (and its almost 100% predictible from the start...).

If you haven't fled by now, you either love torture or your so dense this game might be for you (join the other <7% that have played through more than half of this game...).

If you want a game like this, go play Dragon Age I or II, Divinity (for gods sake its way better), or pretty much any other turn based RPG game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005951688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 828, 'last_played': 1407631032}
review: Not very much fun.  The characters are not likeable, and the combat, though neither interesting or enjoyable, is quite slow.

review:
Good storyline - easy to follow but not linear
Good variation in missions
Nice blend of characters - cool interaction in dialogue
Lovely turn-based action with a lot of choices
Good music - gives the game a good adventuring wibe
Great way to build and level up your party

Love this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197991440833', 'num_games_owned': 2604, 'num_reviews': 256, 'playtime_forever': 338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1410489358}
review: Fascinating turn-based RPG. I love the story so far, enriched by these interesting characters. If you're into the Dark Eye universe, this is a must-buy, for everyone else: If you enjoy challenging battles that involve the environment, you will find yourself at home. Don't expect anything groundbreaking tho - fights can drag on for a while and there is no way to quicksave during a battle, which can get frustrating if you can't figure out a certain tactic - especially on the hardest difficulty.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995423785', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1077, 'last_played': 1404775347}
review:
I bought this game having read a lot of the reviews. I was expecting it to be primarily centered around hex-grid combat. I knew this and dived in - I love games like HoMM and Kings Bounty. Other reviews have mentioned that the game is essentially battle to battle, with a few static village screens thrown in to try and create a background. Even so, I was expecting so much more. Everything in the game seems to have been implemented with the minimum amount of thought. There are relatively few upgradable skills and I found it fairly easy to just divide skill groups between party members and max them out fairly early in the game. Other reviewers have mentioned difficulty spikes in certain battles and this is occassionally true - some of the early battles are harder than the 'legendary' arena battles you have to overcome later on.

Actually, one of the main sticking points for me was the distinct lack of equipment - or at least variety of equipment. If the game is going to be based entirely around battles, surely you should feel like winning is going to bring some great bounty, but in the end all you get is a pair of boots and 5 coins, or whatever. There aren't even any item conditions to mix things up (rusty swards, superior buckler, etc). The amount of XP you get after a battle seems to bear very little resemblence to its difficulty either. All of this leaves the game without any reason for you to be excited or want to carry on into the next battle (apart from the inherent addictiveness of turn-based RPG combat). You feel like maybe you should be progressing the story, but I also found the story boring for the most part, apart from a few of the cut-scene events. I recently bought the Baldurs Gate 2:EE and played for a few hours, the contrast in characterisation is ludicrous - straight away I was enjoying the quips and comments from party members - while the characters in Blackguards just aren't really memorable, I found myself interested at the beginning, but raply lost interest, either through poor writing or due to the incredibly slow pace of storytelling.

Overall, I felt there weren't really any redeeming features for Blackguards - sure its graphically competent (although by no means pretty), sure the combat and strategy is acceptable (but by no means exciting or ground breaking in any way), sure the character concepts are interesting, but they just don't go anywhere. It's all a bit of a muddle really.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003025040', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3533, 'last_played': 1410203571}
review:
Era tanto che non giocavo fino in fondo un gioco.

E' un buon rpg, ha una bella trama e risulta estremamente bilanciato nella difficoltÃ .
E' un po' come giocare ad una versione moderna e molto piÃ¹ rpg di un vecchio Fantasy General o un piÃ¹ recente Fantasy War.
In partica Ã¨ un susseguirsi di battaglie su schema a griglia che risultano molto ben caratterizzate.
Ad un livello successivo, sempre su mappa statica, troviamo la mappa del dungeon in cui ci troviamo dove possiamo spostarci di stanza in stanza (mappe di battaglia esagonali). Ad un livello ancora superiore troviamo la mappa statica del mondo in cui possiamo spostarci "liberamente" tra le varie location che riconducono inevitabilmente a cittÃ  (ruolo e componente rpg), dungeon o direttamente a terreni di battaglia. 

Ho letto in giro che Ã¨ difficile, devo dire che se non si distribuiscono con cura i pavv e le abilitÃ  potrebbe risultare molto piÃ¹ ostico di quello che Ã¨. Per quanto mi riguarda, affrontando tutte le quest che mi Ã¨ stato possibile individuare, sono riuscito senza frustrazioni a finirlo con molta soddisfazione.

Lo consiglio a pieni voti, una nota sul prezzo.
Non ci spenderei piÃ¹ di 20/25â‚¬, questo non perchÃ¨ non parliamo di un titolo AAA, per gli appassionati del genere lo Ã¨, ma perchÃ¨ considero che titoli anche in tripla A debbano costare massimo quella cifra. Io personalmente l'ho preso in saldo a 11â‚¬ e in ogni caso sui 20 andate ad occhi chiusi.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992686079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1410132844}
review:
Scripted mis-chances and rather insane mis-chances are just the start. (I had a 5% chance to hit a troll 7 hexes big...really? Or tried to cast a spell and had it fail 3 times with a 90% and then another 85% all in a row...which is about a 1 in a million chance I believe)  As well I at least disliked both the dialog and the leveling system which rather then letting you pick what you want if you do not go up in certain skills you will make the game impossible since there are no methods of leveling up other then the pre-set battles.  I tired with 4 different setup and every time(sometimes sooner then others) ran into a just stupidly setup battle where I would have selected a much different skill set then I had.

I did end up not playing this game much but unless it takes off(always a possibility) it seems that you are just meandering through life without much direction other then random people giving you quests that I mean go to X and have a battle...no real interesting battles other then some I get to run through enemies with everyone killing me in a time limit or press a button causing some other random thing to happen that I feel was just put there to make the battle go on longer rather then for flavor.

I am sure there are plenty of people who like this game but I just don't see why I would play this when there are so many better games out there even in this genre then this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971500794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 2450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2450, 'last_played': 1410133721}
review:
Pretty good SRPG, decent graphics,gameplay and leveling mechanics in terms of many choices to level up in and really create characters you want for your tactics.
Some of the fights, or rather mechanics in the games are kind of broken. You can miss like 10-15 times on a row, even with maxed skills and thus lose fights on it, and other times you might hit and crit on bosses constantly and wipe them extremly fast... A quick examples are bosses that has 40% dodge on any attacks you do. Now imagien that they also poison you, and spawning mobs that are basically impossible to kill. Now, you can lose this fight, like I did 10+ times because you keep missing everytime. And yes, then another time, you might hit basically every swing and boss is down before you know it. Thats not balanced, its just random and in a SRPG based on tactics luck should never play a big part into it. I can understand some luck mechanics for the rpg-elements, but 40% miss on a boss that hit hard back? and he is a tank? Come on...

I would give this game maybe a 7.5 or 8.0 of 10. When this game is at its best its actually really good, but when its at its worst its horrible. Probably need better beta test for the sequal in terms of balancing out battles, be more open about what to level up in, lots of trial and errors if you dont know what your supposed to level up or not. Also, the story and sidequest need to be better... basically as it is now, side-quest are kind of neccessary to finish for that vital AP which you level up in. So its not even a choice to do them or not.

I finished the game in 40 hours on normal difficulty, so this is a pretty lenghty game I guess 35 to 45+ hours.
Would I buy the sequal? Probably, yes, especially when its on some kind of a cheap discount, because I love srpg's and wanna support them (Final Fantasy Tactics need a sequal...) - but if the sequal for Blackguards, which is in development at this moment, get good reviews from the critics, I would probably buy it at launch. 
As I said this game could be great, it isnt however atm in this state in terms of balancing and storywise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006627168', 'num_games_owned': 1690, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1418240853}
review:
Truly horrible font

This is a RPG with lots of written text (Conversations, ...). Yet noone bothered to make sure that it is actually readable.
Sure you CAN read it if you try, but only much slower than you do normally. This is the least readable font I have seen in years.

But don't take my word on it, judge for yourself:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=284444538

Note how there is no straight baseline, how the same letter has different looks, the thin l (lower L) and I (upper i), the distorted L and F, ...

One important twist is that not all parts of the game are affected by this. The most important areas that are affected are conversations, menus and help. The suggested change to different resolutions did not make the fonts better, just different.

While this particular screenshot was taken from the demo it still looks the same in version 1.5 (and they have anounced that they won't do further updates)

Can't really say much about the rest of the game, this basically prevented me from even finishing the tutorial.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970072265', 'num_games_owned': 358, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1409654241}
review:
Tja... leider hab ich nun Gewissheit. Dieses Spiel wirkt etwas unfertig und sehr ungeschliffen.
Vorweg, ich habe die Nordlandtrilogie durch gespielt und hab etwas Ã¤hnliches erwartet, wusste allerdings, dass sich bei DSA inzwischen das Regelwerk stark geÃ¤ndert hat.

Die Charaktererstellung hat echt SpaÃŸ gemacht, die ist ja egtl. bei jedem Rollenspiel eines der Highlights.
Man kauft sich mit Abenteuerpunkten seine FÃ¤higkeiten zusammen was ich fÃ¼r eine groÃŸe Verbesserung gegenÃ¼ber dem alten Zufallsbasierten System halte. Allerdings kann man keine Rasse wÃ¤hlen, das stÃ¶ÃŸt dann schon etwas Ã¼bel auf.

Dann wird man auch schon sehr schnell in`s Geschehen geworfen. Das Spiel ist eine riesige Aneinanderreihung von rundenbasierten KÃ¤mpfen auf unterschiedlichen Schlachtfeldern. AuÃŸerhalb von Gefechten kann man lediglich von Punkt zu Punkt laufen.
Und auch wenn das Kampfsystem nicht schlecht ist, so wirkt es recht unausgereift. Ich weiss nicht, ob das Pen&Paperspiel mit DSA v.4 die Aktionspunkte von frÃ¼her vollkommen entfernt hat, aber es wirkt, gerade wenn man die alten Spiele kennt, wie eine sehr abgestumpfte Version der frÃ¼heren Teile mit weit weniger Tiefe.
Und leider ist auch das Interface nicht besonders gelungen. Reihenfolge, KK und AE sind alles zusammen am linken unteren Bildschirm aufgefÃ¼hrt. Die rechte untere Ecke bleibt vollkommen ungenutzt und eine genauere Ãœbersicht Ã¼ber den Charakter, der gerade dran ist wÃ¤re wirklich angebracht. 
Das RingmenÃ¼ ist das verwirrendste am Kampfinterface. Das Spiel ist nie fÃ¼r die Konsolen erschienen und dennoch muss man sich mit dieser Ausgeburt der HÃ¶lle herumschlagen. Was Daedalic zu so einer Entscheidung getrieben hat, ist mir schleierhaft.

Es kann jedenfalls nicht sein, dass sie die wunderschÃ¶ne Grafik zu wenig wie mÃ¶glich verdecken wollten. Denn die Figuren wirken tot und teils hÃ¤sslich. Die Charaktere sind garnicht wieder zu erkennen wenn man die wunderschÃ¶nen Zeichnungen betrachtet und dann wieder die hÃ¤sslichen 3D-Modelle dazu sieht. Leider sind auch in den Dialogen zwischen den KÃ¤mpfen immer nur die toten Modells zu sehen, die sich Ã¼ber Textboxen am unteren Bildschirmrand unterhalten.
Hier sei angemerkt, dass das gesammte Spiel vertont ist, und die meiste Zeit auch ausgezeichnet, allerdings immerwieder von einigen Sprechern unterbrochen, die die Stimmung tÃ¶ten.

Leider hat Daedalic hier viel potential verschenkt und Blackguards kann mit der QualitÃ¤t ihrer Point&Click-Adventures nicht im geringsten mit halten. Schlecht ist es dennoch nicht... nur halt eben langweiliger Durchschnitt.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970812613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1409519893}
review: Altough I love RPG games I am really dissapointed in this one. Ok this is rather a strategy game than an RPG, but it even fails at that. There are virtually no strategy options on the battlefield. Attack or cast spell. If you are a fighter you stuck with the first option, and hope for some decent damage. Most damage I did was around 9. Enemies constantly do damage over 10+. And spellcasters fizzle their spells 50% of the time. Combine this with the fact that you can't even cast spell out of combat (eg: no healing). And you get this complicated luck based game, with 0 fun factor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032590325', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1409171215}
review:
This game has a lot going for it. There is a lot to customize. There are some interesting story elements, but it is just isn't fun to play. I love SRPGs. It's my favorite genre. This game isn't a great example of them, however. The characters are flat. The battles are uninteresting. The voice acting at times is horrendous. 

My most major issue, however, is the rate at which hits are calculated. You can have a 95% chance to hit, and only hit 60% of the time. It's very frustrating. 


If you wish to buy this game, you're not making a terrible choice. This game isn't terrible by any stretch of the imagination. I just don't recommend that people play it. It doesn't hold your attention long enough to get into anything interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008056105', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1050, 'last_played': 1409942251}
review: I thought it would be fun. It kind of is, but it's incredibly frustrating. Poor detection on clicking enemies and random luck screws you over worse than it does in XCOM. It's really inconsistant in its mechanics. You'd think it would be simple, that highest initiative goes first. But it doesn't. It seems like it only improves chances of going earlier in the turn order. Because I'll restart a level and a different character gets the first move. You'd think this would make things interesting but it just makes it incredibly difficult to learn from your mistakes when it constantly changes. Wounds just break immersion so much it's baffling that they put them in. Your characters get "wounds" that carry over from one fight to the next, which cripples them somewhat and you have to see a healer constantly if you didn't invest heavily in some kind of "do-it-yourself" wound healing. Really kills the immersion for me at least to leave a dungeon, go get healed and come back after every room. Some maps are just really unreasonable and you have to try over and over again to even almost win. I mean, it speaks volumes when the first option in the esc menu is "Try Again". I mean, I'm trying to be fair. The game is fun and the concept is great. Overall it's an okay game but if it weren't for the overwhelming swarm of tiny annoyances, it would have been amazing. All in all, it's far from a waste of money, but I honestly wish I had bought something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022068194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 671, 'last_played': 1688551964}
review: A strong contender for best strategy RPG of the year in my mind, this Hex-based RPG set within the Dark Eye mythos balances fun and challenging gameplay while not sacrificing any story or narrative content. The voice acting is a little weak and overblown, but otherwise a fantastic game with lots of promise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007742874', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 7715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1793, 'last_played': 1432644634}
review:
Graphics:  4/10 
Sound/dialog:  6/10 (Characters say some really dumb things)
Gameplay:  3/10    (CHANCE BASED COMBAT SUUUUUUCKS)
Performance:  Just pathetic (choppy and very low framerate no matter what quality on any system)

Chance based combat is the single biggest pile of garbage you could hand an RPG player.  This isn't RPG so much as digital slot machine with swords and spells, don't play it if you're a prone gambler because it'll trigger you.

FOR EXAMPLE:  The mage...

Your AOE attacks, the whole reason for having a mage present (because single target spells are far weaker than ranged weapons) only ever has a 45% chance of casting.  At All.  

You can't rely on ANY actions from ANY of your characters once you factor in dodge/block/parry because EVERYTHING is just as likely to fail as it is hit.  EVEN HEALING.

Nailed-to-the-floor linear with no chance to do random battles and level up - even levelling is on rails, rails of garbage that can derail your team-train.  I'm on my third dead-end playthrough at 3 hours because I keep hitting dead ends without proper abilities.

Bought thinking 'Awesome, a final fantasy tactics type thing!'  Instead I got crap gameplay and gambler's rage.

review: Jeux tres mediocre ,graphisme et animation depasse , on aurait pu esperer de veritable combat tactique mais il n en est rien sachant que l issu des combats est assujeti a un facteur "chance" nauseeux , en gros qu importe ta strategie ou ton equipement tu as 1 chance sur 2 de manquer ton attaque ou ton sort .On finit par s ennuyer ferme sachant que le scenario timbre poste vous tiendras pas non plus en haleine ... passez vite votre chemin.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027938810', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 2562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2562, 'last_played': 1397935068}
review: 8/10, one of the most enjoyable turn-based titles of the past year. Reasons? A lot of innovation: combat and level-up system, plot twists. Most annoying thing I remember weeks after playing it - no way to cancel or speed up animation. The bottom line is: close to a must for the lovers of genre, but I could hardly recommend it to newcomers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006677489', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 891, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1409520642}
review:
Fun turn-based tactical rpg.  Feels very old school and linear (no exploring or going your own path) but the storyline isn't terrible and the combat is a lot of fun so that's fine with me.  Invetory system feels very dated and cumbersome, but it gets the job done, compared to other RPGs though its a little annoying.  

Despite a few minor flaws I'm enjoying myself playing this and am glad I bought it on sale.  I couldn't justisfy full price on this one especially when there are far better RPGs at that price (Divinity I'm looking at you) but hey for $13 its good entertainment!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031651888', 'num_games_owned': 798, 'num_reviews': 441, 'playtime_forever': 3338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3338, 'last_played': 1409417929}
review:
Pas besoin d'avoir fini le jeu pour le recommander ! DÃ©jÃ  presque 30 heures que j'y joue, et malgrÃ© l'aspect rÃ©pÃ©titif qui ne plaira pas Ã  tout le monde (peu d'exploration, villes Ã  Ã©cran fixe, et beaucoup de combats), j'ADORE.

Daedalic Ã©tait dÃ©jÃ  un maÃ®tre dans le domaine de point'n click, et leur premier essai de RPG est un succÃ¨s. Les combats s'effectuent sur un terrain en damier hexagonal, au tour par tour, avec les rÃ¨gles de l'oeil noir. Assez difficiles Ã  apprÃ©hender pour des dÃ©butants, elles donnent toutefois une grande satisfaction lorsqu'on arrive Ã  les maÃ®triser et Ã  faire Ã©voluer son petit groupe.

Certains combats sont tactiques, d'autres TRES tactiques avec des mises en situation spÃ©ciales (groupe sÃ©parÃ©, compagnon inutilisable, perte d'Ã©quipement, temps limitÃ©). Rajoutez Ã  cela que le terrain peut Ãªtre piÃ©gÃ© ou obstruÃ©, et que les compÃ©tences et sortilÃ¨ges peuvent Ãªtre utiles dans une situation et inutiles dans une autre, et vous obtenez un excellent "tactical" comme on dit.

Mais attention, ceux qui n'aiment pas le tour par tour et qui favorisent avant tout l'exploration de cartes ou des dialogues riches avec choix/consÃ©quences devront passer leur chemin. Ici, c'est avant tout du combat avec un scÃ©nario assez lÃ©ger (mais qui a le mÃ©rite d'exister).

author: {'steamid': '76561197966687282', 'num_games_owned': 341, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1408832307}
review: I spent perhaps the past 4 hours playing this game and find that it's just not good enough to keep me plugging away at the repetitious win the roll or die battles. I've played several similar style games to this like Xcom, but this just lacked the feeling of tactical control of the situation. My suggestion for someone looking towards a good PC RPG with tactics - Divinity Original Sin. I just finished that game and found it to be very original in game play and enjoyable all the way through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018815227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1408798759}
review: Don't buy.  The game keeps things frustratingly difficult by keeping your equipment poor, charging you an arm and a leg to level things up, making all your actions fail at a 50% chance dispite that it says 90%, and after 9 hours of playing I never felt once that I had gotten more powerful.  Never once did I walk away from playing and think "Wow I can really tell my characters are getting stronger, I've spent my time and money wisely on this game."  Mostly I curse and say "F#ck this S#it I'm done".  And you know what I am.  Uninstalling it as soon as I click Post review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055217507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 6667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 984, 'last_played': 1658632367}
review: Graphics aren't great, gameplay is okay.. That put on top of the fact that some major missions are based on terrible RNG (worst I've seen).. I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone on a budget, if you have extra dough.. Sure why not?

author: {'steamid': '76561197970573455', 'num_games_owned': 580, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1408688738}
review:
The game is based on a complex rule system, which is not explained very well, if at all.  They try and simplify it where possible to simple percentages, but it is often unclear what exactly causes these percentages to rise or fall, leading to the game feeling much more complicated than it needs to be. 
Coupled with a difficulty curve that transitions from too easy to too hard with nothing inbetween, makes playing this game a frustrating experience.  There are much better turn based strategy games out there, wouldn't recommend this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107229874', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2773, 'last_played': 1481491550}
review: Fun and entertaining game

author: {'steamid': '76561198074169780', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1404051201}
review:
I too was excited about this game. It had a great intro video, and looked crisp. I have enjoyed rpg's since I tried Might & Magic 7. That game had a pretty long learning curve with no proper introduction and my younger self had no idea of the concept of doing quests for xp. But slowly I got stronger and stronger, and I learned my way trough the game.

Every time I encounter games without tutorials or hints to character building, I think of myself learning to play M&M7, thinking I just need to invest a few hours and things will clear up.

So me and a friend bought Blackguards, and played it both. He is older than me and I got a lot of grief from him, when I complained about the learning curve and difficulty. He said I am from a time when games are easy and I am a spoiled gamer.

That seems to be the issue here. People throw grief at the people not willing to spend 13 replays of a fight. Probably because they did 13 replays and want the rest of us to suffer the same. I play games to have fun, and Blackguards gives me no pleasure.

Am I a spoiled gamer? Maybe I am! Maybe I just dont want to sit and redo the same battle 13 times in a row. That gives me no pleasure! It does trigger a lot of screaming at the computer, cursing and pulling out hair. Maybe I am a spoiled gamer, but I would much rather chop off my arms than play any more than 8 hours of Blackguards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041433533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1449028119}
review:
Blackguard got some bad reviews, however this is a fine pice of old-school RPG. Battles are hard and tactical, and you might need to reload often (or cheat like I do). The story is good, and captivating. I like that there is no idle going around in big places and killing random monsters, each battle and each place somehow furthers story.
So I recommed Blackguard for all those old-school RPG loving fans out there!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025350259', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1242, 'last_played': 1428412283}
review:
This game is a little different, but clearly one of the best I've played in many years in this game category.

the skill tree is very good and the characters  are very developed and grows during gameplay when you can buy new weapons skills / spells and special skills.

as I said you will not regret this purchase, and it comes highly recommended!..

author: {'steamid': '76561198034410532', 'num_games_owned': 143, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 945, 'last_played': 1407606113}
review:
TrÃ¨s enthousiaste Ã  l'idÃ©e de dÃ©buter ce jeu, je partais sur une bonne impression. Personnalisation poussÃ©e du personnage, Ã  la maniÃ¨re d'un jdr papier, graphismes sympathiques, bande son agrÃ©able.
Mais, hÃ©las, tout retombe lorsque l'on s'aperÃ§oit que le jeu est trÃ¨s mal Ã©quilibrÃ©, que la trame scÃ©naristique reste plate et sans saveur, et que certains dÃ©nouement sont... navrants. 
Bon potentiel, mais sans finition, la sauce ne prend pas. Dommage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003008927', 'num_games_owned': 473, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 4977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4698, 'last_played': 1543029933}
review:
Blackguards, un RPG que je n'attendais pas vraiment contrairement Ã  d'autres titres du moment, et qui pourtant m'a davantage plu.
Les RPG tactiques ne sont pas mes favoris, mais force est d'admettre que ce dernier m'a fait renouer avec le genre.

Fan de RPG en tour par tour et en pause tactique, le gameplay m'a vraiment sÃ©duit.
Si vous aimez le genre, vous devriez apprÃ©cier ce Blackguards.
HÃ©ros et ennemis effectuent leurs actions, chacun leurs tours.
Les possibilitÃ©s d'Ã©volution des personnages sont assez poussÃ©es.
De petites innovations viennent rajouter du piment, comme les environnements interactifs.
Il est possible de dÃ©truire des obstacles pour se frayer un passage, mettre le feu Ã  des parties inflammables de la carte avec des magies ou armes enflammÃ©es, ou encore de provoquer une chute de pierres sur des ennemis mal placÃ©s, en dÃ©truisant un dÃ©cor au bon moment et j'en passe...
De mÃªme des piÃ¨ges sont parfois dissimulÃ©s sur la cartes, ou les terrains sauvages peu praticables peuvent vous rÃ©server des surprises...
A vous de prendre avantage de tout cela.

Le level design de ce jeu est vraiment de qualitÃ©, et sans cesse renouvelÃ©.
Les dÃ©veloppeurs ne se sont pas contentÃ© de crÃ©er des terrains vagues avec des ennemis dessus.
En plus des dÃ©cors interactifs, tous les champs de bataille sont vraiment travaillÃ©s, et certains sont vraiment originaux.
Conjuguez cela avec des conditions de victoires variÃ©es, et vous obtenez des affrontements souvent uniques.

Mais c'est surtout le challenge plutÃ´t relevÃ© qui m'a dÃ©finitivement conquis !
Il s'agit juste du plus gros point faible des RPG du moment, la difficultÃ© est trop souvent au ras des pÃ¢querettes ou mal calibrÃ©e ( difficile en dÃ©but d'aventure, et trop facile Ã  la fin).
Dans Blackguards, c'est le plus gros point fort.
Ce jeu est difficile du dÃ©but Ã  la fin !
J'ai savourÃ© chaque combat, ou chaque choix d'action devra Ãªtre murement rÃ©flÃ©chie.
Je conseille au hardcore gamers de mettre le jeu en difficultÃ© maximum dÃ¨s le dÃ©but, quant aux autres ils mettront le jeu en facile ou moyen ,et viendront pleurer sur les forums comme certains car ils n'ont pas le niveau...
Ce challenge Ã©levÃ© est Ã  la fois du aux ennemis retords, ainsi qu'au level design ingÃ©nieux.
La seule ombre au tableau est le cÃ´tÃ© parfois trop alÃ©atoire des combats.
La chance peu avoir un impact dÃ©cisif sur la rÃ©ussite de certaines actions, dont lâ€™Ã©chec peut vous pousser Ã  recommencer le combat tout entier.
D'ailleurs l'option rapide pour recommencer l'affrontement n'est pas lÃ  pour rien...
Mais cela devient moins vrai par la suite, car vos personnages deviennent plus efficaces, et les chances de rÃ©ussites de leurs actions augmentent drastiquement.
D'ailleurs certaines compÃ©tences sont vraiment trop efficaces, d'autant plus qu'elles peuvent Ãªtre spammÃ©es Ã  loisir ( triple tir de l'archer fumÃ©....).
J'ai sauvÃ© certaines confrontations rien que grÃ¢ce Ã  mon archer, mais ce fut sans grande fieretÃ© ni mÃ©rite...
Pour en venir Ã  la spÃ©cialisation des persos, celle-ci est plutÃ´t complÃ¨te, et propose beaucoup de sorts diffÃ©rents bien fun.
Mais il faut avouer que la personnalisation est un peu trop complexe, car chaque compÃ©tence demande des prÃ©-requis dans certaines stats, et on fini par s'y perdre dans le nombre de compÃ©tence Ã  devoir apprendre.
La consÃ©quence, est qu'il est facile de rater son personnage, surtout quand toutes les compÃ©tences et sorts ne se valent pas !
Le problÃ¨me aurait facilement pu Ãªtre contournÃ© en donnant la possibilitÃ© de respect ses personnages, mais non.
Et de grosses erreurs peuvent se traduire par un bloquage dans le jeu, et devoir recommencer de 0...frustrant.

Autre petit problÃ¨me : l'Ã©quipement est vraiment distribuÃ© et disponible au compte goutte, et les vrais sets intÃ©ressants se font rares.
C'est tout de mÃªme dommage car il s'agit d'une carotte bien apprÃ©ciable dans les RPG.

Le scÃ©nario du jeu est malheureusement trop classique et quelconque...et pourtant, la narration a pour moi Ã©tÃ© l'un des moteurs du jeu, exactement comme ce fut le cas avec Dragon Age Origins.
Ce n'est pas forcement l'histoire qui donne envie d'avancer, mais les personnages charismatiques, et les dialogues savoureux.
J'ai vu ces points critiquÃ©s ailleurs, mais je ne suis pas d'accord.
La plupart des protagonistes sont attachants, et l'humour est bien prÃ©sent.

Les quÃªtes du jeu peuvent souvent se rÃ©soudre de faÃ§on diffÃ©rentes.
Le joueur se voit offrir de nombreux choix dans les dialogues, et sur le champs de bataille.
Mais je regrette le fait que les affrontements directs sont TOUJOURS mieux rÃ©compensÃ©s que les solutions pacifiques.
Seuls les combats vous donneront de l'expÃ©rience, et autant d'argent.
Il m'est donc souvent arrivÃ© de prendre une dÃ©cision contraire Ã  mes valeurs, en privilÃ©giant la brutalitÃ©.

La durÃ©e de vie du titre est excellente.
Mais pas tant grÃ¢ce Ã  la quÃªte principale qui n'est finalement pas si longue.
C'est plutÃ´t l'abondance de quÃªtes annexes, toutes trÃ¨s intÃ©ressantes, qui vous prendra du temps.

Attention par contre, le jeu ne propose aucune exploration Ã  pieds ou autre dans divers environnements.
On se dÃ©place sur une map pour choisir les lieux Ã  visiter (ville, grotte etc.)
A l'intÃ©rieur du dit lieu choisi, le joueur observe un plan fixe Ã  la 1ere personne, et clique sur les protagonistes pour converser, ou choisi un itinÃ©raire, ce qui l'amÃ©nerera sur un nouveau plan fixe (etc.), avec des combats qui se dÃ©clencheront en fonction des Ã©venements (dialogues et dÃ©placements).
Pour moi ce n'est pas un gros dÃ©faut car la prioritÃ© des develloppeurs Ã©tait de se concentrer sur le gameplay des combats.
Mais fuyez ce jeu si vous Ãªtes du genre Ã  privilÃ©gier l'exploration.

Globalement ce Blackguards est tout simplement l'un des meilleurs RPG auquel j'ai pu jouer ces derniÃ¨res annÃ©es, et je suis assez surpris de constater certains retours mitigÃ©s.
Pour avoir jouÃ© Ã  certains Point and Clic des dÃ©veloppeurs de chez Deadlic, je peux dire qu'ils sont bien plus douÃ©s en RPG.
J'attends Blackguards 2 avec enthousiasme.


* Points forts :

+ C'est plutÃ´t joli
+ Gameplay au tour par tour rÃ©ussi
+ La spÃ©cialisation des personnages
+ Les sorts nombreux
+ La stratÃ©gie
+ Les interactions avec les environnements
+ Le level design sans cesse renouvelÃ©
+ Le challenge relevÃ©
+ Les personnages attachants
+ Les dialogues savoureux
+ Les choix
+ Excellente durÃ©e de vie


* Points faibles :

- L'histoire quelconque
- la violence mieux rÃ©compensÃ©e que la diplomatie dans les choix
- La chance parfois trop prÃ©sente
- Le spam possible de compÃ©tences cheatÃ©es (triple tir de l'archer)
- Personnalisation des persos un peu trop complexe
- PossibilitÃ© de rater ses personnages
- RespÃ©cialisation impossible
- Manque d'Ã©quipement et de loots
- ZERO exploration
- Quelques bugs


17/20

review:
Ein ausgezeichznetes Taktik-Spiel mit einigen Rollenspielelementen. Die Story ist linear aber gut erzÃ¤hlt, die Charaktere sind lebensecht gestaltet. Bei der Charakter- und Gruppenentwicklung gibt es viele Freiheiten, die das Spiel auch im zweiten Durchgang noch spannend machen; auch gibt es immer mehrere zum Ziel fÃ¼hrende Strategien.
Insgesamt ein bisschen zu kampflastig, dafÃ¼r sind die KÃ¤mpfe aber auch wirklich gut gemacht. Ein groÃŸer Bonuspunkt ist, dass man sich sehr eng an die offiziellen Vorgaben P&P-Welt Aventurien gehalten hat.
